Description A: Behavior therapy was shown to be quick and effective for phobias.
Description B: Behavior therapy was shown to be slow and ineffective for phobias.

Description A: Helmholtz was the first to measure the speed with which afferent signals in peripheral nerves are conducted.
Description B: Helmholtz was the first to measure the speed with which afferent signals in central nerves are conducted.

Description A: Cognitive therapists teach their clients methods for reducing the frequency of negative thoughts.
Description B: Cognitive therapists teach their clients methods for increasing the frequency of negative thoughts.

Description A: Cognition can become dysfunctional so that the knowledge acquired about the world is false.
Description B: Cognition can become optimal so that the knowledge acquired about the world is always accurate.

Description A: Most cognitive processing never enters consciousness.
Description B: Most cognitive processing always enters consciousness.

Description A: Schizophrenic patients frequently experience complex auditory hallucinations.
Description B: Schizophrenic patients rarely experience complex auditory hallucinations.

Description A: Visual perception is a prime example of complex computational processes.
Description B: Visual perception is a prime example of simple computational processes.

Description A: Blind sight refers to the ability to detect visual properties despite having no sensory perception.
Description B: Blind sight refers to the inability to detect visual properties despite having full sensory perception.

Description A: Patients with unilateral neglect often do not acknowledge objects on the left side.
Description B: Patients with unilateral neglect often do not acknowledge objects on the right side.

Description A: Helmholtz's ideas about unconscious inferences were largely ignored.
Description B: Helmholtz's ideas about unconscious inferences were widely accepted.

Description A: Francis Crick and Christopher Koch initiated the search for the neural correlates of consciousness.
Description B: Francis Crick and Christopher Koch ended the search for the neural correlates of consciousness.

Description A: The fusiform gyrus is specialized for the processing of faces.
Description B: The fusiform gyrus is specialized for the processing of landscapes.

Description A: Cognitive therapy has been particularly successful in the treatment of depression.
Description B: Cognitive therapy has been particularly unsuccessful in the treatment of depression.

Description A: Unconscious processing can be seen in cases of spatial neglect.
Description B: Unconscious processing cannot be seen in cases of spatial neglect.

Description A: Unconscious inferences play a significant role in what we perceive.
Description B: Unconscious inferences play no role in what we perceive.

Description A: Classical conditioning involves learning a relationship between two stimuli.
Description B: Classical conditioning involves learning a relationship between an organism's behavior and the consequences of that behavior.

Description A: Classical conditioning was first described in the early 1900s by Ivan Pavlov.
Description B: Classical conditioning was first described in the late 1800s by Ivan Pavlov.

Description A: The conditioned stimulus is paired with an unconditioned stimulus to produce a conditioned response.
Description B: The conditioned stimulus is paired with an innate response to produce an unconditioned response.

Description A: Extinction is an important adaptive mechanism.
Description B: Extinction is unrelated to adaptive mechanisms.

Description A: Operant conditioning involves associating specific behavior with a reinforcing event.
Description B: Operant conditioning involves associating two stimuli without reinforcement.

Description A: Extinction signifies that the CS now signals the US will not occur.
Description B: Extinction implies the CS now signals the US will certainly occur.

Description A: Operant conditioning can be considered the formation of a predictive relationship between an action and an outcome.
Description B: Operant conditioning is unrelated to the outcomes of an action.

Description A: Taste aversion develops even when the unconditioned response occurs after a long delay.
Description B: Taste aversion requires immediate occurrence of the unconditioned response.

Description A: Absent-mindedness results from a lack of attention to immediate experience.
Description B: Absent-mindedness results from consistent and focused attention.

Description A: Blocking refers to a temporary inability to access information stored in memory.
Description B: Blocking refers to permanent loss of information stored in memory.

Description A: Misattribution involves associating a memory with an incorrect time or place.
Description B: Misattribution involves associating memory accurately and without error.

Description A: Suggestibility refers to incorporating new information into memory based on leading questions.
Description B: Suggestibility enhances memory recall without external influence.

Description A: Bias involves distortions in memory due to one's general knowledge and beliefs.
Description B: Bias ensures memory accuracy by removing personal knowledge influences.

Description A: Persistence refers to the constant remembering of information or events.
Description B: Persistence allows selective forgetting of unwanted memories.

Description A: Operant behaviors are said to be emitted rather than elicited.
Description B: Operant behaviors are always elicited by a specific stimulus.

Description A: Intracortical electrodes record the activity of neurons near the electrode tip and can also be used to deliver electrical stimulation.
Description B: Intracortical electrodes record neuron activity throughout the entire brain and deliver electrical stimulation to all brain areas.

Description A: BMIs can help to regulate pathological neural activity by measuring neural activity, processing it, and subsequently stimulating neurons.
Description B: BMIs can help to regulate pathological neural activity by directly modifying the brain's structure and altering neuron pathways.

Description A: A discrete decoder estimates one of several possible movement goals from neural population activity.
Description B: A discrete decoder estimates continuous moment-by-moment movement details from neural population activity.

Description A: The field is making substantial progress in increasing the performance of BMIs, in terms of speed and accuracy of estimated movements.
Description B: The field is making significant regress in the performance of BMIs, in terms of the slow and inaccurate estimation of movements.

Description A: Using this paradigm, a recent study recorded neural activity simultaneously in the primary cortex and striatum with M1 neurons designated as output neurons.
Description B: Using this paradigm, a recent study recorded neural activity only in the striatum and designated all neurons involved as nonoutput neurons.

Description A: BMIs are medical devices that read out and/or alter electrophysiological activity at the level of populations of neurons.
Description B: BMIs are medical devices that exclusively enhance electrophysiological activity without altering it at the level of individual neurons.

Description A: BMIs raise new neuroethics questions, which need to be considered with the benefits provided by BMIs to people with injury or disease.
Description B: BMIs raise no neuroethics questions, as their benefits to people with injury or disease are unequivocal.

Description A: BMIs are increasingly used as a tool for understanding brain function by simplifying the brain’s input and output interfaces.
Description B: BMIs are rarely used as a tool for understanding brain function due to their complexity in brain interfaces.

Description A: In a BMI, one can choose to use only a subset of the recorded neurons (the output neurons) for controlling movements.
Description B: In a BMI, one must use all recorded neurons to ensure universal control over movements.

Description A: Efforts to increase the functional lifetime of electrodes include mitigating immunological responses.
Description B: Efforts to increase the functional lifetime of electrodes exclude addressing immunological responses.

Description A: BMIs based on different neural sensors have different risks and benefits.
Description B: BMIs based on different neural sensors have universal risks and benefits regardless of their differences.

Description A: Identifying output versus nonoutput neurons in a study using arm or eye movements would be challenging.
Description B: Identifying output versus nonoutput neurons in a study using arm or eye movements is straightforward and simple.

Description A: BMIs can help restore lost motor capabilities by measuring activity from many individual neurons.
Description B: BMIs can help restore lost motor capabilities by exclusively measuring activity from limited individual neurons.

Description A: Future advances of BMI will depend in part on developments in neurotechnology, including hardware and software.
Description B: Future advances of BMI will solely rely on the improvements in hardware technology alone.

Description A: BMIs can help restore lost sensory capabilities by stimulating neurons to convey sensory information to the brain.
Description B: BMIs can help restore lost sensory capabilities by removing neurons to stop sensory information from reaching the brain.

Description A: TRPM8 receptors respond to temperatures below 25°C (77°F), which are perceived as cool or cold.
Description B: TRPM8 receptors respond to temperatures below 45°C (113°F), which are perceived as warm.

Description A: TRPA1 receptors have thermal thresholds below 17°C (63°F), representing sensations described as frigid or cold.
Description B: TRPA1 receptors have thermal thresholds above 27°C (80°F), representing sensations described as warm.

Description A: TRPV1 and TRPV2 receptors respond to temperatures exceeding 45°C (113°F) and mediate sensations of burning pain.
Description B: TRPV1 and TRPV2 receptors respond to temperatures below 17°C (63°F) to mediate sensations of cold pain.

Description A: Cold receptors are approximately 100 times more sensitive to sudden drops in skin temperature than to gradual changes.
Description B: Cold receptors are approximately 100 times more sensitive to gradual increases in skin temperature than to sudden changes.

Description A: Nociceptors innervated by Aδ fibers produce sharp, pricking pain and respond to mechanical stimuli like punctures or pinches.
Description B: Nociceptors innervated by Aδ fibers produce dull, burning pain and respond to cooling stimuli like drafts or cold temperatures.

Description A: C fibers typically produce dull, burning pain and respond to polymodal stimuli such as puncture, noxious heat, and chemicals.
Description B: C fibers typically produce sharp, localized pain and respond to mechanical stimuli exclusively, such as pinching or puncture.

Description A: The H1 histamine receptor mediates itch sensations triggered by histamine and can be blocked by antihistamines.
Description B: The H1 histamine receptor mediates pain sensations triggered by histamine and cannot be blocked by antihistamines.

Description A: TRPA1 receptors mediate sensations from pungent substances like horseradish and garlic, triggering pain or irritation.
Description B: TRPA1 receptors mediate sensations from sweet substances like honey or sugar, triggering sensations of warmth and comfort.

Description A: Capsaicin, the active ingredient in chili peppers, activates nociceptive C fibers that mediate burning pain.
Description B: Capsaicin, the active ingredient in chili peppers, activates TRPM8 receptors that mediate cooling sensations.

Description A: Warm receptors fire monotonically with increasing skin temperature and saturate at thresholds of pain.
Description B: Warm receptors are highly sensitive to rapid changes in skin temperature and respond sharply to temperature drops.

Description A: Nociceptors signal impending tissue injury and provide constant reminders about already-injured tissues needing protection.
Description B: Nociceptors only provide signals for pain during initial tissue injury and are inactive for already-injured tissues.

Description A: Mechanical nociceptors respond to sharp objects that puncture the skin, such as pinpricks or serrated forceps.
Description B: Mechanical nociceptors respond to blunt objects that apply strong pressure but do not puncture the skin.

Description A: TRPV3 receptors respond to warming of the skin above 35°C (95°F) and generate sensations from warm to hot.
Description B: TRPV3 receptors respond to cooling of the skin below 17°C (63°F) and generate sensations of cold.

Description A: Sensory terminals express channels like Piezo2 or TRP receptors for sensory transduction, optimizing information gathering.
Description B: Sensory terminals express voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels for action potential generation, optimizing impulse transmission.

Description A: Visceral afferent fibers regulate respiration, gastrointestinal function, and mechanical sensing like stomach distension.
Description B: Visceral afferent fibers exclusively regulate respiratory function without involvement in gastrointestinal sensing.

Description A: Most ion channels have three states: open, closed, and inactivated or desensitized.
Description B: Most ion channels have four states: open, closed, semi-open, and inactivated or desensitized.

Description A: Ion channels act as catalysts for the passive flux of ions across the membrane.
Description B: Ion channels act as pumps for the active transport of ions across the membrane.

Description A: Ion transporters and pumps undergo conformational changes for different phases of the transport cycle.
Description B: Ion transporters and pumps provide continuous pathways for ions without conformational changes.

Description A: The expression patterns of some ion channels change during development and in response to changes in neuronal activity patterns.
Description B: The expression patterns of all ion channels remain constant during development and do not respond to changes in neuronal activity patterns.

Description A: Most ion channels are selectively permeable to certain ions.
Description B: Most ion channels are impermeable to all ions.

Description A: Ion channels have gates that open and close in response to different signals.
Description B: Ion channels have gates that always remain in a fixed position.

Description A: CLC exchangers have two gates that control Cl− flux.
Description B: CLC exchangers have a single gate that control Cl− flux.

Description A: Most exchangers and pumps are thought to have two gates, one external and one internal.
Description B: Most exchangers and pumps are thought to have only one gate that is alternately open internally and externally.

Description A: These features have been conserved with surprising fidelity from prokaryotes through humans.
Description B: These features have only been conserved in humans.

Description A: CLC channels are built on a structure similar to transporters, but with modified gates.
Description B: CLC channels are built on a completely different structure than transporters and have no gates.

Description A: Most ion channels are composed of multiple subunits.
Description B: Most ion channels are composed of a single subunit.

Description A: Structure-function studies of voltage-gated ion channels have provided insights into K+ channel conduction.
Description B: Structure-function studies have not provided any meaningful insights into K+ channel conduction.

Description A: The driving force for active ion fluxes comes from either the hydrolysis of ATP or favorable electrochemical potential difference.
Description B: The driving force for active ion fluxes only comes from mechanical stimuli.

Description A: Ions cross cell membranes through two main classes of integral membrane proteins—ion channels and ion pumps or transporters.
Description B: Ions cross cell membranes through one main class of integral membrane proteins—ion channels.

Description A: Ion channels allow electrically charged ions to rapidly cross the nonpolar environment of the cell membrane.
Description B: Ion channels prevent electrically charged ions from crossing the cell membrane.

Description A: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) parameters that activate the motor cortex improve the recovery of locomotion following incomplete spinal cord injury.
Description B: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) parameters that activate the motor cortex worsen the recovery of locomotion following incomplete spinal cord injury.

Description A: The motor cortex in humans plays a more important role in locomotion than in other mammals.
Description B: The motor cortex in humans plays a less important role in locomotion than in other mammals.

Description A: Spinal circuits can generate a complex locomotor pattern in isolation from descending and rhythmical peripheral afferent inputs.
Description B: Spinal circuits cannot generate any locomotor pattern without descending and rhythmical peripheral afferent inputs.

Description A: The posterior parietal cortex (PPC) is part of a network that contributes to the advanced planning of gait based on visual information.
Description B: The posterior parietal cortex (PPC) is part of a network that contributes to the advanced planning of gait based on auditory information.

Description A: Peripheral afferent inputs modulate the function of spinal locomotor circuits.
Description B: Peripheral afferent inputs do not modulate the function of spinal locomotor circuits.

Description A: Neurons in the pedunculopontine nucleus can be affected in Parkinson disease, contributing to severe gait disturbances.
Description B: Neurons in the pedunculopontine nucleus cannot be affected in Parkinson disease and do not contribute to gait disturbances.

Description A: Inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia are used to correct motor errors and select appropriate patterns of motor activity.
Description B: Inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia do not correct motor errors or select patterns of motor activity.

Description A: The available evidence suggests that the neural control mechanisms determined from experiments in animals are also used to control locomotion in humans.
Description B: The available evidence suggests that the neural control mechanisms determined from experiments in animals are not used to control locomotion in humans.

Description A: Imaging studies show increased activity in parts of the midbrain important for initiation and speed control of locomotion.
Description B: Imaging studies show decreased activity in parts of the midbrain important for initiation and speed control of locomotion.

Description A: Recent technological advances now offer unparalleled opportunities to investigate the control mechanisms underlying locomotion.
Description B: Recent technological advances limit opportunities to investigate the control mechanisms underlying locomotion.

Description A: The organization of neural pathways involved in the generation and regulation of locomotion in mammals has been determined in significant detail.
Description B: The organization of neural pathways involved in the generation and regulation of locomotion in mammals remains poorly understood.

Description A: Excitatory rhythm-generating neurons together with commissural inhibitory neurons are responsible for left–right alternation.
Description B: Excitatory neurons alone are responsible for left–right alternation, without the involvement of inhibitory neurons.

Description A: Circuits controlling speed of locomotion and selecting gaits are localized in the midbrain.
Description B: Circuits controlling speed of locomotion and selecting gaits are localized in the forebrain.

Description A: The motor cortex provides precise control of muscle activity patterns to allow animals to make visually guided anticipatory adjustments of their gait.
Description B: The motor cortex does not contribute to visually guided anticipatory adjustments of animal gait.

Description A: Activity in the pedunculopontine nucleus can affect locomotion in Parkinson disease.
Description B: Activity in the pedunculopontine nucleus does not affect locomotion in Parkinson disease.

Description A: The fragile X mutation leads to the expansion of the CGG triplet on the FMR1 gene to more than 200 repeats.
Description B: The fragile X mutation leads to the expansion of the CGG triplet on the FMR1 gene to less than 50 repeats.

Description A: Approximately 30% of boys with fragile X meet all diagnostic criteria for ASD.
Description B: Approximately 50% of boys with fragile X meet all diagnostic criteria for ASD.

Description A: Rett syndrome is primarily caused by loss-of-function mutations in the MECP2 gene.
Description B: Rett syndrome is primarily caused by gain-of-function mutations in the MECP2 gene.

Description A: Williams syndrome is caused by a segmental deletion of about 27 genes on chromosome 7.
Description B: Williams syndrome is caused by a duplication of about 27 genes on chromosome 7.

Description A: Prader-Willi syndrome results from a deletion on chromosome 15 inherited from the father.
Description B: Prader-Willi syndrome results from a deletion on chromosome 15 inherited from the mother.

Description A: Angelman syndrome is characterized by severe intellectual disability and inappropriate laughter.
Description B: Angelman syndrome is characterized by mild intellectual disability and inappropriate laughter.

Description A: Rett syndrome primarily affects girls due to its inheritance pattern linked to the X chromosome.
Description B: Rett syndrome primarily affects boys due to its inheritance pattern linked to the X chromosome.

Description A: Williams syndrome leads to increased sociability and an affinity for music.
Description B: Williams syndrome leads to decreased sociability and an aversion to music.

Description A: The prevalence of Rett syndrome is approximately 1 in 10,000 live female births.
Description B: The prevalence of Rett syndrome is approximately 1 in 10,000 live male births.

Description A: MECP2 duplication syndrome primarily affects males with severe intellectual disability.
Description B: MECP2 duplication syndrome primarily affects females with mild intellectual disability.

Description A: Lack of functional FMRP is responsible for fragile X syndrome.
Description B: Excess functional FMRP is responsible for fragile X syndrome.

Description A: The major challenges in developing treatments for fragile X include identifying clinical endpoints.
Description B: The major challenges in developing treatments for fragile X include producing excess FMRP.

Description A: The MECP2 gene product binds to methylated cytosine bases in DNA, regulating gene expression.
Description B: The MECP2 gene product binds to unmethylated cytosine bases in DNA, regulating gene expression.

Description A: Williams syndrome occurs in 1 in 10,000 live births.
Description B: Williams syndrome occurs in 1 in 20,000 live births.

Description A: Loss of function of the UBE3A gene on the maternal chromosome leads to Angelman syndrome.
Description B: Loss of function of the UBE3A gene on the paternal chromosome leads to Angelman syndrome.

Description A: The neuromuscular junction abnormalities in myasthenia gravis include reduced numbers of ACh receptors.
Description B: The neuromuscular junction abnormalities in myasthenia gravis include increased numbers of ACh receptors.

Description A: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors can ameliorate symptoms in myasthenia gravis by prolonging the action of acetylcholine.
Description B: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors worsen symptoms in myasthenia gravis by shortening the action of acetylcholine.

Description A: In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, the first postsynaptic potential is abnormally small, but subsequent responses increase in amplitude.
Description B: In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, the first postsynaptic potential is abnormally large, but subsequent responses decrease in amplitude.

Description A: Duchenne muscular dystrophy affects only males as it is transmitted as an X-linked recessive trait.
Description B: Duchenne muscular dystrophy affects both males and females equally as it is transmitted as an X-linked recessive trait.

Description A: The slow channel syndrome is characterized by prominent limb weakness with little weakness of cranial muscles.
Description B: The slow channel syndrome is characterized by prominent cranial muscle weakness with little weakness of limb muscles.

Description A: Dermatomyositis is defined by two clinical features: rash and myopathy.
Description B: Dermatomyositis is defined by three clinical features: rash, myopathy, and neuropathy.

Description A: The mutations in the slow channel syndrome increase the affinity of the nicotinic ACh receptor for acetylcholine.
Description B: The mutations in the slow channel syndrome decrease the affinity of the nicotinic ACh receptor for acetylcholine.

Description A: In congenital myasthenia, the infant has an inherited defect in some component of the neuromuscular junction.
Description B: In congenital myasthenia, the infant has an acquired defect in some component of the neuromuscular junction.

Description A: The fast channel syndrome can respond to either acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or 3,4-diaminopyridine.
Description B: The fast channel syndrome can respond to neither acetylcholinesterase inhibitors nor 3,4-diaminopyridine.

Description A: Becker muscular dystrophy is typically milder than Duchenne because dystrophin is present but may be abnormal.
Description B: Becker muscular dystrophy is typically more severe than Duchenne because dystrophin is absent entirely.

Description A: Plasmapheresis involves filtering the plasma and can be beneficial for myasthenia gravis patients.
Description B: Plasmapheresis involves adding antibodies to the plasma and can be beneficial for myasthenia gravis patients.

Description A: In congenital myasthenia, end-plate currents are slow to decay, causing prolonged muscle potential response.
Description B: In congenital myasthenia, end-plate currents are fast to decay, causing decreased muscle potential response.

Description A: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is often associated with small-cell lung cancer.
Description B: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is rarely associated with small-cell lung cancer.

Description A: Dystrophin confers tensile strength to the muscle cell by linking it to the extracellular matrix.
Description B: Dystrophin confers tensile strength to the muscle cell by preventing it from linking to the extracellular matrix.

Description A: Botulinum toxin impairs the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals, causing neuromuscular block.
Description B: Botulinum toxin increases the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals, causing neuromuscular block.

Description A: Marmoset monkeys exhibit human-like pitch perception and can discriminate a missing fundamental in harmonic sounds with a precision as small as one semitone for periodicity above 440 Hz.
Description B: Marmoset monkeys exhibit human-like pitch perception and can discriminate a missing fundamental in harmonic sounds with a precision as small as one semitone for periodicity above 200 Hz.

Description A: The pitch-selective neurons in marmoset monkeys are located at the low-frequency border between A1 and the rostral auditory cortex (area R).
Description B: The pitch-selective neurons in marmoset monkeys are located at the high-frequency border between A1 and the rostral auditory cortex (area R).

Description A: The perception of the missing fundamental remains robust despite the loss of some harmonic components.
Description B: The perception of the missing fundamental is highly fragile and becomes distorted with the loss of some harmonic components.

Description A: Human imaging studies have identified a region at the lateral end of Heschl’s gyrus that mirrors the pitch center location in marmoset monkeys.
Description B: Human imaging studies have identified a region at the medial end of Heschl’s gyrus that mirrors the pitch center location in marmoset monkeys.

Description A: Pitch-selective neurons in marmosets respond to pitch-evoking sounds like harmonic sounds and click trains.
Description B: Pitch-selective neurons in marmosets do not respond to pitch-evoking sounds like harmonic sounds and click trains.

Description A: Harmonic template neurons are distributed across A1 and R, covering the entire hearing range of marmosets, from approximately 1 kHz to 32 kHz.
Description B: Harmonic template neurons are confined to a narrow region of A1, covering only a range from approximately 1 kHz to 5 kHz.

Description A: Xiaoqin Wang and colleagues discovered pitch-selective neurons in marmosets about a decade ago.
Description B: Xiaoqin Wang and colleagues discovered pitch-selective neurons in marmosets two decades ago.

Description A: Pitch-selective neurons increase their firing rates as the behavioral salience of pitch increases.
Description B: Pitch-selective neurons decrease their firing rates as the behavioral salience of pitch increases.

Description A: The core regions of auditory cortex in marmosets also contain a class of harmonic template neurons.
Description B: The core regions of auditory cortex in marmosets contain only pitch-selective neurons, not harmonic template neurons.

Description A: Pitch carries crucial linguistic information in tonal languages such as Chinese.
Description B: Pitch is irrelevant to linguistic information in tonal languages such as Chinese.

Description A: Pitch allows harmonically structured periodic sounds to be perceived and ordered on a musical scale.
Description B: Pitch does not allow harmonically structured periodic sounds to be perceived and ordered on a musical scale.

Description A: Monkeys are capable of spectral pitch discrimination and melody recognition.
Description B: Monkeys are incapable of spectral pitch discrimination and melody recognition.

Description A: When listening to an orchestra, we hear the melody of the soloist over the background of accompanying instruments.
Description B: When listening to an orchestra, we cannot hear the melody of the soloist over the background of accompanying instruments.

Description A: Birds, cats, and monkeys can also pick out pitch like humans.
Description B: Birds, cats, and monkeys cannot pick out pitch like humans.

Description A: The slowing of the phase-locking limit along the ascending auditory pathway is necessary for auditory information integration in the cerebral cortex.
Description B: The slowing of the phase-locking limit along the ascending auditory pathway is irrelevant for auditory information integration in the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Nerve growth factor (NGF) binds to TrkA receptors on primary nociceptive terminals, triggering upregulation in expression of ion channels that increase nociceptor excitability.
Description B: Nerve growth factor (NGF) binds to TrkA receptors on primary nociceptive terminals, reducing expression of ion channels that decrease nociceptor excitability.

Description A: Retrograde transport of signaling endosomes enhances expression of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF).
Description B: Retrograde transport of signaling endosomes suppresses expression of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF).

Description A: Central sensitization decreases pain thresholds (allodynia) and can lead to spontaneous pain in the absence of peripheral stimulation.
Description B: Central sensitization increases pain thresholds (allodynia) and eliminates spontaneous pain in the absence of peripheral stimulation.

Description A: Peripheral nerve damage decreases GABAergic inhibitory controls, exacerbating hyperactivity of nociceptive pathways in the dorsal horn.
Description B: Peripheral nerve damage increases GABAergic inhibitory controls, reducing hyperactivity of nociceptive pathways in the dorsal horn.

Description A: Peripheral nerve injury activates microglia, which release mediators that reduce inhibitory controls exerted by GABAergic interneurons.
Description B: Peripheral nerve injury activates microglia, which release mediators that increase inhibitory controls exerted by GABAergic interneurons.

Description A: Mechanical allodynia can involve inappropriate engagement of dorsal horn nociceptive pathways by Aβ myelinated afferents.
Description B: Mechanical allodynia typically involves appropriate engagement of dorsal horn nociceptive pathways by uninjured nociceptors.

Description A: NMDA receptor activation in the dorsal horn contributes to central sensitization and increased excitability of dorsal horn neurons.
Description B: NMDA receptor activation in the dorsal horn reduces central sensitization and decreases excitability of dorsal horn neurons.

Description A: Activation of NK1 receptors by C fibers generates long-lasting cumulative depolarization in dorsal horn neurons, contributing to central sensitization.
Description B: Activation of NK1 receptors by C fibers generates transient depolarization that inhibits central sensitization.

Description A: Under normal conditions, large-diameter, nonnociceptive Aβ afferent fibers activate GABAergic interneurons in the dorsal horn to inhibit pain transmission circuits.
Description B: Under normal conditions, large-diameter, nonnociceptive Aβ afferent fibers deactivate GABAergic interneurons in the dorsal horn, promoting pain transmission circuits.

Description A: Loss of GABAergic interneurons due to peripheral nerve injury reduces inhibitory control and contributes to Aβ-mediated mechanical hypersensitivity.
Description B: Loss of GABAergic interneurons due to peripheral nerve injury increases inhibitory control and reduces Aβ-mediated mechanical hypersensitivity.

Description A: Elevation of residual Ca2+ in presynaptic terminals increases the release of glutamate and substance P, contributing to dorsal horn neuron excitability.
Description B: Elevation of residual Ca2+ in presynaptic terminals decreases the release of glutamate and substance P, reducing dorsal horn neuron excitability.

Description A: Activation of postsynaptic NMDA receptors in dorsal horn neurons results in long-lasting depolarization and increased neural excitability.
Description B: Activation of postsynaptic NMDA receptors in dorsal horn neurons results in short-lasting hyperpolarization and decreased neural excitability.

Description A: Second-messenger systems influenced by NK1 receptors enhance the performance of NMDA receptors during dorsal horn sensitization.
Description B: Second-messenger systems influenced by NK1 receptors inhibit the performance of NMDA receptors during dorsal horn sensitization.

Description A: Peripheral nerve injury can lead to inappropriate engagement of dorsal horn projection neurons by Aβ afferents.
Description B: Peripheral nerve injury prevents engagement of dorsal horn projection neurons by Aβ afferents.

Description A: Microglial cell activation in the dorsal horn releases mediators that enhance excitability and reduce GABAergic inhibition.
Description B: Microglial cell activation in the dorsal horn releases mediators that suppress excitability and restore GABAergic inhibition.

Description A: The inability to mentalize, or 'mind blindness,' was first tested in children with autism using a simple puppet game, the Sally-Anne test.
Description B: The inability to mentalize, or 'mind blindness,' was first tested in children with autism using a complex mathematical game, the Sally-Anne test.

Description A: The Sally-Anne test involves Sally putting a ball into her basket before leaving the room.
Description B: The Sally-Anne test involves Sally putting a ball into her box before leaving the room.

Description A: Children with Down syndrome typically pass the Sally-Anne test at a younger age than children with autism.
Description B: Children with Down syndrome typically do not pass the Sally-Anne test at a younger age than children with autism.

Description A: The inferior temporal cortex within the fusiform gyrus is involved in face processing.
Description B: The superior temporal sulcus is involved in face processing.

Description A: The orbitofrontal cortex is implicated in social deficits in autism.
Description B: The cerebellum is implicated in social deficits in autism.

Description A: Functional MRI studies have shown that activity in the mentalizing network is reduced in subjects with ASD.
Description B: Functional MRI studies have shown that activity in the mentalizing network is increased in subjects with ASD.

Description A: The amygdala is involved in the evaluation of social and nonsocial information for indications of danger in the environment.
Description B: The posterior parietal cortex is involved in the evaluation of social and nonsocial information for indications of danger in the environment.

Description A: The medial prefrontal cortex is involved in monitoring one's own thoughts.
Description B: The supplementary motor area is involved in monitoring one's own thoughts.

Description A: It is thought that mentalizing is impaired in ASD with profound effects on social development.
Description B: It is thought that mentalizing is enhanced in ASD with profound effects on social development.

Description A: Face processing involves a region of the inferior temporal cortex within the fusiform gyrus.
Description B: Face processing involves a region of the superior temporal sulcus.

Description A: Young children with ASD show excellent appreciation of physical causes and events.
Description B: Young children with ASD show poor appreciation of physical causes and events.

Description A: Autism Spectrum Disorder Phenotypes Also Share Distinctive Cognitive Abnormalities.
Description B: Autism Spectrum Disorder Phenotypes Share No Cognitive Abnormalities.

Description A: Variations of the Sally-Anne test have been used with children and adults with ASD since the mid-1980s.
Description B: Variations of the Sally-Anne test have been used with children and adults with ASD since the early 1970s.

Description A: From birth, normal infants prefer to attend to people rather than other stimuli.
Description B: From birth, normal infants prefer to attend to inanimate objects rather than people.

Description A: Insight into the mental state of others depends on the capacity to mentalize spontaneously.
Description B: Insight into the mental state of others depends on the capacity to mentalize effortfully.

Description A: Neurons born in the germinal zone of the dentate gyrus in adult rodents are integrated into hippocampal circuits.
Description B: Neurons born in the germinal zone of the dentate gyrus in adult rodents cannot be integrated into hippocampal circuits.

Description A: Neurogenesis in the adult brain was initially met with skepticism, but later confirmed with improved technologies.
Description B: Neurogenesis in the adult brain was widely accepted immediately without skepticism.

Description A: Adult-born neurons are generated near the surface of the lateral ventricles and migrate to the olfactory bulb.
Description B: Adult-born neurons are generated in the olfactory bulb and migrate to the lateral ventricles.

Description A: Adult neurogenesis can be influenced by environmental factors such as enrichment and physical activity.
Description B: Adult neurogenesis is unaffected by environmental factors such as enrichment and physical activity.

Description A: New neurons in the adult brain are highly similar to those born at embryonic stages.
Description B: New neurons in the adult brain are completely dissimilar to those born at embryonic stages.

Description A: The generation of new neurons in adults is linked to certain behaviors mediated by the olfactory bulb and hippocampus.
Description B: The generation of new neurons in adults has no link to behaviors mediated by the olfactory bulb and hippocampus.

Description A: Joseph Altman discovered neurogenesis continues into adulthood in some parts of the mammalian brain in the 1960s.
Description B: Joseph Altman discovered neurogenesis stops completely before adulthood in all parts of the mammalian brain.

Description A: New neurons are added to the adult olfactory bulb and form functional circuits.
Description B: New neurons are added to the adult olfactory bulb but do not form functional circuits.

Description A: Stem cells are the source of neurons in the adult as well as the embryo.
Description B: Stem cells are not the source of neurons in the adult, only in the embryo.

Description A: In the hematopoietic system, a few stem cells can repopulate the entire adaptive immune system.
Description B: In the hematopoietic system, a few stem cells cannot repopulate the entire adaptive immune system.

Description A: Neuronal death is a frequent consequence of neural insults such as stroke and neurodegenerative disease.
Description B: Neuronal death is rare following neural insults such as stroke and neurodegenerative disease.

Description A: Transplantation of developing neurons into experimental animals has shown promising results in reversing effects of injury.
Description B: Transplantation of developing neurons into experimental animals has never shown promising results.

Description A: Stem cells in adulthood are derived from radial glia.
Description B: Stem cells in adulthood are not derived from radial glia.

Description A: Neurogenesis in adult animals can be decreased in models of depression and chronic stress.
Description B: Neurogenesis in adult animals remains unchanged in models of depression and chronic stress.

Description A: Neurons born at embryonic stages are gradually replaced by later-born neurons, maintaining their total number.
Description B: Neurons born at embryonic stages are never replaced by later-born neurons.

Description A: Pierre Paul Broca discovered that damage to the posterior portion of the left frontal lobe (Broca’s area) produces a specific deficit in language.
Description B: Pierre Paul Broca discovered that damage to the posterior portion of the left frontal lobe (Broca’s area) enhances language capabilities.

Description A: Episodic memory involves interactions between the medial temporal lobe and association cortices.
Description B: Episodic memory involves interactions between the occipital lobe and association cortices.

Description A: Operant conditioning involves associating a specific behavior with a reinforcing event.
Description B: Operant conditioning involves associating a specific behavior with a non-reinforcing event.

Description A: The Hippocampus supports episodic memory by building relational associations.
Description B: The Hippocampus disrupts episodic memory by breaking relational associations.

Description A: Short-term memory maintains transient representations of information relevant to immediate goals.
Description B: Short-term memory maintains permanent representations of information relevant to long-term goals.

Description A: Memory involves encoding, storage, retrieval, and consolidation.
Description B: Memory involves only encoding and retrieval, but not storage and consolidation.

Description A: Implicit memory supports a range of behaviors in humans and animals.
Description B: Implicit memory supports only a narrow range of behaviors specific to humans.

Description A: Short-term memory is selectively transferred to long-term memory.
Description B: Short-term memory automatically transfers all information to long-term memory without selection.

Description A: Errors and imperfections in memory shed light on normal memory processes.
Description B: Errors and imperfections in memory have no relevance to understanding normal memory processes.

Description A: Working memory consists of at least two subsystems: one for verbal information and another for visuospatial information.
Description B: Working memory consists of a single unified system for all types of information.

Description A: The medial temporal lobe is critical for episodic long-term memory.
Description B: The medial temporal lobe is irrelevant for episodic long-term memory.

Description A: Memory storage involves many different parts of the brain.
Description B: Memory storage is confined to a single part of the brain.

Description A: Phonological storage partially depends on articulatory processes in Broca’s area.
Description B: Phonological storage has no dependency on articulatory processes in Broca’s area.

Description A: Working memory involves activation of representations of information stored in specialized cortical regions.
Description B: Working memory functions independently of representations in specialized cortical regions.

Description A: Executive control processes in working memory allocate attentional resources to the verbal and visuospatial subsystems.
Description B: Executive control processes in working memory do not interact with verbal or visuospatial subsystems.

Description A: The relative proportion of hybrid fibers in a muscle increases with age.
Description B: The relative proportion of hybrid fibers in a muscle decreases with age.

Description A: Physical activity has little effect on the composition of a muscle's fibers.
Description B: Physical activity drastically changes the composition of a muscle's fibers.

Description A: Strength training can increase the size of type I fibers by 0% to 20%.
Description B: Strength training can decrease the size of type I fibers by 0% to 20%.

Description A: Endurance training increases the enzyme activities of oxidative metabolic pathways.
Description B: Endurance training decreases the enzyme activities of oxidative metabolic pathways.

Description A: Bed rest or limb immobilization decreases the size and intrinsic force capacity of muscle fibers.
Description B: Bed rest or limb immobilization increases the size and intrinsic force capacity of muscle fibers.

Description A: Space flight reduces the proportion of type I fibers in some leg muscles.
Description B: Space flight increases the proportion of type I fibers in some leg muscles.

Description A: The force exerted by a muscle during contraction depends on the number of motor units that are activated.
Description B: The force exerted by a muscle during contraction is independent of the number of motor units that are activated.

Description A: The order in which motor units are recruited is determined by intrinsic differences in the responsiveness of individual motor neurons.
Description B: The order in which motor units are recruited is random and not determined by intrinsic factors.

Description A: Recruitment of motor neurons follows the size principle, starting with the smallest first.
Description B: Recruitment of motor neurons follows the size principle, starting with the largest first.

Description A: Small motor neurons have a higher input resistance due to fewer ion channels.
Description B: Small motor neurons have a lower input resistance due to more ion channels.

Description A: Motor units in hand muscles are all recruited by about 60% of maximal voluntary contraction.
Description B: Motor units in hand muscles are all recruited by about 100% of maximal voluntary contraction.

Description A: In biceps brachii, deltoid, and tibialis anterior muscles, recruitment continues up to approximately 85% of maximal force.
Description B: In biceps brachii, deltoid, and tibialis anterior muscles, recruitment continues up to approximately 50% of maximal force.

Description A: Beyond the upper limit of motor unit recruitment, changes in muscle force depend on action potential rate.
Description B: Beyond the upper limit of motor unit recruitment, changes in muscle force depend on synaptic inputs.

Description A: Variation in discharge rate affects muscle force more significantly except at low forces.
Description B: Variation in discharge rate affects muscle force consistently at all force levels.

Description A: The size principle of motor neuron recruitment was enunciated by Elwood Henneman.
Description B: The size principle of motor neuron recruitment was enunciated by Edgar Adrian.

Description A: In the painting by Anatjari Tjampitjinpa, Tingarri instructors are depicted as concentric circles and their young initiates as horseshoe shapes.
Description B: In the painting by Anatjari Tjampitjinpa, Tingarri instructors are depicted as horseshoe shapes and their young initiates as concentric circles.

Description A: The painting by Anatjari Tjampitjinpa depicts the sandhill country of the central Australian desert.
Description B: The painting by Anatjari Tjampitjinpa depicts the rainforest region of northern Australia.

Description A: Circuits controlling the forelimb are located in the cervical enlargement.
Description B: Circuits controlling the forelimb are located in the lumbar spinal cord.

Description A: The core of the rhythm-generating circuits in rodents includes Shox2ON and Hb9 neurons.
Description B: The core of the rhythm-generating circuits in rodents includes V0D and V0V neurons.

Description A: The flexor-extensor alternation around the different joints is sequential.
Description B: The flexor-extensor alternation around the different joints is simultaneous.

Description A: V0D commissural neurons make up about half of the V0 population.
Description B: V0V commissural neurons make up about half of the V0 population.

Description A: Left–right alternation depends on crossed inhibition.
Description B: Left–right alternation depends on direct excitation.

Description A: The dual inhibitory system in left–right alternation includes V0 commissural neurons.
Description B: The dual inhibitory system in left–right alternation includes V3 commissural neurons.

Description A: V2a excitatory neurons are part of the left–right alternating circuit.
Description B: V2a excitatory neurons are part of the flexor-extensor circuit.

Description A: Proprioceptors include stretch-sensitive muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs.
Description B: Proprioceptors include stretch-sensitive ligaments and Golgi tendon organs.

Description A: The stance phase becomes shorter as the stepping rate increases.
Description B: The swing phase becomes shorter as the stepping rate increases.

Description A: Preventing hip extension in a limb suppresses stepping in that limb.
Description B: Preventing hip flexion in a limb suppresses stepping in that limb.

Description A: Activation of sensory fibers from Golgi tendon organs in ankle extensor muscles prolongs the stance phase.
Description B: Activation of sensory fibers from Golgi tendon organs in hip flexor muscles prolongs the stance phase.

Description A: The interlimb coordination pathways involve both inhibitory and excitatory intersegmental connections.
Description B: The interlimb coordination pathways involve only inhibitory intersegmental connections.

Description A: Flexor and extensor modules provide direct motor neuron inhibition in a reciprocal fashion.
Description B: Flexor and extensor modules provide direct motor neuron excitation in a reciprocal fashion.

Description A: V0 commissural neurons are crucial for left–right alternation at all speeds of locomotion.
Description B: V0 commissural neurons are crucial for left–right synchrony at all speeds of locomotion.

Description A: Separate excitatory non-V0 commissural neurons are responsible for synchrony in gaits such as bound and gallop.
Description B: Separate inhibitory non-V0 commissural neurons are responsible for synchrony in gaits such as bound and gallop.

Description A: The organ of Corti contains approximately 16,000 hair cells arrayed in four rows: a single row of inner hair cells and three rows of outer hair cells.
Description B: The organ of Corti contains approximately 10,000 hair cells arrayed in four rows: two rows of inner hair cells and two rows of outer hair cells.

Description A: The tectorial membrane is anchored at its base, and its tapered distal edge forms a fragile connection with the organ of Corti.
Description B: The tectorial membrane is not anchored at its base, and its tapered distal edge forms a rigid connection with the organ of Corti.

Description A: Outer hair cells are supported at their bases by Deiters’s cells.
Description B: Outer hair cells are supported at their bases by pillar cells.

Description A: Each organ of Corti contains approximately 30,000 afferent nerve fibers that carry information into the brain along the eighth cranial nerve.
Description B: Each organ of Corti contains approximately 20,000 afferent nerve fibers that carry information into the brain along the eighth cranial nerve.

Description A: Hair bundles comprise a few tens to a few hundred cylindrical processes called stereocilia.
Description B: Hair bundles comprise a few tens to a few thousand cylindrical processes called stereocilia.

Description A: The inner hair-cell bundles of the mammalian cochlea have a roughly linear form.
Description B: The inner hair-cell bundles of the mammalian cochlea have a roughly circular form.

Description A: Each stereocilium is of constant diameter along most of its length, tapering just above its basal insertion.
Description B: Each stereocilium varies in diameter along most of its length, tapering just below its basal insertion.

Description A: Hair cells are not neurons; they lack both dendrites and axons.
Description B: Hair cells are neurons and they have both dendrites and axons.

Description A: Deflection of the hair bundle toward its tall edge opens additional channels, thereby depolarizing the cell.
Description B: Deflection of the hair bundle toward its short edge opens additional channels, thereby depolarizing the cell.

Description A: The logarithm of the frequency decreases roughly in proportion to the distance from the cochlea’s base.
Description B: The logarithm of the frequency increases roughly in proportion to the distance from the cochlea’s base.

Description A: The mechanical properties of the cochlear partition as a whole determine the dispersion of sound's frequency components along the cochlea’s longitudinal axis.
Description B: The electrical properties of the cochlear partition as a whole determine the dispersion of sound's frequency components along the cochlea’s longitudinal axis.

Description A: Afferent and efferent nerve endings contact the basolateral surface of the plasma membrane.
Description B: Afferent and efferent nerve endings contact the apical surface of the plasma membrane.

Description A: Outer hair-cell bundles have a V or W shape.
Description B: Outer hair-cell bundles have a linear shape.

Description A: In an unstimulated cell, 10% to 50% of the channels involved in stimulus transduction are open.
Description B: In an unstimulated cell, 0% of the channels involved in stimulus transduction are open.

Description A: Each stereocilium consists of a fascicle of actin filaments heavily cross-linked by proteins plastin, fascin, and epsin.
Description B: Each stereocilium consists of a fascicle of collagen filaments heavily cross-linked by proteins plastin, fascin, and epsin.

Description A: Fibers from the nasal hemiretina cross to the opposite hemisphere at the optic chiasm.
Description B: Fibers from the nasal hemiretina stay on the same side at the optic chiasm.

Description A: A lesion of the optic chiasm causes a loss of vision in the temporal half of each visual hemifield (bitemporal hemianopsia).
Description B: A lesion of the optic chiasm causes a loss of vision in the nasal half of each visual hemifield (binasal hemianopsia).

Description A: A lesion of the optic tract causes a loss of vision in the opposite half of the visual hemifield (contralateral hemianopsia).
Description B: A lesion of the optic tract causes a loss of vision in the same half of the visual hemifield (ipsilateral hemianopsia).

Description A: Cells in the lateral geniculate nucleus send their axons along the optic radiation to the primary visual cortex.
Description B: Cells in the lateral geniculate nucleus send their axons directly to the frontal cortex.

Description A: The dorsal pathway is concerned with visually guided movement.
Description B: The dorsal pathway is concerned with object recognition.

Description A: The primary visual cortex in each hemisphere represents slightly more than half the visual field.
Description B: The primary visual cortex in each hemisphere represents less than one-quarter of the visual field.

Description A: A major fiber bundle called the corpus callosum connects the two hemispheres.
Description B: A major fiber bundle called the optic nerve connects the two hemispheres.

Description A: The ventral pathway is concerned with object recognition.
Description B: The ventral pathway is concerned with pupil dilation.

Description A: The superior colliculus is involved in eye movement.
Description B: The superior colliculus is involved in auditory processing.

Description A: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has helped to establish homologies between the visual areas of the macaque and human brains.
Description B: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is incapable of establishing homologies between primate visual areas.

Description A: Functional streams in visual processing were appreciated based on pathway tracing studies in monkeys.
Description B: Functional streams in visual processing were dismissed based on pathway tracing studies in monkeys.

Description A: The visual areas of cortex can be differentiated by the functional properties of their neurons.
Description B: The visual areas of cortex are identical and cannot be differentiated by the functional properties of their neurons.

Description A: A lesion in the upper bank of the calcarine sulcus causes a partial deficit in the inferior quadrant.
Description B: A lesion in the upper bank of the calcarine sulcus causes a partial deficit in the superior quadrant.

Description A: Macacque monkeys have more than 30 areas involved with vision.
Description B: Macakque monkeys have only 10 areas involved with vision.

Description A: Light signals are relayed through the midbrain pretectum in the pupillary reflex.
Description B: Light signals are directly processed in the frontal cortex in the pupillary reflex.

Description A: The visual system calculates the brightness of surfaces from information about contrast at the edges of surfaces.
Description B: The visual system calculates the brightness of surfaces from information about uniform brightness within the surfaces.

Description A: Some neurons in V4 respond similarly to different illumination wavelengths if the perceived color remains constant.
Description B: Some neurons in V4 only respond to varying illumination wavelengths regardless of perceived color consistency.

Description A: The visual system assumes that illumination comes from above.
Description B: The visual system assumes that illumination comes from below.

Description A: A plaid pattern moving in a single direction is perceived when gratings are superimposed and moved independently in different directions.
Description B: Gratings are perceived to slide past each other when superimposed and moved independently in different directions.

Description A: The responses of some neurons in the visual cortex correlate with perceived brightness.
Description B: The responses of all neurons in the visual cortex solely depend on surface boundaries, not perceived brightness.

Description A: The barber-pole illusion is influenced by scene segmentation cues.
Description B: The barber-pole illusion is unaffected by scene segmentation cues and relies only on local motion.

Description A: Under most conditions, we do not perceive the object itself to be changing even as the retinal image of an object changes.
Description B: Under most conditions, we perceive the object itself to be changing whenever the retinal image changes.

Description A: Contextual influences are pervasive in intermediate-level visual processing.
Description B: Contextual influences have minimal impact on intermediate-level visual processing.

Description A: To identify an object, we must know the properties of its surface rather than those of the reflected light.
Description B: Identifying an object requires knowing the properties of the reflected light rather than its surface.

Description A: Perceptual fill-in happens when neurons with receptive fields within a disk begin to respond in a fashion similar to those with receptive fields in the surrounding area.
Description B: Perceptual fill-in occurs when neurons maintain distinct responses for boundaries and surrounding area without changes.

Description A: Motion perception is influenced by the scene's segmentation cues.
Description B: Motion perception is determined only by local motion signals, independent of scene segmentation cues.

Description A: Some neurons do respond to the interiors of surfaces, signaling local brightness, texture, or color.
Description B: No neurons respond to the interiors of surfaces; they only signal boundaries.

Description A: Gratings can test whether a neuron is sensitive to local or global motion signals.
Description B: Gratings provide no information about a neuron's sensitivity to motion signals.

Description A: Our ability to perceive an object's size and color as constant illustrates a fundamental principle of the visual system.
Description B: The visual system passively records images like a camera but often misperceives size and color.

Description A: Brightness perception is influenced by three-dimensional shape.
Description B: Brightness perception is primarily unaffected by three-dimensional shape.

Description A: Delay-period activity in the inferior temporal cortex is associated with short-term storage of visual patterns and color information.
Description B: Delay-period activity in the inferior temporal cortex is associated with long-term storage of auditory patterns and color information.

Description A: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex initially encode the sensory properties of the sample object and later encode the expected associated object.
Description B: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex encode the spatial properties of the expected object from the beginning.

Description A: Thomas Albright and colleagues trained monkeys to associate pairs of objects that had no prior relatedness.
Description B: Thomas Albright and colleagues trained monkeys using objects that had an inherent physical relatedness.

Description A: The visual paired-association task differs from delayed match-to-sample because the match and cue are two different stimuli.
Description B: The visual paired-association task is identical to the delayed match-to-sample task because the match and cue are the same stimuli.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral prefrontal cortex show category-specific responses.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral prefrontal cortex do not show any category-specific responses.

Description A: The delayed-response task requires a specific response based on remembered information during a brief delay.
Description B: The delayed-response task does not require remembering information during a delay.

Description A: Activity in the inferior temporal cortex can be eliminated by the appearance of another image.
Description B: Activity in the inferior temporal cortex remains unchanged regardless of new images appearing.

Description A: Earl Miller's experiments demonstrated task-dependent delay-period activity in the prefrontal cortex.
Description B: Earl Miller's experiments showed no change in delay-period activity based on tasks in the prefrontal cortex.

Description A: Visual information is maintained in short-term working memory by ongoing neuronal firing.
Description B: Visual information is maintained in short-term working memory without any neuronal activity.

Description A: Monkeys were trained to categorize images as cat or dog if they had 50% or more features of that animal.
Description B: Monkeys were trained to categorize images based on 20% or more features of an animal.

Description A: Peristimulus time histograms show neuronal responses to visual stimuli.
Description B: Peristimulus time histograms show no neuronal responses to visual stimuli.

Description A: Delay-period activity in the prefrontal cortex may be involved in the recall of long-term memories.
Description B: Delay-period activity in the prefrontal cortex is unrelated to the recall of long-term memories.

Description A: The visual paired-association task involves associating nonidentical stimuli through learning.
Description B: The visual paired-association task involves associating identical stimuli through learning.

Description A: Inferior temporal neurons respond selectively to familiar objects.
Description B: Inferior temporal neurons respond indiscriminately to all objects.

Description A: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex may generate top-down signals to the inferior temporal cortex.
Description B: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex do not interact with the inferior temporal cortex.

Description A: Yu FH and Catterall WA provided an overview of the voltage-gated sodium channel family in Genome Biology in 2003.
Description B: Yu FH and Catterall WA provided an overview of the calcium channel family in Genome Biology in 2003.

Description A: Vassilev PM, Scheuer T, and Catterall WA identified an intracellular peptide segment involved in sodium channel inactivation in 1988.
Description B: Vassilev PM, Scheuer T, and Catterall WA identified an extracellular peptide segment involved in sodium channel inactivation in 1988.

Description A: Sigworth FJ and Neher E observed single Na+ channel currents in cultured rat muscle cells in Nature in 1980.
Description B: Sigworth FJ and Neher E observed single Ca2+ channel currents in cultured rat muscle cells in Nature in 1980.

Description A: Pan X, Li Z, Zhou Q, et al. studied the structure of the human voltage-gated sodium channel Na(v)1.4 in complex with β1 in Science in 2018.
Description B: Pan X, Li Z, Zhou Q, et al. studied the structure of the human voltage-gated calcium channel Na(v)1.4 in complex with β1 in Science in 2018.

Description A: Tateno T, Harsch A, and Robinson HP examined the threshold firing frequency-current relationships of neurons in rat somatosensory cortex in Neurophysiology in 2004.
Description B: Tateno T, Harsch A, and Robinson HP examined the neurotransmitter release dynamics of neurons in rat somatosensory cortex in Neurophysiology in 2004.

Description A: Payandeh J, Scheuer T, Zheng N, and Catterall WA published the crystal structure of a voltage-gated sodium channel in Nature in 2011.
Description B: Payandeh J, Scheuer T, Zheng N, and Catterall WA published the crystal structure of a voltage-gated calcium channel in Nature in 2011.

Description A: McCormick DA, Huguenard JR modeled electrophysiological properties of thalamocortical relay neurons in 1992.
Description B: McCormick DA, Huguenard JR modeled electrophysiological properties of somatosensory neurons in 1992.

Description A: Nowak LG, Azouz R, Sanchez-Vives MV, Gray CM, and McCormick DA analyzed electrophysiological classes of cat primary visual cortical neurons in 2003.
Description B: Nowak LG, Azouz R, Sanchez-Vives MV, Gray CM, and McCormick DA analyzed electrophysiological classes of rat somatosensory cortical neurons in 2003.

Description A: Puopolo M, Raviola E, and Bean BP studied roles of subthreshold calcium current and sodium current in spontaneous firing of mouse midbrain dopamine neurons in 2007.
Description B: Puopolo M, Raviola E, and Bean BP studied roles of subthreshold potassium current and sodium current in spontaneous firing of mouse midbrain dopamine neurons in 2007.

Description A: Yamada R and Kuba H researched structural and functional plasticity at the axon initial segment in 2016.
Description B: Yamada R and Kuba H researched structural and functional plasticity at the synaptic cleft in 2016.

Description A: Yang N, George AL Jr, and Horn R explored molecular basis of charge movement in voltage-gated sodium channels in 1996.
Description B: Yang N, George AL Jr, and Horn R explored molecular basis of charge movement in ligand-gated sodium channels in 1996.

Description A: Tai C, Abe Y, Westenbroek RE, Scheuer T, and Catterall WA studied impaired excitability of somatostatin- and parvalbumin-expressing cortical interneurons in a mouse model of Dravet syndrome in 2014.
Description B: Tai C, Abe Y, Westenbroek RE, Scheuer T, and Catterall WA studied impaired excitability of astrocytes in a mouse model of Dravet syndrome in 2014.

Description A: Proft J and Weiss N investigated G protein regulation of neuronal calcium channels in 2015.
Description B: Proft J and Weiss N investigated protein kinase regulation of neuronal calcium channels in 2015.

Description A: Llinás R and Jahnsen H conducted electrophysiology studies of mammalian thalamic neurons in vitro, published in Nature in 1982.
Description B: Llinás R and Jahnsen H conducted electrophysiology studies of mammalian neocortical neurons in vivo, published in Nature in 1982.

Description A: McCormick DA, Connors BW, Lighthall JW, and Prince DA compared electrophysiology of pyramidal and sparsely spiny stellate neurons of the neocortex in 1985.
Description B: McCormick DA, Connors BW, Lighthall JW, and Prince DA compared electrophysiology of pyramidal and densely spiny neurons of the neocortex in 1985.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) have been extensively studied for their role in representing decision variables during decision-making processes.
Description B: Neurons in the motor cortex have been extensively studied for their role in representing decision variables during decision-making processes.

Description A: The accumulation of evidence in the decision-making process can resemble a drift-diffusion process.
Description B: The accumulation of evidence in the decision-making process cannot resemble a drift-diffusion process.

Description A: The bounded accumulation framework suggests that the brain terminates decisions when accumulated evidence reaches a threshold.
Description B: The bounded accumulation framework suggests that the brain does not terminate decisions when accumulated evidence reaches a threshold.

Description A: The decision variable in perceptual decision-making is an accumulation of both signal and noise.
Description B: The decision variable in perceptual decision-making is an accumulation of signal only.

Description A: Persistent neural activity has been observed in both the frontal lobe and the motor cortex.
Description B: Persistent neural activity has only been observed in the frontal lobe.

Description A: The flutter-vibration task demonstrates that the persistent neural activity can represent sensory qualities, such as the vibration frequency of the reference stimulus.
Description B: The flutter-vibration task demonstrates that the persistent neural activity cannot represent sensory qualities, such as the vibration frequency of the reference stimulus.

Description A: Random dot motion tasks highlight the role of persistent neural activity in accumulating evidence for decisions.
Description B: Random dot motion tasks do not highlight the role of persistent neural activity in accumulating evidence for decisions.

Description A: The process of evidence accumulation for decision-making is often noisy and can be anticorrelated between competing choices.
Description B: The process of evidence accumulation for decision-making is never noisy and cannot be anticorrelated between competing choices.

Description A: Studies by Romo in the prefrontal cortex have shown neurons respond persistently and in a graded manner to flutter-vibration stimuli.
Description B: Studies by Romo in the prefrontal cortex have shown neurons respond immediately without any graded manner to flutter-vibration stimuli.

Description A: Gradual increase in neuron firing rates often indicates accumulation of evidence for one choice over the other in decision-making.
Description B: Gradual increase in neuron firing rates does not indicate accumulation of evidence for one choice over the other in decision-making.

Description A: Neurons representing evolving decisions start at a common firing rate level and change as more evidence is acquired.
Description B: Neurons representing evolving decisions do not start at a common firing rate level and do not change as more evidence is acquired.

Description A: Romo found that neurons in the prefrontal cortex respond during the delay period while the monkey awaited a second stimulus.
Description B: Romo found that neurons in the parietal cortex respond during the delay period while the monkey awaited a second stimulus.

Description A: Fluctuations in neuronal response can indicate the variability of evidence being accumulated.
Description B: Fluctuations in neuronal response do not indicate the variability of evidence being accumulated.

Description A: The striatum is a proposed candidate for where the threshold operation is applied in decision-making processes.
Description B: The cerebellum is a proposed candidate for where the threshold operation is applied in decision-making processes.

Description A: Persistent neural activity in the brain is thought to involve working memory as well as decision-making.
Description B: Persistent neural activity in the brain is thought not to involve working memory but only decision-making.

Description A: The decision process in perceptual tasks is an accumulation of both signal and noise represented by neuronal firing rates.
Description B: The decision process in perceptual tasks is only an accumulation of signal represented by neuronal firing rates.

Description A: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis results from the production of antibodies that bind to the extracellular domain of the ACh receptor.
Description B: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis results from the production of antibodies that bind to the intracellular domain of the ACh receptor.

Description A: In the neuronal ACh receptor, two α-subunits combine with three β-subunits to form the pentamer.
Description B: In the neuronal ACh receptor, one α-subunit combines with four β-subunits to form the pentamer.

Description A: Each α-subunit binds one molecule of nicotine at a site located at the interface with a neighboring β-subunit.
Description B: Each α-subunit binds two molecules of nicotine at a site located at the interface with a neighboring γ-subunit.

Description A: The M2 segment of each subunit forms the lining of the pore.
Description B: The M3 segment of each subunit forms the lining of the pore.

Description A: The high-resolution X-ray crystal structure model of a human neuronal nicotinic ACh receptor-channel is reproduced with permission from Morales-Perez et al. 2016.
Description B: The high-resolution X-ray crystal structure model of a human neuronal nicotinic ACh receptor-channel is reproduced with permission from Morales-Perez et al. 2018.

Description A: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis leads to a decrease in the number or function of the nicotinic ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
Description B: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis leads to an increase in the number or function of the nicotinic ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

Description A: The pore of the ACh receptor gradually narrows within the bilayer of the membrane.
Description B: The pore of the ACh receptor gradually widens within the bilayer of the membrane.

Description A: The extracellular region of the receptor-channel is approximately 6 nm in length.
Description B: The extracellular region of the receptor-channel is approximately 3 nm in length.

Description A: Negatively charged amino acids on each subunit form three rings of negative charge around the pore.
Description B: Positively charged amino acids on each subunit form three rings of positive charge around the pore.

Description A: Binding of ligand is thought to promote the closure of the cleft between neighboring subunits.
Description B: Binding of ligand is thought to promote the opening of the cleft between neighboring subunits.

Description A: A mutation in an amino acid residue in the M2 segment leads to a prolonged channel open time.
Description B: A mutation in an amino acid residue in the M1 segment leads to a prolonged channel open time.

Description A: The desensitized state of the neuronal nicotinic receptor has M2 segments that form a narrow constriction near the intracellular side of the membrane.
Description B: The desensitized state of the neuronal nicotinic receptor has M3 segments that form a narrow constriction near the intracellular side of the membrane.

Description A: The pore diameter in the open state is approximately 0.6 nm based on electrophysiological measurements.
Description B: The pore diameter in the open state is approximately 1 nm based on electrophysiological measurements.

Description A: The hydrophobic constriction is thought to provide a high-energy barrier that restricts the passage of hydrated cations.
Description B: The hydrophilic constriction is thought to provide a low-energy barrier that restricts the passage of hydrated cations.

Description A: Nicotine binds to the receptor-channel at the interface with neighboring β-subunits in neuronal receptors.
Description B: Nicotine binds to the receptor-channel at the interface with neighboring γ-subunits in neuronal receptors.

Description A: Each hemisphere of the brain is primarily concerned with sensory and motor processes on the contralateral side of the body.
Description B: Each hemisphere of the brain is primarily concerned with sensory and motor processes on the ipsilateral side of the body.

Description A: The crests of the convolutions in the brain's cortex are called gyri, and the grooves are called sulci or fissures.
Description B: The grooves in the brain's cortex are called gyri, and the crests are called sulci or fissures.

Description A: Broca's area, related to speech production, is located in the left frontal lobe.
Description B: Broca's area, related to speech production, is located in the right frontal lobe.

Description A: Wernicke's area processes auditory input for language and is important for understanding speech.
Description B: Wernicke's area processes visual input for language and is important for understanding speech.

Description A: In Broca's aphasia, a patient can understand language but cannot speak grammatically.
Description B: In Broca's aphasia, a patient cannot understand language but can speak fluently.

Description A: The central sulcus separates the precentral gyrus from the postcentral gyrus.
Description B: The central sulcus unites the precentral gyrus with the postcentral gyrus.

Description A: The frontal lobe is involved in planning future actions and control of movement.
Description B: The frontal lobe is primarily involved in processing auditory information and memory recall.

Description A: The temporal lobe is responsible for the recognition of objects and faces.
Description B: The occipital lobe is responsible for the recognition of objects and faces.

Description A: Conduction aphasia occurs when the arcuate fasciculus is destroyed.
