Description B: Conduction aphasia occurs when Broca's area is destroyed.

Description A: In conduction aphasia, patients understand spoken and written language but struggle to repeat it.
Description B: In conduction aphasia, patients cannot form coherent words or sentences at all.

Description A: Broca founded neuropsychology as an empirical science distinct from phrenology.
Description B: Broca founded phrenology as an empirical science distinct from neuropsychology.

Description A: Area 4 in Brodmann's classification corresponds to the motor cortex, which controls voluntary movement.
Description B: Area 17 in Brodmann's classification corresponds to the motor cortex, which controls voluntary movement.

Description A: Karl Wernicke described a type of aphasia characterized by a failure of comprehension rather than expression.
Description B: Karl Wernicke described an aphasia where patients can understand language perfectly but cannot speak comprehensibly.

Description A: Brodmann's cortical localization method distinguished areas by cell shapes and layered arrangements.
Description B: Brodmann's cortical localization method distinguished areas by cell shapes and neuronal connectivity patterns.

Description A: The parietal lobe forms a body image and relates it to extrapersonal space.
Description B: The occipital lobe forms a body image and relates it to extrapersonal space.

Description A: The thalamus acts as a gatekeeper for information to the cerebral cortex, preventing or enhancing the passage of specific information depending on the behavioral state of the organism.
Description B: The thalamus acts as a passive relay station for information to the cerebral cortex, transmitting all sensory data without alteration.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus project to the primary visual cortex.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus project to the primary auditory cortex.

Description A: The thalamic reticular nucleus is made up almost totally of inhibitory neurons that synapse onto the relay cells and does not project to the neocortex.
Description B: The thalamic reticular nucleus is made up almost totally of excitatory neurons that synapse onto the relay cells and projects to the neocortex.

Description A: Each of the sensory systems, except olfaction, has a similar processing step within a distinct region of the thalamus.
Description B: Each of the sensory systems, including olfaction, has a similar processing step within a distinct region of the thalamus.

Description A: Somatosensory information is conveyed from dorsal root ganglia to the ventral posterior lateral nucleus and from there to the primary somatosensory cortex.
Description B: Somatosensory information is conveyed from dorsal root ganglia directly to the primary motor cortex.

Description A: The anterior group of thalamic nuclei is thought to be related to memory and emotion.
Description B: The anterior group of thalamic nuclei is primarily involved in direct sensory relay.

Description A: The ventral posterior nuclei convey somatosensory information to the neocortex.
Description B: The ventral posterior nuclei convey olfactory information to the neocortex.

Description A: The medial geniculate nucleus is a component of the auditory system.
Description B: The medial geniculate nucleus is mainly involved in visual processing.

Description A: The pulvinar is extensively interconnected with widespread regions of the parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.
Description B: The pulvinar is primarily connected only with the frontal lobe.

Description A: The ventral anterior and ventral lateral nuclei are important for motor control and carry information to the motor cortex.
Description B: The ventral anterior and ventral lateral nuclei are responsible for processing visual information.

Description A: The reticular nucleus receives input from axons leaving the thalamus en route to the neocortex.
Description B: The reticular nucleus provides output directly to the primary auditory cortex.

Description A: The thalamic nuclei receive extensive feedback projections back from the neocortex.
Description B: The thalamic nuclei do not receive any feedback projections from the neocortex.

Description A: The lateral geniculate nucleus receives information from the retina.
Description B: The lateral geniculate nucleus receives information exclusively from the auditory system.

Description A: The pulvinar is disproportionately enlarged in the human brain compared to rodents.
Description B: The pulvinar is smaller in the human brain compared to rodents.

Description A: The thalamus is an important step in the hierarchy of sensory processing and is not a passive relay station.
Description B: The thalamus is a passive relay station where information is simply passed on to the neocortex.

Description A: Cholinergic neurons are divided into ventrolateral and dorsomedial clusters in the mesopontine region.
Description B: Cholinergic neurons are divided into ventromedial and dorsolateral clusters in the mesopontine region.

Description A: Dopaminergic neurons found in the olfactory bulb are classified as A16.
Description B: Dopaminergic neurons found in the olfactory bulb are classified as A14.

Description A: The A8 and A9 dopaminergic cell groups play a key role in the initiation of movement.
Description B: The A8 and A10 dopaminergic cell groups play a key role in the initiation of movement.

Description A: The A10 group of neurons is located in the ventral tegmental area and projects to the frontal and temporal cortex.
Description B: The A10 group of neurons is located in the dorsolateral tegmental area and projects to the parietal and occipital cortex.

Description A: Monoaminergic neurons typically have spontaneous regular firing patterns regulated by intrinsic pacemaker currents.
Description B: Monoaminergic neurons typically have irregular firing patterns regulated by intrinsic burst currents.

Description A: The basal ganglia depend on continuous dopamine exposure to facilitate motor responses.
Description B: The basal ganglia depend on continuous serotonin exposure to facilitate motor responses.

Description A: Serotonin regulates cardiovascular control and gastrointestinal peristalsis.
Description B: Serotonin regulates renal filtration and hepatic metabolism.

Description A: Serotonergic neurons are involved in the response to a rise in CO2 levels.
Description B: Serotonergic neurons are involved in the response to a rise in O2 levels.

Description A: Histaminergic cell groups are mainly found in the tuberomammillary nucleus.
Description B: Histaminergic cell groups are mainly found in the thalamic nucleus.

Description A: The E1-E5 histaminergic cell groups are the sole source of histamine in the brain.
Description B: The E1-E5 histaminergic cell groups are a minor source of histamine in the brain.

Description A: Dopaminergic neurons project to the striatum and play an important role in movement initiation.
Description B: Dopaminergic neurons project to the hippocampus and play an important role in movement initiation.

Description A: Serotonin has complex functions due to at least 14 different serotonin receptors.
Description B: Serotonin has complex functions due to at least 10 different serotonin receptors.

Description A: The A11 and A13 cell groups are located in the zona incerta of the hypothalamus.
Description B: The A11 and A14 cell groups are located in the zona incerta of the hypothalamus.

Description A: Acetylcholine neurons in the pons project to the brain stem reticular formation and thalamus.
Description B: Acetylcholine neurons in the pons project to the cerebral cortex and hippocampus.

Description A: The basolateral cholinergic neurons play an important role in arousal and selective attention.
Description B: The basal forebrain cholinergic neurons play an important role in arousal and selective attention.

Description A: Deficiencies of vitamin A can lead to night blindness and eventually to blindness if untreated.
Description B: Deficiencies of vitamin B can lead to night blindness and eventually to blindness if untreated.

Description A: The brain’s comparison of signals from different cone types is the basis for color vision.
Description B: The brain’s comparison of signals from different rod types is the basis for color vision.

Description A: Activated rhodopsin in the form of metarhodopsin II diffuses within the disc membrane to encounter transducin.
Description B: Activated rhodopsin in the form of metarhodopsin II diffuses within the disc membrane to encounter melanopsin.

Description A: In darkness, when the cGMP concentration is high, a sizeable Na+ influx maintains the cell at a depolarized level of approximately –40 mV.
Description B: In darkness, when the cGMP concentration is high, a sizeable K+ influx maintains the cell at a depolarized level of approximately –40 mV.

Description A: Stationary night blindness results when rod function has been lost but cone function remains intact.
Description B: Stationary night blindness results when cone function has been lost but rod function remains intact.

Description A: The output of ganglion cells emphasizes temporal changes in stimuli.
Description B: The output of ganglion cells emphasizes spatial constancy in stimuli.

Description A: In night vision, only the rods are active, so all functional photoreceptors have the same absorption spectrum.
Description B: In night vision, only the cones are active, so all functional photoreceptors have the same absorption spectrum.

Description A: Excited rhodopsin activates a phosphodiesterase through the G protein transducin.
Description B: Excited rhodopsin activates a phosphodiesterase through the protein melanopsin.

Description A: Each phosphodiesterase molecule can hydrolyze more than 1,000 molecules of cGMP per second.
Description B: Each phosphodiesterase molecule can hydrolyze more than 1,000 molecules of ATP per second.

Description A: Ganglion cells transmit neural images to the brain through the optic nerve.
Description B: Rod cells transmit neural images to the brain through the optic nerve.

Description A: The photoreceptor layer produces a relatively simple neural representation of the visual scene.
Description B: The ganglion cell layer produces a relatively simple neural representation of the visual scene.

Description A: In a single-photoreceptor system, a green light has the same effect on the visual system as a red light of greater intensity.
Description B: In a single-photoreceptor system, a blue light has the same effect on the visual system as a yellow light of greater intensity.

Description A: M-cells have faster and more transient responses than P-cells.
Description B: P-cells have faster and more transient responses than M-cells.

Description A: Active transducin (Tα-GTP) has an intrinsic GTPase activity.
Description B: Active transducin (Tα-GTP) has an intrinsic ATPase activity.

Description A: Retinal processing extracts low-level features of the scene useful for guiding behavior.
Description B: Retinal processing extracts high-level features of the scene useful for guiding behavior.

Description A: The 22q11.2 microdeletion accounts for approximately 1% of patients diagnosed with schizophrenia.
Description B: The 22q11.2 microdeletion accounts for approximately 10% of patients diagnosed with schizophrenia.

Description A: Individuals with the 22q.11.2 microdeletion have a 25% to 40% risk of schizophrenia and a 20% risk of autism.
Description B: Individuals with the 22q.11.2 microdeletion have a 5% to 10% risk of schizophrenia and a 50% risk of autism.

Description A: The best replicated finding in schizophrenia is the loss of gray matter in prefrontal, temporal, and parietal regions with counterbalancing increases in the size of the cerebral ventricles.
Description B: The best replicated finding in schizophrenia is an increase of gray matter in prefrontal, temporal, and parietal regions with counterbalancing decreases in the size of the cerebral ventricles.

Description A: Loss of gray matter in the cerebral cortex appears to result from loss of synaptic contacts rather than loss of cells.
Description B: Loss of gray matter in the cerebral cortex appears to result from cell death rather than loss of synaptic contacts.

Description A: Functional neuroimaging has demonstrated that patients' deficits in working memory tasks are associated with decrements in activation of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
Description B: Functional neuroimaging has demonstrated that patients' deficits in working memory tasks are associated with increased activation of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.

Description A: Abnormalities in the brain's connectivity are characterized by disruptions between brain regions in schizophrenia.
Description B: Abnormalities in the brain's connectivity are characterized by enhanced connections between brain regions in schizophrenia.

Description A: Postmortem studies have shown that gray matter loss in schizophrenia is due to a reduction in dendritic processes.
Description B: Postmortem studies have shown that gray matter loss in schizophrenia is due to a reduction in glial cells.

Description A: First-degree relatives of individuals with schizophrenia often exhibit gray matter loss intermediate between healthy individuals and those diagnosed with schizophrenia.
Description B: First-degree relatives of individuals with schizophrenia often exhibit more gray matter loss than those diagnosed with schizophrenia.

Description A: Genes identified through genetic studies of schizophrenia can inform the development of therapeutic drugs.
Description B: Genes identified through genetic studies of schizophrenia have no impact on the development of therapeutic drugs.

Description A: Polygenic risk scores provide probabilistic information and can help stratify populations by genetic susceptibility to schizophrenia.
Description B: Polygenic risk scores have no utility in stratifying populations by genetic susceptibility to schizophrenia.

Description A: Loss of gray matter in schizophrenia is not associated with cell death but is linked to a reduction in synaptic connections.
Description B: Loss of gray matter in schizophrenia is primarily due to widespread cell death.

Description A: The potential to study individuals carrying penetrant mutations offers insights into the biology of psychosis.
Description B: The potential to study individuals carrying penetrant mutations has no insights to offer into the biology of psychosis.

Description A: Environmental factors associated with schizophrenia include nutrient deprivation in utero and season of birth.
Description B: Environmental factors associated with schizophrenia include nutrient excess in utero and summer season of birth.

Description A: Syndromic forms of schizophrenia provide important windows into the biology of psychosis.
Description B: Syndromic forms of schizophrenia do not provide any insights into the biology of psychosis.

Description A: Monozygotic twins with schizophrenia have been found to show disease-specific cortical thinning.
Description B: Monozygotic twins with schizophrenia have been found to show an increase in cortical thickness.

Description A: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) was used to test the hypothesis that in patients with schizophrenia working memory engages circuits in the prefrontal cortex differently than in controls.
Description B: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) was used to test the hypothesis that in patients with schizophrenia working memory engages circuits in the occipital cortex differently than in controls.

Description A: The greater demand on working memory requires greater activation of prefrontal cortical circuits.
Description B: The greater demand on working memory requires greater activation of occipital cortical circuits.

Description A: Activity in the prefrontal cortex of two groups—patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls—was examined while subjects performed a working memory task.
Description B: Activity in the parietal cortex of two groups—patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls—was examined while subjects performed a working memory task.

Description A: Brain regions that showed statistically significant reductions in functional connectivity in patients compared to controls are highlighted in red.
Description B: Brain regions that showed statistically significant increases in functional connectivity in patients compared to controls are highlighted in red.

Description A: Unbiased, large-scale genetic studies have found that the strongest association with risk for schizophrenia lies within the major histocompatibility (MHC) locus on chromosome 6.
Description B: Unbiased, large-scale genetic studies have found that the strongest association with risk for schizophrenia lies within the mitochondrial DNA.

Description A: The complement system in the brain tags weak or inefficient synapses for removal by microglia.
Description B: The complement system in the brain strengthens weak or inefficient synapses.

Description A: All current antipsychotic drugs produce their therapeutic effects by blocking D2 dopamine receptors in the forebrain.
Description B: All current antipsychotic drugs produce their therapeutic effects by blocking serotonin receptors.

Description A: Complement factor C4, a component of the complement cascade, is synthesized by neurons and astrocytes.
Description B: Complement factor C4, a component of the complement cascade, is synthesized by oligodendrocytes and astrocytes.

Description A: Elevated expression of the complement factor C4A involved in synaptic pruning is one of the mechanisms leading to schizophrenia.
Description B: Elevated expression of the complement factor C4A involved in synaptic strengthening is one of the mechanisms leading to schizophrenia.

Description A: Overpruning of synapses during adolescence is one plausible mechanism that should be explored further in studies of youth at high risk for schizophrenia.
Description B: Underpruning of synapses during adolescence is one plausible mechanism that should be explored further in studies of youth at high risk for schizophrenia.

Description A: Increased expression in the brain of C4A is associated with a higher risk for schizophrenia.
Description B: Increased expression in the brain of C4B is associated with a higher risk for schizophrenia.

Description A: Variants within the MHC locus that give rise to high levels of C4A expression in brain increase schizophrenia risk.
Description B: Variants within the MHC locus that give rise to low levels of C4A expression in brain increase schizophrenia risk.

Description A: Photomicrographs of pyramidal neurons from the cerebral cortex show the morphology of layer III pyramidal neurons.
Description B: Photomicrographs of pyramidal neurons from the cerebral cortex show the morphology of layer V pyramidal neurons.

Description A: Antipsychotic drugs act by blocking D2 dopamine receptors in the brain.
Description B: Antipsychotic drugs act by enhancing dopamine receptor activity in the brain.

Description A: The complement factor C4 is associated with the complement cascade which is involved in synaptic pruning.
Description B: The complement factor C4 is associated with the blood clotting cascade which is involved in synaptic pruning.

Description A: Mirror neurons discharge both when the monkey actively grasps objects and when it observes similar actions performed by another monkey or the experimenter.
Description B: Mirror neurons discharge only when the monkey actively grasps objects and not when it observes similar actions performed by another monkey or the experimenter.

Description A: During motor action with 'mixed' objects, many neurons in PMv and M1 display a strong dependence on different grasping actions.
Description B: During motor action with 'mixed' objects, few neurons in PMv and M1 display a strong dependence on different grasping actions.

Description A: Acetylcholine (ACh) is released at all vertebrate neuromuscular junctions by spinal motor neurons.
Description B: Acetylcholine (ACh) is released at vertebrate neuromuscular junctions predominantly by sensory neurons.

Description A: Otto Loewi demonstrated that stimulation of the vagus nerve terminals in frog hearts released 'vagustoff,' later identified as ACh.
Description B: Otto Loewi demonstrated that stimulation of the adrenal gland terminals in frog hearts released 'vagustoff,' later identified as ACh.

Description A: Neuropeptides are processed in the Golgi apparatus and packaged in large dense-core vesicles approximately 70–250 nm in diameter.
Description B: Neuropeptides are processed in mitochondria and packaged in large dense-core vesicles approximately 70–250 nm in diameter.

Description A: Large dense-core vesicles contain both catecholamines and neuroactive peptides and do not undergo local recycling after fusion with the plasma membrane.
Description B: Large dense-core vesicles only contain catecholamines and undergo local recycling after fusion with the plasma membrane.

Description A: Acetylcholine is released by all preganglionic neurons in the autonomic nervous system and by parasympathetic postganglionic neurons.
Description B: Acetylcholine is released only by sympathetic postganglionic neurons in the autonomic nervous system.

Description A: Small synaptic vesicles are characteristic of neurons that use ACh, glutamate, GABA, and glycine as transmitters.
Description B: Small synaptic vesicles are characteristic of neurons that use serotonin and dopamine as transmitters.

Description A: Only a few small-molecule substances act as classical neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine, glutamate, GABA, glycine, and ATP.
Description B: Many small-molecule substances act as classical neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine, glutamate, GABA, glycine, and melatonin.

Description A: Neurotransmitters can activate autoreceptors on the presynaptic neuron that modulate further transmitter release or synthesis.
Description B: Neurotransmitters can activate autoreceptors on postsynaptic neurons to inhibit transmitter synthesis.

Description A: Astrocytes and microglia can synthesize, store, and release neurotransmitters, as well as express receptors that modulate their function.
Description B: Astrocytes and microglia only store and release neurotransmitters but do not synthesize them.

Description A: Dale and Loewi shared the Nobel Prize in 1946 for their work on neurotransmitter discoveries.
Description B: Dale and Loewi shared the Nobel Prize in 1956 for their work on neurotransmitter discoveries.

Description A: The chromaffin vesicles of the adrenal gland were named due to their reaction with chromate and were shown to accumulate neurotransmitters like epinephrine.
Description B: The chromaffin vesicles of the adrenal gland were named due to their reaction with mercury and were shown to accumulate neurotransmitters like epinephrine.

Description A: Classical neurotransmitters are removed from the extracellular environment through mechanisms specific to either synaptic clefts or extrasynaptic spaces.
Description B: Classical neurotransmitters are removed from extracellular environments solely through synaptic clefts.

Description A: Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter that does not follow classical rules as it is not released from vesicles.
Description B: Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter that follows all classical rules of neurotransmission and is released from vesicles.

Description A: The biosynthesis of acetylcholine depends on dietary choline delivered to neurons through the bloodstream.
Description B: The biosynthesis of acetylcholine involves choline synthesized directly by nervous tissue.

Description A: Acetylcholine is synthesized in a single enzymatic reaction catalyzed by choline acetyltransferase.
Description B: Acetylcholine biosynthesis involves multiple enzymatic reactions including oxidation and methylation.

Description A: Thunberg’s illusion, first demonstrated in 1896, is a strong, often painful heat felt after placing the hand on a grill of alternating warm and cool bars.
Description B: Thunberg’s illusion, first demonstrated in 1896, is a mild, often painless heat felt after placing the hand on a grill with uniform temperature bars.

Description A: Positron emission tomography (PET) was used to compare the cortical areas activated by Thunberg’s grill with those activated by cool, warm, noxious cold, and noxious heat stimuli separately.
Description B: Positron emission tomography (PET) was used to compare the cortical areas activated by Thunberg’s grill with auditory and visual stimuli.

Description A: The anterior cingulate cortex is activated by Thunberg’s grill and by noxious heat and cold, but not by discrete warm and cool stimuli.
Description B: The anterior cingulate cortex is activated by Thunberg’s grill and discrete warm stimuli, but not by noxious heat and cool stimuli.

Description A: A serotonergic pathway arises in the nucleus raphe magnus and projects through the dorsolateral funiculus to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
Description B: A serotonergic pathway arises in the locus ceruleus and projects through the dorsolateral funiculus to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

Description A: Naloxone blocks stimulation-produced analgesia, indicating the presence of endogenous opioids in the brain.
Description B: Naloxone enhances stimulation-produced analgesia, indicating the absence of endogenous opioids in the brain.

Description A: Stimulation of the periaqueductal gray matter blocks spinally mediated withdrawal reflexes that are normally evoked by noxious stimulation.
Description B: Stimulation of the periaqueductal gray matter enhances spinally mediated withdrawal reflexes that are normally evoked by noxious stimulation.

Description A: Opioid receptors fall into four major classes: mu (μ), delta (δ), kappa (κ), and orphanin FQ.
Description B: Opioid receptors fall into four major classes: alpha (α), beta (β), gamma (γ), and epsilon (ε).

Description A: Pain perception is regulated by a balance of activity in nociceptive and nonnociceptive afferent fibers.
Description B: Pain perception is unaffected by any balance of activity in nociceptive and nonnociceptive afferent fibers.

Description A: The shaking of the hand that follows a hammer blow or burn may alleviate pain by activating large-diameter afferent fibers.
Description B: The shaking of the hand that follows a hammer blow or burn exacerbates pain by activating small-diameter afferent fibers.

Description A: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) uses stimulating electrodes placed at peripheral locations to activate large-diameter afferent fibers.
Description B: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) uses stimulating electrodes placed at peripheral locations to inhibit small-diameter afferent fibers.

Description A: The anterior cingulate and insula regions of the cerebral cortex are activated when the hand is placed on Thunberg’s grill but not when warm and cool stimuli are applied separately.
Description B: The occipital and temporal regions of the cerebral cortex are activated when the hand is placed on Thunberg’s grill and when warm and cool stimuli are applied separately.

Description A: Opioid receptors are highly concentrated in the superficial dorsal horn of the spinal cord and the ventral.
Description B: Opioid receptors are highly concentrated in the deep dorsal horn of the spinal cord and the cerebellum.

Description A: Mice in which the gene for the μ receptor has been inactivated are insensitive to morphine and other opiate agonists.
Description B: Mice in which the gene for the μ receptor has been inactivated are hypersensitive to morphine and other opiate agonists.

Description A: Electrical stimulation of the brain produces analgesia specifically by activating the periaqueductal gray region.
Description B: Electrical stimulation of the brain produces analgesia by inhibiting the cerebral cortex directly.

Description A: The gate-control hypothesis was proposed in the 1960s to account for the fact that activation of low-threshold primary afferent fibers can attenuate pain.
Description B: The gate-control hypothesis was proposed in the 1960s to explain why activation of high-threshold primary afferent fibers enhances pain.

Description A: The neuronal signal for horizontal saccades originates in the paramedian pontine reticular formation.
Description B: The neuronal signal for horizontal saccades originates in the medial vestibular nucleus.

Description A: Omnipause neurons fire continuously except around the time of a saccade; firing ceases shortly before and during all saccades.
Description B: Omnipause neurons fire intermittently and increase firing during saccades.

Description A: Medium-lead excitatory burst neurons make direct excitatory connections to motor neurons and interneurons in the ipsilateral abducens nucleus.
Description B: Medium-lead excitatory burst neurons inhibit motor neurons and interneurons in the ipsilateral abducens nucleus.

Description A: The medial vestibular nucleus and nucleus prepositus hypoglossi perform neural integration of the velocity signal for horizontal eye movements.
Description B: The lateral vestibular nucleus performs neural integration of the velocity signal for horizontal eye movements.

Description A: Lesions of the medial longitudinal fasciculus disconnect the medial rectus motor neurons from the abducens interneurons.
Description B: Lesions of the medial longitudinal fasciculus connect the medial rectus motor neurons to the abducens interneurons.

Description A: The burst neurons responsible for vertical saccades are found in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus.
Description B: The burst neurons responsible for vertical saccades are found in the caudal interstitial nucleus of the lateral longitudinal fasciculus.

Description A: Vertical and torsional neural integration are performed in the interstitial nucleus of Cajal.
Description B: Vertical and torsional neural integration are performed in the abducens nucleus.

Description A: The oculomotor portion of the dorsal vermis controls the duration of the pulse and thus the accuracy of the saccade.
Description B: The oculomotor portion of the dorsal vermis contributes to weakening the saccade.

Description A: A midline lesion of the commissural connections in the brain may cause failure of the neural integrator.
Description B: A midline lesion of the commissural connections in the brain enhances the neural integrator's function.

Description A: The flocculus and paraflocculus of the vestibulocerebellum calibrate the neural integrator.
Description B: The flocculus and paraflocculus of the vestibulocerebellum impede the neural integrator.

Description A: Lesions that include the paramedian pontine reticular formation result in paralysis of ipsiversive horizontal gaze of both eyes.
Description B: Lesions that include the paramedian pontine reticular formation improve ipsiversive horizontal gaze of both eyes.

Description A: Purely vertical saccades require activity on both sides of the mesencephalic reticular formation.
Description B: Purely vertical saccades require activity on one side of the mesencephalic reticular formation.

Description A: If the motor neurons received signals from only the burst cells, the eyes would drift back to the starting position after a saccade.
Description B: If the motor neurons received signals from only the burst cells, the eyes would remain fixed after a saccade.

Description A: Burst neurons and omnipause cells are coordinated to control saccade stability.
Description B: Burst neurons and omnipause cells operate independently during saccades to control stability.

Description A: The fastigial nucleus increases saccade velocity at the beginning of contraversive saccades.
Description B: The fastigial nucleus decreases saccade velocity at the beginning of contraversive saccades.

Description A: Astrocytes are found in all areas of the brain; they constitute nearly half the number of brain cells.
Description B: Astrocytes are found only in specific areas of the brain; they constitute a quarter of the number of brain cells.

Description A: In the central nervous system, more than half of the protein in myelin is the proteolipid protein (PLP).
Description B: In the central nervous system, less than half of the protein in myelin is the proteolipid protein (PLP).

Description A: Shiverer mice that inherit both defective genes have only approximately 10% of the myelin basic protein (MBP) found in normal mice.
Description B: Shiverer mice that inherit both defective genes have approximately 90% of the myelin basic protein (MBP) found in normal mice.

Description A: Astrocytes express many of the same voltage-gated ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors that neurons do.
Description B: Astrocytes do not express any of the same voltage-gated ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors that neurons do.

Description A: The mutation that causes the shiverer disease is a recessive deletion of five of the six exons of the gene for myelin basic protein.
Description B: The mutation that causes the shiverer disease is a dominant deletion of five of the six exons of the gene for myelin basic protein.

Description A: Myelin composition is similar to the plasmalemma, consisting of 70% lipid and 30% protein.
Description B: Myelin composition is similar to the plasmalemma, consisting of 30% lipid and 70% protein.

Description A: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is the most common inherited peripheral neuropathy and is characterized by progressive muscle weakness.
Description B: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a rare inherited peripheral neuropathy and is characterized by progressive muscle strength.

Description A: Astrocytes play important roles in nourishing neurons and regulating ion concentrations.
Description B: Astrocytes play minimal roles in nourishing neurons and do not regulate ion concentrations.

Description A: Shiverer mice with the transfected gene express the wild-type gene but produce only 20% of the normal amounts of MBP.
Description B: Shiverer mice with the transfected gene express the wild-type gene and produce 80% of the normal amounts of MBP.

Description A: In the peripheral nervous system, myelin contains P0 protein, as well as the hydrophobic protein PMP22.
Description B: In the peripheral nervous system, myelin contains no P0 protein, only the hydrophobic protein PMP22.

Description A: Proteolipids are soluble only in organic solvents because they contain long chains of fatty acids.
Description B: Proteolipids are soluble only in aqueous solutions because they contain short chains of fatty acids.

Description A: Myelin basic protein is situated on the cytoplasmic surface of compact myelin.
Description B: Myelin basic protein is situated on the outermost surface of compact myelin.

Description A: Mutations of the PMP22 gene cause several hereditary peripheral neuropathies.
Description B: Mutations of the PMP22 gene cause several central nervous system disorders.

Description A: Astrocytes can act as spatial buffers by taking up K+ at sites of neuronal activity.
Description B: Astrocytes cannot act as spatial buffers and do not take up K+ at sites of neuronal activity.

Description A: Astrocytes and neurons communicate to modulate synaptic signaling in poorly understood ways.
Description B: Astrocytes and neurons communicate to inhibit synaptic signaling in well-understood ways.

Description A: Learning and memory are enhanced in mice that overexpress a subunit of the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor.
Description B: Learning and memory are diminished in mice that overexpress a subunit of the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor.

Description A: The amplitude of the current generated by the NMDA receptors is enhanced in hippocampal neurons from mice that express higher levels of the NR2B subunit compared to wild type mice.
Description B: The amplitude of the current generated by the NMDA receptors is reduced in hippocampal neurons from mice that express higher levels of the NR2B subunit compared to wild type mice.

Description A: Long-term potentiation produced by tetanic stimulation of Schaffer collateral synapses is greater in transgenic mice than in wild type mice.
Description B: Long-term potentiation produced by tetanic stimulation of Schaffer collateral synapses is weaker in transgenic mice than in wild type mice.

Description A: Spatial learning is enhanced in transgenic mice, with transgenic mice reducing their escape latency faster than wild type mice.
Description B: Spatial learning is reduced in transgenic mice, with transgenic mice reducing their escape latency slower than wild type mice.

Description A: Transgenic mice spend more time in the target quadrant than do wild-type mice during the probe trial.
Description B: Transgenic mice spend less time in the target quadrant than do wild-type mice during the probe trial.

Description A: Doxycycline can reverse deficits in long-term potentiation in transgenic mice overexpressing CaMKII-Asp286 kinase.
Description B: Doxycycline enhances deficits in long-term potentiation in transgenic mice overexpressing CaMKII-Asp286 kinase.

Description A: Transgenic mice with doxycycline perform as well as wild type mice in learning the Barnes maze task.
Description B: Transgenic mice with doxycycline perform worse than wild type mice in learning the Barnes maze task.

Description A: Protein phosphatase 2A is required for long-term depression (LTD).
Description B: Protein phosphatase 2A is not required for long-term depression (LTD).

Description A: Inhibition of phosphatase 2A reduces behavioral flexibility in transgenic mice.
Description B: Inhibition of phosphatase 2A enhances behavioral flexibility in transgenic mice.

Description A: The NMDA receptors are required for long-term depression.
Description B: The NMDA receptors are not required for long-term depression.

Description A: Expression of a phosphatase inhibitor in transgenic mice can block the induction of LTD.
Description B: Expression of a phosphatase inhibitor in transgenic mice enhances the induction of LTD.

Description A: When a phosphatase inhibitor transgene is turned off, transgenic mice display normal learning.
Description B: When a phosphatase inhibitor transgene is turned off, transgenic mice display impaired learning.

Description A: The removal of AMPA receptors through endocytosis is involved in long-term depression.
Description B: The insertion of AMPA receptors is involved in long-term depression.

Description A: In the hippocampal CA1 region, a 1 Hz stimulation can produce long-term depression.
Description B: In the hippocampal CA1 region, a 10 Hz stimulation can produce long-term depression.

Description A: APV, a drug, can block the NMDA receptors and subsequently inhibit long-term depression.
Description B: APV, a drug, can enhance NMDA receptor activity and subsequently promote long-term depression.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) fire when a monkey directs attention to the object's location.
Description B: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area (AIP) fire when a monkey directs attention to the object's location.

Description A: The likelihood ratio (LR) greater than 1 favors rain.
Description B: The likelihood ratio (LR) greater than 1 favors no rain.

Description A: In the medial intraparietal area (MIP), neurons fire when the monkey is preparing to reach for a visual target.
Description B: In the lateral intraparietal area (LIP), neurons fire when the monkey is preparing to reach for a visual target.

Description A: The log-likelihood ratio provides a natural scale for belief and replaces multiplication with addition.
Description B: The log-likelihood ratio complicates the scale for belief and replaces addition with multiplication.

Description A: A monkey had to decide whether to look at a red or green target, only one of which would lead to a reward.
Description B: A monkey had to decide whether to look at a red or blue target, both of which would lead to a reward.

Description A: Monkeys can be trained to perform a version of the weather prediction task.
Description B: Monkeys cannot be trained to perform a version of the weather prediction task.

Description A: Persistent neural activity maintains working memory, attention, and plans of action.
Description B: Transient neural activity maintains working memory, attention, and plans of action.

Description A: The neuron assigned positive values when the red target was in the response field.
Description B: The neuron assigned negative values when the red target was in the response field.

Description A: Neurons encode the cumulative sum of the logarithm of the probability ratios.
Description B: Neurons encode the cumulative difference of the probabilities.

Description A: The neuron does not fire if an object is presented outside the neuron’s response field even if the monkey is asked to attend to the location of the neuron’s response field.
Description B: The neuron fires if an object is presented outside the neuron’s response field, regardless of the monkey’s attention.

Description A: A good decision-maker should base the decision on the product of the likelihood ratios or the sum of their logarithms.
Description B: A good decision-maker should base the decision on the sum of the likelihood ratios rather than their product.

Description A: LRs greater than 1 have positive logarithms.
Description B: LRs greater than 1 have negative logarithms.

Description A: The firing can persist for several seconds after the stimulus has been removed.
Description B: The firing stops immediately after the stimulus has been removed.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) represent the accumulation of noisy evidence.
Description B: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area (AIP) represent the accumulation of noisy evidence.

Description A: Some shapes were highly reliable predictors that a reward will occur if the choice is for green or red.
Description B: All shapes were equally reliable predictors for rewards regardless of color choice.

Description A: Mania affects cognitive processes, often impairing attention and verbal memory.
Description B: Mania improves cognitive processes, enhancing attention and verbal memory.

Description A: Bipolar disorder can be exacerbated by sleep deprivation.
Description B: Bipolar disorder can be easily managed with sleep deprivation.

Description A: Anxiety disorders are the most common psychiatric disorders worldwide.
Description B: Anxiety disorders are the rarest psychiatric disorders worldwide.

Description A: Fear activates the sympathetic nervous system to prepare the body to cope.
Description B: Fear deactivates the sympathetic nervous system to prepare the body to cope.

Description A: The DSM-5 divides pathological anxiety syndromes into several distinct disorders.
Description B: The DSM-5 combines pathological anxiety syndromes into a single disorder.

Description A: Panic attacks are a severe manifestation of anxiety with discrete periods of intense foreboding.
Description B: Panic attacks are a mild manifestation of anxiety with no periods of intense foreboding.

Description A: PTSD follows an experience of severe danger or injury.
Description B: PTSD follows experiences of mild inconvenience or minor injury.

Description A: Generalized anxiety disorder is diagnosed when a person suffers chronic worry not warranted by circumstances.
Description B: Generalized anxiety disorder is diagnosed when a person suffers no worry regardless of circumstances.

Description A: Bipolar disorder generally begins in young adulthood.
Description B: Bipolar disorder generally begins in late adulthood.

Description A: Anxiety disorders can lead to excessive preoccupation with possible threats.
Description B: Anxiety disorders eliminate preoccupation with possible threats.

Description A: Social anxiety disorder can lead to avoidance of verbal classroom participation.
Description B: Social anxiety disorder encourages verbal classroom participation.

Description A: Individuals with rapid cycles in bipolar disorder tend to be less responsive to mood-stabilizing drugs.
Description B: Individuals with rapid cycles in bipolar disorder tend to be more responsive to mood-stabilizing drugs.

Description A: Manic episodes of type 2 bipolar disorder do not require hospitalization.
Description B: Manic episodes of type 2 bipolar disorder always require hospitalization.

Description A: Fear interrupts ongoing behaviors by alerting and aversive responses.
Description B: Fear encourages ongoing behaviors by calming and soothing responses.

Description A: In bipolar disorder, periods of normal mood vary widely among patients.
Description B: In bipolar disorder, periods of normal mood are consistent across all patients.

Description A: Decision-making has been studied in simple organisms, notably worms, flies, bees, and leeches, as well as in mammals from mice to primates.
Description B: Decision-making has been studied exclusively in simple organisms, notably worms and flies, and not in mammals such as mice or primates.

Description A: The hope is that biological insights from simple organisms will inform our understanding of processes characterized in mammals, especially primates.
Description B: Insights from simple organisms are believed to be irrelevant to understanding processes in mammals, especially primates.

Description A: Not all plans come to fruition, and not all thought leads to action.
Description B: All plans come to fruition, and all thought leads to action.

Description A: Psychologists and neuroscientists have long been concerned with decisions.
Description B: Until recently, decisions were only studied by economists and political scientists, with no input from psychologists and neuroscientists.

Description A: Detection experiments provided evidence that the visual system is capable of detecting a single photon.
Description B: Detection experiments showed that the visual system cannot detect a single photon.

Description A: The decision rule is to say “yes” if the evidence exceeds some criterion or threshold.
Description B: The decision rule is to say “no” if the evidence exceeds some criterion or threshold.

Description A: A false alarm occurs when a decision-maker responds “yes” when there was no stimulus.
Description B: A false alarm occurs when a decision-maker responds “no” when there was a stimulus.

Description A: The criterion represents a decision rule which instantiates knowledge about the problem.
Description B: The criterion is merely a formality and does not relate to knowledge about the problem.

Description A: The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) shows how changing the criterion affects the accuracy of the decision.
Description B: The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) does not relate to changes in criterion or decision accuracy.

Description A: The neural bases for more cognitive decisions have been examined by extending simple perceptual decisions.
Description B: The neural bases for cognitive decisions have not been examined in the context of extending perceptual decisions.

Description A: Every yes/no answer is a choice based on the sensory evidence.
Description B: Every yes/no answer is arbitrary and unrelated to sensory evidence.

Description A: The height of curves in signal detection theory represents the probability of observing a measurement under two conditions: signal present or absent.
Description B: The height of curves in signal detection theory is unrelated to the probability of observing measurements under signal conditions.

Description A: The challenge for neuroscience is to relate signal, noise, and criterion to neural representations.
Description B: There are no challenges in neuroscience related to signal, noise, and criterion in neural representations.

Description A: Decision-makers do not make the same decision even when confronting repetitions of identical facts.
Description B: Decision-makers always make the same decision when confronting repetitions of identical facts.

Description A: A lax criterion too often results in many false alarms because background noise exceeds the threshold.
Description B: A lax criterion prevents false alarms because background noise never exceeds the threshold.

Description A: Depth is computed from the difference between the two eyes’ views of the world and must be reconciled by the brain.
Description B: Depth is computed solely from the information received by a single eye without any input from the other.

Description A: An object lying in the plane of fixation produces images at corresponding positions on the two retinas.
Description B: An object lying in the plane of fixation produces images at non-corresponding positions on the two retinas.

Description A: The concept of binocular disparity involves objects located at different depths from the observer.
Description B: The concept of binocular disparity involves objects at the same distance from the observer.

Description A: Visual cortical neurons can be selective for objects lying both in front of the plane of fixation and behind it.
Description B: Visual cortical neurons are selective only for objects lying on the plane of fixation.

Description A: Objects near the observer can partially occlude those situated farther away.
Description B: Objects near the observer are always completely visible without occlusion.

Description A: Neurons in area V2 show sensitivity to global disparity cues.
Description B: Neurons in area V2 show no sensitivity to global disparity cues.

Description A: The integration of binocular input begins in the primary visual cortex.
Description B: The integration of binocular input begins in the auditory cortex.

Description A: Ocular dominance varies among cells in V1.
Description B: Ocular dominance is uniform among all cells in V1.

Description A: Depth plays an important role in both surface segmentation and establishing three-dimensional properties.
Description B: Depth is irrelevant to surface segmentation and establishing three-dimensional properties.

Description A: Binocular disparity involves properties known as near cells and far cells.
Description B: Binocular disparity excludes properties such as near cells and far cells.

Description A: Some neurons are selective for objects lying on the plane of fixation.
Description B: All neurons are selective for objects lying on the plane of fixation.

Description A: Random-dot stereograms demonstrate the global scope of disparity analysis.
Description B: Random-dot stereograms demonstrate a localized scope of disparity analysis.

Description A: Depth determination uses many monocular cues.
Description B: Depth determination uses no monocular cues.

Description A: Binocular neurons are selective for depth, computing it from relative retinal positions.
Description B: Binocular neurons compute depth exclusively from brain signals without retinal involvement.

Description A: Determining the depths of multiple objects requires linking the retinal images of all objects in the two eyes.
Description B: Determining the depths of multiple objects requires linking the retinal images in one eye only.

Description A: Neural crest cells pass through the anterior half of each somite but avoid the posterior half.
Description B: Neural crest cells pass through the posterior half of each somite but avoid the anterior half.

Description A: Neural crest stem cells are a small group of neuroepithelial cells at the boundary of the neural tube and epidermal ectoderm.
Description B: Neural crest stem cells are a small group of neuroepithelial cells at the center of the neural tube.

Description A: Neural crest cell migration requires significant cytoarchitectural and cell adhesive changes and differs from most migratory events in the central nervous system.
Description B: Neural crest cell migration does not require any cytoarchitectural and cell adhesive changes and is similar to most migratory events in the central nervous system.

Description A: BMPs trigger changes in neural crest cells by inducing expression of transcription factors like snail, slug, and twist.
Description B: BMPs trigger changes in neural crest cells by inhibiting expression of transcription factors like snail, slug, and twist.

Description A: Neural crest cells express integrins, which are receptors for extracellular matrix proteins found along peripheral migratory paths.
Description B: Neural crest cells avoid expressing integrins, which are receptors for extracellular matrix proteins found along peripheral migratory paths.

Description A: The first structures encountered by migrating neural crest cells are somites.
Description B: The first structures encountered by migrating neural crest cells are blood vessels.

Description A: Neural crest cells migrate to various sites throughout the body without relying on scaffolding, hence termed free migration.
Description B: Neural crest cells migrate to various sites throughout the body by relying heavily on scaffolding, hence termed assisted migration.

Description A: Outer radial glia lack contact with the ventricular surface and exhibit molecular differences from inner radial glia.
Description B: Outer radial glia maintain contact with the ventricular surface and exhibit the same molecular characteristics as inner radial glia.

Description A: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are required for neural crest migration at later stages.
Description B: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are not required for neural crest migration at later stages.

Description A: Ephrins provide a repellant signal that prevents neural crest cells from invading the posterior half of somites.
Description B: Ephrins provide an attractive signal that encourages neural crest cells to invade the posterior half of somites.

Description A: Development of sensory neurons is initiated at the time the cells emigrate from the neural tube.
Description B: Development of sensory neurons is completed before the cells emigrate from the neural tube.

Description A: Sensory neurons that express Runx1 and TrkA become nociceptors.
Description B: Sensory neurons that express Runx1 and TrkA become proprioceptors.

Description A: Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) can be reprogrammed from adult skin cells.
Description B: Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) cannot be reprogrammed from adult skin cells.

Description A: Neurogenin-1 and neurogenin-2 are key bHLH factors for the differentiation of glutamatergic pyramidal neurons.
Description B: Neurogenin-1 and neurogenin-2 are key bHLH factors for the differentiation of GABAergic interneurons.

Description A: Neurotransmitter choice determines the communication capabilities of neurons with their postsynaptic targets.
Description B: Neurotransmitter choice has no impact on the communication capabilities of neurons with their postsynaptic targets.

Description A: The human brain has approximately 1,000-fold fewer neurons than the mouse brain.
Description B: The mouse brain contains approximately 1,000-fold fewer neurons than the human brain.

Description A: Damage to the right parietal lobe can lead to unilateral visual neglect, causing patients to be unaware of the left side of space or objects.
Description B: Damage to the right temporal lobe can lead to unilateral visual neglect, causing patients to be unaware of the left side of space or objects.

Description A: Prosopagnosia, or face recognition deficits, is associated with lesions of the temporal lobe.
Description B: Prosopagnosia, or face recognition deficits, is associated with lesions of the parietal lobe.

Description A: The ‘what’ pathway in the brain is specialized for processing faces, objects, color, and semantic memory.
Description B: The ‘where’ pathway in the brain is specialized for processing faces, objects, color, and semantic memory.

Description A: The dorsal stream is primarily responsible for motor actions like reaching and grasping.
Description B: The ventral stream is primarily responsible for motor actions like reaching and grasping.

Description A: Wernicke aphasia, a form of agnosia, is associated with language comprehension deficits.
Description B: Wernicke aphasia, a form of agnosia, is associated with deficits in face recognition.

Description A: Damage to the right temporal-parietal junction is commonly associated with theory of mind deficits.
Description B: Damage to the left temporal-parietal junction is commonly associated with theory of mind deficits.

Description A: The ventral visual pathway is often referred to as the ‘what’ pathway.
Description B: The ventral visual pathway is often referred to as the ‘where’ pathway.

Description A: Neurons involved in color constancy help in recognizing the spectral properties of objects under varying lighting conditions.
Description B: Neurons involved in color constancy fail to adapt to spectral variations in lighting conditions.

Description A: Consciousness involves subjective experiences such as awareness, volition, and agency.
Description B: Consciousness only involves levels of arousal, such as wakefulness and sleep.

Description A: Sleep, delirium, and hypoglycemia are examples of altered states of consciousness.
Description B: Delirium, hallucinations, and epilepsy are examples of normal states of consciousness.

Description A: Nonconscious mental processes can influence decisions and behaviors without conscious awareness.
Description B: Conscious awareness is required for all decision-making processes to influence behavior.

Description A: Neural circuits associated with theory of mind are active in tasks that require reasoning about another person’s motivations.
Description B: Neural circuits associated with theory of mind are primarily active during motor coordination tasks.

Description A: Children under 3 years old often fail theory of mind tasks, showing an inability to predict another's belief based on false information.
Description B: Children under 3 years old often pass theory of mind tasks, showing an advanced understanding of others’ beliefs.

Description A: The brain can process sounds nonconsciously, such as distinguishing a baby’s cry from ambient noise.
Description B: The brain cannot process sounds nonconsciously and relies solely on conscious awareness for sound recognition.

Description A: Provisional commitments to actions like reaching or grasping involve decision-making processes in the brain.
Description B: Provisional commitments to actions like reaching or grasping are purely reflexive and not related to decision-making.

Description A: During non-REM sleep, the patient's PCO2 increases to near 60 mm Hg.
Description B: During non-REM sleep, the patient's PCO2 decreases to near 60 mm Hg.

Description A: Repetitive apnea at the rate of approximately once per minute causes the patient’s SaO2 to fall repetitively and dramatically.
Description B: Repetitive apnea at the rate of approximately once per minute causes the patient’s SaO2 to rise repetitively and dramatically.

Description A: Descending inputs from the limbic system can produce hyperventilation in connection with pain or anxiety.
Description B: Descending inputs from the limbic system can produce hypoventilation in connection with pain or anxiety.

Description A: Monoaminergic neurons in the brain stem can modulate motor tone.
Description B: Monoaminergic neurons in the brain stem cannot modulate motor tone.

Description A: The ventral respiratory group is connected with the pontine respiratory group in the pons.
Description B: The ventral respiratory group is connected with the thalamic respiratory group in the pons.

Description A: The A8–A10 cell groups are located in and near the substantia nigra and modulate motor systems and forebrain mechanisms of reward.
Description B: The A8–A10 cell groups are located in and near the cerebellum and modulate motor systems and forebrain mechanisms of reward.

Description A: The monoaminergic systems were among the first in the brain to be identified and mapped due to their fluorescence when exposed to formaldehyde.
Description B: The monoaminergic systems were among the last in the brain to be identified and mapped due to their fluorescence when exposed to formaldehyde.

Description A: All histaminergic neurons are found mostly within the tuberomammillary nucleus in the posterior lateral hypothalamus.
Description B: All histaminergic neurons are found mostly within the anterior lateral hypothalamus outside the tuberomammillary nucleus.

Description A: Breathing in most normal individuals becomes unstable during sleep at high altitudes.
Description B: Breathing in most normal individuals becomes stable during sleep at high altitudes.

Description A: Serotonergic neurons modulate afferent pain signals, thermoregulation, cardiovascular control, and breathing.
Description B: Serotonergic neurons do not modulate afferent pain signals, thermoregulation, cardiovascular control, and breathing.

Description A: The locus ceruleus plays an important role in arousal and attention.
Description B: The locus ceruleus does not play any role in arousal and attention.

Description A: Sleep apnea often goes undetected in many people.
Description B: Sleep apnea is always detected in many people.

Description A: Hyperventilation during exercise leads to a sustained drop in blood CO2.
Description B: Hyperventilation during exercise leads to an increase in blood CO2.

Description A: Breathing must be coordinated with many motor actions that share the same muscles.
Description B: Breathing need not be coordinated with any motor actions that share the same muscles.

Description A: Voluntary motor pathways can take over the control of breathing during talking, eating, singing, swimming, or playing a wind instrument.
Description B: Voluntary motor pathways can never take over the control of breathing during talking, eating, singing, swimming, or playing a wind instrument.

Description A: The monoaminergic systems adjust the responsiveness of a wide variety of sensory systems.
Description B: The monoaminergic systems do not adjust the responsiveness of any sensory systems.

Description A: Three semicircular canals in each inner ear detect rotational motion and work in bilateral synergistic pairs.
Description B: Three semicircular canals in each inner ear detect linear motion and work in unilateral pairs.

Description A: Two otolith organs in each ear detect linear translations and tilts relative to gravity.
Description B: Two otolith organs in each ear detect rotational movements and sound vibrations.

Description A: Vestibular nuclei neurons receive converging multisensory and motor signals from visual, proprioceptive, cerebellar, and cortical sources.
Description B: Vestibular nuclei neurons receive signals solely from cerebellar and proprioceptive sources.

Description A: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to the oculomotor system allow eye muscles to compensate for head movement through the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
Description B: Projections from the vestibular nuclei prevent eye muscles from compensating for head movement.

Description A: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to motor areas and the spinal cord facilitate postural stability.
Description B: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to motor areas hinder postural stability.

Description A: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to the thalamus and cortex ensure spatial orientation and influence spatial perception more generally.
Description B: Projections from the vestibular nuclei serve solely to regulate balance and posture.

Description A: Vestibular signals processed in the hippocampal regions are crucial for spatial location and navigation functions.
Description B: Vestibular signals processed in the hippocampal regions are primarily for auditory processing.

Description A: Disease or trauma to the vestibular system can produce nausea, vertigo, dizziness, balance disorders, visual instability, and spatial confusion.
Description B: Disease or trauma to the vestibular system affects only the visual system.

Description A: Vestibular signals are combined with visual signals in several cortical regions through Bayesian cue integration to provide motion perception.
Description B: Vestibular signals and visual signals operate independently in the brain, without integration.

Description A: We are only beginning to appreciate the role of the vestibular system in cognition.
Description B: The role of the vestibular system in cognition is well understood and needs no further research.

Description A: When lifting two objects of different size but equal weight, people report that the smaller object feels heavier.
Description B: When lifting two objects of different size but equal weight, people report that the larger object feels heavier.

Description A: The sensorimotor system can independently generate grip and load forces appropriate to the weights of objects despite persistent perception of weight differences.
Description B: The sensorimotor system relies entirely on conscious perception to generate grip and load forces appropriate to the weights of objects.

Description A: Motor planning allows purposeful movements to be represented abstractly in the brain, enabling flexibility of action.
Description B: Motor planning ensures that all movements are encoded as specific joint motions for precise execution.

Description A: The tendency for hand movements to follow straight-line paths highlights task-centered motor planning efforts by the brain.
Description B: Hand movements typically follow curved paths, which demonstrates the brain's reliance on joint-centered motor planning.

Description A: Optic ataxia results from damage to the dorsal stream, causing a deficit in the control of actions despite intact perception.
Description B: Optic ataxia results from damage to the ventral stream, causing impaired visual perception but intact control of actions.

Description A: The size–weight illusion demonstrates the separation between sensorimotor actions and high-level cognitive centers in the brain.
Description B: The size–weight illusion occurs because sensorimotor actions depend directly on conscious weight estimation.

Description A: Visual information for action is processed in the dorsal stream, which projects to the posterior parietal cortex.
Description B: Visual information for action is processed in the ventral stream, which projects to the posterior parietal cortex.

Description A: Hand speed profiles are typically smooth, unimodal, and roughly symmetric during straight-line movements.
Description B: Hand speed profiles are irregular, multimodal, and asymmetrical during straight-line movements.

Description A: Damage to the ventral stream in the brain can result in visual agnosia, impairing conscious visual perception.
Description B: Damage to the dorsal stream in the brain can result in visual agnosia, impairing conscious visual perception.

Description A: Patients with visual agnosia can put a card through a slot even though they are unable to indicate its orientation verbally.
Description B: Patients with visual agnosia are unable to put a card through a slot or indicate its orientation verbally.

Description A: Motor equivalence demonstrates that handwriting appears structurally similar regardless of limb or body segment used.
Description B: Motor equivalence shows that handwriting differs significantly depending on the limb or body segment used.

Description A: Planning movements with reference to joints requires computing nonlinear combinations of joint angles.
Description B: Planning movements with reference to joints results in linear combinations of joint angles.

Description A: Reaching movements tend to follow straight paths, even though muscle rotations induce joint arcs.
Description B: Reaching movements typically produce curved arcs, directly reflecting muscle rotations at joints.

Description A: Subjects can rapidly learn to scale fingertip forces appropriately for the true weight of objects despite illusions.
Description B: Subjects cannot adjust fingertip forces for the true weight of objects when experiencing weight illusions.

Description A: Motor systems achieve redundancy, allowing the same task to be performed in multiple ways.
Description B: Motor systems lack redundancy, requiring a fixed approach for performing each task.

Description A: DBS can help people with Parkinson disease by delivering electrical pulses to targeted areas in the brain to disrupt the aberrant neural activity.
Description B: DBS can help people with Parkinson disease by implanting sensor electrodes to visualize brain activity without delivering electrical pulses.

Description A: Communication BMIs are designed to provide a fast and accurate interface with a plethora of electronic devices.
Description B: Communication BMIs are designed to solely interpret speech and translate it into visual text.

Description A: Antiseizure BMIs operate by continuously monitoring neural activity in a brain region determined to be involved with seizures.
Description B: Antiseizure BMIs operate by discontinuously analyzing neural activity without monitoring specific brain regions.

Description A: Intracortical electrode arrays are implanted in the outer 1 to 2 mm of cortex.
Description B: Intracortical electrode arrays are implanted on the scalp rather than the cortex.

Description A: Replacement part BMIs can potentially restore lost functionality of a brain region damaged by stroke.
Description B: Replacement part BMIs are incapable of addressing any damage from strokes.

Description A: Deep brain stimulation can help reduce Parkinson disease-related tremor for years.
Description B: Deep brain stimulation can reduce tremor associated with Parkinson disease for only a few minutes.

Description A: BMIs build on basic neuroscientific research in voluntary movement.
Description B: BMIs build primarily on aesthetic medical sciences unrelated to movement.

Description A: Arrays of penetrating intracortical electrodes can record action potentials from individual neurons.
Description B: Arrays of penetrating intracortical electrodes can only record from neuron clusters instead of individual neurons.

Description A: Communication BMIs could benefit people with ALS who often cannot communicate with the outside world.
Description B: Communication BMIs have no benefits for people with ALS.

Description A: Visual cortex injury can impact how BMIs interpret neural signals.
Description B: Visual cortex injury has no effect on BMIs since they don't rely on neural signals.

Description A: Measuring and modulating neural activity relies on advanced neurotechnology.
Description B: Measuring and modulating neural activity depends only on basic technology.

Description A: Replacement part BMIs might also be used to initiate and guide neural plasticity.
Description B: Replacement part BMIs do not contribute to neural plasticity initiation or guidance.

Description A: Antiseizure BMIs respond within milliseconds to disrupt seizure-related neural activity.
Description B: Antiseizure BMIs take several minutes to respond to unusual neural activity.

Description A: BMIs can improve quality of life by restoring some lost motor function.
Description B: BMIs exclusively focus on enhancing sensory functions rather than motor functions.

Description A: The design and development of BMIs have largely depended on laboratory animal research.
Description B: The design and development of BMIs have primarily come from human clinical trials.

Description A: Aristotle defined five senses—vision, hearing, touch, taste, and smell—each linked to specific sense organs in the body: eyes, ears, skin, tongue, and nose.
Description B: Aristotle defined seven senses—vision, hearing, touch, taste, smell, balance, and intuition—each linked to specific sense organs in the body.

Description A: Sensory information is processed in parallel pathways in the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Sensory information is processed in sequential pathways in the spinal cord.

Description A: Pain is not considered to be a specific sensory modality but rather an affliction of the soul.
Description B: Pain is considered to be a specific sensory modality linked to the nervous system.

Description A: The principal receptor cells include photoreceptors, chemoreceptors, thermal receptors, and mechanoreceptors.
Description B: The principal receptor cells include nociceptors, olfactoreceptors, thermoreceptors, and mechanoreceptors.

Description A: Feedback pathways from the brain regulate sensory coding mechanisms.
Description B: Feedback pathways from the peripheral nerves regulate sensory coding mechanisms.

Description A: Sense organs transform stimulus energy into electrical signals that are encoded as trains of action potentials.
Description B: Sense organs transform electrical energy into stimulus signals that are encoded as trains of action potentials.

Description A: Psychophysics quantifies the perception of stimulus properties.
Description B: Psychophysics quantifies the transmission of neural signals.

Description A: The modern study of sensation and perception began in the 19th century with the emergence of experimental psychology.
Description B: The modern study of sensation and perception began in the 18th century with the emergence of experimental physics.

Description A: The semiotic sensory modalities—thermal senses, pain, visceral sensations, and proprioception—are mediated by receptors distributed throughout the body.
Description B: The somatosensory modalities—thermal senses, pain, visceral sensations, and proprioception—are mediated by receptors distributed throughout the body.

Description A: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has been used to identify regions of the brain involved in the perception of pain.
Description B: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has been used to identify regions of the spinal cord involved in the perception of pain.

Description A: Kant classified the five senses as categories of human understanding.
Description B: Kant classified the five senses as mere physical attributes.

Description A: Sensation informs and enriches all life, and the fundamentals of sensory processing have been conserved throughout vertebrate evolution.
Description B: Sensation confuses all life, and the fundamentals of sensory processing have evolved independently among vertebrates.

Description A: Locke, the preeminent empiricist, advanced the idea that the mind at birth is a blank slate, or tabula rasa.
Description B: Locke, the preeminent empiricist, advanced the idea that the mind at birth is full of innate ideas.

Description A: Sequences of action potentials signal the temporal dynamics of stimuli.
Description B: Sequences of action potentials signal the spatial dynamics of stimuli.

Description A: The sensory pathways have both serial and parallel components, consisting of fiber tracts with thousands or millions of axons.
Description B: The sensory pathways have only serial components, consisting of fiber tracts with tens of axons.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area of the monkey represent only those objects of potential importance to the monkey.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area of the monkey represent all objects in the visual field regardless of their importance.

Description A: Patients with lesions of the right parietal lobe tend to report less of what lies in the left hemifield than in the right hemifield.
Description B: Patients with lesions of the right parietal lobe tend to report more of what lies in the left hemifield than in the right hemifield.

Description A: The abrupt appearance of a visual stimulus involuntarily evokes attention.
Description B: The gradual appearance of a visual stimulus involuntarily evokes attention.

Description A: Activity evoked by a saccade plan lies at the peak of the priority map.
Description B: Activity evoked by a saccade plan lies at the base of the priority map.

Description A: The responses to a behaviorally irrelevant stimulus are much smaller than for any event that evokes attention.
Description B: The responses to a behaviorally irrelevant stimulus are much larger than for any event that evokes attention.

Description A: The ventral horn contains large motor neurons, whereas the dorsal horn contains smaller sensory neurons.
Description B: The dorsal horn contains large motor neurons, whereas the ventral horn contains smaller sensory neurons.

Description A: The proportion of gray matter to white matter is greater at sacral levels than at cervical levels.
Description B: The proportion of white matter to gray matter is greater at sacral levels than at cervical levels.

Description A: Fibers of the gracile fascicle carry somatosensory information from the lower limbs.
Description B: Fibers of the cuneate fascicle carry somatosensory information from the lower limbs.

Description A: The dorsal columns contain only ascending axons that carry somatosensory information to the brain stem.
Description B: The dorsal columns contain ascending and descending axons that carry somatosensory information to the brain stem.

Description A: The cervical enlargement is a region where a large number of fibers innervating the arms enter or leave the spinal cord.
Description B: The lumbar enlargement is a region where a large number of fibers innervating the arms enter or leave the spinal cord.

Description A: The proportion of ascending and descending axons increases toward the rostral end of the spinal cord.
Description B: The proportion of ascending and descending axons increases toward the caudal end of the spinal cord.

Description A: Descending axons in the ventral columns control axial muscles and posture.
Description B: Ascending axons in the ventral columns control axial muscles and posture.

Description A: The epicritic system is responsible for fine touch, pressure, and proprioception.
Description B: The protopathic system is responsible for fine touch, pressure, and proprioception.

Description A: Interneurons in the gray matter regulate the output of spinal cord motor neurons.
Description B: Motor neurons in the gray matter regulate the output of spinal cord interneurons.

Description A: The hippocampus is involved in storing the memory of the tennis ball return.
Description B: The cerebellum is involved in storing the memory of the tennis ball return.

Description A: The cerebellum adjusts movements based on proprioceptive information from peripheral sensory receptors.
Description B: The cerebellum adjusts movements based on visual information from the eyes.

Description A: The basal ganglia help initiate motor patterns and recall learned movements.
Description B: The amygdala helps initiate motor patterns and recall learned movements.

Description A: Ascending somatosensory axons in the lateral and ventral columns convey information about pain and thermal sensation.
Description B: Descending somatosensory axons in the lateral and ventral columns convey information about pain and thermal sensation.

Description A: The posterior parietal cortex provides a player with a sense of where their body is located in space.
