Description B: The motor cortex provides a player with a sense of where their body is located in space.

Description A: Brain stem neurons regulate heart rate, respiration, and arousal during movement.
Description B: The hippocampus regulates heart rate, respiration, and arousal during movement.

Description A: Intermediate-level visual processing includes contour integration and surface segmentation.
Description B: Intermediate-level visual processing excludes contour integration and surface segmentation.

Description A: Visual primitives include orientation selectivity and color selectivity.
Description B: Visual primitives include motion detection and sound sensitivity.

Description A: Neurons in visual cortical areas perform local and global analysis of scene properties.
Description B: Neurons in visual cortical areas only perform local analysis without considering global scene properties.

Description A: Change blindness demonstrates the importance of attention in object recognition.
Description B: Change blindness demonstrates the insignificance of attention in object recognition.

Description A: Top-down influences in visual processing can alter neuron properties based on perceptual tasks.
Description B: Top-down influences in visual processing cannot alter neuron properties based on perceptual tasks.

Description A: The association field mediates contour integration in visual cortex.
Description B: The association field is irrelevant to contour integration in visual cortex.

Description A: Feedback connections in cortical areas are as important as feedforward connections.
Description B: Feedback connections in cortical areas are less important than feedforward connections.

Description A: Neurons adapt their functions based on different behavioral contexts.
Description B: Neurons maintain fixed functions regardless of behavioral contexts.

Description A: High-level visual processing integrates information from memory and executive areas.
Description B: High-level visual processing operates independently of memory and executive areas.

Description A: The inferior temporal cortex is important for face processing in primates.
Description B: The inferior temporal cortex plays no role in face processing in primates.

Description A: Object recognition involves perceptual constancy.
Description B: Object recognition does not involve perceptual constancy.

Description A: Implicit visual learning can change the selectivity of neuronal responses.
Description B: Implicit visual learning has no effect on the selectivity of neuronal responses.

Description A: Visual memory interacts with both working memory and long-term memory systems.
Description B: Visual memory interacts only with long-term memory systems but not with working memory.

Description A: Low-level visual processing detects contrasts in light patterns projected onto the retina.
Description B: Low-level visual processing does not detect contrasts in light patterns projected onto the retina.

Description A: Intermediate-level processing deals with segregation of surfaces.
Description B: Intermediate-level processing deals exclusively with color identification.

Description A: The visual system interprets scenes and parses them into distinct components, separating foreground from background.
Description B: The visual system directly reproduces point-by-point light intensities, similar to the operation of a camera.

Description A: The Gestalt psychologists argued that perception depends on the properties of the stimulus as well as its context within the visual field.
Description B: The Gestalt psychologists argued that perception depends solely on the properties of the stimulus, independent of its context within the visual field.

Description A: Separating figure from background in a visual scene relies on geometric principles and cognitive influences like attention and expectation.
Description B: Separating figure from background in a visual scene relies only on geometric principles, with no influence from attention or expectation.

Description A: The principle of good continuation helps link line elements into unified shapes in visual perception.
Description B: The principle of good continuation disrupts the linking of line elements, preventing unified shapes in visual perception.

Description A: Vision is a biological process that has evolved in step with our ecological needs, prioritizing useful information over exact details.
Description B: Vision is a biological process that evolved to prioritize exact details of the visual scene over ecological context.

Description A: Object recognition depends on segmenting a scene into foreground and background elements, influenced by higher cognitive processes.
Description B: Object recognition is independent of segmentation into foreground and background elements and uninfluenced by cognitive processes.

Description A: The visual system processes information about shape, color, distance, and movement using computational rules inherent in neural wiring.
Description B: The visual system processes information about shape, color, distance, and movement only using learned cultural norms.

Description A: Statistical studies of natural scenes show that object boundaries often contain visual elements in close proximity and maintaining smooth contours.
Description B: Statistical studies of natural scenes show that object boundaries rarely contain visual elements in close proximity or smooth contours.

Description A: Gestalt features such as similarity, proximity, and good continuation characterize objects in natural scenes.
Description B: Gestalt features such as similarity, proximity, and good continuation are irrelevant to objects in natural scenes.

Description A: The receptive fields of neurons help analyze visual form, particularly object boundaries.
Description B: The receptive fields of neurons are unrelated to the analysis of visual form or object boundaries.

Description A: Visual processing occurs at three levels: low, intermediate, and high, involving tasks from local contrast detection to object recognition.
Description B: Visual processing occurs only at one level, focusing solely on object recognition.

Description A: Visual perception is an active and creative process that combines retinal information with neural rules and past experiences.
Description B: Visual perception is a passive process, limited to the information provided to the retina without neural involvement or prior experience.

Description A: The Gestalt principle of proximity means that features closer together are more likely to be grouped visually.
Description B: The Gestalt principle of proximity means that features farther apart are more likely to be grouped visually.

Description A: The German term Gestalt translates to configuration or form, emphasizing the holistic interpretation of visual stimuli.
Description B: The German term Gestalt translates to distortion or error, emphasizing fragmented perception of visual stimuli.

Description A: Smooth contours in a visual scene tend to stand out due to the principle of contour saliency.
Description B: Smooth contours in a visual scene tend to be indistinguishable due to the principle of contour saliency.

Description A: Layer IV is the principal layer of input from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.
Description B: Layer V is the principal layer of input from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.

Description A: Fibers from the parvocellular layer terminate in layer IVCβ, whereas the magnocellular fibers terminate in layer IVCα.
Description B: Fibers from the magnocellular layer terminate in layer IVCβ, whereas the parvocellular fibers terminate in layer IVCα.

Description A: The intrinsic cortical excitatory connections are mediated by spiny stellate and pyramidal cells.
Description B: The intrinsic cortical excitatory connections are mediated by smooth stellate and pyramidal cells.

Description A: A variety of γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)-ergic smooth stellate cells are responsible for inhibitory connections.
Description B: A variety of γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)-ergic spiny stellate cells are responsible for inhibitory connections.

Description A: The activity of the excitatory pyramidal and spiny stellate neurons is tightly controlled by local networks of inhibitory interneurons.
Description B: The activity of the excitatory pyramidal and spiny stellate neurons is loosely controlled by local networks of inhibitory interneurons.

Description A: Inhibitory interneurons come in multiple classes distinguished by their morphology and their coexpression of distinct peptides.
Description B: Inhibitory interneurons come in a single class distinguished solely by their size.

Description A: Horizontal connections allow target neurons to integrate information over a relatively large area of the visual field.
Description B: Horizontal connections allow target neurons to integrate information over a relatively small area of the visual field.

Description A: Feedback projections are thought to provide a means whereby higher centers in a pathway can influence lower ones.
Description B: Feedback projections are thought to provide a means whereby lower centers in a pathway can influence higher ones.

Description A: The number of neurons projecting from the cortex to the LGN is 10-fold the number projecting from the LGN to the cortex.
Description B: The number of neurons projecting from the cortex to the LGN is equal to the number projecting from the LGN to the cortex.

Description A: The visual cortex is organized visuotopically.
Description B: The visual cortex is organized haphazardly without clear structure.

Description A: Some interneurons form cascading circuits where interneurons of one class target interneurons of another class.
Description B: Some interneurons form cascading circuits where interneurons of one class target excitatory neurons directly.

Description A: The axons of pyramidal cells extend for many millimeters parallel to the cortical surface.
Description B: The axons of pyramidal cells extend directly perpendicular to the cortical surface.

Description A: Long-range horizontal connections in each layer of the visual cortex integrate information from different parts of the visual field.
Description B: Long-range horizontal connections in each layer of the visual cortex segregate information from different parts of the visual field.

Description A: Feedback connections may support integration because they originate from cells with larger receptive fields.
Description B: Feedback connections may support integration because they originate from cells with smaller receptive fields.

Description A: Dendritic arbors are colored blue, and axonal arbors are shown in brown.
Description B: Dendritic arbors are colored brown, and axonal arbors are shown in blue.

Description A: Cholesterol is the precursor of all steroid hormones and is converted via a series of enzymatic reactions into progesterone and testosterone.
Description B: Cholesterol is the precursor of all steroid hormones and is converted via a series of enzymatic reactions into cortisol and testosterone.

Description A: Testosterone or related androgens are obligate precursors of all estrogens in the body, a conversion that is catalyzed by aromatase.
Description B: Testosterone or related androgens are obligate precursors of all progesterones in the body, a conversion that is catalyzed by aromatase.

Description A: The expression of 5α-reductase in target tissues converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone, an androgen.
Description B: The expression of 5α-reductase in target tissues converts testosterone into estradiol, an androgen.

Description A: The androgen receptor binds DHT approximately three-fold more tightly than testosterone, accounting for the greater potency of DHT.
Description B: The androgen receptor binds testosterone approximately three-fold more tightly than DHT, accounting for the greater potency of testosterone.

Description A: In adulthood, patients with CAIS opt for surgical removal of the testes and hormonal supplementation appropriate for females.
Description B: In adulthood, patients with CAIS opt for keeping the testes and hormonal supplementation appropriate for males.

Description A: Sex-specific behaviors occur because the nervous system differs between males and females, influenced by genetic and environmental factors.
Description B: Sex-specific behaviors occur because the nervous system is identical between males and females, influenced solely by environmental factors.

Description A: Male SNB motor neurons are larger in size and have larger dendritic arbors, with a corresponding increase in the number of synapses they receive.
Description B: Female SNB motor neurons are larger in size and have larger dendritic arbors, with a corresponding decrease in the number of synapses they receive.

Description A: The bulbocavernosus muscle is larger in males than females; it is completely absent in females of some mammalian species.
Description B: The bulbocavernosus muscle is larger in females than males; it is completely absent in males of some mammalian species.

Description A: Steroid hormone receptors are ligand-activated transcription factors with several signature motifs including a hormone-binding domain.
Description B: Steroid hormone receptors are ligand-activated transcription factors with several signature motifs excluding a hormone-binding domain.

Description A: Patients with CAIS are chromosomally XY but carry a loss-of-function allele of the X-linked androgen receptor that abolishes cellular responses to testosterone and DHT.
Description B: Patients with CAIS are chromosomally XX but carry a loss-of-function allele of the Y-linked androgen receptor that abolishes cellular responses to testosterone and DHT.

Description A: At birth, male and female rats have similar numbers of neurons in the SNB, but female-specific cell death causes sexual dimorphism.
Description B: At birth, male and female rats have different numbers of neurons in the SNB, causing sexual dimorphism due to male-specific cell generation.

Description A: Hormones activate transcriptional activity by binding to receptors, which enter the nucleus to dimerize and bind to specific sequence elements.
Description B: Hormones activate transcriptional activity by binding to receptors, which remain in the cytoplasm and bind to nonspecific sequence elements.

Description A: Erectile function is controlled by a sexually dimorphic circuit in the spinal cord.
Description B: Erectile function is controlled by a sexually monomorphic circuit in the spinal cord.

Description A: The sex determination pathway in insects relies exclusively on pathways within individual neurons, independent of hormonal secretion.
Description B: The sex determination pathway in insects relies heavily on hormonal secretion from the gonads.

Description A: In the fruit fly, a sex determination cascade initiates expression of a transcription factor, fruitless (Fru) that specifies male sexual behaviors.
Description B: In the fruit fly, a sex determination cascade initiates expression of a transcription factor, fruitless (Fru), that specifies female sexual behaviors.

Description A: The parts of the drill that are not in plain sight to her are known to be in the line of sight of the man.
Description B: The parts of the drill that are in plain sight to her are known to be hidden from the line of sight of the man.

Description A: Narrative allows us to reason in more complex environments than simple reports.
Description B: Narrative limits our ability to reason in complex environments compared to simple reports.

Description A: The conscious awareness of an item might arise when the nonconscious brain reaches a decision to report the item to another mind.
Description B: The conscious awareness of an item does not arise when the nonconscious brain reaches a decision to report the item to another mind.

Description A: The speed–accuracy trade-off is controlled by setting a bound or threshold on the amount of evidence required to terminate a decision.
Description B: The speed–accuracy trade-off is controlled by eliminating any bound or threshold on the amount of evidence required to terminate a decision.

Description A: Decision-making provides a window on the neuroscience of cognition.
Description B: Decision-making provides a barrier to understanding the neuroscience of cognition.

Description A: For certain perceptual decisions, the source of evidence and its neural representation are known.
Description B: For certain perceptual decisions, the source of evidence and its neural representation are not known.

Description A: The evolutionary advantage of narrative reasoning is evident.
Description B: The evolutionary advantage of narrative reasoning is not evident.

Description A: Knowledge of an item satisfies most aspects of conscious awareness.
Description B: Knowledge of an item does not satisfy any aspects of conscious awareness.

Description A: The report might involve narrative or simple pointing to the location of a tool.
Description B: The report must always involve complex narrative and cannot simply point to the location of a tool.

Description A: The provisional intention to foveate corresponds to preconscious knowledge of object location.
Description B: The provisional intention to foveate does not correspond to preconscious knowledge of object location.

Description A: Objects imbued by narrative have a presence independent of the perceiver's mind.
Description B: Objects imbued by narrative have a presence dependent solely on the perceiver's mind.

Description A: Narrative can incorporate history, simulation, prediction, etiology, purpose, and consequence.
Description B: Narrative cannot incorporate history, simulation, prediction, etiology, purpose, or consequence.

Description A: We do not yet know how thresholds are implemented in brain circuits.
Description B: We have a complete understanding of how thresholds are implemented in brain circuits.

Description A: For neural systems, noise is attributed to the variable discharge of single neurons.
Description B: For neural systems, noise is attributed to the constant discharge of all neurons.

Description A: Brain activity supporting possible hand posture is not the hand posture itself.
Description B: Brain activity supporting possible hand posture is exactly the hand posture itself.

Description A: The persistence of memories of disturbing experiences increases the likelihood that we will recall information about arousing or traumatic events at crucial times.
Description B: The persistence of memories of joyous experiences increases the likelihood that we will recall information about arousing or traumatic events at crucial times.

Description A: Working memory maintains goal-relevant information for short periods.
Description B: Working memory maintains goal-relevant information for long periods.

Description A: Explicit memory involves both episodic and semantic memory.
Description B: Explicit memory involves both episodic and implicit memory.

Description A: Implicit memory includes the learning of motor and perceptual skills, perceptual regularities, and reinforced habits.
Description B: Implicit memory includes detailed recollection of personal experiences and facts about the world.

Description A: The initiation of long-term storage of explicit memory requires the temporal lobe system.
Description B: The initiation of long-term storage of explicit memory requires the cerebellum.

Description A: Forgetting forms like transience and blocking help avoid overwhelming clutter of details.
Description B: Forgetting forms like transience and blocking enhance memory recall.

Description A: Implicit memory is expressed in the performance of tasks even without conscious awareness.
Description B: Implicit memory requires conscious awareness and deliberate recall.

Description A: Motivation impacts memory retrieval through different prioritization mechanisms.
Description B: Motivation has no impact on memory retrieval.

Description A: A healthy memory system does not retain all the details of every experience.
Description B: A healthy memory system retains all the details of every experience.

Description A: The medial temporal lobe is involved in the retrieval of explicit memories.
Description B: The medial temporal lobe is not involved in the retrieval of explicit memories.

Description A: False memories may relate to the adaptive function of integrating experiences over time.
Description B: False memories have no relation to the integration of experiences over time.

Description A: Persistent memory of disturbing experiences can have adaptive value.
Description B: Persistent memory of disturbing experiences is purely detrimental.

Description A: Explicit memory retrieval involves the frontoparietal networks aiding attention and cognitive control.
Description B: Explicit memory retrieval does not involve the frontoparietal networks.

Description A: Implicit memory involves conceptual and perceptual priming.
Description B: Implicit memory involves conceptual and perceptual forgetting.

Description A: Emotional components of a story correlate with activity in the amygdala.
Description B: Emotional components of a story correlate with activity in the occipital lobe.

Description A: Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the synthesis of dopamine and norepinephrine.
Description B: Dopamine β-hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the synthesis of dopamine and norepinephrine.

Description A: The catecholamine transmitters include dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.
Description B: The catecholamine transmitters include dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.

Description A: Neurons that release norepinephrine do not express phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase.
Description B: Neurons that release norepinephrine express phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase.

Description A: Norepinephrine is synthesized within vesicles of adrenergic neurons.
Description B: Norepinephrine is synthesized in the cytoplasm of adrenergic neurons.

Description A: l-DOPA decarboxylase is synonymous with aromatic amino acid decarboxylase.
Description B: l-DOPA decarboxylase and aromatic amino acid decarboxylase are two different enzymes.

Description A: Dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra project to the striatum and play a role in movement control.
Description B: Dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra project to the hippocampus and play a role in memory control.

Description A: Tryptophan hydroxylase is similar in catalytic mechanism to tyrosine hydroxylase.
Description B: Tryptophan hydroxylase is unrelated to tyrosine hydroxylase in catalytic mechanism.

Description A: Epinephrine synthesis occurs in the adrenal medulla after norepinephrine exits the vesicles.
Description B: Epinephrine synthesis occurs directly inside vesicles in the adrenal medulla.

Description A: Only a small number of neurons in the brain use epinephrine as a neurotransmitter.
Description B: Most neurons in the brain use epinephrine as a neurotransmitter.

Description A: Elevated levels of tyrosine hydroxylase are observed in cell bodies after prolonged stimulation.
Description B: Elevated levels of tyrosine hydroxylase are never associated with prolonged stimulation.

Description A: Dopamine was initially thought to function only as a precursor to norepinephrine.
Description B: Dopamine was initially thought to function as a precursor to serotonin.

Description A: Serotonin is synthesized from the essential amino acid tryptophan.
Description B: Serotonin is synthesized from the essential amino acid tyrosine.

Description A: VMAT transports dopamine into synaptic vesicles for release.
Description B: VMAT transports tyrosine into synaptic vesicles for release.

Description A: Circadian changes in extracellular dopamine in the striatum are associated with altered dopamine transporter activity.
Description B: Circadian changes in extracellular dopamine in the striatum are unrelated to dopamine transporter activity.

Description A: Histamine synthesis involves the decarboxylation of the amino acid histidine.
Description B: Histamine synthesis involves the oxidation of the amino acid histidine.

Description A: The vestibular system in vertebrates has remained highly conserved across many species.
Description B: The vestibular system in vertebrates has evolved drastically over different species.

Description A: The bony labyrinth is a structure within the petrous portion of the temporal bone.
Description B: The bony labyrinth is a structure within the frontal bone of the skull.

Description A: Otolith organs sense linear accelerations.
Description B: Otolith organs sense rotational accelerations.

Description A: Vestibular signals are essential for spatial orientation and spatial navigation.
Description B: Vestibular signals are unnecessary for spatial orientation and spatial navigation.

Description A: Vestibulo-Ocular Reflexes stabilize the eyes when the head moves.
Description B: Vestibulo-Ocular Reflexes destabilize the eyes when the head moves.

Description A: Many animals' behaviors are referenced to gravito-inertial acceleration (GIA).
Description B: Animal behaviors are rarely referenced to gravito-inertial acceleration (GIA).

Description A: Inertial guidance systems have been used by vertebrates for 500 million years.
Description B: Inertial guidance systems were first developed by humans in the last century.

Description A: The utricle and saccule measure linear accelerations.
Description B: The utricle and saccule measure angular accelerations.

Description A: The semicircular canals measure angular accelerations.
Description B: The semicircular canals measure linear accelerations.

Description A: Central vestibular nuclei integrate vestibular, visual, proprioceptive, and motor signals.
Description B: Central vestibular nuclei only integrate motor signals.

Description A: The membranous labyrinth contains sensors for both the vestibular and auditory systems.
Description B: The membranous labyrinth contains sensors only for the vestibular system.

Description A: The space between the bone and membrane of the labyrinth is filled with perilymph.
Description B: The space between the bone and membrane of the labyrinth is filled with endolymph.

Description A: Gravity is referenced as gravito-inertial acceleration (GIA), directing toward the core of our planet.
Description B: Gravity is referenced as linear acceleration, directing away from the core of our planet.

Description A: Vestibular information is widespread in the cortex.
Description B: Vestibular information is concentrated only in the thalamus.

Description A: Vestibular signals originate in the labyrinths of the internal ear.
Description B: Vestibular signals originate in the frontal lobe of the brain.

Description A: Deletions on the maternal chromosome not directly involving the UBE3A gene were observed in rare patients with Angelman syndrome.
Description B: Deletions on the paternal chromosome not directly involving the UBE3A gene were observed in rare patients with Angelman syndrome.

Description A: Duplications of the 15q11-13 region are a well-established risk factor for nonsyndromic ASD.
Description B: Duplications of the 15q11-14 region are a well-established risk factor for nonsyndromic ASD.

Description A: Angelman syndrome has marked intellectual disability associated with the syndrome.
Description B: Angelman syndrome has mild intellectual disability associated with the syndrome.

Description A: Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by social disability.
Description B: Angelman syndrome is characterized by social disability.

Description A: Studies of fragile X, Rett, Williams, Angelman, and Prader-Willi syndromes account for a small fraction of the burden of social disability in the population.
Description B: Studies of fragile X, Rett, Williams, Angelman, and Prader-Willi syndromes account for a large fraction of the burden of social disability in the population.

Description A: Functional de novo missense mutations in the gene UBE3A have been found in individuals with ASD.
Description B: Functional de novo missense mutations in the gene UBE3A have not been found in individuals with ASD.

Description A: Epigenetic mechanisms and chromatin dynamics have been identified in the study of neurodevelopmental syndromes.
Description B: Epigenetic mechanisms and chromatin dynamics have not been identified in the study of neurodevelopmental syndromes.

Description A: Aberrant local protein synthesis has been linked to nonsyndromic forms of ASD.
Description B: Aberrant local protein synthesis has not been linked to nonsyndromic forms of ASD.

Description A: Rationally designed therapies may reverse key symptoms long after initial pathology has begun in brain development.
Description B: Rationally designed therapies cannot reverse key symptoms long after initial pathology has begun in brain development.

Description A: De novo single nucleotide variants and indels in ASD increase with the father's age.
Description B: De novo single nucleotide variants and indels in ASD decrease with the father's age.

Description A: Neuroligins are cell adhesion molecules found at postsynaptic densities of glutaminergic synapses.
Description B: Neuroligins are cell adhesion molecules found at presynaptic densities of glutaminergic synapses.

Description A: De novo copy number variations tended to cluster in distinct regions of the genome.
Description B: De novo copy number variations appeared to be randomly distributed throughout the genome.

Description A: About a dozen genomic intervals reach genome-wide significance for ASD risk based on screening for de novo mutations.
Description B: About a dozen genomic intervals do not reach genome-wide significance for ASD risk based on screening for de novo mutations.

Description A: De novo mutations contribute to ASD risk in a small percentage of the total population.
Description B: De novo mutations contribute to ASD risk in a large percentage of the total population.

Description A: Studies have found that the vast majority of deleterious de novo sequence mutations in ASD cases are present on the paternally inherited chromosome.
Description B: Studies have found that the vast majority of deleterious de novo sequence mutations in ASD cases are present on the maternally inherited chromosome.

Description A: Neuroactive peptides are processed within the neuron’s intracellular membrane system by specific proteolytic cleavage.
Description B: Neuroactive peptides are processed outside the neuron by proteolytic cleavage in the bloodstream.

Description A: Tyramine, found in red wine and cheese, acts as a false neurotransmitter while also stimulating the release of biogenic amines.
Description B: Tyramine, found in red wine and cheese, inhibits the release of biogenic amines and only acts as a false neurotransmitter.

Description A: Enzymes that catalyze the synthesis of most low-molecular-weight neurotransmitters can be found in the cytoplasm.
Description B: Enzymes that catalyze the synthesis of most low-molecular-weight neurotransmitters are exclusively found in the cell membrane.

Description A: Dopamine can be released from dendrites as well as axons, differing from classical neurotransmission.
Description B: Dopamine is only released from axons, following the traditional pathway of classical neurotransmission.

Description A: Neuroactive peptides are grouped into families with similar amino acid sequences.
Description B: Neuroactive peptides are not grouped into families and have completely distinct amino acid sequences.

Description A: The opioid family of neuropeptides includes endorphins, enkephalins, and dynorphins.
Description B: The opioid family of neuropeptides includes acetylcholine, dopamine, and serotonin.

Description A: The proenkephalin precursor produces multiple copies of Met-enkephalin and one copy of Leu-enkephalin.
Description B: The proenkephalin precursor only produces a single molecule of Met-enkephalin and no Leu-enkephalin.

Description A: Proteolytic cleavage in neuroactive peptides often occurs at basic amino acid residues like lysine and arginine.
Description B: Proteolytic cleavage in neuroactive peptides never occurs at basic amino acid residues like lysine and arginine.

Description A: Neuroactive peptides can act as neurotransmitters, hormones, or products of neuroendocrine secretion.
Description B: Neuroactive peptides only act as neurotransmitters and have no hormonal functions.

Description A: Egg-laying hormone from the marine mollusk Aplysia serves as both a hormone and a neurotransmitter.
Description B: Egg-laying hormone from the marine mollusk Aplysia serves only as a neurotransmitter and not as a hormone.

Description A: The processing of neuroactive peptides also occurs in vesicles within the neuron’s intracellular system.
Description B: The processing of neuroactive peptides occurs exclusively at the cell surface of neurons.

Description A: Serine proteases, which include trypsin, catalyze the cleavage of neuroactive peptide precursors.
Description B: Serine proteases, which include trypsin, do not play a role in the cleavage of neuroactive peptide precursors.

Description A: Morphine binds to mu opioid receptors, which are also targeted by endogenous opioid peptides.
Description B: Morphine binds to dopamine receptors and has no interaction with mu opioid receptors.

Description A: Some neuropeptides, like substance P, are involved in the perception of pain in the central nervous system.
Description B: Some neuropeptides, like substance P, only regulate stress responses and are not involved in pain perception.

Description A: Polyproteins can generate diversity by producing several distinct peptides cleaved from a single precursor.
Description B: Polyproteins lack diversity as they produce only one identical peptide from a single precursor.

Description A: Glutamate receptors are localized at excitatory synapses, and GABA and glycine receptors are localized at inhibitory synapses.
Description B: Glutamate receptors are localized at inhibitory synapses, and GABA and glycine receptors are localized at excitatory synapses.

Description A: Gephyrin links glycine receptors to microtubules, while PSD-95 links NMDA-type glutamate receptors to the cytoskeleton.
Description B: Gephyrin links NMDA-type glutamate receptors to microtubules, while PSD-95 links glycine receptors to the cytoskeleton.

Description A: In gephyrin mutant mice, glycine receptors fail to cluster at synaptic sites on spinal motor neurons, and glutamate receptor clusters remain unaffected.
Description B: In gephyrin mutant mice, glutamate receptor clusters fail to form at synaptic sites on spinal motor neurons, while glycine receptors remain unaffected.

Description A: Neuroligins promote presynaptic organization, while neurexins promote postsynaptic organization.
Description B: Neuroligins promote postsynaptic organization, while neurexins promote presynaptic organization.

Description A: Neurexin–neuroligin interactions facilitate precise apposition of pre- and postsynaptic specializations.
Description B: Neurexin–neuroligin interactions inhibit the precise apposition of pre- and postsynaptic specializations.

Description A: Neuroligin1 is concentrated in the postsynaptic membrane of excitatory synapses, and levels of glutamate receptors are reduced in neuroligin1 mutants.
Description B: Neuroligin1 is concentrated in the presynaptic membrane of inhibitory synapses, and levels of glutamate receptors are increased in neuroligin1 mutants.

Description A: Neuroligin2 plays a critical role in patterning the inhibitory postsynaptic membrane.
Description B: Neuroligin2 plays a critical role in patterning the excitatory postsynaptic membrane.

Description A: Thousands of neurexin isoforms are generated through differences in promoter choice and alternative splicing.
Description B: Hundreds of neurexin isoforms are generated through differences in promoter choice and alternative splicing.

Description A: Neurexins bind to multiple postsynaptic organizing molecules in addition to neuroligins.
Description B: Neurexins bind exclusively to neuroligins at postsynaptic sites.

Description A: Alternative splicing of neuroligins results in differential expression and multiple presynaptic partners.
Description B: Neuroligins are not subject to alternative splicing, resulting in limited presynaptic partners.

Description A: PDZ-containing proteins serve as scaffolding molecules that link components on both sides of the synapse.
Description B: PDZ-containing proteins serve exclusively as ion channels in the synaptic membrane.

Description A: Fibroblast cells engineered to express neuroligin induce presynaptic specializations in neurons.
Description B: Fibroblast cells engineered to express neuroligin induce postsynaptic specializations in neurons.

Description A: Neurons grown with control cells fail to form pre- and postsynaptic specializations.
Description B: Neurons grown with control cells form extensive pre- and postsynaptic specializations.

Description A: FGF proteins are among the recently discovered synaptic organizing molecules.
Description B: FGF proteins are unrelated to synaptic organizing mechanisms.

Description A: The PSD family contains PDZ domains that interact with synaptic proteins to assemble signaling complexes.
Description B: The PSD family of proteins contains no domains that interact with synaptic proteins.

Description A: Bradykinin directly activates both Aδ and C nociceptors and increases the synthesis and release of prostaglandins from nearby cells.
Description B: Bradykinin directly inhibits both Aδ and C nociceptors and decreases the synthesis and release of prostaglandins from nearby cells.

Description A: The COX-2 enzyme is preferentially induced under conditions of peripheral inflammation, enhancing pain sensitivity.
Description B: The COX-1 enzyme is preferentially induced under conditions of peripheral inflammation, enhancing pain sensitivity.

Description A: Release of substance P and CGRP from C fibers provokes plasma extravasation and vasodilation.
Description B: Release of substance P and CGRP from C fibers provokes plasma stabilization and vasoconstriction.

Description A: Aspirin and other NSAIDs are effective in controlling pain because they block the activity of COX enzymes.
Description B: Aspirin and other NSAIDs are effective in controlling pain because they enhance the activity of COX enzymes.

Description A: Neurogenic inflammation depends on neural activity and is influenced by the release of neuropeptides like CGRP.
Description B: Neurogenic inflammation is independent of neural activity and unaffected by the release of neuropeptides like CGRP.

Description A: Inhibition of NGF function and signaling blocks pain sensation as effectively as COX inhibitors and opiates.
Description B: Promotion of NGF function and signaling blocks pain sensation as effectively as COX inhibitors and opiates.

Description A: Repeated exposure to noxious stimuli can lead to central sensitization, involving N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA)-type glutamate receptors.
Description B: Repeated exposure to noxious stimuli can lead to peripheral sensitization, involving GABA receptors.

Description A: Pharmacological antagonists of substance P can block neurogenic inflammation and vasodilation in humans.
Description B: Pharmacological agonists of substance P can block neurogenic inflammation and vasodilation in humans.

Description A: Neurotrophins like NGF and BDNF are causative agents in pain, especially in inflammatory states.
Description B: Neurotrophins like NGF and BDNF are preventive agents in pain, especially in inflammatory states.

Description A: Histamine is released from mast cells after tissue injury and activates polymodal nociceptors.
Description B: Histamine is released from mast cells after tissue injury and deactivates polymodal nociceptors.

Description A: ATP, acetylcholine, and serotonin are released from damaged endothelial cells and platelets.
Description B: ATP, acetylcholine, and serotonin are released from healthy endothelial cells and platelets.

Description A: COX enzymes are key to prostaglandin synthesis, which can be reduced by aspirin.
Description B: COX enzymes prevent prostaglandin synthesis, which can be increased by aspirin.

Description A: Substance P acts on mast cells to evoke degranulation and release of histamine.
Description B: Substance P acts on mast cells to inhibit degranulation and release of histamine.

Description A: Prostaglandins are metabolites of arachidonic acid generated through COX enzyme activity.
Description B: Prostaglandins are metabolites of arachidonic acid generated through lipoxygenase activity.

Description A: Repeated noxious stimuli exposure leads to long-term changes in dorsal horn neuron responses, termed 'windup.'
Description B: Repeated noxious stimuli exposure leads to short-term changes in dorsal horn neuron responses, termed 'windcool.'

Description A: Autism spectrum disorder is present in at least 1.5% of the population.
Description B: Autism spectrum disorder is present in at least 5% of the population.

Description A: Autism spectrum disorders occur predominantly in males, with a typically cited 4:1 male-to-female ratio now being called into question.
Description B: Autism spectrum disorders occur predominantly in males, with a typically cited 1:1 male-to-female ratio.

Description A: ASD must be detectable before 3 years of age, but recent studies have shown it is possible to identify affected children within the first year of life in high-risk families.
Description B: ASD must be detectable before 6 years of age, and recent studies suggest it is difficult to identify affected children before 3 years of age.

Description A: Approximately 10% of clearly affected children with ASD show improvement, with little or no evidence of social disability later in life.
Description B: Approximately 50% of clearly affected children with ASD show significant improvement, with no evidence of social disability later in life.

Description A: Within the scientific community, a consensus has emerged that the increase in ASD prevalence reflects changing diagnostic criteria, increased awareness, diagnostic substitution, and some true increase in incidence.
Description B: Within the scientific community, a consensus has emerged that the increase in ASD prevalence solely reflects a true increase in incidence without changes in diagnostic criteria.

Description A: Individuals across the IQ spectrum are affected by ASD, and about half of all individuals with ASD also have intellectual disability based on current diagnostic practices.
Description B: ASD only affects individuals with an IQ below average, and the majority have intellectual disability.

Description A: Although ASD clearly affects the brain, no definitive biological markers have been identified, and diagnosis is based on behavioral criteria.
Description B: ASD diagnosis is based on definitive biological markers, rather than behavioral criteria.

Description A: ASD occurs in all countries, cultures, and socioeconomic groups.
Description B: ASD is limited to developed countries and higher socioeconomic groups.

Description A: Until recently, the term 'Asperger syndrome' was used to describe individuals with autism-related traits but normal language acquisition and IQ in the normal range.
Description B: The term 'Asperger syndrome' was always used to describe individuals with delayed language acquisition and below-average IQ.

Description A: Profound social disability has probably always been present in human populations, but autism was first described as a medical syndrome in 1943 by Leo Kanner and in 1944 by Hans Asperger.
Description B: Profound social disability was first recognized in 1900, and autism was defined as a medical syndrome by Freud in 1923.

Description A: ASD is characterized by impaired social communication and stereotyped behaviors with highly restricted interests.
Description B: ASD is characterized by enhanced social communication and diverse, unrestricted interests.

Description A: The current diagnostic framework places Asperger syndrome and pervasive developmental disorder under a single ASD spectrum construct in DSM-5.
Description B: The current DSM-5 diagnostic framework keeps Asperger syndrome and pervasive developmental disorder as separate from ASD.

Description A: Autism is not progressive; rather, special education programs and professional support often lead to improvements in behavior and adaptive functioning.
Description B: Autism is a progressive disorder, with social and behavioral symptoms worsening over time.

Description A: No single behavior is conclusively diagnostic for ASD due to variability in development and external factors like environment and social context.
Description B: A single behavior, such as lack of eye contact, is conclusively diagnostic for ASD regardless of age or context.

Description A: Recent longitudinal studies show approximately 10% of children with ASD significantly improve over time.
Description B: Recent longitudinal studies show 90% of children with ASD significantly improve over time.

Description A: A motor unit comprises a motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates.
Description B: A motor unit comprises a single muscle fiber and the neurons it innervates.

Description A: The axons from a motor nucleus exit the spinal cord in several ventral roots and peripheral nerves.
Description B: The axons from a motor nucleus exit the spinal cord in a single ventral root and peripheral nerve.

Description A: Synaptic input depolarizes the membrane potential of a motor neuron above threshold.
Description B: Synaptic input hyperpolarizes the membrane potential of a motor neuron above threshold.

Description A: Once synaptic input depolarizes the membrane potential of a motor neuron above threshold, the neuron generates an action potential.
Description B: Once synaptic input depolarizes the membrane potential of a motor neuron below threshold, the neuron generates an action potential.

Description A: The action potential releases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular synapse.
Description B: The action potential releases dopamine at the neuromuscular synapse.

Description A: A muscle fiber has electrical properties similar to those of a large-diameter, unmyelinated axon.
Description B: A muscle fiber has electrical properties similar to those of a small-diameter, myelinated axon.

Description A: Most muscle contractions involve the activation of many motor units.
Description B: Most muscle contractions involve the activation of a single motor unit.

Description A: Compound action potentials can be detected by electromyography.
Description B: Compound action potentials cannot be detected by electromyography.

Description A: The electromyogram (EMG) is typically large and can be easily recorded with electrodes.
Description B: The electromyogram (EMG) is typically small and difficult to record with electrodes.

Description A: Motor neurons innervating one muscle are usually clustered into an elongated motor nucleus.
Description B: Motor neurons innervating one muscle are usually dispersed randomly around the motor nucleus.

Description A: The motor neurons innervating one muscle are usually clustered into a motor nucleus that extends over one to four segments within the ventral spinal cord.
Description B: The motor neurons innervating one muscle are scattered throughout the entire spinal cord.

Description A: Action potentials propagate along the sarcolemma of the muscle fiber.
Description B: Action potentials do not propagate along the sarcolemma of the muscle fiber.

Description A: A motor unit comprises a motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates, illustrated by motor neuron A1.
Description B: A motor unit comprises a single muscle fiber, illustrated by muscle fiber A1.

Description A: The motor neurons innervating one muscle are clustered into an elongated motor nucleus.
Description B: The motor neurons innervating one muscle are scattered across different motor clusters.

Description A: Action potentials in all the muscle fibers of a motor unit occur at approximately the same time.
Description B: Action potentials in all the muscle fibers of a motor unit occur at vastly different times.

Description A: During the critical window, testes produce a transient surge of testosterone that masculinizes the developing bipotential nervous system.
Description B: During the critical window, ovaries produce a transient surge of estrogen that masculinizes the developing bipotential nervous system.

Description A: Sex hormones bind to cognate hormone receptors that modulate gene expression.
Description B: Sex hormones detach from cognate hormone receptors to suppress gene expression.

Description A: Many neuronal populations that are sexually dimorphic by morphological and other criteria have been identified in the vertebrate brain over the past few decades.
Description B: Few neuronal populations that are sexually dimorphic by morphological and other criteria have been identified in the vertebrate brain over the past few decades.

Description A: Pheromones guide choice of sexual partner in rodents.
Description B: Pheromones guide choice of dietary preference in rodents.

Description A: Sex hormones control sexual differentiation of neural pathways by utilizing cellular processes such as apoptosis, neurite extension, and synapse formation.
Description B: Sex hormones control sexual differentiation of neural pathways by suppressing cellular processes like apoptosis, neurite growth, and synapse formation.

Description A: Recent molecular studies have identified many sex hormone-regulated genes whose expression patterns are sexually dimorphic.
Description B: Recent molecular studies have identified few sex hormone-regulated genes whose expression patterns are uniform across sexes.

Description A: Both sensory stimuli and past experience profoundly regulate the display of sexually dimorphic behaviors.
Description B: Both sensory stimuli and past experience minimally influence the display of sexually dimorphic behaviors.

Description A: There are many sex differences between the brains of men and women, and in some instances, these sex differences align with gender in adult life rather than gender assigned at birth.
Description B: There are few sex differences between the brains of men and women, and these differences align strictly with gender assigned at birth.

Description A: Many of the actions of testosterone that masculinize the nervous system occur following its conversion to estrogen locally at the site of action.
Description B: Many of the actions of estrogen that masculinize the nervous system occur following its conversion to testosterone locally at the site of action.

Description A: Such sexually dimorphic neuronal populations are likely embedded within neural circuits found in both sexes, and they are thought to guide behavior along male- or female-typical patterns.
Description B: Such sexually dimorphic neuronal populations are exclusive to one sex and guide behavior exclusively along male-typical patterns.

Description A: Initiator caspases (caspase-8, -9, and -10) cleave and activate effector caspases.
Description B: Effector caspases (caspase-8, -9, and -10) cleave and activate initiator caspases.

Description A: The survival of mammalian neurons depends on the balance between antiapoptotic and proapoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family of proteins.
Description B: The survival of mammalian neurons depends on the balance between growth factors and neurotransmitters.

Description A: The binding of neurotrophic factors to their tyrosine kinase receptors is thought to lead to phosphorylation of protein substrates that promote Bcl-2–like activities.
Description B: The binding of neurotrophic factors to G-protein coupled receptors is thought to lead to phosphorylation of protein substrates that promote Bcl-2–like activities.

Description A: The activation of cell-surface death receptors like Fas results in the activation of caspase-8 or -10.
Description B: The activation of cell-surface death receptors like Fas results in the activation of neurotransmitters.

Description A: Stem cells near the ventricular surface of the neural tube divide to expand the neuroepithelium.
Description B: Stem cells near the pial surface of the neural tube divide to expand the neuroepithelium.

Description A: Processes of radial glia extend from the ventricular to the pial surface.
Description B: Processes of radial glia extend from the pial to the cortical surface.

Description A: Unlike excitatory neurons, forebrain interneurons arise subcortically in ganglionic eminences and then migrate tangentially.
Description B: Excitatory neurons and forebrain interneurons both arise in the cortex and migrate radially.

Description A: Neural crest cells migrate from their source at the dorsal tip of the neural tube to form sensory and autonomic neurons and glia.
Description B: Neural crest cells migrate from their source at the pial surface of the neural tube to form sensory and autonomic neurons and glia.

Description A: The greater complexity of the human brain compared to lower mammals is due in part to a larger pool of neuronal progenitors.
Description B: The greater complexity of the human brain compared to lower mammals is due exclusively to the larger size of the neocortex.

Description A: Cerebral organoids enable analysis of some aspects of early brain development.
Description B: Cerebral organoids enable analysis of mature cortical characteristics.

Description A: The nervous system generates up to twice as many neurons as survive in adulthood.
Description B: The nervous system generates up to half as many neurons as are needed in adulthood.

Description A: Trophic factors play a crucial role in determining which neurons within a population live or die.
Description B: Neurotransmitters play a crucial role in determining which neurons within a population live or die.

Description A: Neurotrophins bind to and activate kinases called Trk receptors.
Description B: Neurotrophins bind to and activate kinases called JNK receptors.

Description A: Stem cells near the ventricular surface of the neural tube divide to expand the neuroepithelium.
Description B: Stem cells near the ventricular surface of the neural tube increase cytochrome c in neurons.

Description A: Processes of radial glia extend from the ventricular to the pial surface.
Description B: Processes of radial glia extend from the ventricular to the ganglionic eminences.

Description A: Motor adaptation in monkeys demonstrates that with practice, their initially curved reach trajectories straighten as they adapt to a predictable external force field.
Description B: Motor adaptation in monkeys demonstrates that with practice, their initially straight reach trajectories become curved as they adapt to a predictable external force field.

Description A: Visual feedback from a computer monitor rotated 90° clockwise causes monkeys to move their arms counterclockwise, aligning cursor movement directly to the visual target with practice.
Description B: Visual feedback from a computer monitor rotated 90° clockwise causes monkeys to move their arms clockwise, aligning cursor movement away from the visual target with practice.

Description A: Spike-timing dependent increases in synaptic strength contribute to M1 motor map changes caused by ICMS conditioning between cortical sites A and B.
Description B: Spike-timing dependent decreases in synaptic strength contribute to M1 motor map changes caused by ICMS conditioning between cortical sites A and B.

Description A: Selective changes during visuomotor learning occur only in neurons near the learned direction, which is why adaptation generalizes poorly to other directions.
Description B: Selective changes during visuomotor learning occur universally across all neurons, which is why adaptation generalizes well to all other directions.

Description A: Motor-error signals in the precentral cortex facilitate trial-by-trial motor adaptation based on feedback learning.
Description B: Motor-error signals in the precentral cortex inhibit trial-by-trial motor adaptation based on feedback learning.

Description A: Changes in M1 neuron activity during force-field adaptation follow a cosine-like function depending on the angle between the force direction and the preferred direction of the neuron.
Description B: Changes in M1 neuron activity during force-field adaptation follow a random pattern regardless of the angle between the force direction and the preferred direction of the neuron.

Description A: Cortical areas like M1 show an increased firing response to motor errors simulated using ICMS, enabling adaptive reaching movements.
Description B: Cortical areas like M1 show a decreased firing response to motor errors simulated using ICMS, disabling adaptive reaching movements.

Description A: Monkeys rapidly correct movement errors when allowed brief visual feedback of hand position relative to the target after each reach.
Description B: Monkeys fail to correct movement errors when allowed brief visual feedback of hand position relative to the target after each reach.

Description A: During visuomotor learning, corrections are initially made online after movement onset but are gradually refined through practice.
Description B: During visuomotor learning, corrections are never made online after movement onset and remain uniformly inconsistent despite practice.

Description A: Adaptation-dependent changes in M1 activity diminish progressively as the angle between the force field and cell preferred direction increases.
Description B: Adaptation-dependent changes in M1 activity increase progressively as the angle between the force field and cell preferred direction increases.

Description A: Neural adaptation during visuomotor rotation occurs only for trained directions, explaining poor generalization to untrained directions.
Description B: Neural adaptation during visuomotor rotation occurs for all directions, explaining strong generalization to untrained directions.

Description A: Changes in synaptic strength within M1 horizontal connections support improved motor performance through cortical reorganization.
Description B: Decreases in synaptic strength within M1 horizontal connections hinder motor performance through cortical disorganization.

Description A: Learning motor skills like pellet retrieval results in expanded motor map areas for practiced movements in monkeys.
Description B: Learning motor skills like pellet retrieval results in reduced motor map areas for practiced movements in monkeys.

Description A: Adaptive changes in M1 neuron tuning during visuomotor learning occur at neurons whose preferred directions align closest to the learned movement direction.
Description B: Adaptive changes in M1 neuron tuning during visuomotor learning occur randomly across all neurons regardless of preferred direction.

Description A: Changing the relationship between directional tuning of M1 neurons and cursor motion significantly alters motor learning in brain-machine interfaces.
Description B: Maintaining a consistent relationship between directional tuning of M1 neurons and cursor motion hinders motor learning in brain-machine interfaces.

Description A: The information conveyed by receptors in the viscera is crucial for regulating autonomic functions, particularly in the cardiovascular, respiratory, digestive, and renal systems.
Description B: The information conveyed by receptors in the viscera is crucial for regulating autonomic functions, particularly in the musculoskeletal, endocrine, sensory, and immune systems.

Description A: Interoceptors are primarily chemoreceptors that monitor organ function through such indicators as blood gases and pH.
Description B: Interoceptors are primarily mechanoreceptors that monitor organ function through such indicators as temperature and pressure.

Description A: Somatosensory information from the skin, muscles, joint capsules, and viscera is conveyed by DRG neurons innervating the limbs and trunk or by trigeminal sensory neurons that innervate cranial structures.
Description B: Somatosensory information from the skin, muscles, and joint capsules is only conveyed by DRG neurons, not by trigeminal sensory neurons.

Description A: Functional imaging of individual DRG neurons expressing genetically encoded calcium sensors such as GCaMP6 enables simultaneous optical recordings of activity from populations of receptor neurons.
Description B: Functional imaging of individual DRG neurons expressing genetically encoded calcium sensors such as GCaMP6 is not useful for simultaneous optical recordings of activity from multiple receptor neurons.

Description A: The identification of Piezo protein ion channels as the molecular transducers of touch and proprioception in mammalian mechanoreceptors has provided a novel system for assessing the role of these channels in the senses of touch, proprioception, and visceral function.
Description B: The identification of Piezo protein ion channels as the molecular transducers of vision and hearing in mammalian auditory receptors has provided a novel system for assessing the role of these channels in the senses of sight and sound.

Description A: Dorsal root ganglion neurons are a type of bipolar cell, called pseudo-unipolar cells.
Description B: Dorsal root ganglion neurons are a type of multipolar cell, called bipolar cells.

Description A: The peripheral terminals of individual DRG neurons innervate the skin, muscle, joint capsules, or viscera and contain receptors specialized for particular kinds of stimuli.
Description B: The peripheral terminals of individual DRG neurons innervate only the brain and do not contain receptors specialized for particular kinds of stimuli.

Description A: This axon is called the primary afferent fiber.
Description B: This axon is called the secondary efferent fiber.

Description A: Each DRG neuron can be subdivided into five functional zones: the receptive zone, the spike generation site, the peripheral nerve fiber, the DRG cell body, and the spinal or cranial nerve.
Description B: Each DRG neuron can be subdivided into four functional zones: the axonal terminal, the central relay station, the synaptic cleft, and the dorsal horn.

Description A: The soma of a DRG neuron contains the cell nucleus.
Description B: The soma of a DRG neuron is devoid of a cell nucleus.

Description A: DRGs that innervate mechanoreceptors that sense touch and proprioception have the largest cell bodies and large myelinated axons.
Description B: DRGs that innervate mechanoreceptors that sense touch and proprioception have the smallest cell bodies and unmyelinated axons.

Description A: Peripheral nerve fibers with large cell bodies express neurofilament heavy polypeptide (NFH).
Description B: Peripheral nerve fibers with large cell bodies do not express neurofilament heavy polypeptide (NFH).

Description A: Peripheral nerve fibers are classified into functional groups based on properties related to axon diameter and myelination, conduction velocity, and whether they are sensory or motor.
Description B: Peripheral nerve fibers are classified into functional groups purely based on chemical properties, disregarding axon diameter and presence of myelination.

Description A: DRG neurons differ in the size of their cell soma, gene expression profile, conduction velocity of their axons, sensory transduction molecule(s), innervation pattern in the body, and physiological function.
Description B: DRG neurons are identical in size, gene expression profile, conduction velocity of their axons, and physiological function.

Description A: Damage to peripheral nerves or their targets in the brain may produce sensory deficits in more than one somatosensory submodality or motor deficits in specific muscle groups.
Description B: Damage to peripheral nerves or their targets in the brain never produces sensory deficits in somatosensory submodalities.

Description A: The density of ACh receptors is reduced over time in myasthenia.
Description B: The density of ACh receptors is increased over time in myasthenia.

Description A: Type 1A axonal neuropathy involves a defect in peripheral myelin protein 22.
Description B: Type 1A axonal neuropathy involves a defect in peripheral myelin protein P0.

Description A: Synapse elimination occurs without any overall loss of axons—axons that lose at some muscle fibers win at others.
Description B: Synapse elimination occurs with a significant loss of axons—axons that lose at some muscle fibers rarely win at others.

Description A: Central synapses are not patterned by master organizers akin to agrin, MuSK, LRP4, and laminins.
Description B: Central synapses are patterned by master organizers akin to agrin, MuSK, LRP4, and laminins.

Description A: Loss of no single central organizer studied to date is lethal in the manner observed for agrin, MuSK, LRP4, and laminin mutants.
Description B: Loss of each central organizer studied to date is lethal, similar to agrin, MuSK, LRP4, and laminin mutants.

Description A: The competitive process of synapse elimination is driven by neural activity.
Description B: The competitive process of synapse elimination is driven by random chance.

Description A: Activity dependence of synapse elimination involves microglial cells using the complex system of complement factors.
Description B: Activity dependence of synapse elimination involves astrocytes using the complex system of complement factors.

Description A: In adult mammals, each muscle fiber bears only a single synapse.
Description B: In adult mammals, each muscle fiber bears multiple synapses.

Description A: The process of synapse elimination occurs long after the period of naturally occurring cell death.
Description B: The process of synapse elimination occurs simultaneously with the period of naturally occurring cell death.

Description A: Astrocytes promote both presynaptic and postsynaptic maturation.
Description B: Astrocytes inhibit both presynaptic and postsynaptic maturation.

Description A: Synapse formation is enhanced in the presence of astrocytes.
Description B: Synapse formation is inhibited in the presence of astrocytes.

Description A: Schwann cells are the glia found at neuromuscular junctions.
Description B: Astrocytes are the glia found at neuromuscular junctions.

Description A: Glial cells, including Schwann cells and astrocytes, regulate both formation and elimination of synapses.
Description B: Glial cells, including Schwann cells and astrocytes, only regulate synapse formation, not elimination.

Description A: Genetic variation in many central organizers and synaptic recognition molecules has been associated with behavioral disorders.
Description B: Genetic variation in few central organizers and synaptic recognition molecules has no association with behavioral disorders.

Description A: Paralysis of muscle reduces synapse elimination.
Description B: Paralysis of muscle enhances synapse elimination.

Description A: Synapse elimination provides a means by which activity can change the strength of specific synaptic connections.
Description B: Synapse elimination occurs independently of any changes in the strength of specific synaptic connections.

Description A: Astrocytes provide multiple signals to neurons, such as thrombospondin and cholesterol.
Description B: Astrocytes provide only a single type of signal to neurons, not multiple signals.

Description A: Synaptic transmission between autonomic nervous system neurons that innervate smooth muscle is slower and relies on diffusion of the transmitter.
Description B: Synaptic transmission between autonomic nervous system neurons that innervate smooth muscle is faster and does not rely on diffusion of the transmitter.

Description A: The action of a neurotransmitter depends on the properties of postsynaptic receptors, not the chemical properties of the transmitter.
Description B: The action of a neurotransmitter depends on the chemical properties of the transmitter, not the properties of postsynaptic receptors.

Description A: ACh acts on excitatory ACh receptors at all neuromuscular junctions to trigger contraction.
Description B: ACh acts on inhibitory ACh receptors at all neuromuscular junctions to prevent contraction.

Description A: Presynaptic terminals can have receptors that modify the release process.
Description B: Presynaptic terminals cannot have receptors that modify the release process.

Description A: Receptors that gate ion channels directly are referred to as ionotropic receptors.
Description B: Receptors that gate ion channels directly are referred to as metabotropic receptors.

Description A: Ionotropic receptors produce fast synaptic actions, typically lasting only milliseconds.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors produce slow synaptic actions, typically lasting seconds to minutes.

Description A: Metabotropic receptors can produce synaptic actions that last hundreds of milliseconds to minutes.
Description B: Metabotropic receptors can produce synaptic actions that last only milliseconds.

Description A: Electrical synapses are typically very rapid and synchronize the activity of neuron populations.
Description B: Electrical synapses are typically very slow and do not synchronize neuron activity.

Description A: Metabotropic receptors often lead to the synthesis of second messengers like cAMP that regulate protein phosphorylation.
Description B: Metabotropic receptors do not lead to the synthesis of second messengers like cAMP.

Description A: Electrical and chemical synapses can coexist and interact in the same neuron.
Description B: Electrical and chemical synapses cannot coexist and interact in the same neuron.

Description A: Gap junction coupling can be enhanced by protein phosphorylation.
Description B: Gap junction coupling cannot be influenced by protein phosphorylation.

Description A: Chemical synapses allow for amplification of the presynaptic action potential through the release of thousands of transmitter molecules.
Description B: Chemical synapses cannot amplify the presynaptic action potential as they release only a few transmitter molecules.

Description A: Ionotropic receptors are ligand-gated ion channels that rapidly excite or inhibit the postsynaptic cell.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors are not involved in rapid excitation or inhibition of the postsynaptic cell.

Description A: Receptor proteins derived from different gene families mediate direct or indirect gating of ion channels.
Description B: Receptor proteins derived from the same gene family mediate all ion channel gating.

Description A: John Langley postulated that skeletal muscle sensitivity to curare and nicotine was due to a 'receptive molecule'.
Description B: John Langley postulated that skeletal muscle sensitivity to curare and nicotine was due to muscle fibers.

Description A: Generalized onset seizures have distinctive electroencephalogram (EEG) and single-neuron patterns.
Description B: Generalized onset seizures lack distinctive electroencephalogram (EEG) and single-neuron patterns.

Description A: A typical absence seizure shows sudden onset of synchronous spikes at a frequency of 3 per second lasting approximately 14 seconds.
Description B: A typical absence seizure shows sudden onset of synchronous spikes at a frequency of 5 per second lasting approximately 14 seconds.

Description A: An absence seizure clinically manifests as a staring spell with occasional eye blinks.
Description B: An absence seizure clinically manifests as intense muscle contractions with occasional eye blinks.

Description A: Thalamocortical connections are thought to be essential for the generation of generalized onset seizures.
Description B: Thalamocortical connections are irrelevant for the generation of generalized onset seizures.

Description A: GABAergic inhibitory interneurons inhibit the thalamic relay cells.
Description B: GABAergic inhibitory interneurons excite the thalamic relay cells.

Description A: Mutations in P/Q-type calcium channels have produced several mouse models of generalized epilepsy.
Description B: Mutations in P/Q-type sodium channels have produced several mouse models of generalized epilepsy.

Description A: The typical patient with mesial temporal epilepsy has unilateral disease leading to shrinkage of the hippocampus on one side.
Description B: The typical patient with mesial temporal epilepsy has bilateral disease leading to shrinkage of the hippocampus on both sides.

Description A: Functional neuroimaging showcases changes in cerebral metabolism and blood flow during seizures.
Description B: Functional neuroimaging showcases changes in cerebral structure and mass during seizures.

Description A: During a focal onset seizure, there is approximately a three-fold increase in glucose and oxygen utilization.
Description B: During a focal onset seizure, there is approximately a three-fold decrease in glucose and oxygen utilization.

Description A: EEGs of mice with elevated T-type Ca2+ channels show a paroxysmal spike-wave discharge.
Description B: EEGs of mice with elevated T-type Na+ channels show a paroxysmal spike-wave discharge.

Description A: PET scans using nonhydrolyzable glucose analogs are helpful in identifying seizure foci in patients with normal MRI scans.
Description B: PET scans using nonhydrolyzable protein analogs are helpful in identifying seizure foci in patients with normal MRI scans.

Description A: Injection of radioisotopes and SPECT imaging at the time of a seizure reveal a pattern of hypermetabolism.
Description B: Injection of radioisotopes and SPECT imaging at the time of a seizure reveal a pattern of hypometabolism.

Description A: MRI allows noninvasive, quantitative assessment of the hippocampus size in epilepsy patients.
Description B: MRI allows invasive, quantitative assessment of the hippocampus size in epilepsy patients.

Description A: Functional neuroimaging takes advantage of changes in cerebral metabolism during the ictal and interictal periods.
Description B: Functional neuroimaging takes advantage of changes in cerebral morphology during the ictal and interictal periods.

Description A: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is used to map seizure foci biased toward neurons adjacent to the skull.
Description B: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is used to map seizure foci unbiased toward neurons deep within the skull.

Description A: Muscles perform positive work when they shorten and negative work when they lengthen.
Description B: Muscles perform positive work when they lengthen and negative work when they shorten.

Description A: The force exerted by the muscle during the shortening contraction is greater than the peak forces measured during isotonic loading.
Description B: The force exerted by the muscle during the shortening contraction is less than the peak forces measured during isotonic loading.

Description A: Coactivation of opposing muscles increases the energetic cost of performing a task.
Description B: Coactivation of opposing muscles decreases the energetic cost of performing a task.

Description A: Limb muscles in healthy young adults are active 10% to 20% of the time during waking hours.
Description B: Limb muscles in healthy young adults are active 80% to 90% of the time during waking hours.

Description A: The rate at which motor units are recruited during a voluntary contraction increases with contraction speed.
Description B: The rate at which motor units are recruited during a voluntary contraction decreases with contraction speed.

Description A: Sarcomere force during lengthening contractions is augmented by a Ca2+-mediated increase in titin stiffness.
Description B: Sarcomere force during lengthening contractions is reduced by a Ca2+-mediated increase in titin stiffness.

Description A: Negative velocity reflects a lengthening contraction in a muscle.
Description B: Negative velocity reflects a shortening contraction in a muscle.

Description A: The capacity of muscle to do positive work establishes performance capabilities like the maximal height that can be jumped.
Description B: The capacity of muscle to do positive work limits performance capabilities like the maximal height that can be jumped.

Description A: The force exerted by a muscle depends in part on the number and properties of the motor units that are activated.
Description B: The force exerted by a muscle depends irrespective of the number and properties of the motor units that are activated.

Description A: Unsteady support surfaces usually require joint stiffening through concurrent activation of opposing muscles.
Description B: Unsteady support surfaces usually require joint relaxation through concurrent activation of opposing muscles.

Description A: The nervous system coordinates multiple muscles to create a mechanical link for movement.
Description B: The nervous system coordinates multiple muscles to disconnect mechanical links for movement.

Description A: The sarcomere is the smallest element of muscle that includes a complete set of contractile proteins.
Description B: The sarcomere is the largest element of muscle that includes a complete set of contractile proteins.

Description A: Most of the force generated by activated sarcomeres is transmitted laterally through non-contractile proteins.
Description B: Most of the force generated by activated sarcomeres is transmitted vertically through non-contractile proteins.

Description A: Strain energy stored in the elastic elements of muscle and tendon can be released during the shortening phase.
Description B: Strain energy stored in the elastic elements of muscle and tendon is absorbed during the shortening phase.

Description A: Motor units tend to be activated in a stereotypical order highly correlated with motor neuron size.
Description B: Motor units tend to be activated randomly, with no correlation to motor neuron size.

Description A: The large end bulbs form synapses on bushy cells; smaller boutons contact stellate and octopus cells.
Description B: The large end bulbs form synapses on stellate cells; smaller boutons contact bushy and octopus cells.

Description A: In the dorsal cochlear nucleus, the cell bodies of fusiform and granule cells are intermixed between the outermost molecular layer and the deep layer.
Description B: In the dorsal cochlear nucleus, the cell bodies of bushy and stellate cells are intermixed between the outermost molecular layer and the deep layer.

Description A: Repetitive firing in bushy and octopus cells is prevented by low-voltage-activated conductances.
Description B: Repetitive firing in stellate and fusiform cells is prevented by low-voltage-activated conductances.

Description A: The rise and fall of voltage changes in stellate and fusiform cells is slower than in bushy and octopus cells.
Description B: The rise and fall of voltage changes in bushy and octopus cells is slower than in stellate and fusiform cells.

Description A: The brief synaptic potentials in bushy and octopus cells require larger synaptic currents but encode the timing of auditory nerve inputs more faithfully.
