Description B: The brief synaptic potentials in bushy cells require smaller synaptic currents but encode the timing of auditory nerve inputs less faithfully.

Description A: The neurons of the medial superior olive form a representation of interaural phase along the rostrocaudal and lateromedial dimensions.
Description B: The neurons of the medial superior olive form a representation of interaural phase along the dorsoventral and anterior-posterior dimensions.

Description A: Each bushy, stellate, and fusiform cell receives input from a few auditory nerve fibers and is sharply tuned.
Description B: Each bushy, stellate, and octopus cell receives input from many auditory nerve fibers and is broadly tuned.

Description A: The large axons of globular bushy cells and the large calyceal terminals of Held allow for short and consistently timed delays.
Description B: The small axons of globular bushy cells and the small calyceal terminals of Held allow for long and inconsistently timed delays.

Description A: The medial superior olive receives coincident excitatory inputs from the two ears only when sounds come from the contralateral half of space.
Description B: The medial superior olive receives coincident excitatory inputs from the two ears when sounds come from the ipsilateral half of space.

Description A: Inhibition superimposed on these excitatory inputs plays a significant role in sharpening the map of interaural phase.
Description B: Excitation superimposed on these inhibitory inputs plays a significant role in sharpening the map of interaural intensity.

Description A: The brain receives information about interaural time differences with every cycle of an ongoing sound.
Description B: The brain receives information about interaural time differences only at the beginning and end of a sound.

Description A: Principal cells of the medial superior olive also receive sharply timed inhibition driven by sounds from both the ipsilateral and contralateral sides.
Description B: Principal cells of the medial superior olive receive sharply timed excitation driven by sounds only from the ipsilateral side.

Description A: The lateral superior olive detects interaural intensity differences.
Description B: The lateral superior olive detects interaural frequency differences.

Description A: The pathway that brings ipsilateral inhibition through the lateral nucleus of the trapezoid body is less well understood.
Description B: The pathway that brings contralateral excitation through the lateral nucleus of the trapezoid body is well understood.

Description A: Each medial superior olive forms a map of the location of sound sources in the contralateral hemifield.
Description B: Each medial superior olive forms a map of the location of sound sources in the ipsilateral hemifield.

Description A: The maturation of the field of psychiatric genetics and genomics over the past decade has revealed the frailty of testing pre-specified candidate genes.
Description B: The maturation of the field of psychiatric genetics and genomics over the past year has confirmed the robustness of testing pre-specified candidate genes.

Description A: A striking finding from recent advances in the genetics of human behavior has been the overlap of genetic risks for syndromes with distinct symptoms.
Description B: A striking finding from recent advances in the genetics of human behavior has been the distinct separation of genetic risks for syndromes with similar symptoms.

Description A: Findings across common psychiatric disorders point to extremely high rates of genetic heterogeneity.
Description B: Findings across common psychiatric disorders suggest uniform genetic profiles with low rates of genetic heterogeneity.

Description A: Copy number variations are observed in some neurological and psychiatric disorders.
Description B: Copy number variations are not observed in any neurological and psychiatric disorders.

Description A: Conservation of genes can be detected by measuring the similarity of the sequences at the base or amino acid level.
Description B: Conservation of genes can only be detected in fossil records not in the sequence similarity at the base or amino acid level.

Description A: Eukaryotes have cells with a complex internal structure, including a nucleus.
Description B: Eukaryotes are single-celled organisms with a simple internal structure that lacks a nucleus.

Description A: Introns are spliced from the RNA before the product is made.
Description B: Introns are crucial for protein synthesis and are integrated into the final product.

Description A: Recombination has the effect of making the chromosomes of the offspring distinct from those of the parents.
Description B: Recombination has no effect on the distinctness of chromosomes between offspring and parents.

Description A: Spliced RNAs destined to become templates for protein synthesis are known as mRNAs.
Description B: Spliced RNAs destined to become templates for cellular waste products are known as mRNAs.

Description A: Mutation is an alteration in a genome compared to some reference state.
Description B: Mutation refers accurately to a perfect replication of a genome with no alterations.

Description A: Animals, plants, and fungi are all eukaryotes.
Description B: Animals, plants, and fungi are all prokaryotes.

Description A: Centromere is where sister chromatids are joined.
Description B: Centromere is the region where different chromosomes are completely separated.

Description A: Proteins are not synthesized directly from genomic DNA; instead, an RNA template is constructed.
Description B: Proteins are synthesized directly from genomic DNA without any intermediate RNA template.

Description A: A deletion or duplication of a limited genetic region results in copy number variation.
Description B: A deletion or duplication of a limited genetic region occurs without any resulting copy number variation.

Description A: Conservation can be detected by measuring the similarity of two sequences at the base or amino acid level.
Description B: Conservation cannot be detected by sequence similarity measurement at the base or amino acid level.

Description A: The thalamus relays sensory information from the periphery to the cerebral cortex.
Description B: The thalamus relays sensory information from the cerebral cortex to the periphery.

Description A: The basal ganglia comprise the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.
Description B: The basal ganglia comprise the thalamus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Description A: The corpus callosum contains a large bundle of axons connecting the two hemispheres.
Description B: The cingulate gyrus contains a large bundle of axons connecting the two hemispheres.

Description A: The primary somatosensory cortex occupies the gyrus immediately caudal to the central sulcus.
Description B: The primary motor cortex occupies the gyrus immediately caudal to the central sulcus.

Description A: The primary visual cortex occupies the calcarine sulcus.
Description B: The primary visual cortex occupies the central sulcus.

Description A: The amygdala and hippocampus are regions of the cerebral cortex buried within the temporal lobe.
Description B: The amygdala and thalamus are regions of the cerebral cortex buried within the temporal lobe.

Description A: The ventricles contain and produce the cerebrospinal fluid.
Description B: The ventricles fill and circulate blood throughout the brain.

Description A: The central sulcus separates the frontal and parietal lobes.
Description B: The central sulcus separates the frontal and occipital lobes.

Description A: The lateral sulcus separates the frontal from the temporal lobes.
Description B: The lateral sulcus separates the frontal from the parietal lobes.

Description A: The primary motor cortex occupies the gyrus immediately rostral to the central sulcus.
Description B: The primary somatosensory cortex occupies the gyrus immediately rostral to the central sulcus.

Description A: The corpus callosum contains a large bundle of axons connecting the two hemispheres.
Description B: The hypothalamus contains a large bundle of axons connecting the two hemispheres.

Description A: The four major lobes of the cerebrum are named for the parts of the cranium that cover them.
Description B: The four major lobes of the cerebrum are named for the nerves that innervate them.

Description A: Figure 1–5 shows the main cortical and subcortical regions can be imaged in the brain of a living individual.
Description B: Figure 1–5 shows the main cortical and subcortical regions of a fossilized brain.

Description A: The midbrain is part of the brain stem.
Description B: The cerebellum is part of the brain stem.

Description A: The spinal cord is the most caudal region of the central nervous system.
Description B: The cerebrum is the most caudal region of the central nervous system.

Description A: Most corticospinal tract axons originating in one hemisphere cross to the other side of the midline at the pyramid in the caudal medulla.
Description B: Most corticospinal tract axons originating in one hemisphere remain on the same side at the pyramid in the caudal medulla.

Description A: The pyramidal tract originates in cortical layer V in a number of precentral and parietal areas.
Description B: The pyramidal tract originates in cortical layer IV in a number of precentral and parietal areas.

Description A: The pre-SMA and pre-PMd do not send axons directly to the spinal cord.
Description B: The pre-SMA and pre-PMd directly send axons to the spinal cord.

Description A: Corticomotoneuronal cells are M1 neurons with direct monosynaptic projections to spinal motor neurons.
Description B: Corticomotoneuronal cells are M1 neurons with multisynaptic projections to spinal motor neurons.

Description A: Voluntary arm movements require coordination with neural circuits responsible for the control of posture and balance.
Description B: Voluntary arm movements do not require coordination with neural circuits responsible for the control of posture and balance.

Description A: In instructed-delay motor tasks, a delayed stimulus signals when to make the movement.
Description B: In instructed-delay motor tasks, the movement must be made immediately when the target is visible.

Description A: The reticulospinal tract projects to the spinal cord via descending projections from cortical motor areas.
Description B: The reticulospinal tract projects directly to muscles via descending projections from sensory areas.

Description A: Areas PF and PFG correspond roughly to Brodmann’s area 7b.
Description B: Areas PF and PFG correspond roughly to Brodmann’s area 6a.

Description A: A small portion of corticospinal tract axons do not decussate and form the ventral corticospinal tract.
Description B: All corticospinal tract axons decussate and none form the ventral corticospinal tract.

Description A: In primates, many corticospinal axons from M1 terminate directly on spinal alpha motor neurons.
Description B: In primates, no corticospinal axons from M1 terminate directly on spinal alpha motor neurons.

Description A: Most or all planning stages in reaction-time tasks are accomplished in less than 300 ms.
Description B: Planning stages in reaction-time tasks usually take longer than 500 ms.

Description A: Neurons in movement-related cortical areas signal information about an intended motor act during an instructed-delay period.
Description B: Neurons in movement-related cortical areas do not signal information about an intended motor act during an instructed-delay period.

Description A: The lateral corticospinal tract is formed by axons that cross at the pyramid in the caudal medulla.
Description B: The lateral corticospinal tract is formed by axons that do not cross at the pyramid in the caudal medulla.

Description A: In monkeys, corticospinal axons from premotor cortical areas terminate on interneurons in the spinal intermediate zone.
Description B: In monkeys, corticospinal axons from premotor cortical areas terminate directly on spinal motor neurons.

Description A: Corticospinal fibers originate in both motor and premotor cortex for movements of the leg, trunk, and other somatotopic parts.
Description B: Corticospinal fibers originate only in the primary motor cortex for movements of the leg and trunk.

Description A: A presynaptic dense body or synaptic ribbon lies in the cytoplasm adjacent to the release site.
Description B: A presynaptic dense body or synaptic ribbon lies adjacent to the postsynaptic density.

Description A: Outer hair cells receive inputs from neurons in the brainstem in the form of large boutons on their basolateral surfaces.
Description B: Outer hair cells receive inputs solely from the cochlear nerve in the form of large boutons on their basolateral surfaces.

Description A: Approximately 30,000 ganglion cells innervate the hair cells of each inner ear.
Description B: Approximately 3,000 ganglion cells innervate the hair cells of each inner ear.

Description A: Nonmammalian ears are limited in response to frequencies lower than about 12 to 14 kHz.
Description B: Nonmammalian ears are limited in response to frequencies higher than about 12 to 14 kHz.

Description A: A Hopf bifurcation must be driven by an active process, whereby the system mobilizes internal resources of energy to power spontaneous movements.
Description B: A Hopf bifurcation can occur passively without mobilizing internal resources of energy.

Description A: Birds evolved two groups of sensory hair cells that have a division of labor similar to that of mammalian inner and outer hair cells.
Description B: Birds evolved a single group of sensory hair cells that perform the same function as mammalian hair cells.

Description A: Sound amplification associated with active hair-bundle motility was already present in the very first hair cells that evolved.
Description B: Sound amplification associated with active hair-bundle motility developed only in mammals.

Description A: Inner hair cells must be able to release neurotransmitter reliably in response to a threshold receptor potential of only 100 μV or so.
Description B: Inner hair cells require a receptor potential of at least 200 μV to release neurotransmitter reliably.

Description A: Active process turns down in outer hair cells by hyperpolarization.
Description B: Active process is enhanced in outer hair cells by hyperpolarization.

Description A: The characteristic frequency fC corresponds to the frequency of spontaneous oscillation at the critical point.
Description B: The characteristic frequency fC is irrelevant to the spontaneous oscillation frequency at the critical point.

Description A: The presynaptic ribbon is surrounded by clear synaptic vesicles that are attached by tenuous filaments.
Description B: The presynaptic ribbon is surrounded by dense synaptic vesicles that are attached by rigid filaments.

Description A: Electrical resonance contributes to frequency tuning in the ears of many nonmammalian species.
Description B: Electrical resonance does not contribute to frequency tuning in the ears of nonmammalian species.

Description A: Alternate splicing of mRNA encoding cochlear K+ channels tunes the characteristic frequency of resonance along the tonotopic axis.
Description B: Alternate splicing of mRNA encoding cochlear Na+ channels tunes the characteristic frequency of resonance along the tonotopic axis.

Description A: The upper frequency limit of hearing is generally higher in mammals.
Description B: The upper frequency limit of hearing is generally lower in mammals.

Description A: Amphibians, reptiles, and birds acquired their good hearing systems largely independently.
Description B: Amphibians, reptiles, and birds acquired their good hearing systems collectively from a common ancestor.

Description A: The voltage clamp permits the experimenter to 'clamp' the membrane potential at predetermined levels, preventing changes in membrane current from influencing the membrane potential.
Description B: The voltage clamp permits the experimenter to 'clamp' the membrane potential to variable levels, allowing changes in membrane current to influence the membrane potential.

Description A: Depolarization opens voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels, initiating movement of Na+ and K+ across the membrane.
Description B: Depolarization closes voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels, preventing movement of Na+ and K+ across the membrane.

Description A: The voltage clamp is able to pass the correct amount of current across the cell membrane to rapidly step the membrane to a constant predetermined potential.
Description B: The voltage clamp is unable to pass the correct amount of current across the cell membrane to rapidly step the membrane to a constant predetermined potential.

Description A: Today, most voltage-clamp experiments use a patch-clamp amplifier.
Description B: Today, most voltage-clamp experiments use a patch-pipette amplifier.

Description A: Hodgkin and Huxley explained that the Na+ and K+ currents vary as a graded function of the membrane potential.
Description B: Hodgkin and Huxley explained that the Na+ and K+ currents are constant irrespective of the membrane potential.

Description A: Both Na+ and K+ currents initially increase in amplitude as the membrane is made more positive.
Description B: Both Na+ and K+ currents initially decrease in amplitude as the membrane is made more positive.

Description A: The voltage on the output of the amplifier (Vo) is proportional to current flowing through the electrode and through the membrane.
Description B: The voltage on the output of the amplifier (Vo) is inversely proportional to current flowing through the electrode and through the membrane.

Description A: Whole-cell patch clamp recording allows voltage-clamp measurements in small cell bodies of neurons.
Description B: Whole-cell patch clamp recording prevents voltage-clamp measurements in small cell bodies of neurons.

Description A: When the membrane potential is +55 mV, the Na+ current is zero.
Description B: When the membrane potential is +55 mV, the Na+ current is maximum.

Description A: As the voltage becomes more and more positive, the Na+ current eventually declines in amplitude.
Description B: As the voltage becomes more and more positive, the Na+ current continues to increase in amplitude.

Description A: The negative feedback system reduces any difference between the command signal and the output signal.
Description B: The negative feedback system increases any difference between the command signal and the output signal.

Description A: IK can be measured when the Na+ channels are blocked by tetrodotoxin.
Description B: IK can be measured when the Na+ channels are opened by tetrodotoxin.

Description A: As the membrane voltage is made more positive, the outward K+ current becomes larger.
Description B: As the membrane voltage is made more positive, the outward K+ current becomes smaller.

Description A: The patch-clamp technique allows the functional properties of single ion channels to be analyzed.
Description B: The patch-clamp technique prevents the functional properties of single ion channels from being analyzed.

Description A: The feedback amplifier subtracts the membrane potential from the command potential and amplifies any difference between these two signals.
Description B: The feedback amplifier adds the membrane potential to the command potential and amplifies any similarity between these two signals.

Description A: The Basal Ganglia Network consists of three principal input nuclei, two main output nuclei, and one intrinsic nucleus.
Description B: The Basal Ganglia Network consists of three principal output nuclei, two main input nuclei, and one intrinsic nucleus.

Description A: Parkinson Disease can be viewed in part as a failure to select sensorimotor options.
Description B: Parkinson Disease can be viewed in part as a failure to select cognitive options.

Description A: Huntington Disease may reflect a functional imbalance between the direct and indirect pathways.
Description B: Huntington Disease may reflect a balanced function between the direct and indirect pathways.

Description A: The Substantia Nigra Pars Reticulata and the Internal Globus Pallidus are the two principal output nuclei of the Basal Ganglia.
Description B: The Substantia Nigra Pars Reticulata and the Internal Globus Pallidus are the two principal input nuclei of the Basal Ganglia.

Description A: All vertebrates face the challenge of choosing one behavior from several competing options.
Description B: All vertebrates face the challenge of choosing one cognition from several competing options.

Description A: The Basal Ganglia play a role in movement because diseases such as Parkinson and Huntington disease are associated with motor disturbances.
Description B: The Basal Ganglia play a role in movement because diseases such as Parkinson and Huntington disease are primarily cognitive disturbances.

Description A: The Basal Ganglia connections with external structures are characterized by reentrant loops.
Description B: The Basal Ganglia connections with external structures are characterized by unidirectional pathways.

Description A: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and Tourette Syndrome may be characterized by intrusions of nonselected options.
Description B: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and Tourette Syndrome may be characterized by suppression of nonselected options.

Description A: The Striatum, Subthalamic Nucleus, and Substantia Nigra Pars Compacta are the three principal input nuclei of the Basal Ganglia.
Description B: The Striatum, Subthalamic Nucleus, and Internal Globus Pallidus are the three principal input nuclei of the Basal Ganglia.

Description A: Diseases of the Basal Ganglia may involve disorders of selection.
Description B: Diseases of the Basal Ganglia may involve enhancements of selection processes.

Description A: Basal Ganglia output neurons project to external structures that provide input.
Description B: Basal Ganglia output neurons project exclusively within the Basal Ganglia.

Description A: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder reflects the presence of pathologically dominant options.
Description B: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder reflects the suppression of pathologically dominant options.

Description A: Reinforcement learning is an inherent property of the Basal Ganglia selection architecture.
Description B: Reinforcement learning is an external influence on the Basal Ganglia selection architecture.

Description A: Schizophrenia may be associated with a general failure to suppress nonselected options.
Description B: Schizophrenia may be associated with an enhanced ability to suppress nonselected options.

Description A: The internal circuitry of the Basal Ganglia regulates how the components interact.
Description B: The internal circuitry of the Basal Ganglia is irrelevant to how the components interact.

Description A: The cochlea is approximately 9 mm across and is embedded within the temporal bone.
Description B: The cochlea is approximately 20 mm across and is embedded within the temporal bone.

Description A: The auricle acts as a reflector to capture sound efficiently and focus it into the external auditory meatus.
Description B: The auricle acts as an absorber to capture sound efficiently and focus it into the external auditory meatus.

Description A: The auditory ossicles consist of the malleus, incus, and stapes.
Description B: The auditory ossicles consist of the malleus, incus, and cochlea.

Description A: Each of the paired cochleae contains approximately 16,000 hair cells.
Description B: Each of the paired cochleae contains approximately 1,600 hair cells.

Description A: The scala vestibuli is closed by the oval window.
Description B: The scala vestibuli is closed by the round window.

Description A: The external ear is not uniformly effective at capturing sound from all directions.
Description B: The external ear is uniformly effective at capturing sound from all directions.

Description A: The cochlea is a coiled structure of progressively diminishing diameter.
Description B: The cochlea is a straight structure of progressively increasing diameter.

Description A: The basilar membrane separates the cochlear partition from the scala tympani.
Description B: The basilar membrane separates the cochlear partition from the scala vestibuli.

Description A: Hair cells can measure motions of atomic dimensions and transduce stimuli ranging from static inputs to those at frequencies of tens of kilohertz.
Description B: Hair cells can measure motions of atomic dimensions and transduce stimuli ranging from static inputs to those at frequencies of hundreds of kilohertz.

Description A: The malleus is attached to the tympanic membrane.
Description B: The incus is attached to the tympanic membrane.

Description A: The scala tympani has a basal aperture, the round window.
Description B: The scala tympani has a basal aperture, the oval window.

Description A: The auricle has a unique topography that affects sound reflections at different frequencies.
Description B: The auricle has a uniform topography that does not affect sound reflections at different frequencies.

Description A: The middle ear is an air-filled pouch connected to the pharynx by the Eustachian tube.
Description B: The middle ear is a liquid-filled pouch connected to the pharynx by the Eustachian tube.

Description A: The stapes is originally a component of the gill support of ancient fish.
Description B: The incus is originally a component of the gill support of ancient fish.

Description A: The organ of Corti is the site of mechanoelectrical transduction in the cochlea.
Description B: The basilar membrane is the site of mechanoelectrical transduction in the cochlea.

Description A: The outer layer of the tympanum is approximately 9 mm in diameter and 50 μm in thickness.
Description B: The outer layer of the tympanum is approximately 15 mm in diameter and 100 μm in thickness.

Description A: The resting potential of a cell is determined by the proportions of different types of ion channels that are open, together with the value of their equilibrium potentials.
Description B: The resting potential of a cell is determined solely by the ion concentrations inside the cell, independent of the equilibrium potentials.

Description A: In a resting cell in which only K+ channels are present, K+ ions are in equilibrium and Vm = EK.
Description B: In a resting cell in which only K+ channels are present, Na+ ions are in equilibrium and Vm = ENa.

Description A: The Na+-K+ pump is inhibited by ouabain or digitalis plant alkaloids, an action important in the treatment of heart failure.
Description B: The Na+-K+ pump is activated by ouabain or digitalis plant alkaloids, an action important in the treatment of heart failure.

Description A: Mutations in ATP1A2 result in familial hemiplegic migraine.
Description B: Mutations in ATP1A2 result in rapid-onset dystonia parkinsonism.

Description A: The Na+-Ca2+ exchanger uses the potential energy of the electrochemical gradient of Na+ to transport Ca2+ out of a cell.
Description B: The Na+-Ca2+ exchanger uses the potential energy of the electrochemical gradient of Ca2+ to transport Na+ out of a cell.

Description A: Cl− is transported into the cell by the Na+-K+-Cl− cotransporter and out of the cell by the K+-Cl− cotransporter.
Description B: Cl− is transported into the cell by the K+-Cl− cotransporter and out of the cell by the Na+-K+-Cl− cotransporter.

Description A: The Na+-Ca2+ exchanger is termed an antiporter because Na+ and Ca2+ are transported in opposite directions.
Description B: The Na+-Ca2+ exchanger is termed a symporter because Na+ and Ca2+ are transported in the same direction.

Description A: Pumps and transporters use the energy of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) hydrolysis to transport ions against their concentration gradient.
Description B: Pumps and transporters use passive transport to move ions along their concentration gradient.

Description A: Calcium pumps transport two Ca2+ ions for each ATP molecule that is hydrolyzed.
Description B: Calcium pumps transport one Ca2+ ion for each ATP molecule that is hydrolyzed.

Description A: As neurons develop, they begin to express the K+-Cl− cotransporter.
Description B: As neurons develop, they stop expressing any Cl− cotransporter.

Description A: In early neuronal development, cells tend to express primarily the Na+-K+-Cl− cotransporter.
Description B: In early neuronal development, cells express the K+-Cl− cotransporter exclusively.

Description A: In most mature neurons, GABA typically hyperpolarizes the membrane and acts as an inhibitory neurotransmitter.
Description B: In most mature neurons, GABA typically depolarizes the membrane and acts as an excitatory neurotransmitter.

Description A: The increase in depolarization causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, accelerating depolarization further.
Description B: The increase in depolarization causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to close, halting depolarization.

Description A: Chloride transporters use the gradients of other ions as a source of energy.
Description B: Chloride transporters use direct energy from light photons to transport ions.

Description A: The action potential involves a rapid influx of Na+ and subsequent cellular depolarization.
Description B: The action potential involves a rapid efflux of Na+ and subsequent cellular repolarization.

Description A: Intracortically recorded signals from motor cortex were decoded to restore movement via FES in a person with upper spinal cord injury.
Description B: Intracortically recorded signals from sensory cortex were decoded to restore movement via FES in a person with upper spinal cord injury.

Description A: Subjects with paralysis can use sensory feedback delivered by cortical stimulation during BMI control.
Description B: Subjects without paralysis can use sensory feedback delivered by cortical stimulation during BMI control.

Description A: Electrical microstimulation in the primary somatosensory cortex can be used by nonhuman primates to control a cursor on a moment-by-moment basis without vision.
Description B: Electrical microstimulation in the primary motor cortex can be used by nonhuman primates to control a cursor on a moment-by-moment basis without vision.

Description A: BMI cursor control is more accurate when the arm is passively moved together with the BMI cursor along the same path, rather than along a different path.
Description B: BMI cursor control is more accurate when the arm is moved along a different path than the BMI cursor path.

Description A: BMI-directed movements relying solely on visual feedback are slower and less accurate than normal arm movements.
Description B: BMI-directed movements relying solely on visual feedback are faster and more accurate than normal arm movements.

Description A: BMIs can simplify the brain's input and output interface with the outside world while preserving the complexities of brain processing.
Description B: BMIs complicate the brain's input and output interface with the outside world and alter the complexities of brain processing.

Description A: Cochlear implants provide insight into how the brain processes sounds and speech.
Description B: Cochlear implants provide insight into how the brain processes short-term memory.

Description A: Prosthetic arms controlled by BMI can handle hand configurations with ten degrees of freedom.
Description B: Prosthetic arms controlled by BMI are limited to two degrees of freedom in hand configurations.

Description A: Neural activity recorded in the motor cortex is decoded into command signals that control the stimulation of various muscles.
Description B: Neural activity recorded in the somatosensory cortex is decoded into command signals that control the stimulation of various muscles.

Description A: Electrical microstimulation can also be used to provide somatosensory feedback during BMI control.
Description B: Chemical microstimulation can also be used to provide somatosensory feedback during BMI control.

Description A: Surrogate somatosensory information was delivered via electrical microstimulation to a person with compromised sensory afferents.
Description B: Surrogate somatosensory information was delivered via auditory stimulation to a person with compromised sensory afferents.

Description A: One key benefit of BMIs for basic science is that they simplify the brain's input and output interface without simplifying brain complexities.
Description B: One key benefit of BMIs for basic science is that they complicate the brain's input and output interface and simplify brain complexities.

Description A: Nonhuman primates learned to use differences in stimulation feedback to distinguish rewarded targets.
Description B: Nonhuman primates learned to use differences in stimulation feedback to distinguish sound patterns.

Description A: The BMI mapping defines which population activity patterns will allow the subject to successfully move the BMI-directed cursor to visual targets.
Description B: The BMI mapping defines which population activity patterns will allow the subject to successfully communicate through speech.

Description A: Studies using BMI can help elucidate neural mechanisms underlying sensorimotor control.
Description B: Studies using BMI primarily focus on elucidating neural mechanisms underlying emotional control.

Description A: Locomotor networks in the spinal cord, known as central pattern generators (CPGs), generate precise timing and patterning of locomotion.
Description B: Locomotor networks in the spinal cord, known as central pattern generators (CPGs), generate random timing and patterning of locomotion.

Description A: Cortical activity from the motor cortex is involved in the planning and execution of visually guided locomotion.
Description B: Cortical activity from the auditory cortex is involved in the planning and execution of visually guided locomotion.

Description A: Feedback information from cutaneous and proprioceptive inputs helps regulate stride length and propulsion force during locomotion.
Description B: Feedback information from cutaneous and proprioceptive inputs helps regulate sound perception and auditory signals during locomotion.

Description A: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) projects to neurons in the medial reticular formation (MRF), which in turn project to the spinal cord to initiate locomotion.
Description B: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) projects directly to the spinal cord to initiate locomotion without involving the medial reticular formation (MRF).

Description A: The cerebellum contributes to the coordination of locomotor activity and the selection of locomotor patterns.
Description B: The cerebellum contributes exclusively to the initiation of locomotion and has no role in coordination.

Description A: Studies of locomotion often involve chronic electromyographic (EMG) recordings of limb muscles combined with video recordings of movement.
Description B: Studies of locomotion often involve chronic electromyographic (EMG) recordings of cerebral activity combined with video recordings of movement.

Description A: Genetic techniques are used to modify afferent input to the spinal cord in locomotion studies, enabling precise experimental control.
Description B: Genetic techniques are used exclusively to modify brain stem activity, with no effect on spinal cord afferent input in locomotion studies.

Description A: Locomotion requires coordinated activation of muscle groups within a rhythmic cycle.
Description B: Locomotion requires uncoordinated activation of muscle groups within a rhythmic cycle.

Description A: Acute spinal preparations use drugs to chemically induce locomotion by stimulating spinal locomotor circuits.
Description B: Acute spinal preparations use electrical stimulation of cerebral neurons to chemically induce locomotion.

Description A: Intact preparations are used to study locomotion during walking over ground or on a motorized treadmill.
Description B: Intact preparations are used exclusively to study swimming locomotion and not over-ground locomotion.

Description A: Experiments using models like lamprey and tadpole have provided insights into neuronal circuits for swimming locomotion.
Description B: Experiments using models like lamprey and tadpole have provided insights exclusively into over-ground locomotion.

Description A: Decerebrate preparations disconnect higher brain centers from locomotor-initiating regions in the brain stem and spinal cord.
Description B: Decerebrate preparations enhance synchronization between higher brain centers and spinal locomotor circuits.

Description A: Chronic spinal preparations focus on improving locomotor capability after spinal cord injury using drug treatments and training.
Description B: Chronic spinal preparations focus on reducing locomotor capability after spinal cord injury using drug treatments and training.

Description A: Neurons involved in locomotion are identified by their anatomical location, projection pattern, transmitter content, and molecular markers.
Description B: Neurons involved in locomotion are identified exclusively by their electrical activity and not by molecular markers.

Description A: Over-ground locomotion involves intricate interlimb coupling maintained by descending fibers from brain stem nuclei.
Description B: Over-ground locomotion is independent of descending fibers from brain stem nuclei.

Description A: Infants prefer listening to infant-directed speech over adult-directed speech.
Description B: Infants prefer listening to adult-directed speech over infant-directed speech.

Description A: In bilingual children, early advances in the two languages differ depending on the language spoken in parentese.
Description B: In bilingual children, early advances in both languages are identical regardless of the language spoken in parentese.

Description A: The ability to learn a new language generally declines every 2 years after the age of 7.
Description B: The ability to learn a new language improves every 2 years after the age of 7.

Description A: Bilingual infants exhibit greater activation in the prefrontal cortex compared to monolingual infants.
Description B: Monolingual infants exhibit greater activation in the prefrontal cortex compared to bilingual infants.

Description A: Exposure to two languages from birth causes children to reach language milestones at the same age as monolingual peers.
Description B: Exposure to two languages from birth causes children to reach language milestones later than monolingual peers.

Description A: In 'late' bilinguals, the second language and native language are processed in spatially separated areas in the left frontal region.
Description B: In 'late' bilinguals, the second language and native language are processed in the same area in the left frontal region.

Description A: The dual-stream model comprises a larger number of cortical areas compared to the Wernicke-Geschwind model.
Description B: The Wernicke-Geschwind model comprises a larger number of cortical areas compared to the dual-stream model.

Description A: The dorsal stream is strongly left hemisphere dominant.
Description B: The dorsal stream is strongly right hemisphere dominant.

Description A: The ventral stream requires transformation of the auditory signal to representations in a mental lexicon.
Description B: The dorsal stream requires transformation of the auditory signal to representations in a mental lexicon.

Description A: Developmental models indicate that brain structures essential to language processing are operational in early infancy.
Description B: Developmental models indicate that brain structures essential to language processing are not operational until later childhood.

Description A: Studies using DTI indicate that the arcuate fasciculus connects language regions by 3 months of age.
Description B: Studies using DTI indicate that the arcuate fasciculus does not connect language regions until after infancy.

Description A: The arcuate fasciculus and the superior longitudinal fasciculus mediate communication along the dorsal stream.
Description B: The inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus and the uncinate fasciculus mediate communication along the dorsal stream.

Description A: Listening to two languages requires multiple shifts in attention to activate one language over another.
Description B: Listening to two languages requires no shifts in attention to activate one language over another.

Description A: Successful bilingual learning depends on the age at which the second language is learned.
Description B: Successful bilingual learning is independent of the age at which the second language is learned.

Description A: Early connections between sensory areas and language processing areas are detectable in newborns.
Description B: Early connections between sensory areas and language processing areas are undetectable in newborns.

Description A: During walking, the Ib inhibitory interneurons are inhibited, and excitatory interneurons that receive input from Ib sensory fibers are facilitated by the command system for walking.
Description B: During walking, the Ib inhibitory interneurons are activated, and excitatory interneurons that receive input from Ib sensory fibers are suppressed by the command system for walking.

Description A: The stretch reflex pathway acts as a negative feedback system to counteract deviations from the set reference length of a muscle.
Description B: The stretch reflex pathway acts as a positive feedback system to amplify deviations from the set reference length of a muscle.

Description A: Groups I and II sensory fibers converge on common populations of interneurons that integrate force and length information to coordinate muscle activity.
Description B: Groups I and II sensory fibers remain in separate pathways and do not converge on common populations of interneurons.

Description A: Alpha and gamma motor neurons are co-activated during voluntary movements in humans.
Description B: Alpha and gamma motor neurons are independently activated during voluntary movements in humans.

Description A: Direct intracellular recordings have provided evidence for convergence of sensory fibers and descending pathways onto common spinal interneurons.
Description B: Direct intracellular recordings have disproved convergence of sensory fibers and descending pathways onto common spinal interneurons.

Description A: The flexion reflex was once thought to be important for flexor muscle contractions during walking, but intrinsic spinal circuits are now known to be the major component for walking control.
Description B: The flexion reflex is now confirmed as the major component for controlling flexor muscle contractions during walking.

Description A: Stretching a muscle increases spindle sensory afferent activity, leading to muscle contraction and then subsequent muscle shortening.
Description B: Stretching a muscle decreases spindle sensory afferent activity, leading to muscle relaxation and subsequent muscle lengthening.

Description A: Excitatory and inhibitory interneurons activated by group II fibers are now believed to converge with those activated by group Ib afferents.
Description B: Excitatory and inhibitory interneurons activated by group II fibers are completely distinct from those activated by group Ib afferents.

Description A: The stretch reflex loop continuously regulates muscle length by acting as a servomechanism.
Description B: The stretch reflex loop sporadically regulates muscle length and does not function as a servomechanism.

Description A: Intrinsic spinal circuits share many of the interneurons involved in flexion reflexes.
Description B: Intrinsic spinal circuits are completely independent from the interneurons involved in flexion reflexes.

Description A: When muscles shorten faster during movement, spindle sensory fibers decrease their firing rate due to reduced tension on intrafusal fibers.
Description B: When muscles shorten faster during movement, spindle sensory fibers increase their firing rate due to increased tension on intrafusal fibers.

Description A: In humans, sensory feedback through reflex pathways directly contributes to muscle activity during voluntary movements.
Description B: In humans, sensory feedback through reflex pathways does not contribute to muscle activity during voluntary movements.

Description A: Microneurography has revealed co-activation of alpha and gamma motor neurons during voluntary movements.
Description B: Microneurography has disproved co-activation of alpha and gamma motor neurons during voluntary movements.

Description A: Descending pathways and sensory feedback converge at spinal neurons to produce coordinated voluntary movements.
Description B: Descending pathways and sensory feedback remain separate and do not interact at spinal neurons during voluntary movements.

Description A: Stretch reflex pathways improve muscle coordination by responding to deviations from the reference length during movement.
Description B: Stretch reflex pathways inhibit muscle coordination by amplifying deviations from the reference length during movement.

Description A: Autism has a very strong heritable component.
Description B: Autism has a negligible heritable component.

Description A: Rare mutations carrying large biological effects play a role in idiopathic autism spectrum disorder.
Description B: Common mutations carrying small biological effects play a role in idiopathic autism spectrum disorder.

Description A: De novo CNVs at chromosome 16p11.2 carry a substantial risk of autism spectrum disorder.
Description B: De novo CNVs at chromosome 16p11.2 carry a negligible risk of autism spectrum disorder.

Description A: Schizophrenia affects about 1% of all young adults.
Description B: Schizophrenia affects about 10% of all young adults.

Description A: GWASs involving nearly 40,000 cases have resulted in the identification of 108 risk loci for schizophrenia.
Description B: GWASs involving nearly 40,000 cases have resulted in the identification of 8 risk loci for schizophrenia.

Description A: High-throughput sequencing methods have been pursued with some success in schizophrenia.
Description B: High-throughput sequencing methods have been unsuccessful in schizophrenia.

Description A: De novo submicroscopic deletions and duplications in chromosomal structure may dramatically increase an individual’s risk for autism spectrum disorder.
Description B: De novo submicroscopic deletions and duplications in chromosomal structure decrease an individual’s risk for autism spectrum disorder.

Description A: Rare CNVs increase the risk for autism spectrum disorder and other developmental disorders.
Description B: Common CNVs increase the risk for autism spectrum disorder and other developmental disorders.

Description A: Complement C4 factor has a strong and definable effect on schizophrenia risk.
Description B: Complement C4 factor has no effect on schizophrenia risk.

Description A: Studies of individuals ascertained by genotype have found a wide variety of associated behavioral phenotypes.
Description B: Studies of individuals ascertained by phenotype have found a narrow range of associated behavioral phenotypes.

Description A: Rare genetic syndromes like fragile X syndrome provide important insights into molecular mechanisms of human behaviors.
Description B: Rare genetic syndromes like fragile X syndrome provide no insights into molecular mechanisms of human behaviors.

Description A: Having a first-degree relative with schizophrenia results in an approximately 10-fold increase in risk.
Description B: Having a first-degree relative with schizophrenia results in a 2-fold increase in risk.

Description A: GWAS studies of major depression have reached sample sizes adequate to confirm statistically significant associated common variants.
Description B: GWAS studies of major depression have not reached adequate sample sizes to confirm statistically significant associated common variants.

Description A: Genes involved in synaptic formation are overrepresented in autism spectrum disorder signatures.
Description B: Genes involved in synaptic inhibition are overrepresented in autism spectrum disorder signatures.

Description A: Autism spectrum disorder may coexist with normal intelligence and typical functioning in other domains.
Description B: Autism spectrum disorder cannot coexist with normal intelligence or typical functioning in other domains.

Description A: Exome sequencing for rare and de novo risk alleles requires much larger cohorts to identify statistically significant risks for schizophrenia.
Description B: Exome sequencing for rare and de novo risk alleles requires smaller cohorts to identify statistically significant risks for schizophrenia.

Description A: The regeneration of severed axons is robust in the peripheral nervous system of mammals.
Description B: The regeneration of severed axons is robust in the central nervous system of mammals.

Description A: Many new ideas for treatment of brain damage are now in clinical trials.
Description B: Few new ideas for treatment of brain damage are now in clinical trials.

Description A: Developmental neuroscience is helping to replace neurons lost to damage or disease.
Description B: Developmental neuroscience is primarily focused on studying disease without contributing to neuron replacement.

Description A: Therapeutic interventions may promote regeneration of injured central neurons.
Description B: Therapeutic interventions have no impact on the regeneration of injured central neurons.

Description A: Components of myelin inhibit neurite outgrowth.
Description B: Components of myelin promote neurite outgrowth.

Description A: Studies of normal development provide an essential foundation for discovering what has gone wrong in disease.
Description B: Studies of normal development have no impact on understanding disease.

Description A: There is increasing evidence that some brain disorders are due to disturbances in the formation of neural circuits early in life.
Description B: There is decreasing evidence linking early neural circuit formation to brain disorders.

Description A: The regeneration of severed axons is poor in the central nervous system of mammals.
Description B: The regeneration of severed axons is excellent in the central nervous system of mammals.

Description A: The focus of the chapter is on augmenting the ability of neurons to recover normal function.
Description B: The focus of the chapter is on preventing neuron function recovery.

Description A: Neurons in the injured brain can die, but new ones can be born.
Description B: Neurons in the injured brain cannot die or be born.

Description A: Environmental factors support the regeneration of injured axons.
Description B: Environmental factors hinder the regeneration of injured axons.

Description A: An intrinsic growth program promotes regeneration.
Description B: An intrinsic growth program hinders regeneration.

Description A: Restoration of function is the aim of regenerative therapies.
Description B: Regenerative therapies aim to eliminate function.

Description A: Injury-induced scarring hinders axonal regeneration.
Description B: Injury-induced scarring enhances axonal regeneration.

Description A: Stimulation of neurogenesis in regions of injury may contribute to restoring function.
Description B: Stimulation of neurogenesis in regions of injury has no effect on restoring function.

Description A: Parkinson disease damages a small population of neurons that use dopamine as a neurotransmitter.
Description B: Parkinson disease damages a small population of neurons that use serotonin as a neurotransmitter.

Description A: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and poliomyelitis strike only motor neurons.
Description B: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and poliomyelitis affect primarily sensory neurons.

Description A: Some diseases affect only the cell body, axon, or receptive elements of a neuron.
Description B: Some diseases affect the entirety of the neuron, including all cell types simultaneously.

Description A: The stretch reflex circuit involves a few hundred sensory neurons and a hundred motor neurons.
Description B: The stretch reflex circuit involves thousands of sensory neurons and hundreds of motor neurons.

Description A: Reflex circuits lead to action immediately after the sensory stimulus.
Description B: Reflex circuits lead to action only after a significant delay following the sensory stimulus.

Description A: The graded firing rates of neurons in the motor cortex affect the latency and type of movement performed.
Description B: The graded firing rates of neurons in the motor cortex do not affect the timing or type of movement performed.

Description A: Neural circuits can be modified by experience with short-term and long-term physiological changes.
Description B: Neural circuits cannot be modified by experience and remain static throughout life.

Description A: Nerve cells are the signaling units of the nervous system using electrical signals within and chemical signals between cells.
Description B: Nerve cells are not involved in signaling in the nervous system and communicate through chemical signals only.

Description A: Glial cells support nerve cells and some provide insulation to speed the propagation of action potentials.
Description B: Glial cells are responsible for nerve signaling and act as primary signaling units.

Description A: The plasticity hypothesis proposed by Ramón y Cajal is central to understanding neural adaptability.
Description B: The plasticity hypothesis was never proven significant to understanding neural adaptability.

Description A: Learning results in behavioral changes that endure for years, while simple reflexes can be modified for a shorter period.
Description B: Learning does not affect behavior long-term and simple reflexes are permanent and unchangeable.

Description A: Functional plasticity at chemical synapses includes short-term and long-term changes.
Description B: Functional plasticity at chemical synapses affects chemical balance only without short-term or long-term changes.

Description A: Diverse molecular expressions explain why certain diseases affect some neurons and not others.
Description B: Diverse molecular expressions have no effect on disease specificity in neurons.

Description A: Chemical synapses are modified during early development and throughout life.
Description B: Chemical synapses are static and remain unchanged throughout life after early development.

Description A: Some invertebrate animals can perform sophisticated behaviors similar to reflexes with fewer neurons than vertebrates.
Description B: Invertebrate animals require more neurons than vertebrates to perform any reflexive behaviors.

Description A: The receptive fields of type 1 receptors in the superficial layers of skin encompass spot-like patches of skin.
Description B: The receptive fields of type 1 receptors in the superficial layers of skin encompass broad regions of skin.

Description A: The distal pad of the index finger has the keenest tactile sensitivity among fingers.
Description B: The distal pad of the little finger has the keenest tactile sensitivity among fingers.

Description A: SA1 fibers are stimulated more vigorously by smaller objects pressing against the skin than larger objects.
Description B: SA1 fibers are stimulated more vigorously by larger objects pressing against the skin than smaller objects.

Description A: Blind individuals use the spatial sensitivity of SA1 and RA1 fibers to perceive Braille patterns.
Description B: Blind individuals use the spatial sensitivity of SA2 and RA2 fibers to perceive Braille patterns.

Description A: The receptive field contour map of slowly adapting type 1 (SA1) fibers resembles that of rapidly adapting type 1 (RA1) fibers.
Description B: The receptive field contour map of slowly adapting type 1 (SA1) fibers resembles that of rapidly adapting type 2 (RA2) fibers.

Description A: Tactile acuity is slightly greater in women than in men due to the smaller papillary ridge diameter in women.
Description B: Tactile acuity is slightly greater in men than in women due to the smaller papillary ridge diameter in men.

Description A: The spatial acuity threshold spacing on the human fingertip is approximately 1.0 mm.
Description B: The spatial acuity threshold spacing on the human fingertip is approximately 3.0 mm.

Description A: Pacinian corpuscles (RA2 fibers) signal skin vibrations evoked by the motion of Braille dots, but not their periodicity.
Description B: Pacinian corpuscles (RA2 fibers) signal the periodicity of Braille dots, but not skin vibrations evoked by their motion.

Description A: SA2 fibers provide information about the shape of large objects grasped with the entire hand.
Description B: RA1 fibers provide information about the shape of large objects grasped with the entire hand.

Description A: The tactile spatial resolution is 50% poorer at the distal pad of the little finger than the index finger.
Description B: The tactile spatial resolution is 50% poorer at the distal pad of the index finger than the little finger.

Description A: SA2 fibers respond more vigorously to skin stretch than to skin indentation.
Description B: SA2 fibers respond more vigorously to skin indentation than to skin stretch.

Description A: Edges typically evoke higher firing rates in SA1 fibers than flat surfaces.
Description B: Flat surfaces typically evoke higher firing rates in SA1 fibers than edges.

Description A: The two-point threshold on the fingers is approximately 2 mm, which is much smaller than that on the palm or back.
Description B: The two-point threshold on the fingers is approximately 10 mm, which is much smaller than that on the palm or back.

Description A: Ruffini endings located near finger joints detect skin stretch over knuckles and aid in the perception of finger joint angles.
Description B: Meissner corpuscles located near finger joints detect skin stretch over knuckles and aid in the perception of finger joint angles.

Description A: Blind individuals distinguish Braille dots through specific combinations of SA1 fibers firing synchronously.
Description B: Blind individuals distinguish Braille dots through specific combinations of RA2 fibers firing synchronously.

Description A: Muscle spindles are small encapsulated sensory receptors that signal changes in the length of the muscle.
Description B: Muscle spindles are large sensory receptors that signal changes in the thickness of the muscle.

Description A: In monosynaptic pathways, Ia sensory axons make excitatory connections on alpha motor neurons that innervate homonymous and synergist muscles.
Description B: In monosynaptic pathways, Ia sensory axons make inhibitory connections on alpha motor neurons that innervate homonymous and synergist muscles.

Description A: Gamma motor neurons adjust the sensitivity of the muscle spindles by altering the firing rate of sensory axons.
Description B: Alpha motor neurons adjust the sensitivity of the muscle spindles by altering the firing rate of sensory axons.

Description A: When a muscle is stretched, activity in the sensory axons of muscle spindles increases.
Description B: When a muscle shortens, activity in the sensory axons of muscle spindles increases.

Description A: The dynamic gamma motor neurons innervate the dynamic bag fibers.
Description B: The static gamma motor neurons innervate the dynamic bag fibers.

Description A: Increases in the firing rate of static gamma motor neurons decrease the dynamic sensitivity of primary endings.
Description B: Increases in the firing rate of dynamic gamma motor neurons decrease the dynamic sensitivity of primary endings.

Description A: Gamma motor neurons have small-diameter myelinated axons.
Description B: Gamma motor neurons have large-diameter myelinated axons.

Description A: Type II sensory axons serve as secondary sensory endings.
Description B: Type Ia sensory axons serve as secondary sensory endings.

Description A: Primary sensory endings are highly sensitive to the velocity of stretch.
Description B: Primary sensory endings are insensitive to the velocity of stretch.

Description A: When a static gamma motor neuron is stimulated, the steady-state response of the Ia fiber increases but the dynamic response decreases.
Description B: When a static gamma motor neuron is stimulated, both steady-state and dynamic responses of the Ia fiber increase.

Description A: The Hoffmann reflex is the analog of the monosynaptic stretch reflex in humans.
Description B: The Hoffmann reflex is unrelated to the monosynaptic stretch reflex in humans.

Description A: Nuclear bag fibers can be classified as dynamic or static.
Description B: Nuclear chain fibers can be classified as dynamic or static.

Description A: The primary sensory endings provide information about speed of movements.
Description B: The secondary sensory endings provide information about speed of movements.

Description A: Intrafusal fibers are innervated by gamma motor neurons.
Description B: Extrafusal fibers are innervated by gamma motor neurons.

Description A: Intrafusal muscle fibers do not contribute significantly to the force of muscle contraction.
Description B: Intrafusal muscle fibers contribute significantly to the force of muscle contraction.

Description A: The voltage-gated Na+ channel is formed from a single polypeptide chain that contains four homologous domains, each with six membrane-spanning α-helixes.
Description B: The voltage-gated Na+ channel is formed from two polypeptide chains that contain three homologous domains, each with six membrane-spanning α-helixes.

Description A: Gap-junction channels are formed from a pair of hemichannels, each hemichannel composed of six identical subunits.
Description B: Gap-junction channels are formed from a pair of hemichannels, each hemichannel composed of four identical subunits.

Description A: Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels share the same general structural pattern as voltage-gated Na+ channels, though their amino acid sequences differ.
Description B: Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels have a completely different structural pattern from voltage-gated Na+ channels, with more membrane-spanning segments.

Description A: The TRP channels are important for Ca2+ metabolism, visual signaling, and sensation in higher animals.
Description B: The TRP channels are predominantly involved in auditory processing and olfactory signaling in higher animals.

Description A: Voltage-gated K+ channels are composed of four subunits, each with six transmembrane segments and a pore-forming P-region.
Description B: Voltage-gated K+ channels are composed of three subunits, each with five transmembrane segments and a pore-forming P-region.

Description A: The diversity of ion channels arises from the combinatorial permutations of channel subunits encoded by related genes.
Description B: The diversity of ion channels arises solely from a fixed number of genetically identical subunits.

Description A: Inward-rectifying K+ channels have two transmembrane segments connected by a P-region.
Description B: Inward-rectifying K+ channels have four transmembrane segments connected by two P-regions.

Description A: K2P channels are composed of subunits with two repeated pore-forming segments.
Description B: K2P channels are composed of subunits with three repeated pore-forming segments.

Description A: Biochemical and molecular biological approaches have helped define the structure-function relationships in ion channels.
Description B: Biochemical approaches exclusively determine the assembly process of ion channels, without impacting structure-function relationships.

Description A: The first high-resolution X-ray crystallographic analysis of an ion-selective channel was focused on a non-voltage-gated K+ channel termed KcsA.
Description B: The first high-resolution X-ray crystallographic analysis of an ion-selective channel focused on a voltage-gated K+ channel termed KcsA.

Description A: The KcsA channel is made up of four identical subunits arranged symmetrically around a central pore.
Description B: The KcsA channel is made up of three identical subunits arranged asymmetrically around a central pore.

Description A: The selectivity filter of the KcsA channel is formed by the P-loop connecting the two α-helixes in each subunit.
Description B: The selectivity filter of the KcsA channel is formed by an extended region with no direct relation to the α-helixes.

Description A: CLC Cl- channels help set the resting potential of skeletal muscle cells and certain neurons.
Description B: CLC Cl- channels primarily function in regulating the active potential of cardiac muscle cells.

Description A: The transient receptor potential (TRP) family of nonselective cation channels includes a large group of tetrameric channels.
Description B: The transient receptor potential (TRP) family of nonselective cation channels comprises a group of monomeric channels.

Description A: In the KcsA channel, the inner helixes form a narrow opening known as the 'smoke hole' of the tepee.
Description B: In the KcsA channel, the inner helixes form a wide opening known as the 'entry gate' of the tepee.

Description A: Seizures are temporary disruptions of brain function resulting from abnormal neuronal activity.
Description B: Seizures are permanent disruptions of brain function resulting from abnormal neuronal activity.

Description A: The Greeks were aware that head injuries to one side of the brain could cause seizure activity on the opposite side of the body.
Description B: The Greeks believed head injuries to one side of the brain could cause seizure activity on the same side of the body.

Description A: Focal onset seizures originate in a small group of neurons and can occur without alteration of consciousness.
Description B: Focal onset seizures originate in a large group of neurons and never occur without alteration of consciousness.

Description A: The first surgical treatment for epilepsy was performed in 1886 by Victor Horsley.
Description B: The first surgical treatment for epilepsy was performed in 1937 by Victor Horsley.

Description A: Generalized onset seizures begin without an aura or focal onset and involve both hemispheres from the start.
Description B: Generalized onset seizures begin with an aura or focal onset and involve only one hemisphere.

Description A: The diagnosis of epilepsy has consequences that can affect educational opportunities and employment.
Description B: The diagnosis of epilepsy has no impact on educational opportunities and employment.

Description A: A seizure's signs and symptoms depend on the location and extent of brain regions affected.
Description B: A seizure's signs and symptoms are identical regardless of the affected brain regions.

Description A: Epilepsy is a chronic condition of recurrent seizures.
Description B: Epilepsy is a acute condition of single seizures.

Description A: John Hughlings Jackson realized that seizures could occur without a loss of consciousness.
Description B: John Hughlings Jackson believed all seizures resulted in loss of consciousness.

Description A: Typical absence seizures in children are associated with staring and sudden cessation of all motor activity.
Description B: Typical absence seizures in children are associated with intense motor activity and focus.

Description A: Focal onset seizures can be preceded by telltale symptoms called auras.
Description B: Focal onset seizures never have any symptoms preceding them.

Description A: The aura is a product of electrical activity in the seizure focus.
Description B: The aura has no relation to electrical activity in the seizure focus.

Description A: Generalized onset tonic-clonic seizures are characterized by tonic contraction followed by clonic jerking.
Description B: Generalized onset tonic-clonic seizures only involve mild muscle tremors.

Description A: The most common motor type of generalized onset seizure is the tonic-clonic seizure.
Description B: The most common motor type of generalized onset seizure is the absence seizure.

Description A: Mutations in ion channels are among the genetic causes of epilepsy.
Description B: Environmental factors alone are responsible for the genetic causes of epilepsy.

Description A: The primate subventricular zone is greatly enlarged compared to the mouse and becomes subdivided into inner and outer regions, which contain large populations of radial glial cells, both of which generate neurons.
Description B: The primate subventricular zone is greatly enlarged compared to the mouse and becomes subdivided into a single region, which generates neurons without relying on radial glial cells.

Description A: Glutamatergic pyramidal neurons derive from the cortical ventricular zone, and their differentiation depends on the activities of neurogenin-1 and -2.
Description B: Glutamatergic pyramidal neurons derive from the rhombic lip, and their differentiation depends on the activities of Mash1 and Dlx2.

Description A: GABAergic Purkinje neurons migrate from the deep cerebellar proliferative zone, settle in the Purkinje cell layer, and are specified by the bHLH protein Ptf1a.
Description B: GABAergic Purkinje neurons migrate from the ventricular zone, settle in the Purkinje cell layer, and are specified by the bHLH protein Math-1.

Description A: The sweat gland secretes a cocktail of interleukin-6–like cytokines, notably cardiotrophin-1, leukemia inhibitory factor, and ciliary neurotrophic factor, which induce cholinergic properties in sympathetic neurons.
Description B: The sweat gland secretes a cocktail of growth factors, notably BMPs and Runx proteins, which induce cholinergic properties in sympathetic neurons.

Description A: Sympathetic neurons that innervate sweat glands switch to a cholinergic transmitter phenotype through environmental signals from the sweat gland cells.
Description B: Sympathetic neurons that innervate sweat glands retain their noradrenergic transmitter phenotype due to environmental signals from the sweat gland cells.

Description A: The neurotransmitter phenotype can be influenced post-neuronal differentiation by environmental signals exposing neural crest cells during their migratory pathway.
Description B: The neurotransmitter phenotype is permanently fixed at the earliest stage of neuronal differentiation and cannot be influenced later by environmental signals.

Description A: GABAergic neurons derive from the ventricular zone in the cerebellum, while glutamatergic neurons migrate into the cerebellum from the rhombic lip.
Description B: Both GABAergic and glutamatergic neurons derive from the ventricular zone in the cerebellum.

Description A: Several aspects of neuronal metabolism linked to transmitter synthesis and release are controlled by factors secreted by sweat gland cells.
Description B: Neuronal metabolism linked to transmitter synthesis and release is innate and independent of factors secreted by sweat gland cells.

Description A: GABAergic and glutamatergic neurons in the cerebral cortex are generated in different proliferative zones and are specified by different bHLH transcription factors.
Description B: GABAergic and glutamatergic neurons in the cerebral cortex are generated in the same proliferative zone and are specified by the same bHLH transcription factors.

Description A: Radial glial cells in the primate subventricular zone contribute to cortical expansion by generating neurons.
Description B: Radial glial cells in the primate subventricular zone are primarily involved in non-neuronal functions during cortical expansion.

Description A: Neurogenin-1 and Neurogenin-2 are transcription factors essential for the differentiation of glutamatergic pyramidal neurons in the cortical ventricular zone.
Description B: Neurogenin-1 and Neurogenin-2 are transcription factors essential for the differentiation of inhibitory interneurons in the cortical ventricular zone.

Description A: Acetylcholine is stored in small clear vesicles in cholinergic neurons, while norepinephrine is stored in dense-core vesicles in noradrenergic neurons.
Description B: Acetylcholine is stored in dense-core vesicles in cholinergic neurons, while norepinephrine is stored in small clear vesicles in noradrenergic neurons.

Description A: The layered cortical structure develops in human organoids and is stained with antibodies to transcription factors like Satb2, Ctip2, and Pax6.
Description B: The layered cortical structure develops in human organoids but does not express transcription factors like Satb2, Ctip2, and Pax6.

Description A: The neurotransmitter switch from noradrenergic to cholinergic in sympathetic neurons is induced by cytokines secreted by sweat gland cells.
Description B: The neurotransmitter switch from cholinergic to noradrenergic in sympathetic neurons is induced by cytokines secreted by sweat gland cells.

Description A: Several secreted factors, including cardiotrophin-1 and leukemia inhibitory factor, trigger a transmitter phenotype switch in sympathetic neurons.
Description B: Several secreted factors, including BMPs and Runx proteins, trigger a transmitter phenotype switch in sympathetic neurons.

Description A: Closure of one eye during the critical period for binocular development enhances the motility of dendritic spines.
Description B: Closure of one eye after the critical period for binocular development enhances the motility of dendritic spines.

Description A: Axons from the open eye sprout new terminals at sites vacated by fibers from the closed eye.
Description B: Axons from the closed eye sprout new terminals at sites vacated by fibers from the open eye.

Description A: Thalamocortical axons carrying signals from contralateral and ipsilateral eyes are segregated in the binocular zone in visual cortex.
Description B: Thalamocortical axons carrying signals from contralateral and ipsilateral eyes are mixed in the binocular zone in visual cortex.

Description A: Administration of excess BDNF modifies the formation of ocular dominance columns.
Description B: Administration of excess BDNF has no effect on the formation of ocular dominance columns.

Description A: The critical period for monocular deprivation extends in mice lacking Nogo signaling.
Description B: The critical period for monocular deprivation shortens in mice lacking Nogo signaling.

Description A: In mutant mice lacking Nogo or NogoR, the critical period remains open into adulthood.
Description B: In mutant mice lacking Nogo or NogoR, the critical period closes early during development.

Description A: Synaptic activity may regulate the secretion of neurotrophic factors by cortical neurons.
Description B: Synaptic activity has no impact on the secretion of neurotrophic factors by cortical neurons.

Description A: Perineuronal nets form around the time that the critical period closes.
Description B: Perineuronal nets form long before the critical period closes.

Description A: Experience-independent spontaneous neural activity leads to early circuit refinement.
Description B: Experience-dependent spontaneous neural activity leads to early circuit refinement.

Description A: BDNF and trkB signaling can influence plasticity in the cortex.
Description B: BDNF and trkB signaling have no influence on plasticity in the cortex.

Description A: The segregation of visual cortex into ocular dominance columns begins before the onset of visual experience.
Description B: The segregation of visual cortex into ocular dominance columns begins after the onset of visual experience.

Description A: Formation of myelin creates physical barriers to sprouting and axonal growth.
Description B: Formation of myelin facilitates sprouting and axonal growth.

Description A: In the visual cortex, pyramidal neurons have many spines with density remaining comparatively constant under normal conditions.
Description B: In the visual cortex, pyramidal neurons have many spines with density varying greatly under normal conditions.

Description A: Neuronal growth programs decrease with age as described in the text.
Description B: Neuronal growth programs increase with age as described in the text.

Description A: Infusion of chondroitinase maintains plasticity by digesting perineuronal nets.
Description B: Infusion of chondroitinase blocks plasticity by digesting perineuronal nets.

Description A: Major depressive disorder often begins early in life, but first episodes do occur across the lifespan.
Description B: Major depressive disorder often begins later in life, and first episodes occur only in adulthood.

Description A: Bipolar disorder is less common than unipolar depression, with a prevalence of approximately 1% worldwide.
Description B: Bipolar disorder is more common than unipolar depression, with a prevalence of approximately 5% worldwide.

Description A: The World Health Organization reports that depression is a leading cause of disability worldwide.
Description B: The World Health Organization reports that depression is a minor cause of disability worldwide.

Description A: A diagnosis of bipolar disorder requires at least one episode of mania.
Description B: A diagnosis of bipolar disorder does not require an episode of mania.

Description A: Electroconvulsive therapy is highly effective against depression.
Description B: Electroconvulsive therapy is considered ineffective against depression.

Description A: The lifetime risk of major depressive disorder in the United States is approximately 19%.
Description B: The lifetime risk of major depressive disorder in the United States is less than 5%.

Description A: Both genetic and environmental risk factors contribute to mood and anxiety disorders.
Description B: Only environmental risk factors contribute to mood and anxiety disorders.

Description A: Major depressive disorder in childhood occurs equally in males and females.
Description B: Major depressive disorder in childhood occurs more commonly in females.

Description A: Psychotherapy is effective in the treatment of major depressive disorder and anxiety disorders.
Description B: Psychotherapy is ineffective in the treatment of major depressive disorder and anxiety disorders.

Description A: Current antidepressant drugs affect monoaminergic neural systems.
Description B: Current antidepressant drugs affect cardiovascular systems.

Description A: Ketamine shows promise as a rapidly acting drug to treat major depressive disorder.
Description B: Ketamine has been proven ineffective as a treatment for major depressive disorder.

Description A: Major depression is diagnosed when people suffer from depressive episodes alone.
Description B: Major depression is diagnosed only when manic episodes are involved.

Description A: Depression is a leading cause of economic loss from noncommunicable disease.
Description B: Depression does not contribute to economic loss from noncommunicable disease.

Description A: Mood disorders can be divided into two general classes: unipolar depression and bipolar disorder.
Description B: Mood disorders are divided into more than three distinct classes.
