Description A: Bipolar disorder is named for its chief symptom, swings of mood between mania and depression.
Description B: Bipolar disorder is named because it involves only the depressive phase.

Description A: Long-term potentiation (LTP) at the Schaffer collateral pathway requires NMDA receptor activation and is blocked by APV.
Description B: Long-term potentiation (LTP) at the Schaffer collateral pathway requires only AMPA receptor activation and is blocked by APV.

Description A: In the mossy fiber pathway, LTP is initiated by a large Ca2+ influx into presynaptic terminals.
Description B: In the mossy fiber pathway, LTP is initiated by a large Mg2+ influx into presynaptic terminals.

Description A: APV has no effect on LTP at mossy fiber synapses with CA3 pyramidal neurons.
Description B: APV completely blocks LTP at mossy fiber synapses with CA3 pyramidal neurons.

Description A: LTP at the direct perforant pathways involves NMDA receptors and L-type Ca2+ channels.
Description B: LTP at the direct perforant pathways involves NMDA receptors and L-type Na+ channels.

Description A: Mossy fiber LTP does not require activation of postsynaptic cells.
Description B: Mossy fiber LTP requires activation of postsynaptic cells.

Description A: LTP can last for days in intact animals using implanted electrodes.
Description B: LTP can last for a few minutes in intact animals using implanted electrodes.

Description A: NMDA receptors act as coincidence detectors requiring both presynaptic and postsynaptic activity.
Description B: NMDA receptors can function independently of presynaptic activity.

Description A: In the Schaffer collateral pathway, APV blocks NMDA receptor activation.
Description B: In the Schaffer collateral pathway, APV enhances NMDA receptor activation.

Description A: LTP at different synapses involves distinct cellular and molecular mechanisms.
Description B: LTP at different synapses involves identical cellular and molecular mechanisms.

Description A: Calcium influx is crucial for triggering mossy fiber LTP.
Description B: Potassium influx is crucial for triggering mossy fiber LTP.

Description A: LTP in the Schaffer collateral pathway requires associative activation of NMDA receptors.
Description B: LTP in the Schaffer collateral pathway requires non-associative activation of NMDA receptors.

Description A: LTP at Schaffer collateral synapses is completely blocked by NMDA receptor antagonists during tetanic stimulation.
Description B: LTP at Schaffer collateral synapses is only mildly affected by NMDA receptor antagonists during tetanic stimulation.

Description A: The pore of NMDA receptor-channels is blocked by Mg2+ at resting potentials.
Description B: The pore of NMDA receptor-channels is blocked by Ca2+ at resting potentials.

Description A: Different forms of LTP rely on distinct second-messenger signaling pathways.
Description B: Different forms of LTP rely on identical second-messenger signaling pathways.

Description A: LTP induction at the direct pathway from the entorhinal cortex to CA1 involves L-type Ca2+ channels.
Description B: LTP induction at the direct pathway from the entorhinal cortex to CA1 involves L-type K+ channels.

Description A: The co-activation of alpha and gamma motor neurons allows feedback from muscle spindles to reinforce activation in alpha motor neurons, compensating for disturbances in muscle length during movement.
Description B: The co-activation of alpha and gamma motor neurons suppresses feedback from muscle spindles, preventing muscle disturbance compensation during movement.

Description A: Ia inhibitory interneurons receive inputs from motor cortex axon collaterals to coordinate reciprocal inhibition in voluntary movements.
Description B: Ia inhibitory interneurons receive inputs exclusively from sensory fibers to coordinate reciprocal inhibition in voluntary movements.

Description A: Renshaw cells create inhibitory synaptic connections with motor neurons, forming a negative feedback system that regulates firing rates.
Description B: Renshaw cells create excitatory synaptic connections with motor neurons, forming a positive feedback system that enhances firing rates.

Description A: During locomotion, Ib sensory fibers from extensor muscles produce an excitatory effect on homonymous motor neurons due to a state-dependent reflex reversal.
Description B: During locomotion, Ib sensory fibers from extensor muscles produce an inhibitory effect on homonymous motor neurons due to a state-dependent reflex reversal.

Description A: Presynaptic inhibition reduces neurotransmitter release from Ia sensory axons, shaping activity in Ia afferent networks to facilitate muscle activation.
Description B: Presynaptic inhibition increases neurotransmitter release from Ia sensory axons to enhance stretch reflexes across all motor neurons.

Description A: Reciprocal innervation during voluntary movements relaxes antagonist muscles to enhance movement speed and efficiency.
Description B: Reciprocal innervation during voluntary movements contracts antagonist muscles to enhance movement speed and efficiency.

Description A: Co-contraction of flexor and extensor muscles is useful for precision and stabilization of joints during specific tasks.
Description B: Co-contraction of flexor and extensor muscles reduces precision and destabilizes joints during specific tasks.

Description A: Descending inputs modulate sensory input by altering synaptic efficiency of primary sensory fibers in the spinal cord.
Description B: Descending inputs suppress sensory input by eliminating synaptic activity of primary sensory fibers in the spinal cord.

Description A: Presynaptic inhibition typically increases feedback access during unexpected disturbances in movement.
Description B: Presynaptic inhibition typically decreases feedback access during unexpected disturbances in movement.

Description A: State-dependent reflex reversal allows Golgi tendon organ feedback to support muscle activation during locomotion.
Description B: State-dependent reflex reversal prevents Golgi tendon organ feedback from influencing muscle activation during locomotion.

Description A: Ia sensory fibers produce increased presynaptic inhibition on antagonist motor neurons at the onset of agonist contraction.
Description B: Ia sensory fibers reduce presynaptic inhibition on antagonist motor neurons at the onset of agonist contraction.

Description A: Presynaptic inhibition of Ia fibers is regulated by GABAergic interneurons, which reduce sensory feedback through chloride-mediated depolarization.
Description B: Presynaptic inhibition of Ia fibers is regulated by GABAergic interneurons, which enhance sensory feedback through sodium-mediated depolarization.

Description A: Descending motor commands can selectively modulate presynaptic inhibition, making voluntary movements more coordinated.
Description B: Descending motor commands eliminate presynaptic inhibition, making voluntary movements more uncoordinated.

Description A: Descending inputs promote excitatory pathways during locomotion to enhance contraction of extensor muscles.
Description B: Descending inputs suppress excitatory pathways during locomotion to reduce contraction of extensor muscles.

Description A: Renshaw cells adjust motor neuron excitability and stabilize firing rates through inhibitory feedback.
Description B: Renshaw cells adjust motor neuron excitability and destabilize firing rates through excitatory feedback.

Description A: In most mammals, including humans, an XY genotype drives differentiation of the embryonic gonad into testes.
Description B: In most mammals, including humans, an XX genotype drives differentiation of the embryonic gonad into testes.

Description A: The SRY gene is responsible for sex reversal in individuals who are chromosomally male (XY) but externally indistinguishable from females.
Description B: The SRY gene is responsible for sex reversal in individuals who are chromosomally female (XX) but externally indistinguishable from males.

Description A: The presence of the Y chromosome, rather than the lack of a second X chromosome, is the crucial determinant of male differentiation.
Description B: The presence of the X chromosome, rather than the lack of a second Y chromosome, is the crucial determinant of male differentiation.

Description A: The SRY gene is located on the Y chromosome and is crucial for male differentiation.
Description B: The SRY gene is located on the X chromosome and is crucial for male differentiation.

Description A: Aromatase is expressed at high levels in the ovaries, converting testosterone to estrogen.
Description B: Aromatase is expressed at high levels in the testes, converting testosterone to estrogen.

Description A: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) results in overproduction of testosterone and related androgens.
Description B: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) results in underproduction of testosterone and related androgens.

Description A: 5α-reductase II deficiency results in ambiguous or feminized external genitalia in chromosomally male patients.
Description B: 5α-reductase II deficiency results in overtly virilized external genitalia in chromosomally male patients.

Description A: The Y chromosome overrides a female default program to generate male gonads.
Description B: The X chromosome overrides a female default program to generate male gonads.

Description A: The SRY gene encodes a transcription factor that regulates expression of genes required for male gonadal differentiation.
Description B: The SRY gene encodes an enzyme that prevents male gonadal differentiation.

Description A: The XY genotype leads to ovarian differentiation in humans.
Description B: The XY genotype leads to testicular differentiation in humans.

Description A: 5α-dihydrotestosterone is responsible for the induction of secondary male characteristics such as facial and body hair.
Description B: 5α-dihydrotestosterone is responsible for the induction of secondary female characteristics such as facial and body hair.

Description A: SRY translocates to another chromosome to produce chromosomally female individuals who are externally male.
Description B: SRY translocates to another chromosome to produce chromosomally male individuals who are externally female.

Description A: Testosterone is converted by 5α-reductase into 5α-dihydrotestosterone in various target tissues.
Description B: Testosterone is converted by aromatase into 5α-dihydrotestosterone in various target tissues.

Description A: Female cells have two active X chromosomes.
Description B: Female cells have one active X chromosome.

Description A: The sex-determining activity of the Y chromosome is encoded by the gene SRY.
Description B: The sex-determining activity of the X chromosome is encoded by the gene SRY.

Description A: Antigravity support in humans requires active tonic muscle contraction, particularly in ankle, trunk, and neck extensors.
Description B: Antigravity support in humans does not require active tonic muscle contraction in ankle, trunk, and neck extensors.

Description A: Complex patterns of muscle activation produce direction-specific forces to control the body’s center of mass.
Description B: Simple patterns of muscle activation produce direction-specific forces to control the body’s center of mass.

Description A: Postural tone should not be considered a static state of muscle activation.
Description B: Postural tone should be considered a static state of muscle activation.

Description A: Stiffening of the limbs through muscle co-contraction is not sufficient for balance control.
Description B: Stiffening of the limbs through muscle co-contraction is sufficient for balance control.

Description A: Postural orientation can interact with balance control, but the two systems can act independently.
Description B: Postural orientation cannot interact with balance control, and the two systems must always act together.

Description A: Soccer goalies may orient their body to intercept a ball by sacrificing balance.
Description B: Soccer goalies always prioritize maintaining balance when intercepting a ball.

Description A: Monosynaptic stretch reflexes are too weak to move the body center of mass effectively.
Description B: Monosynaptic stretch reflexes are strong enough to move the body center of mass effectively.

Description A: The latency of automatic postural responses is shorter than voluntary reaction time.
Description B: The latency of automatic postural responses is longer than voluntary reaction time.

Description A: The latency of human postural response in ankle muscles is 90–120 ms.
Description B: The latency of human postural response in ankle muscles is 30–40 ms.

Description A: Automatic postural responses use synergies to control muscles.
Description B: Automatic postural responses activate individual muscles independently.

Description A: The set of muscles recruited in a postural response depends on the body’s initial stance.
Description B: The set of muscles recruited in a postural response is the same regardless of the body’s initial stance.

Description A: Postural responses involving a change in support base, such as stepping, have longer latencies.
Description B: Postural responses involving a change in support base have shorter latencies.

Description A: The amplitude of EMG activity depends on both the speed and direction of postural disturbance.
Description B: The amplitude of EMG activity is independent of the speed and direction of postural disturbance.

Description A: When the support surface moves backward, the gastrocnemius is recruited for the postural response.
Description B: When the support surface moves backward, the gastrocnemius is not recruited for the postural response.

Description A: Older views of motor control focused on trunk and proximal limb muscles as the main postural effectors.
Description B: Older views of motor control emphasized distal limb muscles as the main postural effectors.

Description A: The scar tissue formed by reactive astrocytes hinders axonal regeneration by mechanical interference and by producing growth-inhibiting proteins.
Description B: The scar tissue formed by reactive astrocytes promotes axonal regeneration by mechanical interference and by producing growth-promoting proteins.

Description A: A conditioning lesion can stimulate the regeneration of a central branch of a primary sensory neuron axon by previously injuring the peripheral branch.
Description B: A conditioning lesion prevents regeneration of a central branch of a primary sensory neuron axon by previously protecting the peripheral branch.

Description A: Elevated levels of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) can stimulate axonal regrowth.
Description B: Elevated levels of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) inhibit axonal regrowth.

Description A: The growth-associated protein GAP-43 is expressed at high levels in embryonic central and peripheral neurons.
Description B: The growth-associated protein GAP-43 is expressed at low levels in embryonic central and peripheral neurons.

Description A: Deletion of the SOCS3 gene in mice enhances the ability of cytokines to promote axonal regeneration.
Description B: Deletion of the SOCS3 gene in mice reduces the ability of cytokines to promote axonal regeneration.

Description A: The PTEN gene inhibits axonal regrowth following injury by downregulating mTOR signaling.
Description B: The PTEN gene promotes axonal regrowth following injury by upregulating mTOR signaling.

Description A: Intact axons can form new connections that aid in recovery of function following injury.
Description B: Intact axons lose the ability to form new connections following injury, hindering recovery of function.

Description A: Rewiring ability of the central nervous system can be enhanced through therapeutic interventions.
Description B: Rewiring ability of the central nervous system is permanently lost in adulthood, even with therapeutic interventions.

Description A: Reactive astrocytes produce chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans that directly inhibit axon extension.
Description B: Reactive astrocytes produce chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans that promote axon extension.

Description A: Chondroitinase, an enzyme that breaks down CSPG sugar chains, promotes axon regeneration.
Description B: Chondroitinase, an enzyme that forms CSPG sugar chains, inhibits axon regeneration.

Description A: Elevated cAMP levels following injury can mimic the effects of a conditioning lesion.
Description B: Reduced cAMP levels following injury can mimic the effects of a conditioning lesion.

Description A: Mature peripheral neurons maintain robustly high levels of GAP-43, which aids axonal growth.
Description B: Mature peripheral neurons decrease levels of GAP-43, which inhibits axonal growth.

Description A: The ability of the nervous system to rewire is most vigorous during early postnatal life.
Description B: The ability of the nervous system to rewire diminishes completely during early postnatal life.

Description A: SOCS3 inhibition leads to improved regeneration in the optic nerve.
Description B: SOCS3 inhibition leads to diminished regeneration in the optic nerve.

Description A: Loss of both SOCS3 and PTEN genes results in greater regenerative ability than the loss of either alone.
Description B: Loss of both SOCS3 and PTEN genes results in lesser regenerative ability than the loss of either alone.

Description A: Gall's studies of localized brain functions led to phrenology, a discipline concerned with determining personality and character based on the detailed shape of the skull.
Description B: Gall's studies of localized brain functions led to phrenology, a discipline concerned with determining intelligence levels based on the detailed shape of the skull.

Description A: Pierre Flourens concluded that specific brain regions are not responsible for specific behaviors, suggesting a holistic view of the brain.
Description B: Pierre Flourens concluded that specific brain regions are responsible for specific behaviors, challenging the holistic view of the brain.

Description A: Paul Pierre Broca studied focal epilepsy and showed that different motor and sensory functions could be traced to specific parts of the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Hughlings Jackson studied focal epilepsy and showed that different motor and sensory functions could be traced to specific parts of the cerebral cortex.

Description A: The cerebrum comprises two cerebral hemispheres, each consisting of a heavily wrinkled outer layer known as the cerebral cortex.
Description B: The cerebrum comprises four cerebral hemispheres, each consisting of a heavily wrinkled outer layer known as the cerebral cortex.

Description A: The cerebellum modulates the force and range of movement and is involved in the learning of motor skills.
Description B: The cerebellum modulates the force and range of movement and is involved in the learning of language skills.

Description A: The occipital lobe receives visual information and is critical for all aspects of vision.
Description B: The frontal lobe receives visual information and is critical for all aspects of vision.

Description A: The basal ganglia regulate movement execution and habit learning, two forms of implicit memory.
Description B: The basal ganglia regulate movement execution and explicit memory learning.

Description A: The hippocampus is critical for storage of memory of people, places, things, and events, a form of explicit memory.
Description B: The hippocampus is critical for storage of memory of routine tasks, a form of implicit memory.

Description A: The thalamus processes most of the information reaching the cerebral cortex from the rest of the central nervous system.
Description B: The medulla processes most of the information reaching the cerebral cortex from the rest of the central nervous system.

Description A: The medulla oblongata includes several centers responsible for vital autonomic functions such as digestion and heart rate control.
Description B: The cerebellum includes several centers responsible for vital autonomic functions such as digestion and heart rate control.

Description A: The cingulate cortex is important for regulation of emotion, pain perception, and cognition.
Description B: The insular cortex is important for regulation of emotional processing and spatial reasoning.

Description A: Modern brain imaging techniques can demonstrate that cognitive operations rely primarily on the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Modern brain imaging techniques can demonstrate that cognitive operations rely primarily on the spinal cord.

Description A: The central nervous system has two main parts: the spinal cord and the brain.
Description B: The central nervous system has three main parts: the spinal cord, the brain, and the peripheral nerves.

Description A: Flourens proposed that injury to any one area of a cerebral hemisphere should affect all higher functions equally.
Description B: Flourens proposed that injury to any one area of a cerebral hemisphere should affect only specific higher functions.

Description A: The cerebral cortex makes up the surface layer of the cerebrum and is important for many brain functions.
Description B: The cerebral cortex makes up the surface layer of the cerebellum and is important for visual processing.

Description A: Neurons in areas V1 and V2 signal foreground–background relationships.
Description B: Neurons in areas V3 and V4 signal foreground–background relationships.

Description A: A random-dot stereogram produces a three-dimensional image when adjacent dark vertical stripes are registered.
Description B: A random-dot stereogram produces a two-dimensional image when adjacent dark vertical stripes are registered.

Description A: Cells in area V2 have the property of 'border ownership.'
Description B: Cells in area V1 have the property of 'border ownership.'

Description A: Vergence is a cue that originates outside the visual system.
Description B: Vergence is a cue that originates within the visual system.

Description A: Directional selectivity in neurons likely involves sequential activation of regions on different sides of the receptive field.
Description B: Directional selectivity in neurons does not involve sequential activation of regions on different sides of the receptive field.

Description A: Response latencies of presynaptic neurons influence a neuron’s selectivity for the direction of movement.
Description B: Response latencies of postsynaptic neurons influence a neuron’s selectivity for the direction of movement.

Description A: The barber-pole illusion shows the predominance of global relationships over the perception of simple attributes.
Description B: The barber-pole illusion shows the predominance of simple attributes over global relationships.

Description A: Neurons in area MT or V5 specialize in motion.
Description B: Neurons in area V1 or V2 specialize in motion.

Description A: Perception of direction depends on scene segmentation rather than local cues.
Description B: Perception of direction depends primarily on local cues rather than scene segmentation.

Description A: A cell in area V2 responds to a vertical bar with near disparity.
Description B: A cell in area V2 responds to a vertical bar with far disparity.

Description A: Differentiating the edge of each object from the background is essential for visual processing.
Description B: Ignoring the edge of each object in relation to the background is essential for visual processing.

Description A: Brightness perception is highly dependent on context.
Description B: Brightness perception is independent of context.

Description A: An object's direction and speed of movement must be integrated into a computation of the movement of a whole object.
Description B: An object's direction and speed of movement can be analyzed separately from the computation of the movement of a whole object.

Description A: Perceptual constancies help maintain the appearance of an object even as lighting conditions change.
Description B: Perceptual constancies cause the appearance of an object to drastically change with different lighting conditions.

Description A: The perception of motion integrates bottom-up analysis of local motion signals with top-down scene segmentation.
Description B: The perception of motion relies solely on bottom-up analysis of local motion signals without top-down scene segmentation.

Description A: Neuron-specific uptake mechanisms are crucial for recapturing neurotransmitters for reuse.
Description B: Neuron-specific uptake mechanisms are crucial for breaking down neurotransmitters into non-reusable forms.

Description A: Amphetamines act on vesicular transporters within the cell in addition to transporters on the neuron's external membrane.
Description B: Amphetamines only interact with transporters on the neuron's external membrane, not vesicular transporters within the cell.

Description A: The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, like fluoxetine, are generally better tolerated than tricyclic antidepressants.
Description B: The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, like fluoxetine, are generally less tolerated than tricyclic antidepressants.

Description A: Cocaine blocks the uptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.
Description B: Cocaine enhances the uptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.

Description A: High-affinity uptake is an essential process for synaptic signaling and involves transporter molecules.
Description B: High-affinity uptake is not necessary for synaptic signaling and does not involve transporter molecules.

Description A: Amines and GABA's synaptic signaling can be prolonged by blocking uptake transporters.
Description B: Blocking uptake transporters shortens the synaptic signaling of amines and GABA.

Description A: Neurotransmitter sodium symporters (NSS) have a structure which threads through the plasma membrane 12 times.
Description B: Neurotransmitter sodium symporters (NSS) have a structure which threads through the plasma membrane only 6 times.

Description A: COMT is significant in regulating cortical dopamine levels because of the low levels of the dopamine uptake transporter.
Description B: COMT is insignificant in regulating cortical dopamine levels regardless of the low levels of the dopamine uptake transporter.

Description A: Secondary antibodies in indirect immunofluorescence are tagged with fluorescent dyes.
Description B: Secondary antibodies in indirect immunofluorescence are tagged with non-fluorescent compounds.

Description A: Plasma membrane transporters utilize a symport mechanism driven by the Na+ electrochemical gradient.
Description B: Plasma membrane transporters utilize an antiport mechanism driven by the K+ electrochemical gradient.

Description A: Fluorescent false neurotransmitters (FFNs) are used to monitor transmitter release in real-time.
Description B: Fluorescent false neurotransmitters (FFNs) hinder the process of monitoring transmitter release in real-time.

Description A: MAO inhibitors are utilized in treating depression and Parkinson's disease.
Description B: MAO inhibitors are used solely in treating sleep disorders.

Description A: Julius Axelrod was awarded a share of the Nobel Prize for the co-discovery of neuronal norepinephrine uptake.
Description B: Julius Axelrod was not associated with the Nobel Prize related to neuronal norepinephrine uptake.

Description A: Butyrylcholinesterase can degrade molecules like cocaine and succinylcholine.
Description B: Butyrylcholinesterase is limited to degrading only acetylcholine molecules.

Description A: The electron micrograph shows a section through the cell body of an Aplysia bag cell.
Description B: The electron micrograph indicates a section through the cell body of a mammalian neuron.

Description A: The early vertebrate embryo consists of three layers of cells—ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
Description B: The early vertebrate embryo consists of four layers of cells—ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm, and hypoderm.

Description A: The entire nervous system arises from the ectoderm, specifically from a central strip called the neural plate.
Description B: The entire nervous system arises from the endoderm, specifically from a central strip called the neural plate.

Description A: Formation of neural plate within the ectoderm occurs by a process called induction.
Description B: Formation of neural plate within the ectoderm occurs by a process called differentiation.

Description A: Induction involves a mechanism in which mesoderm-derived soluble factors prevent ectoderm-derived BMPs from suppressing the neural fate.
Description B: Induction involves a mechanism in which mesoderm-derived soluble factors encourage ectoderm-derived BMPs to suppress the neural fate.

Description A: Following induction, the neural plate invaginates from the ectoderm to form a neural tube.
Description B: Following induction, the neural plate remains flat on the ectoderm and forms the neural band.

Description A: The tube gives rise to the central nervous system.
Description B: The tube gives rise to the digestive system.

Description A: Cells at the border between neural tube and ectoderm form neural crest, which migrates through the embryo to form the sensory and autonomic ganglia.
Description B: Cells at the border between neural tube and ectoderm form neural crest, which migrates through the embryo to form the immune system.

Description A: Regionalization along the anterior-posterior axis leads to a series of subdivisions, with the anterior region becoming the brain.
Description B: Regionalization along the anterior-posterior axis leads to a series of subdivisions, with the posterior region becoming the brain.

Description A: The forebrain divides to form the telencephalon and diencephalon.
Description B: The forebrain divides to form the cerebellum and spinal cord.

Description A: Anterior-posterior patterning is established by gradients of Wnt signaling.
Description B: Anterior-posterior patterning is established by gradients of BMP signaling.

Description A: The isthmic organizer at the boundary of hindbrain and midbrain secretes Wnts and FGFs.
Description B: The isthmic organizer at the boundary of forebrain and hindbrain secretes Wnts and FGFs.

Description A: Differential expression of transcription factors called Hox proteins is important in motor neuron diversification.
Description B: Differential expression of transcription factors called Pax proteins is important in motor neuron diversification.

Description A: Regionalization of the cerebral cortex is influenced by gradients of morphogens.
Description B: Regionalization of the cerebral cortex is influenced by gradients of neurotransmitters.

Description A: Different levels of Shh and BMPs induce different transcription factors.
Description B: Different levels of Shh and BMPs induce the same transcription factors.

Description A: Recent advances enable neuroscientists to recapitulate some early neural development processes using cultured human cells.
Description B: Recent advances enable neuroscientists to recapitulate some early neural development processes using laboratory animals only.

Description A: Neuronal membrane properties make an important contribution to the function of the central pattern generator (CPG).
Description B: Neuronal membrane properties have no impact on the function of the central pattern generator (CPG).

Description A: Neurons have a variety of K+, Na+, and Ca2+ channels that determine their activity and response to synaptic inputs.
Description B: Neurons primarily have Cl- channels that determine their activity and response to synaptic inputs.

Description A: In the lamprey, bursting due to NMDA receptor activation plays a role in generating swimming.
Description B: In the lamprey, NMDA receptor activation hinders the ability to generate swimming.

Description A: Plateau properties amplify and prolong the effect of synaptic excitatory inputs.
Description B: Plateau properties diminish the effect of synaptic excitatory inputs.

Description A: Conditional bursting triggered by glutaminergic activation of NMDA receptors has been described in spinal cord interneurons and motor neurons in lamprey, rodents, and amphibians.
Description B: Conditional bursting triggered by glutaminergic activation of NMDA receptors has been described only in invertebrates.

Description A: HCN channels are found in many CPG neurons and motor neurons and may help neurons escape from inhibition.
Description B: HCN channels are found solely in peripheral neurons and are not involved in inhibition escape.

Description A: Hyperpolarization removes the resting inactivation of voltage-gated A-type transient K+ channels.
Description B: Depolarization removes the resting inactivation of voltage-gated A-type transient K+ channels.

Description A: The cardinal classes of interneuronal types belong to dorsally located interneurons (dI1–dI6) and ventrally located interneurons (V0–V3).
Description B: The cardinal classes of interneuronal types belong only to ventrally located interneurons.

Description A: The molecular code of the spinal cord neurons is used to mark cells with a marker protein such as green fluorescent protein.
Description B: The molecular code of the spinal cord neurons cannot be used to mark cells with marker proteins.

Description A: Mechanoreceptors in the skin have a powerful influence on the CPG.
Description B: Mechanoreceptors in the skin have no influence on the central pattern generator (CPG).

Description A: Activation and inactivation kinetics of Na+ channels are factors in regulating the firing rate of a cell.
Description B: Activation and inactivation kinetics of Na+ channels do not affect the firing rate of a cell.

Description A: The slowly inactivating Na+ channels are generally not regulated by neurotransmitters.
Description B: The slowly inactivating Na+ channels are primarily regulated by neurotransmitters.

Description A: Reciprocal inhibition between neurons is a common design in locomotor circuits.
Description B: Reciprocal inhibition between neurons is uncommon in locomotor circuits.

Description A: Golgi tendon organs have inhibitory actions on ankle extensor motor neurons when the body is at rest.
Description B: Golgi tendon organs have excitatory actions on ankle extensor motor neurons when the body is at rest.

Description A: Proprioceptive information from muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs contributes significantly to the generation of burst activity in extensor motor neurons.
Description B: Proprioceptive information from muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs is irrelevant to burst activity in extensor motor neurons.

Description A: In delay eyeblink conditioning, a neutral sensory stimulus such as a light or a tone is repeatedly paired with an aversive unconditioned stimulus like an air puff to the eye.
Description B: In delay eyeblink conditioning, a neutral sensory stimulus such as a light or a tone is paired with a positive unconditioned stimulus like a pleasant sound.

Description A: Recurrent excitation can explain how a brief pulse of input can lead to a persistent change in firing rate through a process akin to mathematical integration.
Description B: Recurrent inhibition can explain how a brief pulse of input can lead to a persistent change in firing rate through a process akin to mathematical subtraction.

Description A: Damage to certain brain stem structures in humans can lead to gaze-evoked nystagmus.
Description B: Damage to certain brain stem structures in humans can lead to gaze-evoked steady vision.

Description A: Oculomotor integrator circuits typically contain two opposing classes of neurons.
Description B: Oculomotor integrator circuits typically contain only one class of neurons.

Description A: Hebbian plasticity involves strengthening synapses when a presynaptic input helps cause a neuron to fire an action potential.
Description B: Hebbian plasticity involves weakening synapses when a presynaptic input helps cause a neuron to fire an action potential.

Description A: Hebbian plasticity by itself would keep making synapses stronger and stronger.
Description B: Hebbian plasticity by itself would keep making synapses weaker and weaker.

Description A: Climbing fiber inputs to a specific region of the cerebellum signal the occurrence of an aversive stimulus.
Description B: Climbing fiber inputs to a specific region of the cerebellum signal the occurrence of a pleasant stimulus.

Description A: Experience-dependent changes responsible for learning and memory occur primarily at synapses.
Description B: Experience-dependent changes responsible for learning and memory occur primarily at cell bodies.

Description A: Experimental studies suggest that integrator networks are subject to modification via experience.
Description B: Experimental studies suggest that integrator networks are immune to modification via experience.

Description A: A transient input in a perfectly tuned recurrent network produces a change in firing rate that lasts indefinitely.
Description B: A transient input in a perfectly tuned recurrent network produces a change in firing rate that quickly disappears.

Description A: Recurrent excitation helps explain how neural circuits perform integration.
Description B: Recurrent excitation helps explain how neural circuits perform differentiation.

Description A: Neurons receive velocity information and provide steady output to the oculomotor neurons.
Description B: Neurons receive position information and provide steady output to the oculomotor neurons.

Description A: Mutual inhibition among opposing neuron populations can play a role in sustaining activity and integration.
Description B: Mutual excitation among opposing neuron populations can play a role in sustaining activity and integration.

Description A: The cerebellum's role in simple forms of motor learning is well understood.
Description B: The cerebellum's role in simple forms of motor learning is poorly understood.

Description A: Lesions in the medial vestibular nucleus in monkeys suggest that the neural integrator circuit lies within these structures.
Description B: Lesions in the medial vestibular nucleus in monkeys suggest that the neural integrator circuit lies outside of these structures.

Description A: Voluntary movements are purposeful, intentional, and context-dependent, unlike stereotypical fixed-latency reflexive responses.
Description B: Voluntary movements are automatic, reflexive, and trigger-based, unlike intentional context-dependent responses.

Description A: The primary motor cortex plays an important role in motor execution.
Description B: The primary motor cortex plays no role in motor execution.

Description A: The primary motor cortex includes a detailed map of the motor periphery.
Description B: The primary motor cortex lacks a detailed map of the motor periphery.

Description A: Some neurons in the primary motor cortex project directly to spinal motor neurons.
Description B: No neurons in the primary motor cortex project directly to spinal motor neurons.

Description A: Volitional self-control endows primate voluntary behavior with much of its richness and flexibility.
Description B: Volitional self-control limits primate voluntary behavior to rigid and inflexible patterns.

Description A: Voluntary movements allow choices between alternatives, including the choice not to act.
Description B: Voluntary movements eliminate choices and compel individuals to act.

Description A: The parietal cortex provides information about the world and the body for state estimation to plan and execute motor actions.
Description B: The parietal cortex does not provide any information for state estimation to plan and execute motor actions.

Description A: Premotor cortex supports motor selection and planning.
Description B: Premotor cortex is irrelevant to motor selection and planning.

Description A: Voluntary behavior is the physical manifestation of an individual's intention to act on the environment.
Description B: Voluntary behavior has nothing to do with an individual's intention to act on the environment.

Description A: Theories of perception, cognition, and movement are traditionally partitioned into three analytic components: perceptual mechanisms, cognitive processes, and motor systems.
Description B: Theories of perception, cognition, and movement are traditionally unified into a single undivided theory.

Description A: Humans can use fingers, hands, and arms independent of locomotion to exploit their environment.
Description B: Humans must use locomotion to exploit their environment, with no independent use of fingers, hands, or arms.

Description A: Throughout evolution, voluntary behavior features have become increasingly prominent in higher primates.
Description B: Throughout evolution, voluntary behavior features have become increasingly diminished in higher primates.

Description A: Large areas of the cerebral cortex are implicated in various aspects of voluntary motor control.
Description B: Large areas of the cerebral cortex are not involved in voluntary motor control.

Description A: Theoretical frameworks help interpret behavior and the neural basis of voluntary control.
Description B: Theoretical frameworks hinder the interpretation of behavior and the neural basis of voluntary control.

Description A: Voluntary movements are typically accompanied by a sense of 'ownership' of the actions.
Description B: Voluntary movements are usually devoid of any sense of 'ownership' by the individual.

Description A: The cochlear nerve contains 95% myelinated fibers, which receive input from inner hair cells, and 5% unmyelinated fibers that receive input from outer hair cells.
Description B: The cochlear nerve contains 95% unmyelinated fibers, which receive input from outer hair cells, and 5% myelinated fibers that receive input from inner hair cells.

Description A: Fibers encoding low frequencies terminate ventrally in the cochlear nuclei, while fibers encoding high frequencies terminate dorsally.
Description B: Fibers encoding high frequencies terminate ventrally in the cochlear nuclei, while fibers encoding low frequencies terminate dorsally.

Description A: Bushy cells in the ventral cochlear nucleus project bilaterally to the superior olivary complex, enabling localization of sounds.
Description B: Bushy cells in the ventral cochlear nucleus project unilaterally to the inferior colliculus, enabling sound localization.

Description A: Octopus cells are able to detect sound onsets and brief gaps, allowing animals to mark the spectral components from one source.
Description B: Octopus cells detect continuous sounds and spectral consistency, allowing animals to ignore changing sound sources.

Description A: Stellate cells encode the spectrum of sounds with their tonotopic array and terminate widely across various auditory centers.
Description B: Stellate cells encode temporal delays in sound and only terminate locally within the cochlear nuclei.

Description A: Fusiform cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus receive both somatosensory and auditory inputs, distinguishing between predictable and unpredictable sounds.
Description B: Fusiform cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus process only auditory inputs, distinguishing only loud sounds from soft sounds.

Description A: The medial superior olive is responsible for generating a map of interaural time differences to locate sound sources horizontally.
Description B: The medial superior olive is responsible for generating a map of sound frequencies to decode auditory pitch perception.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral superior olive integrate ipsilateral excitation and contralateral inhibition to measure interaural intensity differences.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral superior olive integrate ipsilateral inhibition and contralateral excitation to measure auditory pitch.

Description A: The cochlear nuclei are organized tonotopically, meaning fibers carrying low-frequency information terminate ventrally, and fibers carrying high-frequency information terminate dorsally.
Description B: The cochlear nuclei are randomly organized, with no specific arrangement regarding frequency encoding.

Description A: The unmyelinated fibers of the cochlear nerve are thought to respond to cochlear damage and contribute to hyperacusis.
Description B: Unmyelinated fibers of the cochlear nerve primarily enhance sound sensitivity and play no role in hyperacusis.

Description A: Octopus cells terminate in large excitatory calyceal endings on neurons of the ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus.
Description B: Octopus cells only terminate locally within the cochlear nuclei without projecting to higher auditory centers.

Description A: Parallel circuits in the auditory pathway extract different acoustic information simultaneously from signals carried by cochlear nerve fibers.
Description B: Only a single auditory circuit operates at a time to extract acoustic information from cochlear nerve signals.

Description A: Large spherical bushy cells in the ventral cochlear nucleus detect low-frequency sounds and contribute to interaural time delay processing.
Description B: Large spherical bushy cells detect high-frequency sounds and contribute to interaural intensity processing.

Description A: Cartwheel cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus inhibit fusiform cells via cerebellar-like circuits.
Description B: Cartwheel cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus enhance fusiform cells' excitatory responses through specialized circuits.

Description A: Phase-locked firing occurs in cochlear nerve fibers below 4 kHz, allowing mammals to encode timing information about sound.
Description B: Phase-locked firing occurs in cochlear nerve fibers above 4 kHz, allowing mammals to encode sound amplitude variations.

Description A: The absolute refractory period of a nerve fiber typically lasts a few milliseconds during which it is impossible to generate another action potential.
Description B: The absolute refractory period of a nerve fiber typically lasts a few milliseconds during which it is easy to generate another action potential.

Description A: The relative refractory period typically lasts 5 to 10 ms and requires a larger stimulus to generate another action potential.
Description B: The relative refractory period typically lasts 15 to 20 ms and requires a smaller stimulus to generate another action potential.

Description A: Upon membrane repolarization, the gating charge movement generates a small outward current known as a gating current.
Description B: Upon membrane depolarization, the gating charge movement generates a large outward current known as a gating current.

Description A: Voltage-gated sodium channels select for sodium ions on the basis of size, charge, and energy of hydration of the ion.
Description B: Voltage-gated potassium channels select for sodium ions on the basis of size, charge, and energy of hydration of the ion.

Description A: Sodium conductance peaks at about 0 mV as all Na+ channels have moved to the activated conformation.
Description B: Sodium conductance peaks at about -100 mV as all Na+ channels have moved to the activated conformation.

Description A: The relative refractory period corresponds to partial recovery from Na+ channel inactivation.
Description B: The absolute refractory period corresponds to partial recovery from Na+ channel inactivation.

Description A: Inactivation of Na+ channels involves conformational changes enabling binding of cytoplasmic linkers to binding sites near the pore-forming helices.
Description B: Activation of Na+ channels involves conformational changes enabling binding of cytoplasmic linkers to binding sites near the pore-forming helices.

Description A: The gating current is produced by outward movement of positively charged residues through the membrane electric field.
Description B: The gating current is produced by inward movement of positively charged residues through the membrane electric field.

Description A: The empirical equations by Hodgkin and Huxley describe changes in conductance, but not channel mechanisms.
Description B: The empirical equations by Hodgkin and Huxley describe changes in channel mechanisms, but not conductance.

Description A: Voltage-gated ion channels exhibit conductance changes over a narrow range of membrane potential with saturating values.
Description B: Voltage-gated ion channels exhibit conductance changes over a wide range of membrane potential with saturating values.

Description A: Hodgkin and Huxley deduced that a conformational change moves charged particles through the membrane electric field.
Description B: Hodgkin and Huxley deduced that a conformational change moves uncharged particles through the membrane electric field.

Description A: Patch-clamp recordings have provided detailed information about properties of voltage-dependent Na+ channels.
Description B: Patch-clamp recordings have provided detailed information about properties of voltage-dependent K+ channels.

Description A: Early experiments showed impossibity to generate another action potential immediately after the first due to Na+ channel inactivation.
Description B: Early experiments showed possibility to easily generate another action potential immediately after the first due to Na+ channel activation.

Description A: Individual voltage-gated Na+ channels open in an all-or-none fashion, conducting brief current pulses.
Description B: Individual voltage-gated Na+ channels open in a gradual fashion, adjusting the amplitude of the current pulses.

Description A: Sodium channel selectivity involves high energetic costs due to Na+ ion's smaller radius and strong interaction with its waters of hydration.
Description B: Sodium channel selectivity involves low energetic costs due to Na+ ion's smaller radius and weak interaction with its waters of hydration.

Description A: The characteristic frequency of a cochlear hair cell depends on its position along the longitudinal axis of the cochlea.
Description B: The characteristic frequency of a cochlear hair cell depends on the size of the cochlear nerve rather than its position.

Description A: Hair cells that respond to low-frequency stimuli have the tallest hair bundles, while those that respond to high-frequency signals have the shortest.
Description B: Hair cells that respond to low-frequency stimuli have the shortest hair bundles, while those that respond to high-frequency signals have the tallest.

Description A: The tuning curve of a cochlear hair cell is typically V-shaped, and the tip represents the cell's characteristic frequency.
Description B: The tuning curve of a cochlear hair cell is typically flat, and the tip represents the cell's highest sensitivity to low frequencies.

Description A: Adaptation ensures that hair bundles maintain sensitivity to weak stimuli at their resting position.
Description B: Adaptation prevents hair bundles from responding to weak stimuli at their resting position.

Description A: Myosin molecules in hair cells are involved in maintaining tip-link tension, which keeps transduction channels partially open at rest.
Description B: Myosin molecules in hair cells are unrelated to tip-link tension or the opening of transduction channels at rest.

Description A: During adaptation, calcium ions reduce the upward force of myosin molecules, leading to channel closure.
Description B: During adaptation, calcium ions increase the upward force of myosin molecules, leading to channel closure.

Description A: The process of adaptation allows hair cells to remain sensitive to transient stimuli while disregarding static inputs.
Description B: The process of adaptation causes hair cells to be equally sensitive to both transient and static inputs.

Description A: Hair cells use passive filtering from the basilar membrane and mechanical amplification for frequency selectivity.
Description B: Hair cells use electrical amplification only and do not involve passive filtering for frequency selectivity.

Description A: The tuning fork analogy describes how hair bundle heights vary systematically along the tonotopic axis.
Description B: The tuning fork analogy describes how cochlear nerve length varies systematically with sound frequency.

Description A: Adaptation restores sensitivity to small, rapid hair-bundle deflections despite prolonged stimuli.
Description B: Adaptation eliminates sensitivity to small, rapid hair-bundle deflections during prolonged stimuli.

Description A: Hair-cell adaptation mechanisms rely on repositioning tip-link insertional plaques.
Description B: Hair-cell adaptation mechanisms are unaffected by changes in tip-link insertional plaques.

Description A: Hair cells are capable of high-pass filtering to disregard low-frequency inputs when appropriate.
Description B: Hair cells exclusively perform low-pass filtering, amplifying lower-frequency inputs.

Description A: The steepness of the tuning curve on the high-frequency side is greater compared to the low-frequency side.
Description B: The steepness of the tuning curve is uniform on both the high- and low-frequency sides.

Description A: Slow adaptation in hair cells can involve myosin motors driven by ATP hydrolysis.
Description B: Slow adaptation in hair cells occurs without the involvement of ATP-driven motors.

Description A: Fast adaptation kinetics vary along the tonotopic axis, helping set characteristic frequencies of responsiveness.
Description B: Fast adaptation kinetics are uniform across the tonotopic axis, independent of characteristic frequencies.

Description A: A mutation in a case of early onset narcolepsy and a generalized absence of hypocretin peptides is observed in human narcoleptic brains.
Description B: A mutation in a case of early onset narcolepsy and a generalized increase of hypocretin peptides is observed in human narcoleptic brains.

Description A: Sleep drives metabolite clearance from the adult brain.
Description B: Wakefulness drives metabolite clearance from the adult brain.

Description A: Field receptors respond to stroking or stretching of the skin in their receptive fields and are excited by painful stimuli like pulling hairs or strong pressure.
Description B: Field receptors exclusively respond to hair movement or air puffs and are not involved in sensing mechanical pain.

Description A: Muscle spindle afferent fibers encode the amplitude and speed of voluntary movements as well as passive limb displacement caused by external forces.
Description B: Muscle spindle afferent fibers encode only passive limb displacement caused by external forces and not voluntary movements.

Description A: Golgi tendon organs are located at the junction between skeletal muscle and tendons, measuring the forces generated by muscle contraction.
Description B: Golgi tendon organs are embedded inside muscle fibers and primarily detect the length of the muscle.

Description A: Joint receptors play little role in postural sensations of joint angle, which are mainly determined by muscle spindle receptors and efferent motor commands.
Description B: Joint receptors are the primary determinants of postural sensations of joint angle, independent of muscle spindle receptors or efferent motor commands.

Description A: Awl/auchene hairs are innervated by three different classes of sensory fibers: Aβ RA-LTMRs, Aδ-LTMRs, and C-LTMRs.
Description B: Awl/auchene hairs are exclusively innervated by Aβ RA-LTMRs, but no other sensory fiber classes.

Description A: TRP channels are gated by temperature and chemical ligands, and different types respond to different temperature ranges and activation thresholds.
Description B: TRP channels are exclusively gated by temperature and do not respond to chemical ligands.

Description A: TRPV1 receptors respond to heat and produce burning pain sensations, being activated by substances like capsaicin and acids.
Description B: TRPV1 receptors only respond to cold stimuli and are activated by soothing substances like menthol.

Description A: Intrafusal muscle fibers are aligned parallel to larger muscle fibers within a capsule, and they detect muscle stretch via mechanoreceptive ion channels.
Description B: Intrafusal muscle fibers are positioned perpendicular to larger muscle fibers and detect muscle contraction via ion channels.

Description A: The thermal qualities of objects are uniquely somatosensory and mediated by free nerve endings in the epidermis.
Description B: The thermal qualities of objects are primarily apprehended visually and not mediated by epidermal free nerve endings.

Description A: Temperature sense involves a combinatorial code of multiple receptor types, transmitted by small-diameter afferent fibers.
Description B: Temperature sense is transmitted exclusively by large-diameter afferent fibers involving one receptor type.

Description A: Humans are sensitive to sudden changes in skin temperature and are generally unaware of slow changes in the range of 31°C to 36°C.
Description B: Humans are equally sensitive to both sudden and slow changes in skin temperature, even within the range of 31°C to 36°C.

Description A: Piezo2 mediates signals transmitted by afferent fibers from muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs.
Description B: Piezo2 is involved exclusively in signals from joint receptors and not muscle spindles or Golgi tendon organs.

Description A: TRPM8 receptors respond to cooling, cold stimuli, and substances like menthol and mint.
Description B: TRPM8 receptors respond to heating, warm stimuli, and substances like camphor.

Description A: Merkel cells are located at the epidermal–dermal boundary surrounding large-diameter guard hairs.
Description B: Merkel cells are evenly distributed across the surface of the epidermis and unrelated to guard hairs.

Description A: Zigzag hairs are the most numerous type of hair follicles and are innervated by Aδ- and C-LTMRs.
Description B: Zigzag hairs are the least numerous type of hair follicles and are exclusively innervated by Aβ RA-LTMRs.

Description A: Cyclooxygenase is one of the enzymes that metabolizes arachidonic acid to produce prostaglandins and thromboxanes.
Description B: Cyclooxygenase metabolizes arachidonic acid to produce leukotrienes exclusively.

Description A: CB1 receptors are the most abundant type of G protein–coupled receptor in the brain and predominantly inhibit neurotransmitter release.
Description B: CB1 receptors are concentrated in the peripheral immune system and predominantly stimulate neurotransmitter release.

Description A: Anandamide consists of arachidonic acid coupled to ethanolamine and is one of the two main endocannabinoids.
Description B: Anandamide consists of arachidonic acid coupled to glycerol and is the only identified endocannabinoid.

Description A: Nitric oxide (NO) stimulates guanylyl cyclase to convert GTP into cyclic GMP.
Description B: Nitric oxide (NO) inhibits guanylyl cyclase, preventing the conversion of GTP into cyclic GMP.

Description A: Ionotropic receptors primarily regulate membrane conductance by opening or closing ion channels locally.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors regulate second-messenger cascades and are slower than metabotropic receptors.

Description A: Lipoxygenases metabolize arachidonic acid into several active metabolites, including leukotrienes.
Description B: Lipoxygenases metabolize arachidonic acid exclusively into prostaglandins and thromboxanes.

Description A: The activation of CB1 receptors can inhibit both GABA and glutamate release from presynaptic terminals.
Description B: The activation of CB1 receptors can stimulate both GABA and glutamate release from presynaptic terminals.

Description A: Endocannabinoids are lipid metabolites that diffuse through membranes and modulate neighboring cells.
Description B: Endocannabinoids are water-soluble metabolites that only act inside the cell where they are synthesized.

Description A: Activation of metabotropic receptors can increase or decrease the opening of ion channels.
Description B: Activation of metabotropic receptors exclusively increases the opening of ion channels.

Description A: Prostaglandins and thromboxane synthesis in the brain is stimulated by acute cerebral ischemia.
Description B: Prostaglandins and thromboxane synthesis in the brain is inhibited during acute cerebral ischemia.

Description A: Cyclooxygenase is inhibited by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like aspirin and indomethacin.
Description B: Cyclooxygenase is activated by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like aspirin and indomethacin.

Description A: Nitric oxide readily diffuses through membranes and does not require surface receptors for action.
Description B: Nitric oxide requires surface receptors for diffusion through membranes.

Description A: The CB2 receptor subtype modulates immune responses by being primarily located on lymphocytes.
Description B: The CB2 receptor subtype predominantly inhibits neurotransmitter release in the brain.

Description A: Cyclic GMP activates a protein kinase (PKG) that phosphorylates specific substrates in neuronal cells.
Description B: Cyclic GMP inhibits protein kinase (PKG) activity and prevents substrate phosphorylation.

Description A: Metabotropic receptors can act on ion channels far from their own location by utilizing second messengers.
Description B: Metabotropic receptors only affect ion channels localized near their binding site.

Description A: Late LTP recruits the cAMP and PKA signaling pathway to activate by phosphorylation the cAMP response element binding protein (CREB) transcription factor.
Description B: Late LTP recruits the cAMP and PKC signaling pathway to activate by phosphorylation the cAMP response element binding protein (CREB) transcription factor.

Description A: Late LTP in the Schaffer collateral pathway is synapse specific.
Description B: Late LTP in the Schaffer collateral pathway is non-synapse specific.

Description A: PKMζ is an atypical isoform of PKC that is constitutively active.
Description B: PKMζ is an atypical isoform of PKC that is conditionally active.

Description A: Spatial memory depends on long-term potentiation (LTP).
Description B: Spatial memory does not depend on long-term potentiation (LTP).

Description A: Uwe Frey and Richard Morris proposed the synaptic capture hypothesis to explain synapse specificity.
Description B: Uwe Frey and Richard Morris proposed the synaptic capture hypothesis to explain synapse non-specificity.

Description A: Blocking NMDA receptors in the hippocampus before training causes difficulty in learning spatial tasks.
Description B: Blocking NMDA receptors in the hippocampus before training enhances the learning of spatial tasks.

Description A: CaMKII can become persistently active after a brief exposure to Ca2+ through its autophosphorylation.
Description B: CaMKII cannot become persistently active after a brief exposure to Ca2+.

Description A: NMDA receptor-dependent LTP is important for forming associations between events in explicit memory.
Description B: NMDA receptor-dependent LTP does not contribute to forming associations between events in explicit memory.

Description A: The synaptic capture hypothesis suggests that synapses are tagged to make use of newly synthesized proteins.
Description B: The synaptic capture hypothesis suggests that synapses are tagged to avoid using newly synthesized proteins.

Description A: The NR1 subunit of the NMDA receptor is essential for functional NMDA receptor formation.
Description B: The NR1 subunit of the NMDA receptor is non-essential for functional NMDA receptor formation.

Description A: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) is induced when the presynaptic neuron fires just before the postsynaptic neuron.
Description B: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) is induced when the postsynaptic neuron fires just before the presynaptic neuron.

Description A: PKMζ synthesis increases during LTP, altering synaptic strength rapidly.
Description B: PKMζ synthesis decreases during LTP, weakening synaptic strength rapidly.

Description A: Associative LTP enables weak synaptic inputs to be potentiated when paired with strong inputs.
Description B: Associative LTP prevents weak synaptic inputs from being potentiated even when paired with strong inputs.

Description A: Mutations in CREB binding protein (CBP) impair late LTP and learning in mice.
Description B: Mutations in CREB binding protein (CBP) enhance late LTP and learning in mice.

Description A: Genetic deletion of PKMζ shows negligible effect on late LTP.
Description B: Genetic deletion of PKMζ shows profound detrimental effects on late LTP.

Description A: Long-term potentiation (LTP) can be reverted by blocking PKMζ several hours after induction.
Description B: Long-term potentiation (LTP) cannot be reverted by blocking PKMζ several hours after induction.

Description A: The prism goggles displace the retinal image by 5° to 30° in adolescent owls.
Description B: The prism goggles displace the retinal image by 0° to 10° in adolescent owls.

Description A: Over several weeks, the ITD to which tectal neurons responded optimally changed until the visual and auditory maps came back into register.
Description B: Over several weeks, the ITD to which tectal neurons responded optimally did not change, preventing the visual and auditory maps from coming back into register.

Description A: Reorganization of auditory maps occurs optimally during a critical juvenile period.
Description B: Reorganization of auditory maps occurs optimally during any stage of adulthood.

Description A: In adult owls, the use of goggles has little effect on the organization of the auditory map unless they wore goggles as adolescents.
Description B: In adult owls, the use of goggles has a significant effect on the organization of the auditory map, regardless of their past experience.

Description A: Different functions and brain regions have different critical periods of development.
Description B: All functions and brain regions have the same critical period of development.

Description A: Visual and auditory maps can be realigned in adulthood through several strategies.
Description B: Visual and auditory maps cannot be realigned in adulthood under any circumstances.

Description A: Prism experience causes rewiring of connections between two deeper auditory nuclei in owls.
Description B: Prism experience does not affect connections between any auditory nuclei in owls.

Description A: The auditory pathway in a normal owl includes mapping ITD in frequency-specific channels in the brain stem.
Description B: The auditory pathway in a normal owl ignores ITD mapping in frequency-specific channels in the brain stem.

Description A: In humans, different cognitive skills have different timing of critical periods.
Description B: In humans, all cognitive skills develop during the same critical period.

Description A: Plasticity of binaural tuning in owls is greater when adult prism-wearing owls hunt live prey.
Description B: Plasticity of binaural tuning in owls decreases when they hunt live prey.

Description A: The timing of critical periods varies between brain regions.
Description B: The timing of critical periods is the same for all brain regions.

Description A: In cats, the critical periods for development of orientation selectivity in visual neurons occur earlier than those for ocular dominance.
Description B: In cats, the critical periods for development of ocular dominance in visual neurons occur earlier than those for orientation selectivity.

Description A: Reorganization due to prism experience in owls allows compensation for image displacement.
Description B: Reorganization due to prism experience in owls does not allow any compensation for image displacement.

Description A: Critical periods can be reopened in adulthood, increasing brain plasticity.
Description B: Critical periods are permanently closed after early development, limiting brain plasticity.

Description A: Certain cognitive capacities must be acquired before puberty to develop optimally.
Description B: Cognitive capacities can be acquired at any age with equal development outcome.

Description A: Short-term sensitization of the gill-withdrawal reflex in Aplysia is produced by applying a noxious stimulus to another part of the body, such as the tail.
Description B: Short-term sensitization of the gill-withdrawal reflex in Aplysia is produced by touching the siphon gently.

Description A: The adenylyl cyclase converts adenosine triphosphate to cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP).
Description B: The adenylyl cyclase converts cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) to adenosine triphosphate.

Description A: Presynaptic facilitation involves two molecular pathways.
Description B: Presynaptic facilitation involves only one molecular pathway.

Description A: Serotonin binds to metabotropic receptors in the sensory neuron terminal.
Description B: Serotonin binds to ionotropic receptors in the sensory neuron terminal.

Description A: The transition from short-term to long-term memory depends on a prolonged rise in cAMP.
Description B: The transition from short-term to long-term memory depends on a decrease in cAMP.

Description A: Spaced training over several days produces sensitization that persists for 1 or more weeks.
Description B: Spaced training over several days produces sensitization that lasts for only a few hours.

Description A: In the presynaptic sensory neuron, the adenylyl cyclase acts as a coincidence detector.
Description B: In the postsynaptic sensory neuron, the adenylyl cyclase acts as a coincidence detector.

Description A: The catalytic subunit of PKA phosphorylates and activates the transcription factor CREB-1.
Description B: The catalytic subunit of PKA phosphorylates and inhibits the transcription factor CREB-2.

Description A: Like the short-term form, long-term sensitization involves changes in the strength of connections at several synapses.
Description B: Unlike the short-term form, long-term sensitization does not involve changes in synaptic connections.

Description A: Activation of specific gene expression is required for long-term memory.
Description B: Activation of specific gene expression is not required for long-term memory.

Description A: In Aplysia, long-term memory involves the growth of new synaptic connections.
Description B: In Aplysia, long-term memory does not involve the growth of new synaptic connections.

Description A: The increase in cAMP leads to prolonged activation of PKA.
Description B: The increase in cAMP leads to inhibited activation of PKA.

Description A: Pathway 2: Serotonin binds to a second class of metabotropic receptor that activates the Gq/11 class of G protein.
Description B: Pathway 2: Serotonin binds to a second class of ionotropic receptor that activates the Gq/11 class of G protein.

Description A: PKC phosphorylates presynaptic proteins, resulting in the mobilization of vesicles containing glutamate.
Description B: PKC phosphorylates postsynaptic proteins, resulting in the depletion of vesicles containing glutamate.

Description A: The postsynaptic component in the gill motor neuron is similar to long-term potentiation in the mammalian brain.
Description B: The postsynaptic component in the gill motor neuron is similar to short-term potentiation in the mammalian brain.

Description A: The disordered myelination in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (type 1A) results from increased production of peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22).
Description B: The disordered myelination in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (type 1A) results from reduced production of peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22).

Description A: Astrocytes secrete several synaptogenic factors, including thrombospondins, hevin, and glycipans, that promote the formation of new synapses.
Description B: Astrocytes secrete several synaptogenic factors, including thrombospondins, hevin, and glycogen, that promote the formation of new synapses.

Description A: Microglia derive from myeloid progenitors in the yolk sac.
Description B: Microglia derive from neuroectodermal progenitors in the yolk sac.

Description A: Astrocytes can help remodel and eliminate excess synapses during development by phagocytosis.
Description B: Astrocytes do not engage in synapse elimination during development.

Description A: PMP22 gene duplication results in two functioning PMP22 genes in patients with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.
Description B: PMP22 gene duplication results in only one functioning PMP22 gene in patients with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Description A: Astrocytes prepare the surface of the neuron for synapse formation and stabilize newly formed synapses.
Description B: Astrocytes destabilize synapse formation in neurons, hindering synaptic stabilization.

Description A: Following injury and disease, microglia undergo changes in morphology and gene expression.
Description B: Following injury and disease, microglia remain morphologically static and do not alter gene expression.

Description A: Astrocytes improve synaptic function and even behavior by releasing nutrients and regulating blood flow.
Description B: Astrocytes degrade synaptic function and behavior by depleting nutrients and reducing blood flow.

Description A: Microglia help sculpt developing neural circuits by engulfing pre- and postsynaptic structures.
Description B: Microglia disrupt neural circuits by destroying pre- and postsynaptic structures indiscriminately.

Description A: Astrocytes ensheathe small arterioles and capillaries throughout the brain.
Description B: Astrocytes never come into contact with the arterioles and capillaries in the brain.

Description A: Astrocytes undergo a transformation called reactive astrogliosis in response to brain injury and disease.
Description B: Astrocytes remain unchanged in response to brain injury and disease.

Description A: Astrocytes release neurotrophic and gliotrophic factors that promote the development and survival of neurons.
Description B: Astrocytes prevent the development and survival of neurons by releasing inhibitory factors.

Description A: Reactive astrocytes can promote repair and recovery or contribute to neuronal death after CNS injury.
Description B: Reactive astrocytes always exclusively promote repair and recovery after CNS injury and never contribute to neuronal death.

Description A: Following brain injury, astrocytes retract from damaged postsynaptic cell bodies.
Description B: Following brain injury, astrocytes do not retract from damaged postsynaptic cell bodies but instead advance towards them.

Description A: Microglia serve to bring lymphocytes into the CNS during infection and stroke.
Description B: Microglia prevent the entry of lymphocytes into the CNS during infection and stroke.

Description A: Neurons in the dorsal nucleus are predominantly binaural, receiving input from the ipsilateral medial superior olive.
Description B: Neurons in the dorsal nucleus are predominantly monaural, receiving input only from the contralateral medial superior olive.

Description A: The inferior colliculus of mammals is subdivided into the central nucleus, dorsal cortex, and external cortex.
Description B: The inferior colliculus of mammals is subdivided into the central cortex, dorsal nucleus, and external nucleus.

Description A: Neurons in the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus are GABAergic and contribute to the precedence effect.
Description B: Neurons in the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus are glycinergic and do not contribute to the precedence effect.

Description A: The central nucleus of the inferior colliculus is organized tonotopically.
Description B: The central nucleus of the inferior colliculus is not organized tonotopically.

Description A: The inferior colliculus acts as a central point for converging auditory pathways.
Description B: The inferior colliculus acts as a peripheral point for converging auditory pathways.

Description A: The superior colliculus aligns auditory, visual, and somatosensory spatial maps.
Description B: The superior colliculus aligns only auditory maps, not visual or somatosensory maps.

Description A: The superior colliculus creates a spatial map of sound from both binaural and monaural cues.
Description B: The superior colliculus creates a spatial map of sound using only monaural cues.

Description A: Interaural time and intensity differences are crucial for sound localization in the horizontal plane.
Description B: Interaural time and intensity differences are crucial for sound localization in the vertical plane.

Description A: Neurons become more selective at successive auditory areas along the ascending pathway.
Description B: Neurons become less selective at successive auditory areas along the ascending pathway.

Description A: Descending projections from the auditory cortex to the medial geniculate body are both anatomically and functionally prominent.
Description B: Descending projections from the auditory cortex to the medial geniculate body are not prominent either anatomically or functionally.

Description A: The inferior colliculus transmits auditory information to the cerebral cortex via the lemniscal and extralemniscal pathways.
Description B: The inferior colliculus transmits auditory information to the cerebral cortex via only the lemniscal pathway.

Description A: The superior colliculus helps reflexive orienting movements of the head and eyes to acoustic and visual cues.
Description B: The superior colliculus helps reflexive orienting movements of the head and eyes to olfactory and tactile cues.

Description A: The receptive field of a cortical neuron contains a sustained firing region for preferred stimuli.
Description B: The receptive field of a cortical neuron only contains an onset firing region.

Description A: Tuning can be modulated by descending inputs from the cortex in the inferior colliculus.
Description B: Tuning cannot be modulated by descending inputs from the cortex in the inferior colliculus.

Description A: Inhibition in the inferior colliculus can suppress simulated reflections of sounds.
Description B: Inhibition in the inferior colliculus cannot suppress simulated reflections of sounds.

Description A: The population vectors were calculated by vectorial addition of all the single-cell vectors in each cluster.
Description B: The population vectors were calculated by multiplying all the single-cell vectors in each cluster.

Description A: The decoded population-vector signals varied systematically with the direction of output forces.
Description B: The decoded population-vector signals did not vary with the direction of output forces.

Description A: M1 neurons displayed a broad range of changes in their activity patterns.
Description B: M1 neurons displayed consistent changes in their activity patterns.

Description A: M1 neurons can signal impending intended movements.
Description B: M1 neurons cannot signal impending intended movements.

Description A: Afferent input from cutaneous and muscle sensory neurons is equally prevalent for hand-related neurons.
Description B: Afferent input from cutaneous and muscle sensory neurons is mostly absent for hand-related neurons.

Description A: Motor corrections beginning in the long-latency epoch are modulated by the behavioral context.
