Description B: Motor corrections beginning in the long-latency epoch are not modulated by the behavioral context.

Description A: Sensory feedback supports our ability to make rapid goal-directed corrections for motor errors.
Description B: Sensory feedback does not support our ability to make rapid corrections for motor errors.

Description A: Muscle afferent feedback to M1 is surprisingly rapid.
Description B: Muscle afferent feedback to M1 is unusually slow.

Description A: Perturbation-related activity is observed in cortical regions beginning at approximately 20 ms after disturbance.
Description B: Perturbation-related activity is observed starting 200 ms after disturbance.

Description A: The transcortical feedback pathway supports rapid long-latency motor responses.
Description B: The transcortical feedback pathway hinders rapid long-latency motor responses.

Description A: Movement disorders such as Parkinson disease involve cognitive and affective changes.
Description B: Movement disorders such as Parkinson disease do not involve cognitive and affective changes.

Description A: Synaptic function is a common physiological point that many different disease conditions converge on.
Description B: Genetic variance is a common physiological point that many different disease conditions converge on.

Description A: Aging and neurodegenerative disorders bring about synaptic loss through gradual alterations in protein and RNA homeostasis.
Description B: Aging and neurodegenerative disorders bring about synaptic improvement through gradual alterations in protein and RNA homeostasis.

Description A: The motor unit is the basic unit of motor function, consisting of a motor neuron and the group of muscle fibers it innervates.
Description B: The motor neuron is the basic unit of motor function, consisting solely of a group of muscle fibers.

Description A: Smooth muscle is used primarily for internal actions such as peristalsis and control of blood flow.
Description B: Smooth muscle is used primarily for external actions such as movement of limbs.

Description A: Myasthenia Gravis is a well-studied example of a neuromuscular junction disease.
Description B: Myasthenia Gravis is unrelated to neuromuscular junction diseases.

Description A: Disorders of the motor unit can be grouped into motor neuron diseases, peripheral neuropathies, neuromuscular junction disorders, and myopathies.
Description B: Disorders of the motor unit can only be grouped into myopathies.

Description A: Peripheral neuropathies involve both sensory and motor neurons.
Description B: Peripheral neuropathies involve only the sensory neurons.

Description A: In motor neuron diseases, the motor neurons and motor tracts in the spinal cord degenerate, while sensory nerves are spared.
Description B: In motor neuron diseases, both motor and sensory neurons degenerate.

Description A: Diseases of skeletal muscle can be inherited or acquired.
Description B: Diseases of skeletal muscle can only be inherited.

Description A: The smallest motor units are the first to be recruited during voluntary movements.
Description B: The largest motor units are the first to be recruited during voluntary movements.

Description A: When a peripheral nerve is cut, the muscles it innervates become paralyzed and waste progressively.
Description B: When a peripheral nerve is cut, the muscles it innervates grow stronger.

Description A: The contraction of skeletal muscles is a major task of the brain's information processing.
Description B: The relaxation of skeletal muscles is a major task of the brain's information processing.

Description A: In 1925, Charles Sherrington introduced the term motor unit.
Description B: In 1925, Charles Sherrington introduced the term sensory unit.

Description A: Motor neuron diseases do not affect sensory neurons, such as in the case of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.
Description B: Motor neuron diseases affect both motor and sensory neurons, such as in the case of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

Description A: The term 'atrophy' refers to the wasting away of once-normal muscle.
Description B: The term 'atrophy' refers to the strengthening and growth of muscle.

Description A: In humans, the amygdala is necessary for fear responses to external, but not internal, stimuli.
Description B: In humans, the amygdala is necessary for fear responses to internal, but not external, stimuli.

Description A: The human amygdala is involved in emotions broadly, including when subjects observe pictures of stimuli associated with food, sex, and money.
Description B: The human amygdala is involved only in negative emotions and does not respond when subjects observe stimuli associated with food, sex, and money.

Description A: Patients with damage to the amygdala show no conditioned skin-conductance responses to a CS but have normal declarative memory of the conditioning experience.
Description B: Patients with damage to the amygdala show normal conditioned skin-conductance responses to a CS but have no declarative memory of the conditioning experience.

Description A: Emotions like fear can be regulated through cognitive strategies, which involve changes in amygdala activation.
Description B: Emotions like fear cannot be regulated through cognitive strategies and remain constant irrespective of amygdala activation.

Description A: Patients with bilateral amygdala lesions are impaired in recognizing fear from facial expressions.
Description B: Patients with bilateral amygdala lesions have no difficulty recognizing fear from facial expressions.

Description A: The amygdala interacts with the ventral striatum in motivational consequences of Pavlovian conditioning.
Description B: The amygdala interacts only with the hippocampus and not with the ventral striatum in motivational consequences of Pavlovian conditioning.

Description A: Studies show that the amygdala is involved in both positive and negative emotional processing.
Description B: Studies show that the amygdala is only involved in negative emotional processing and not positive.

Description A: Emotion can influence decision making by modulating the subjective evaluation of risk, effort, and value.
Description B: Emotion does not influence decision making with regard to the subjective evaluation of risk, effort, and value.

Description A: Patients with hippocampal damage show normal implicit emotional learning but have no conscious memory of the conditioning experience.
Description B: Patients with hippocampal damage show no implicit emotional learning and have conscious memory of the conditioning experience.

Description A: The circuitry underlying fear extinction is highly relevant to psychiatric illnesses like PTSD.
Description B: The circuitry underlying fear extinction is not relevant to psychiatric illnesses like PTSD.

Description A: The amygdala is a component of a distributed neural network that processes cues related to addictive drugs.
Description B: The amygdala functions independently of other neural networks and does not process cues related to addictive drugs.

Description A: Emotion regulation strategies can involve both suppressing motor behaviors and controlling how situations are evaluated.
Description B: Emotion regulation strategies can involve only suppressing motor behaviors and not controlling how situations are evaluated.

Description A: Conditioned fear responses are never completely erased during extinction, as shown by the phenomenon of reinstatement.
Description B: Conditioned fear responses can be completely erased during extinction, eliminating any chance of reinstatement.

Description A: The ventromedial prefrontal cortex is involved in various aspects of emotional processing.
Description B: The ventromedial prefrontal cortex has no involvement in emotional processing.

Description A: A dynamic neural substrate for emotion states suggests that individual states result from interactions among multiple brain regions.
Description B: A static neural structure for emotion states suggests that individual states result from only a single specific brain region.

Description A: The subthalamic nucleus receives short-latency excitatory sensory input from the brain stem.
Description B: The subthalamic nucleus receives short-latency inhibitory sensory input from the brain stem.

Description A: Glutamatergic inputs from both cerebral cortex and thalamus impinge on striatal interneurons.
Description B: Glutamatergic inputs from both cerebral cortex and thalamus avoid striatal interneurons.

Description A: Projections from the basal ganglia output nuclei to the thalamus and brain stem are also topographically ordered.
Description B: Projections from the basal ganglia output nuclei to the thalamus and brain stem are randomly ordered.

Description A: The subthalamus receives phasic excitatory signals from the cerebral cortex, thalamus, and brain stem.
Description B: The subthalamus receives phasic inhibitory signals from the cerebral cortex, thalamus, and brain stem.

Description A: An important component of the projections from different functional areas of cerebral cortex makes exclusive contact with specific regions of the basal ganglia input nuclei.
Description B: Projections from different functional areas of cerebral cortex randomly contact regions of the basal ganglia input nuclei.

Description A: The main external sources of input to the striatum also provide parallel inputs to the subthalamic nucleus.
Description B: The main external sources of input to the striatum do not provide parallel inputs to the subthalamic nucleus.

Description A: Dopamine can increase the excitability of medium spiny neurons in the direct pathways while decreasing those in the indirect pathway.
Description B: Dopamine can decrease the excitability of medium spiny neurons in the direct pathways while increasing those in the indirect pathway.

Description A: The concept of parallel projecting reentrant loops has been extended to include connections with motivational structures in the brain stem.
Description B: The concept of parallel projecting reentrant loops has not been considered for connections with motivational structures in the brain stem.

Description A: Signals received by the striatum from the cerebral cortex and thalamus are conveyed by excitatory glutamatergic neurotransmission.
Description B: Signals received by the striatum from the cerebral cortex and thalamus are conveyed by inhibitory glutamatergic neurotransmission.

Description A: The basal ganglia output neurons project to thalamic regions that project back to basal ganglia input nuclei.
Description B: The basal ganglia output neurons project to thalamic regions but do not project back to basal ganglia input nuclei.

Description A: The connections between the cerebral cortex and basal ganglia can be viewed as a series of reentrant parallel projecting, partly segregated c. loops.
Description B: The connections between the cerebral cortex and basal ganglia can be viewed as a single non-segregated continuum.

Description A: Output projections of the basal ganglia are extensively collateralized, contacting targets in the thalamus, midbrain, and hindbrain.
Description B: Output projections of the basal ganglia are linear, contacting only direct targets without collateralization.

Description A: Extended reentrant loop organization is a dominant feature characterizing the basal ganglia connections with external structures.
Description B: Reentrant loop organization is rarely observed in the basal ganglia connections with external structures.

Description A: Ventral midbrain dopamine neurons receive input from external structures and other basal ganglia nuclei.
Description B: Ventral midbrain dopamine neurons receive input solely from external structures.

Description A: The reentrant loop architecture through the basal ganglia emphasizes the importance of the thalamic relay position.
Description B: The reentrant loop architecture through the basal ganglia disregards the position of the thalamic relay.

Description A: Bimodal neurons in the ventral intraparietal cortex of a monkey respond to both visual and tactile stimuli.
Description B: Bimodal neurons in the ventral intraparietal cortex of a monkey respond only to tactile stimuli.

Description A: The medial dorsal nucleus inactivation impairs monkeys' ability to identify where their eyes land after a saccade.
Description B: The medial dorsal nucleus activation enhances monkeys' ability to identify where their eyes land after a saccade.

Description A: Lesions in the parietal cortex cause a neglect of the contralateral visual world.
Description B: Lesions in the parietal cortex enhance perception of the contralateral visual world.

Description A: Neurons in the face region of area 3a in the somatosensory cortex have a representation of the position of the eye in the orbit.
Description B: Neurons in the face region of area 3a in the somatosensory cortex have no representation of the position of the eye in the orbit.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area respond to targets for eye movements and objects of visual attention.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area respond solely to auditory stimuli.

Description A: Neurons in the ventral intraparietal area have tactile receptive fields on the face.
Description B: Neurons in the ventral intraparietal area have tactile receptive fields on the hands.

Description A: The parietal cortex sums a number of different signals to create a priority map of the visual field.
Description B: The parietal cortex ignores visual signals in creating a priority map of the visual field.

Description A: Visual information provided by the parietal cortex enables the motor system to adjust hand grip to match the size of the object.
Description B: Visual information provided by the parietal cortex has no influence on hand grip.

Description A: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area respond to targets for grasping even in total darkness.
Description B: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area need visual cues to respond to targets for grasping.

Description A: Neurons in the medial intraparietal area have a representation of arm position.
Description B: Neurons in the medial intraparietal area have no representation of arm position.

Description A: Attention is the ability of the brain to select objects in the world for further analysis.
Description B: Attention prevents the brain from selecting objects in the world for analysis.

Description A: Patients with lesions in inferior temporal cortex adjust their grip perfectly well even though they cannot describe the size of the object.
Description B: Patients without lesions in inferior temporal cortex adjust their grip poorly even though they can describe the size of the object.

Description A: Saccades actively maintain perceptual continuity.
Description B: Saccades disrupt perceptual continuity.

Description A: The ventral intraparietal area projects to the mouth area of premotor cortex.
Description B: The ventral intraparietal area projects to the foot area of premotor cortex.

Description A: The lateral intraparietal area integrates information from different signals to create a priority map.
Description B: The lateral intraparietal area disregards different signals and creates a random map.

Description A: Size constancy refers to the perceptual constancy where an object placed at different distances from an observer is perceived as having the same size.
Description B: Size constancy refers to the perceptual constancy where an object placed at various positions in the visual field is perceived as having different sizes.

Description A: Position constancy entails recognizing objects as the same regardless of their location in the visual field.
Description B: Position constancy means objects are perceived as different depending on their color change in the visual field.

Description A: Viewpoint invariance refers to the perceptual constancy of three-dimensional objects observed from different angles.
Description B: Viewpoint invariance means that when switching angles, some past visibility of features is retained regardless of new viewing angles.

Description A: Perceptual constancy involves invariant attributes being represented independently of other image properties.
Description B: Perceptual constancy implies that invariant attributes are constantly changing with other image properties.

Description A: Neurons in anterior face patches exhibit great robustness to changes in viewpoint.
Description B: Neurons in posterior face patches exhibit great robustness to changes in viewpoint.

Description A: Categorical perception is classically defined as the ability to distinguish objects of different categories better than objects of the same category.
Description B: Categorical perception is classically defined as the ability to recognize objects of the same category better than objects of different categories.

Description A: Studies of conditions under which viewpoint invariance fails may lead to insights into the neural mechanisms of behavior.
Description B: Studies of conditions under which viewpoint invariance succeeds always provide insight into neural mechanisms of behavior.

Description A: Carl Olson and colleagues examined the responses of neurons in a particular region of the inferior temporal cortex to stimuli that were mirror images.
Description B: Carl Olson and colleagues studied neurons exclusively in the frontal cortex to analyze mirror image responses.

Description A: Visual memory influences the processing of incoming visual information and object recognition relies on past experiences.
Description B: Visual memory does not influence the processing of incoming visual information or object recognition.

Description A: Population responses in posterior face areas contain more information about head orientation than those in anterior areas.
Description B: Population responses in anterior face areas contain more information about head orientation than those in posterior areas.

Description A: Inferior temporal cortex neurons do not exhibit viewpoint invariance and are systematically tuned to viewing angles.
Description B: Inferior temporal cortex neurons exhibit viewpoint invariance and are unsystematically tuned to viewing angles irrespective of changes.

Description A: The visual system attempts to generalize across different retinal images generated by a single object.
Description B: The visual system discourages generalization across different retinal images generated by a single object.

Description A: Face-selective cells in the temporal cortex meet the criterion for category-selective neurons.
Description B: Face-selective cells in the prefrontal cortex meet the criterion for category-selective neurons.

Description A: Studies have shown familiarization with novel faces alters tuning of face-selective neurons in inferior temporal cortex.
Description B: Studies have shown familiarization with novel faces does not alter tuning of face-selective neurons in the occipital cortex.

Description A: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex exhibit category-selective responses linked to behavioral significance of stimuli.
Description B: Neurons in inferior temporal cortex exhibit category-selective responses linked primarily to non-behavioral features of stimuli.

Description A: In Plato’s “Allegory of the Cave,” the prisoners' experience is limited to shadows cast upon the wall of the cave by objects passing before a fire.
Description B: In Plato’s “Allegory of the Cave,” the prisoners' experience is limited to reflections in water by objects present under sunlight.

Description A: Metaphorically, in Plato's allegory, the shadows represent sensations, which are fleeting and incoherent.
Description B: Metaphorically, in Plato's allegory, the shadows represent memories, which are enduring and coherent.

Description A: The returning prisoner represents the field of modern neuroscience, shedding light on the relationship between sensations and perceptual experience.
Description B: The returning prisoner represents the discipline of modern philosophy, shedding light on the relationship between thoughts and language.

Description A: John Gardner’s tale of Grendel captures perceptual experience as a construct that we impose.
Description B: John Gardner’s tale of Grendel captures perceptual experience as a construct that nature imposes.

Description A: Modern neuroscience promises a mountaintop understanding of perceptual experience, explaining how we construct things from our sensations.
Description B: Modern neuroscience promises an understanding of how we construct memories from our intuitive dreams.

Description A: Vision acquires information through properties of light reflected from objects in the environment.
Description B: Vision acquires information through properties of sound emitted by objects in the environment.

Description A: The chapters survey mechanisms that enable stimulus detection and discrimination.
Description B: The chapters survey mechanisms that enable emotional control and suppression.

Description A: Environmental stimuli such as light, sound, gravity, touch, and chemicals are the origins of human experience.
Description B: Environmental stimuli such as sound, heat, chaos, taste, and magnetism are the origins of cosmic experience.

Description A: Perceptual processes fill evanescent sensations with meaning.
Description B: Perceptual processes fill inherent thoughts with silence.

Description A: The prisoner in Plato's Cave has been freed to witness a larger world of causes.
Description B: The prisoner in Plato's Cave has been trapped to witness an inner world of effects.

Description A: Grendel sees the world as do the shackled prisoners in Plato’s Cave, sensing mere shadows.
Description B: Grendel sees the world as a free traveler in Plato's Cave, sensing colorful images.

Description A: This section on perception offers a mountaintop view of understanding sensory modalities.
Description B: This section on perception offers a basement view of understanding sensory modalities.

Description A: Grendel believes that 'the mountains are what I define them as.'
Description B: Grendel believes that 'the oceans are what nature defines them as.'

Description A: The operations that support attention, decision, and action are based on what is perceived.
Description B: The operations that support memory, fear, and dream are based on imagination.

Description A: Light reflected from objects varies in wavelength and intensity, fluctuating over space and time.
Description B: Light emitted from objects varies in taste and color, remaining constant over dimensions.

Description A: Pharmacological blockade of NMDA receptors with drugs like ketamine produces symptoms resembling schizophrenia.
Description B: Pharmacological blockade of NMDA receptors with drugs like ketamine alleviates symptoms of schizophrenia.

Description A: The GABAA receptor is an ionotropic receptor that directly opens a Cl− channel.
Description B: The GABAA receptor is a metabotropic receptor that activates a second-messenger cascade.

Description A: NMDA receptor malfunction has been implicated in schizophrenia.
Description B: NMDA receptor malfunction has been associated with reducing symptoms of schizophrenia.

Description A: GABA acts on both ionotropic and metabotropic receptors.
Description B: GABA acts only on ionotropic receptors.

Description A: Antibodies to the NMDA receptor reduce levels of the receptor in the membrane in anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.
Description B: Antibodies to the NMDA receptor increase levels of the receptor in the membrane in anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.

Description A: Glycine receptors are composed of three α- and two β-subunits.
Description B: Glycine receptors are composed of two α- and three β-subunits.

Description A: The binding of benzodiazepines stabilizes the GABAA receptor-channel in the open state.
Description B: The binding of benzodiazepines destabilizes the GABAA receptor-channel in the open state.

Description A: AMPA receptors allow sodium and potassium ions to flow through during low-frequency synaptic transmission.
Description B: NMDA receptors allow sodium and potassium ions to flow through during low-frequency synaptic transmission.

Description A: Zolpidem binds selectively to GABAA receptors containing the α1-subunit.
Description B: Zolpidem binds selectively to GABAA receptors containing the α2-subunit.

Description A: Familial startle disease is characterized by abnormally high muscle tone and exaggerated responses to noise.
Description B: Familial startle disease is characterized by decreased muscle tone and muted responses to noise.

Description A: Missense mutations in the glycine receptor α-subunit can underlie familial startle disease.
Description B: Missense mutations in the glycine receptor β-subunit can underlie familial startle disease.

Description A: Benzodiazepines include diazepam, lorazepam, and clonazepam.
Description B: Benzodiazepines include phenobarbital, secobarbital, and zolpidem.

Description A: The pores of NMDA receptor-channels are blocked by Mg2+ at negative membrane potentials.
Description B: The pores of NMDA receptor-channels are blocked by Ca2+ at negative membrane potentials.

Description A: The M2 helix forms the lining of the channel pore in GABAA receptor subunits.
Description B: The M3 helix forms the lining of the channel pore in GABAA receptor subunits.

Description A: Strychnine blocks the glycine receptor and decreases inhibition, leading to convulsions.
Description B: Strychnine enhances the glycine receptor and increases inhibition, preventing convulsions.

Description A: The T1R1-T1R3 umami receptor is more frequently found in fungiform papillae.
Description B: The T1R1-T1R3 umami receptor is more frequently found in circumvallate papillae.

Description A: Domestic cats do not have a functional sweet receptor.
Description B: Domestic cats do not have a functional umami receptor.

Description A: A genetic knockout of T1R1 selectively abolishes umami taste.
Description B: A genetic knockout of T1R1 selectively abolishes sweet taste.

Description A: Humans have 28 T2R genes.
Description B: Humans have 50 T2R genes.

Description A: In primates, neurons transmit gustatory information directly to the taste area of the thalamus.
Description B: In primates, neurons transmit gustatory information directly to the gustatory cortex.

Description A: Bitter tastants can elicit the same perceptual bitter taste quality.
Description B: Bitter tastants can elicit different perceptual taste qualities.

Description A: Otopetrin-1 is the sour-sensing ion channel in the taste system.
Description B: Otopetrin-1 is the sweet-sensing ion channel.

Description A: IMP potentiates the responsiveness of T1R1/T1R3 to l-amino acids.
Description B: IMP potentiates the responsiveness of T1R1/T1R3 to glucose.

Description A: Taste cells expressing T2R receptors are found in circumvallate papillae in mice.
Description B: Taste cells expressing T2R receptors are found in fungiform papillae in mice.

Description A: A single taste bud can contain taste cells of all types such as sweet, umami, and bitter.
Description B: A single taste bud can contain only one type of taste cell.

Description A: Bitter taste has evolved as an aversive signal of toxic molecules.
Description B: Bitter taste has evolved as an attractive signal of nutritious molecules.

Description A: T2R receptors recognize chemicals with high-affinity binding in the micromolar range.
Description B: T2R receptors recognize chemicals with high-affinity binding in the millimolar range.

Description A: A knockout of Otop1 in mice eliminates acid responses from sour taste receptor cells.
Description B: A knockout of Otop1 in mice eliminates sweet responses from sour taste receptor cells.

Description A: The giant panda lacks a functional umami receptor.
Description B: The giant panda lacks a functional sweet receptor.

Description A: The gustatory cortex mediates the conscious perception and discrimination of taste stimuli.
Description B: The gustatory cortex mediates the unconscious perception and discrimination of taste stimuli.

Description A: Ion channels are integral membrane proteins composed of several subunits.
Description B: Ion channels are peripheral membrane proteins composed of several subunits.

Description A: Ion channels often have carbohydrate groups attached to their external surface.
Description B: Ion channels do not have carbohydrate groups attached to their external surface.

Description A: The genes for all the major classes of ion channels have been cloned and sequenced.
Description B: The genes for all the minor classes of ion channels have been cloned and sequenced.

Description A: Regions that show a high degree of sequence similarity are likely to be important in determining the structure and function of the channel.
Description B: Regions that show a low degree of sequence similarity are likely to be important in determining the structure and function of the channel.

Description A: Chimeric channels can be constructed using parts derived from the genes of different species.
Description B: Chimeric channels can be constructed using parts derived from the genes of the same species.

Description A: Site-directed mutagenesis involves substituting or deleting specific amino acid residues.
Description B: Site-directed mutagenesis involves adding new amino acid residues.

Description A: Ion Channels Can Be Grouped Into Gene Families.
Description B: Ion Channels Cannot Be Grouped Into Gene Families.

Description A: Our human genome contains nine genes encoding variants of voltage-gated Na+ channels.
Description B: Our human genome contains ninety genes encoding variants of voltage-gated Na+ channels.

Description A: Voltage-gated Na+ and Ca2+ channels are composed of a large subunit containing four repeats of a basic motif.
Description B: Voltage-gated Na+ and Ca2+ channels are composed of a large subunit containing two repeats of a basic motif.

Description A: The S4 segment contains an unusual pattern of amino acids where every third position contains a positively charged arginine or lysine residue.
Description B: The S4 segment contains an unusual pattern of amino acids where every third position contains a negatively charged glutamic acid or aspartic acid residue.

Description A: Voltage-gated K+ channels are tetramers, with each subunit containing one copy of the basic motif.
Description B: Voltage-gated K+ channels are pentamers, with each subunit containing one copy of the basic motif.

Description A: Most voltage-sensitive cation channels stem from a common ancestral channel.
Description B: Most voltage-sensitive cation channels are unrelated to any ancestral channel.

Description A: A gap-junction channel is composed of two hemi-channels, one from each connected cell.
Description B: A gap-junction channel is composed of one hemi-channel, disconnected from any other cell.

Description A: The ligand-gated ion channels are receptors for neurotransmitters such as ACh, GABA, glycine, or serotonin.
Description B: The ligand-gated ion channels are receptors for neurotransmitters such as glucose, fructose, or galactose.

Description A: Each superfam­ily of ion channel genes is thought to have evolved from a common ancestral gene by gene duplication and divergence.
Description B: Each superfam­ily of ion channel genes is thought to have originated independently without any ancestral genes.

Description A: Blind people are able to walk normally and reach and grasp known objects with ease, despite visual impairment.
Description B: Blind people are unable to walk normally and cannot reach and grasp known objects, despite visual impairment.

Description A: Peripheral neuropathies can lead to clumsy, uncoordinated, and inaccurate movements.
Description B: Peripheral neuropathies lead to highly coordinated and accurate movements.

Description A: Patients with proprioceptive loss struggle with movements involving rapid direction reversals.
Description B: Patients with proprioceptive loss excel at movements involving rapid direction reversals.

Description A: Proprioception and tactile sense are critical for sensorimotor control.
Description B: Proprioception and tactile sense are irrelevant for sensorimotor control.

Description A: Reinforcement learning can be more general than error-based learning because it focuses on success or failure rather than specific errors.
Description B: Reinforcement learning is less general than error-based learning because it focuses on specific errors rather than success or failure.

Description A: Model-free reinforcement learning avoids the computational burden of building a model, but is less able to generalize to new situations.
Description B: Model-free reinforcement learning efficiently builds models but struggles with simple task generalization.

Description A: Motor learning improves motor control in novel situations and relies on different forms of sensory information.
Description B: Motor learning is mostly ineffective in improving motor control in novel situations, regardless of sensory information.

Description A: The state of the body is estimated using both sensory and motor signals together with a forward predictive mode to reduce feedback delays.
Description B: The state of the body is estimated only using motor signals, ignoring sensory input completely.

Description A: Motor planning uses the redundancy of the motor system to reduce motor noise and effort.
Description B: Motor planning ignores the redundancy of the motor system, leading to increased effort.

Description A: Reinforcement signals in the basal ganglia are tied to dopamine systems.
Description B: Reinforcement signals in the basal ganglia are independent of dopamine systems.

Description A: Patients lacking proprioception cannot make an accurate movement that requires a rapid reversal in path when their hand is hidden from view.
Description B: Patients lacking proprioception often excel at making accurate movements that require rapid reversals in path, even when their hand is hidden from view.

Description A: Even with full vision, making a task difficult can happen if tactile feedback is removed.
Description B: Tactile feedback has negligible impact on task difficulty as long as vision is perfect.

Description A: Variability in sensorimotor transformations can lead to trade-offs between speed and accuracy in movements.
Description B: Sensorimotor transformation variability consistently leads to improved speed and accuracy.

Description A: Motor control undergoes continual modification and recalibration throughout life.
Description B: Motor control remains static and unchanging throughout life.

Description A: The motor systems generate commands using feedforward circuits or error-correcting feedback circuits.
Description B: The motor systems generate commands using only feedforward circuits and avoid feedback entirely.

Description A: Munc18 is an essential protein for SNARE-mediated intracellular fusion reactions.
Description B: Synaptotagmin is an essential protein for SNARE-mediated intracellular fusion reactions.

Description A: The SNARE complex consists of a bundle of four α-helixes.
Description B: The SNARE complex consists of a bundle of six α-helixes.

Description A: Synaptotagmin-1, -2, and -9 are identified as Ca2+ sensors for fast vesicle fusion.
Description B: Synaptotagmin-3, -4, and -8 are identified as Ca2+ sensors for fast vesicle fusion.

Description A: Calcium binding to synaptotagmin triggers vesicle fusion through interaction with phospholipids.
Description B: Calcium binding to syntaxin triggers vesicle fusion through interaction with phospholipids.

Description A: NSF binds to SNARE complexes via an adaptor protein called SNAP.
Description B: NSF binds to SNARE complexes via an adaptor protein called SNAP-25.

Description A: Deletion of Munc18 prevents all synaptic fusion in neurons.
Description B: Deletion of synaptotagmin prevents all synaptic fusion in neurons.

Description A: The SNARE cycle involves dissociation of the complex in an ATP-dependent reaction.
Description B: The SNARE cycle involves dissociation of the complex in a GTP-dependent reaction.

Description A: Synaptotagmin proteins function as Ca2+ sensors in endocrine cells.
Description B: Complexin proteins function as Ca2+ sensors in endocrine cells.

Description A: Synaptotagmin-7 mediates slower Ca2+-triggered exocytosis during prolonged activity.
Description B: Synaptotagmin-1 mediates slower Ca2+-triggered exocytosis during prolonged activity.

Description A: Achieving a full understanding of neural mechanisms to maintain memories over a lifetime is a daunting scientific challenge.

Description A: The highest realms of conscious knowledge involve the knowledge of oneself as an individual.
Description B: The highest realms of conscious knowledge involve the knowledge of one's physical abilities.

Description A: The retina's output is conveyed to the brain by just one million optic nerve fibers.
Description B: The retina's output is conveyed to the brain by just one billion optic nerve fibers.

Description A: The retina is composed of five major cell types arranged in three cellular layers.
Description B: The retina is composed of three major cell types arranged in five cellular layers.

Description A: The photoreceptor cells in the outermost layer absorb light and convert it into a neural signal.
Description B: The photoreceptor cells in the innermost layer absorb light and convert it into a neural signal.

Description A: Retinal ganglion cells are the output neurons of the retina, and their axons form the optic nerve.
Description B: Retinal ganglion cells are the input neurons of the retina, and their axons form the optic nerve.

Description B: The retina performs high-level visual processing and does not adjust its sensitivity to changing illumination.

Description A: Visual information lost in the retina cannot be recovered.
Description B: Visual information lost in the retina can be easily recovered.

Description A: The pupil forms a variable aperture in the eye.
Description B: The lens forms a variable aperture in the eye.

Description A: Phototransduction links the absorption of a photon to a change in membrane conductance.
Description B: Phototransduction links the absorption of a photon to a change in temperature.

Description A: There are two types of photoreceptors: rods and cones.
Description B: There are three types of photoreceptors: rods, cones, and fibers.

Description A: Ganglion cells transmit neural images to the brain.
Description B: Amacrine cells transmit neural images to the brain.

Description A: The output of ganglion cells emphasizes temporal changes in stimuli.
Description B: The output of ganglion cells emphasizes spatial constancy in stimuli.

Description B: Spatial filtering is accomplished by increasing contrast.

Description B: The primary genetic defect in myotonic dystrophy is a recessively transmitted expansion of a triplet of base pairs (CTG) in myotonin kinase gene on chromosome 19.

Description A: Dysferlin and caveolin-3 are central to generating rafts of vesicles that coalesce and repair muscle membrane breaches.
Description B: Dysferlin and caveolin-3 are central to generating nuclear bindings that coalesce and repair muscle fiber tears.

Description B: Laminin α2 and dystrophin defects also cause muscular dystrophies by affecting the cytoplasm.

Description A: In myotonic dystrophy, muscle stiffness is due to excessive electrical discharges associated with muscle contractions.
Description B: In myotonic dystrophy, muscle stiffness is due to lack of electrical discharges associated with muscle relaxations.

Description B: The EMG in myotonic dystrophy shows absent action potentials during muscle relapses.

Description B: Emery-Dreifuss dystrophy is associated with defects in the proteins emerin and caveolin-3.

Description B: Myotonic dystrophy includes symptoms like cataracts, bone fragility, and reduced white blood cell count.

Description A: Becker dystrophy results from a deletion of four exons, leading to a milder form of the disease.

Description A: Some limb-girdle muscular dystrophy genes are dominantly transmitted.
Description B: Some limb-girdle muscular dystrophy genes are transmitted exclusively through maternal lines.

Description A: Skeletal muscle actin is associated with nemaline rod myopathy.
Description B: Skeletal muscle actin is associated with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Description A: Distal (Udd) dystrophy is associated with defects in the protein titin.
Description B: Distal (Udd) dystrophy is associated with defects in the protein dystrophin.

Description A: Mutations in dystrophin-associated proteins can lead to muscular dystrophies.
Description B: Mutations in ribosomal proteins can lead to muscular dystrophies.

Description A: Myotonic dystrophy is characterized by the 'warm-up' phenomenon where stiffness improves with activity.
Description B: Myotonic dystrophy is characterized by the 'cool-down' phenomenon where stiffness worsens with activity.

Description A: Ryanodine receptor defects are linked to central core disease and malignant hyperthermia.
Description B: Ryanodine receptor defects are linked to limb-girdle muscular dystrophy and rigid spine syndrome.

Description A: The receptive fields of cortical neurons are much larger than those of somatosensory fibers in peripheral nerves.
Description B: The receptive fields of cortical neurons are much smaller than those of somatosensory fibers in peripheral nerves.

Description A: The barrel cortex in rodents represents the vibrissae in topographic patterns.
Description B: The barrel cortex in rodents represents the auditory inputs in topographic patterns.

Description A: Rodents rhythmically sweep their whiskers across objects similarly to how humans use their fingertips.
Description B: Rodents use their feet similarly to how humans use their fingertips to explore objects.

Description B: Multiple whiskers map onto a single cluster of excitatory neurons in cortical layer IV called a barrel.

Description B: Neurons in area 3b of the primary somatosensory cortex have only excitatory zones within their receptive field.

Description A: The spatial pattern of the whiskers on the face is stereotyped from animal to animal.

Description B: Mice and rats rely more heavily on their sense of vision than on whisker-mediated touch during exploration.

Description A: The receptive fields of neurons can span functional regions of skin activated during motor activity.
Description B: The receptive fields of neurons are always isolated to very specific and unmoving regions of the skin.

Description A: Inputs from SA1 and RA1 touch receptors converge on common neurons in area 3b.
Description B: Inputs from SA1 and RA1 touch receptors diverge to separate neurons in area 3b.

Description A: Neurons in area 2 integrate information about hand shape, grip force, and tactile stimulation.
Description B: Neurons in area 2 respond only to visual information about hand shape.

Description A: Inhibitory receptive fields result from connections through interneurons that limit the spread of excitation.
Description B: Inhibitory receptive fields result from a lack of connections, allowing unrestrained neuronal activity.

Description A: The rat somatosensory cortex is thicker than the primary visual cortex of the cat.
Description B: The rat somatosensory cortex is thinner than the primary visual cortex of the cat.

Description A: Vibrissae and fingertips afford similar psychophysical thresholds and discriminative sensitivities despite structural differences.
Description B: Vibrissae and fingertips afford completely different psychophysical thresholds and discriminative sensitivities due to their structural differences.

Description A: Neurons in areas 1 and 2 of S-I are concerned with information more abstract than innervation sites.
Description B: Neurons in areas 1 and 2 of S-I are concerned with purely physical innervation sites.

Description A: The representation of the largest whiskers in rodent S-I is enlarged relative to other body parts.
Description B: The representation of the largest whiskers in rodent S-I is minimized relative to other body parts.

Description A: The psychometric function plots the percentage of stimuli detected by a human observer as a function of the stimulus magnitude.
Description B: The psychometric function plots the percentage of stimuli detected by a human observer as a function of time.

Description A: Threshold is defined as the stimulus intensity detected on 50% of the trials.
Description B: Threshold is defined as the stimulus intensity detected on 25% of the trials.

Description A: Sensory thresholds are typically determined statistically by presenting a subject with a series of stimuli of random amplitude.
Description B: Sensory thresholds are typically determined by presenting a subject with a series of stimuli of fixed amplitude.

Description A: The method of limits involves subjects reporting the intensity at which a progressively decreasing stimulus is no longer detectable.
Description B: The method of limits involves subjects reporting the intensity at which a steadily increasing stimulus becomes detectable.

Description A: A neural code describes the relationship between activity in a specified neural population and its functional consequences for perception or action.
Description B: A neural code describes the relationship between the amplitude of a stimulus and its psychological impact.

Description A: The neural coding of sensory information is better understood at the early stages of processing than at later stages in the brain.
Description B: The neural coding of sensory information is better understood at the later stages of processing than at early stages in the brain.

Description A: Experimental animals can be trained to respond to controlled sensory stimuli using devices that allow measurement of decision times.
Description B: Experimental animals cannot be trained to respond to controlled sensory stimuli due to their inability to understand decision times.

Description A: In signal detection theory, sensitivity is defined as the number of true positives divided by the number of stimuli presented.
Description B: In signal detection theory, sensitivity is defined as the number of false positives divided by the total number of responses.

Description A: Discriminability in studies is measured with ROC analyses that compare the neural firing rates or choice probability evoked by pairs of stimuli.
Description B: Discriminability in studies is measured with ROC analyses that compare the reaction times of subjects.

Description A: The area under the ROC curve provides an accurate estimate of d′ for each stimulus pair.
Description B: The area under the ROC curve provides an inaccurate estimate of d′ for each stimulus pair.

Description A: Signal detection methods have been applied to studies of neural responses to visual stimuli that differ in orientation, spatial frequency, or coherence of motion.
Description B: Signal detection methods have not been applied to studies involving neural responses to visual stimuli that differ in orientation.

Description A: Values of AUC close to 1 characterize high sensitivity and high specificity.
Description B: Values of AUC close to 1 characterize low sensitivity and low specificity.

Description A: Neuroscientists can modify activity within sensory circuits by direct stimulation with electrical pulses, chemical neurotransmitters, and modulators.
Description B: Neuroscientists cannot modify activity within sensory circuits by direct stimulation with electrical pulses.

Description A: Charles Bell and Johannes Müller proposed the theory of specificity for sensory systems in the 19th century.
Description B: Charles Bell and Johannes Müller proposed the theory of specificity for sensory systems in the 20th century.

Description A: Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) plots display the results of trials with sensitivity on the vertical axis and false-positive rate on the horizontal axis.
Description B: Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) plots display sensitivity versus specificity on both axes.

Description B: The gaze of individuals with ASD is normal when watching social scenes, often fixating primarily on people's eyes.

Description A: Approximately 10% of individuals with ASD demonstrate savant syndrome, according to widely cited estimates.
Description B: Approximately 90% of individuals with ASD demonstrate savant syndrome, according to widely cited estimates.

Description A: Monozygotic twin pairs show 60% to 90% concordance for ASD, while dizygotic twins show 10% to 30% concordance.
Description B: Monozygotic twin pairs show 10% to 30% concordance for ASD, while dizygotic twins show 60% to 90% concordance.

Description A: Neuropsychological data support the idea that brain regions involved in perception are overfunctioning in savant syndrome.
Description B: Neuropsychological data contradict the idea that brain regions involved in perception are overfunctioning in savant syndrome.

Description A: Individuals with ASD have difficulties suggesting various different uses of a single object irrespective of their IQ.
Description B: Individuals with ASD have no difficulties suggesting various different uses of a single object irrespective of their IQ.

Description A: Researchers found that individuals with ASD fixate on people’s mouths instead of showing the normal preference for eyes.
Description B: Researchers found that individuals with ASD fixate on people's eyes instead of showing the normal preference for mouths.

Description B: Klin et al. 2002 studied the patterns of vocal responses in individuals with autism while reading scripts.

Description A: A preference for manipulating bits of information that fit within a strict framework is one explanation for savant syndrome.
Description B: A preference for manipulating bits of information that fit within loose constraints is one explanation for savant syndrome.

Description A: The male-to-female ratio of individuals with ASD is approximately 4:1.
Description B: The male-to-female ratio of individuals with ASD is approximately 1:4.

Description A: The theory that vaccines contribute to ASD has been thoroughly repudiated by subsequent investigations.
Description B: The theory that vaccines contribute to ASD has been widely validated by subsequent investigations.

Description A: The drawing by the gifted artist with high-functioning autism shows remarkably detailed cityscapes.
Description B: The drawing by the gifted artist with high-functioning autism shows simplistic and abstract cityscapes.

Description B: Approximately 100% of monozygotic twins were found to be concordant for the full diagnosis of autism.

Description A: ASD runs in families, increasing the risk of having a second affected child.
Description B: ASD rarely runs in families, decreasing the risk of having a second affected child.

Description A: Current estimates suggest that if parents have one child with ASD, the risk for ASD in a second child increases 5- to 10-fold.
Description B: Current estimates suggest that if parents have one child with ASD, the risk for ASD in a second child remains unchanged.

Description A: Research has established that monognetic twins share all their DNA while dizygotic twins share as much DNA as any sibling pair.
Description B: Research has established that dizygotic twins share all their DNA while monognetic twins share as much DNA as any sibling pair.

Description A: Inner hair cells form a single row, and the stereocilia of each cell are arranged linearly.

Description A: The hair bundles of outer hair cells are directly deflected by the movement of the tectorial membrane.
Description B: The hair bundles of outer hair cells are not directly deflected by the movement of the tectorial membrane.

Description A: A hair cell’s receptor potential can reach up to 25 mV in peak-to-peak magnitude.
Description B: A hair cell’s receptor potential can reach up to 250 mV in peak-to-peak magnitude.

Description A: The tip link is a molecular braid that promotes channel opening when tensed.

Description A: The transduction channels are located at the stereociliary tips near the lower insertion point of the tip link.

Description B: The relation between a hair-bundle deflection and receptor potential is linear.

Description A: An oblique stimulus elicits a response proportional to its vectorial projection along the axis of sensitivity.
Description B: An oblique stimulus elicits no response, regardless of its orientation along the axis of sensitivity.

Description A: At hearing threshold, a stimulus evokes a receptor potential near 100 μV in amplitude.

Description B: The elasticity of gating springs resides exclusively in the cell body structures apart from the tip links.

Description A: The primary cation carrying most of the transduction current is K+.

Description B: The S-I cortex comprises four distinct cytoarchitectonic regions: Brodmann’s areas 5a, 5b, 1, and 2.

Description B: Tactile information enters the cerebral cortex through the primary motor cortex in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobe.

Description B: The S-II cortex covers Brodmann’s area 33.

Description A: A column comprises an elementary functional module of the neocortex.
Description B: A column comprises a non-functional structure of the neocortex.

Description B: Spiny stellate neurons in layer IV are the only inhibitory cells shown that are not pyramidal neurons.

Description B: Each column in the S-I cortex spans five cortical layers from the pial surface to the white matter.

Description B: Thalamocortical axons are relayed to a wide column of pyramidal cells contacted by layer II cell axons.

Description B: Long-term potentiation in the lateral nucleus of the amygdala is triggered by Na+ influx into the postsynaptic neurons in response to strong synaptic activity.

Description B: Flies cannot be classically conditioned with an odorant without using foot shocks.

Description B: Threat learning in mammals engages parallel pathways from the hippocampus to the amygdala.

Description A: The mushroom bodies in Drosophila receive olfactory input from the antennal lobes.
Description B: The mushroom bodies in Drosophila receive olfactory input from the optic lobes.

Description B: Knockout of a CREB activator gene selectively blocks short-term memory in Drosophila without interfering with long-term memory.

Description A: Dopamine released by the unconditioned stimulus in Drosophila synergistically activates adenylyl cyclase.
Description B: Serotonin released by the unconditioned stimulus in Drosophila synergistically activates adenylyl cyclase.

Description A: The lateral nucleus of the amygdala projects to the central nucleus, the output nucleus of the amygdala.

Description A: In Aplysia, reconsolidation of memory involves a destabilization through protein degradation and then reconsolidation through new protein synthesis.
Description B: In Aplysia, reconsolidation of memory involves a stabilization through protein synthesis without prior degradation.

Description A: Threat learning in mammals causes a mouse to freeze after a neutral tone is associated with a foot shock.
Description B: Threat learning in mammals causes a mouse to flee after a neutral tone is associated with a foot shock.

Description A: Flies injected with a caged derivative of ATP undergo aversive conditioning when dopaminergic neurons are activated by light exposure.
Description B: Flies injected with a caged derivative of serotonin undergo aversive conditioning when dopaminergic neurons are activated by light exposure.

Description A: Studies in awake behaving rodents indicate that threat conditioning requires postsynaptic NMDA receptors in the lateral amygdala.
Description B: Studies in awake behaving rodents indicate that threat conditioning requires postsynaptic AMPA receptors in the lateral amygdala.

Description A: An inward-rectifying K+ channel (GIRK) is opened directly by a G protein. Binding of ACh to a muscarinic receptor causes the Gi protein and αiβγ complex to dissociate; the free βγ-subunits bind to a cytoplasmic domain of the channel, causing the channel to open.
Description B: An inward-rectifying Na+ channel (GIRK) is opened directly by a G protein. Binding of ACh to a muscarinic receptor causes the Gi protein and αiβγ complex to dissociate; the free βγ-subunits bind to a cytoplasmic domain of the channel, causing the channel to open.

Description A: Cerebellar Purkinje neurons and hippocampal pyramidal neurons have distinctive patterns of dendritic branching.
Description B: Cerebellar Purkinje neurons and hippocampal pyramidal neurons have uniform patterns of dendritic branching.

Description A: Semaphorin-3A is an attractant for growing dendrites in the developing neocortex.
Description B: Semaphorin-3A is a repellent for growing dendrites in the developing neocortex.

Description A: In the tiling of dendrites, the inhibitory interactions are among neurons of a particular type.
Description B: In the tiling of dendrites, the inhibitory interactions are among neurons of various types.

Description A: Protocadherin γa1 on one dendrite binds well to the same isoform on another dendrite.
Description B: Protocadherin γa1 on one dendrite binds poorly to the same isoform on another dendrite.

Description A: Drosophila Dscam1 encodes around 38,000 distinct proteins through alternative splicing.
Description B: Drosophila Dscam1 encodes around 800 distinct proteins through alternative splicing.

Description A: Dendrites of each neuron bind homophilically to sibling dendrites, leading to self-avoidance.

Description A: The growth cone at the tip of the axon is responsible for axonal growth.
Description B: The axonal shaft is responsible for axonal growth.

Description A: In neurons, transcription factors control the size and complexity of dendritic arbors.
Description B: In neurons, cytoskeletal proteins control the size and complexity of dendritic arbors.

Description A: Tiling allows neuron types to receive information without dendritic overlap.
Description B: Tiling causes neuron types to receive information with dendritic overlap.

Description A: Neurons must have intrinsic information about their shape, as patterns are reminiscent in tissue culture.
Description B: Neurons have no intrinsic information about their shape, as patterns differ in tissue culture.

Description A: The dendrites of neighboring neurons provide cues for spacing patterns.
Description B: The cell bodies of neighboring neurons provide cues for spacing patterns.

Description A: Several cell-surface adhesion molecules mediate self-avoidance by causing repulsion.
Description B: Several cell-surface adhesion molecules mediate self-avoidance by causing attraction.

Description A: Neurons express a random subset of possible Dscam1 or protocadherin isoforms.
Description B: Neurons express identical sets of possible Dscam1 or protocadherin isoforms.

Description A: The consequence of intercellular interactions is determined by signaling rather than adhesion.
Description B: The consequence of intercellular interactions is determined by adhesion rather than signaling.

Description A: Self-avoidance occurs through branches of the same neuron repelling each other.
Description B: Self-avoidance occurs through branches of different neurons repelling each other.

Description A: The cochlear prosthesis transmits signals across the skin to receiving antennas implanted subdermally behind the auricle, conveyed in a fine cable to an electrode array in the cochlea.
Description B: The cochlear prosthesis transmits signals directly to the cochlear nerve fibers without using an electrode array.

Description A: The organ of Corti contains approximately 16,000 mechanosensory hair cells.
Description B: The organ of Corti contains approximately 1,600 mechanosensory hair cells.

Description A: Hair cells transduce basilar-membrane vibrations into receptor potentials that cause sensory neurons to fire.
Description B: Hair cells directly transmit electrical signals to the brain without involving receptor potentials.

Description A: The frequency components of a sound stimulus are detected at different locations along the basilar membrane.

Description A: Hair cells can respond to sound frequencies beyond 100 kHz in some mammalian species.

Description A: Hair cells project a tuft of cylindrical stereocilia from their apical surface.
Description B: Hair cells are devoid of stereocilia and directly detect sound vibrations.

Description A: Hair cells uniquely amplify their inputs to enhance sensitivity and widen the range of detectable stimulus levels.

Description A: Mammals most notably differ from other groups in that their hearing range extends to frequencies beyond 12 to 14 kHz.

Description A: Sensorineural hearing loss is currently treated mostly with hearing aids or cochlear prostheses.
Description B: Sensorineural hearing loss is primarily treated with medication and does not involve cochlear prostheses.

Description A: The cerebellum is important for motor control and some nonmotor functions.
Description B: The cerebellum is only important for nonmotor functions and not motor control.

Description A: Sensory feedback is delayed, so the cerebellum regulates movement by preprogramming commands before feedback arrives.

Description A: Lesions of the cerebral cortex largely prevent movement.

Description A: Cerebellar damage causes greater inaccuracy in multi-joint movements than single-joint movements.

Description B: Cerebellum-dependent learning has no effect on predictions of vestibular input during head movement.

Description A: Cerebellar lesions make tapping movements with hands irregular in rhythm.
Description B: Cerebellar lesions make tapping movements with hands perfectly rhythmic.

Description A: Climbing fibers can selectively induce long-term depression in synapses between parallel fibers and Purkinje cells.

Description B: Climbing fiber activity prevents signaling error even when unexpected resistance is encountered.

Description A: Long-term depression of the synaptic input from parallel fibers to Purkinje cells is a plausible mechanism for cerebellar learning.
Description B: Long-term enhancement of the synaptic input from parallel fibers to Purkinje cells is a plausible mechanism for cerebellar learning.

Description A: The nicotinic ACh receptor is an ionotropic receptor that directly opens an ion channel.
Description B: The nicotinic ACh receptor is a metabotropic receptor that indirectly opens an ion channel.

Description A: Action potentials in axons trigger the release of acetylcholine by causing the fusion of synaptic vesicles at active zones.
Description B: Action potentials in axons inhibit the release of acetylcholine by preventing the fusion of synaptic vesicles at active zones.

Description A: The synaptic cleft at the neuromuscular junction is approximately 100 nm wide.
Description B: The synaptic cleft at the neuromuscular junction is approximately 100 micrometers wide.

Description A: Schwann cells partially enwrap the nerve terminal at the neuromuscular junction.
Description B: Schwann cells are absent at the neuromuscular junction.

Description A: The ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction are packed at the crests of secondary folds.
Description B: The ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction are randomly distributed throughout the muscle surface.

Description A: Acetylcholinesterase rapidly hydrolyzes acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.
Description B: Acetylcholinesterase slowly hydrolyzes acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.

Description A: Synaptic boutons contain machinery for synthesis and release of acetylcholine.
Description B: Synaptic boutons lack machinery for synthesis and release of acetylcholine.

Description A: The end-plate potential can be calculated from an equivalent circuit.
Description B: The end-plate potential is unpredictable and cannot be calculated.

Description A: The neurotransmitter acetylcholine is released in discrete packets at the synapse.
Description B: Acetylcholine is released continuously at the synapse.

Description A: The ion channel at the end-plate is permeable to both sodium and potassium ions.
Description B: The ion channel at the end-plate is only permeable to potassium ions.

Description A: Muscle innervation in adults is restricted to one site called the motor end-plate.
Description B: Muscle innervation in adults occurs at multiple random sites across the surface.

Description A: Acetylcholine receptors are ionotropic and mediate a local change in membrane permeability.
Description B: Acetylcholine receptors are metabotropic and do not change membrane permeability.

Description A: The EPSP at a nerve-muscle synapse can be as large as 75 mV.
Description B: The EPSP at a nerve-muscle synapse typically does not exceed 10 mV.

Description A: Synthetic agents that activate nicotinic ACh receptors can be useful therapeutic agents.
Description B: Synthetic agents that activate nicotinic ACh receptors are generally toxic and not used therapeutically.

Description A: The high-resolution structure of the acetylcholine receptor-channel is revealed by X-ray crystal studies.
Description B: The high-resolution structure of the acetylcholine receptor-channel has not been determined.

Description A: Substance P is released from the central terminals of nociceptive afferents in response to tissue injury.
Description B: Substance P is released from the peripheral terminals of nociceptive afferents in response to tissue injury.

Description A: Glutamate is the primary neurotransmitter of all primary sensory neurons, regardless of sensory modality.
Description B: GABA is the primary neurotransmitter of all primary sensory neurons, regardless of sensory modality.

Description A: Substance P activates the neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptor, which is expressed by neurons in the superficial dorsal horn.
Description B: Substance P activates the serotonin receptor, which is expressed by neurons in the superficial dorsal horn.

Description A: Many neurons in laminae VII and VIII respond to noxious stimuli.
Description B: Neurons in laminae I and II respond to noxious stimuli.

Description A: Substance P is a member of the neurokinin peptide family.
Description B: Substance P is a member of the opioid peptide family.

Description A: Hyperalgesia can be elicited by sensitizing peripheral nociceptors through repetitive exposure to noxious stimuli.
Description B: Hyperalgesia can be elicited by desensitizing peripheral nociceptors.

Description A: Substance P is stored in large, dense-core vesicles at the central terminals of nociceptive sensory neurons.
Description B: Substance P is stored in small, electron-lucent vesicles at the central terminals of nociceptive sensory neurons.

Description A: The activation of lamina VII neurons contributes to the diffuse quality of many pain conditions.
Description B: The activation of lamina V neurons contributes to the diffuse quality of many pain conditions.

Description A: Neuropeptides are released as cotransmitters by many nociceptors with unmyelinated axons.
Description B: Neuropeptides are released as cotransmitters by many nociceptors with myelinated axons.

Description A: Infusion of substance P coupled to a neurotoxin results in the selective destruction of neurons with neurokinin receptors.
Description B: Infusion of substance P coupled to a neurotoxin results in the selective destruction of neurons with mu-opioid receptors.

Description A: Neurons in lamina VI are activated by innocuous joint movement and do not contribute to the transmission of nociceptive information.
Description B: Neurons in lamina VI are activated by nociceptive stimuli and contribute to the transmission of nociceptive information.

Description A: Separate storage sites permit glutamate and neuropeptides to be selectively released under different physiological conditions.
Description B: Mixed storage sites prevent glutamate and neuropeptides from being selectively released under different physiological conditions.

Description A: The μ-opioid receptor, targeted by enkephalins, is expressed presynaptically on the terminals of sensory neurons.
Description B: The μ-opioid receptor, targeted by enkephalins, is expressed postsynaptically on the terminals of sensory neurons.

Description A: Referred pain can occur due to the convergence of visceral and somatic afferent fibers on the same projection neurons in the dorsal horn.
Description B: Referred pain occurs due to the separate transmission pathways of visceral and somatic afferent fibers in the dorsal horn.

Description A: Neurons in lamina V receive input from large-diameter myelinated Aβ mechanoreceptive fibers.
Description B: Neurons in lamina V receive input from small-diameter unmyelinated Aβ mechanoreceptive fibers.

Description A: Leptin and insulin are humoral signals sensed by receptors in the arcuate nucleus and the nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS) to reduce food intake and increase energy expenditure.
Description B: Leptin and insulin are humoral signals sensed by receptors in the arcuate nucleus and the nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS) to increase food intake and decrease energy expenditure.

Description A: AgRP neurons promote hunger by releasing factors that inhibit PVH-MC4R satiety neurons and also directly inhibit POMC neurons.
Description B: AgRP neurons promote satiety by releasing factors that enhance PVH-MC4R satiety neurons and also directly activate POMC neurons.

Description A: POMC neurons release α-melanocyte-stimulating hormone (αMSH), which activates melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4R) and decreases hunger.
Description B: POMC neurons release α-melanocyte-stimulating hormone (αMSH), which inhibits melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4R) and increases hunger.

Description A: Environmental cues predicting food induce inhibition of AgRP neurons even in fasted mice, acting as anticipatory signals.
Description B: Environmental cues predicting food induce activation of AgRP neurons even in fed mice, acting as anticipatory signals.

Description A: The PVH-MC4R satiety neurons decrease hunger via excitatory projections to the lateral parabrachial nucleus.
Description B: The PVH-MC4R satiety neurons increase hunger via inhibitory projections to the lateral parabrachial nucleus.

Description A: Optogenetic stimulation of AgRP neurons induces hyperphagia even in calorically replete mice.
Description B: Optogenetic stimulation of POMC neurons induces hyperphagia even in calorically replete mice.

Description A: The arcuate nucleus contains VGLUT2 neurons that release glutamate to induce satiety.
Description B: The arcuate nucleus contains AgRP neurons that release glutamate to induce satiety.

Description A: Fasting activates AgRP neurons, which promote hunger, while feeding inhibits them.
Description B: Fasting inhibits AgRP neurons, which promote satiety, while feeding activates them.

Description A: Genetic ablation of AgRP neurons in mice causes starvation due to lack of hunger promotion.
Description B: Genetic ablation of AgRP neurons in mice causes obesity due to excessive hunger promotion.

Description A: Leptin treatment inhibits AgRP neurons while activating POMC neurons, reducing hunger.
Description B: Leptin treatment activates AgRP neurons while inhibiting POMC neurons, increasing hunger.

Description A: While genetic deficiency of POMC or MC4R causes obesity, their absence leads to reduced activation of satiety mechanisms.
Description B: While genetic deficiency of POMC or MC4R causes obesity, their absence leads to reduced activation of hunger mechanisms.

Description A: Short-term signals like CCK promote satiation during meals by stimulating vagus nerve sensory fibers.
Description B: Short-term signals like ghrelin promote satiation during meals by stimulating vagus nerve sensory fibers.

Description A: AgRP neurons release GABA, NPY, and AgRP to inhibit MC4R-expressing neurons and promote hunger.
Description B: AgRP neurons release glutamate, NPY, and leptin to activate MC4R-expressing neurons and promote satiety.

Description A: Drive reduction theory suggests that deficiency states create aversive conditions which motivate behavior to resolve discomfort.
Description B: Drive reduction theory suggests that deficiency states create pleasurable conditions which motivate behavior to amplify the discomfort.

Description A: Satiety-promoting POMC neurons release αMSH, which activates MC4R in PVH neurons to decrease hunger.
Description B: Satiety-promoting POMC neurons release αMSH, which inhibits MC4R in PVH neurons to increase hunger.

Description A: Broca’s Aphasia Results From a Large Lesion in the Left Frontal Lobe.
Description B: Broca’s Aphasia Results From a Large Lesion in the Right Parietal Lobe.

Description A: The Left Hemisphere Is Dominant for Language.
Description B: The Right Hemisphere Is Dominant for Language.

Description A: Transcortical Aphasias Result From Damage to Areas Near Broca’s and Wernicke’s Areas.
Description B: Transcortical Aphasias Result From Damage to Areas Near the Occipital Lobe.

Description A: Wernicke’s Aphasia Results From Damage to Left Posterior Temporal Lobe Structures.
Description B: Wernicke’s Aphasia Results From Damage to Right Anterior Temporal Lobe Structures.

Description A: A New Model for the Neural Basis of Language Has Emerged.
Description B: An Old Model for the Neural Basis of Language Has Emerged.

Description A: Studies of the Aphasias Have Provided Insights into Language Processing.
Description B: Studies of the Aphasias Have Provided No Insights into Language Processing.

Description A: Language Has Many Structural Levels: Phonemes, Morphemes, Words, and Sentences.
Description B: Language Has a Single Structural Level: Each Word Stands Alone.

Description A: Successful Bilingual Learning Depends on the Age at Which the Second Language Is Learned.
Description B: Successful Bilingual Learning Is Independent of the Age at Which the Second Language Is Learned.

Description A: The Visual System Is Engaged in Language Production and Perception.
Description B: The Visual System Is Not Involved in Language Production and Perception.

Description A: The Left Hemisphere Is Dominant for Language.
Description B: The Right Hemisphere Is Dominant for Language.

Description A: Language Acquisition in Children Follows a Universal Pattern.
Description B: Language Acquisition in Children Is Random and Without Pattern.

Description A: The Neural Architecture for Language Develops Rapidly During Infancy.
Description B: The Neural Architecture for Language Develops Slowly During Middle Age.

Description A: Global Aphasia Results From Widespread Damage to Several Language Centers.
Description B: Global Aphasia Results From Damage Limited to the Auditory Cortex.

Description A: Prosodic Cues Are Learned as Early as In Utero.
Description B: Prosodic Cues Are Learned Only After Birth.

Description A: The “Universalist” Infant Becomes Linguistically Specialized by Age 1.
Description B: The “Universalist” Infant Becomes Linguistically Specialized by Age 5.

Description A: Numerous Specialized Cortical Regions Contribute to Language Processing.
Description B: Only the Broca’s Area Contributes to Language Processing.

Description A: The therapeutic action of most antipsychotic drugs is due to their ability to block D2 dopamine receptors.
Description B: The therapeutic action of most antipsychotic drugs is due to their ability to block D1 dopamine receptors.

Description A: Clozapine has greater efficacy than other antipsychotic drugs and was reintroduced in the late 1980s with weekly monitoring of white blood cells.
Description B: Clozapine has the same efficacy as other antipsychotic drugs and was introduced in the late 1980s without any monitoring requirements.

Description A: Chlorpromazine, the first effective antipsychotic drug, was initially developed for its antihistaminic and sedating effects.
Description B: Chlorpromazine, the first effective antipsychotic drug, was originally developed to treat Parkinson's disease.

Description A: The liability of second-generation antipsychotic drugs for causing Parkinson-like motor side effects is lower than first-generation drugs.
Description B: The liability of second-generation antipsychotic drugs for causing Parkinson-like motor side effects is higher than first-generation drugs.

Description A: Evidence suggests that schizophrenia may involve hyperactivity in subcortical dopaminergic systems and hypoactivity in cortical regions.
Description B: Evidence suggests that schizophrenia solely involves hyperactivity in cortical dopaminergic systems.

Description A: Antipsychotic drugs are effective at reducing hallucinations and delusions but do not improve cognitive impairments in schizophrenia.
Description B: Antipsychotic drugs are equally effective at reducing hallucinations, delusions, and cognitive impairments in schizophrenia.

Description A: Schizophrenia is hypothesized to be linked to excessive synaptic pruning during adolescence in the prefrontal cortex.
Description B: Schizophrenia is hypothesized to be linked to the growth of additional synaptic connections during adolescence.

Description A: Postmortem studies reveal gray matter loss in the prefrontal and temporal cerebral cortex in schizophrenia.
Description B: Postmortem studies reveal no significant gray matter changes in the cerebral cortex in schizophrenia.

Description A: D1 dopamine receptors in the prefrontal cortex are associated with working memory and executive functions.
Description B: D1 dopamine receptors in the prefrontal cortex are primarily associated with reducing motor symptoms.

Description A: Large-scale clinical trials have shown that the efficacy of second-generation antipsychotic drugs is no greater than that of first-generation drugs.
Description B: Large-scale clinical trials have shown that second-generation antipsychotic drugs are drastically more effective than first-generation drugs.

Description A: The mechanism by which clozapine has superior efficacy compared to other antipsychotics is not fully understood.
Description B: The mechanism by which clozapine has superior efficacy is entirely understood and attributed solely to serotonin receptor binding.

Description A: Some antipsychotic drugs cause Parkinson-like motor symptoms by decreasing dopaminergic transmission.
Description B: Some antipsychotic drugs cause Parkinson-like motor symptoms by increasing dopaminergic transmission.

Description A: Amphetamine-induced dopamine release was found to be greater in individuals with schizophrenia compared to healthy subjects.
Description B: Amphetamine-induced dopamine release was found to be lower in individuals with schizophrenia compared to healthy subjects.

Description A: Schizophrenia is characterized by dramatic psychotic symptoms and deficits in cognition, emotion, and motivation.
Description B: Schizophrenia is exclusively characterized by dramatic cognitive impairment without any psychotic symptoms.

Description A: The discovery of chlorpromazine's psychotic symptom-reducing effects was initially unexpected.
