Description A: Rods are responsible for vision under dim illumination such as moonlight.
Description B: Cones are responsible for vision under dim illumination such as moonlight.

Description A: Cones make no contribution to night vision and are solely responsible for vision in daylight.
Description B: Cones make a significant contribution to night vision and are solely responsible for vision in daylight.

Description A: Primates have only one type of rod but three kinds of cone photoreceptors.
Description B: Primates have three types of rod photoreceptors but only one kind of cone photoreceptor.

Description A: The inner segment of photoreceptor cells contains mitochondria and machinery for protein synthesis.
Description B: The inner segment of photoreceptor cells contains the light-transducing apparatus.

Description A: The outer segment of rods contains free-floating discs within the cytoplasmic space.
Description B: The outer segment of cones contains free-floating discs within the cytoplasmic space.

Description A: Rods and cones differ in their sensitivity to light, with rods being able to signal the absorption of a single photon.
Description B: Rods and cones differ in their sensitivity to light, with cones being able to signal the absorption of a single photon.

Description A: Light must traverse several layers of cells to reach the photoreceptors in most of the retina.
Description B: Light immediately reaches the photoreceptors without crossing any cellular layers in most of the retina.

Description A: The foveola at the center of the fovea has cellular layers pushed aside to reduce light scattering.
Description B: The foveola at the center of the fovea has dense layers of cellular structures that increase light scattering.

Description A: The optic disc is devoid of photoreceptors and corresponds to the blind spot in the visual field.
Description B: The optic disc is densely packed with photoreceptors and corresponds to the sharp vision area in the visual field.

Description A: Rods cease to respond to variations in light intensity as the light level increases toward dawn.
Description B: Rods continue to respond to variations in light intensity even when the light level increases toward dawn.

Description A: The retina contains two types of photoreceptors: rods and cones.
Description B: The retina contains three types of photoreceptors: rods, cones, and ganglion cells.

Description A: The spacing between photoreceptors in the fovea matches the size of the optical blur circle.
Description B: The spacing between photoreceptors in the fovea is significantly mismatched to the size of the optical blur circle.

Description A: The black pigment epithelium in the retina absorbs light to keep it from scattering back into the eye.
Description B: The black pigment epithelium in the retina reflects light to enhance vision clarity.

Description A: In the adult mammalian brain, long-distance neuronal migration occurs.
Description B: In the adult mammalian brain, short-distance neuronal migration occurs.

Description A: Chondroitinase ABC promotes functional recovery after spinal cord injury.
Description B: Chondroitinase ABC hinders functional recovery after spinal cord injury.

Description A: During the earliest phase of the EPSP, the membrane potential is still close to its resting value, El.
Description B: During the earliest phase of the EPSP, the membrane potential is far from its resting value, El.

Description A: The inward synaptic current leaves the cell as outward current through two parallel pathways.
Description B: The inward synaptic current leaves the cell only through a single pathway.

Description A: As the concentration of ACh in the synapse decreases, the ACh receptor-channels begin to close.
Description B: As the concentration of ACh in the synapse increases, the ACh receptor-channels begin to close.

Description A: When the EPSP is at its peak or steady-state value, Ic = 0.
Description B: When the EPSP is at its peak or steady-state value, Ic = 1.

Description A: In the peak EPSP calculation, gEPSP = 5 × 10−6 S and gl = 1 × 10−6 S.
Description B: In the peak EPSP calculation, gEPSP = 10 × 10−6 S and gl = 5 × 10−6 S.

Description A: The peak voltage of the EPSP is a weighted average of the electromotive forces of the two batteries.
Description B: The peak voltage of the EPSP is not influenced by the electromotive forces of the two batteries.

Description A: Most of the outward current leaves the cell as capacitive current during the earliest phase of the EPSP.
Description B: Most of the outward current leaves the cell as ionic current during the earliest phase of the EPSP.

Description A: The current through the ACh receptor-channels is given by Ohm’s law: IEPSP = gEPSP × (Vm − EEPSP).
Description B: The current through the ACh receptor-channels is independent of Ohm’s law: IEPSP = gEPSP + (Vm × EEPSP).

Description A: As the ACh receptor-channels close, IEPSP decreases further.
Description B: As the ACh receptor-channels close, IEPSP increases further.

Description A: When IEPSP and Il are no longer in balance, the membrane potential starts to repolarize.
Description B: When IEPSP and Il are no longer in balance, the membrane potential starts to depolarize.

Description A: Ic, the capacitive current, is directly proportional to the rate of change of membrane potential.
Description B: Ic, the capacitive current, is inversely proportional to the rate of change of membrane potential.

Description A: The weighted average of conductances affects how closely Vm approaches the value of EEPSP.
Description B: The weighted average of conductances does not affect how closely Vm approaches the value of EEPSP.

Description A: The peak amplitude of the EPSP is calculated as ΔVEPSP = Vm − El = −15 mV − (−90 mV) = 75 mV.
Description B: The peak amplitude of the EPSP is calculated as ΔVEPSP = Vm − El = −15 mV − (0 mV) = 75 mV.

Description A: During most of the declining phase, the ACh receptor-channels carry no current because they are all closed.
Description B: During most of the declining phase, the ACh receptor-channels carry significant current despite being closed.

Description A: Current is conducted through the membrane mostly as outward current during the declining phase.
Description B: Current is conducted through the membrane mostly as inward current during the declining phase.

Description A: Higher centers in the brain use inhibitory circuits to focus attention on relevant information from the hand when it is used in skilled tasks.
Description B: Lower centers in the brain use inhibitory circuits to focus attention on relevant information from the hand when it is used in skilled tasks.

Description A: Cortical receptive fields are formed during development and maintained by simultaneous activation of the input pathways.
Description B: Cortical receptive fields are destroyed during development and maintained by simultaneous activation of the input pathways.

Description A: Somatosensory information is conveyed in parallel from the four areas of S-I to higher centers in the cortex.
Description B: Somatosensory information is conveyed in parallel only within the primary motor cortex.

Description A: S-II is located on the upper bank and adjacent parietal operculum of the lateral sulcus in humans and monkeys.
Description B: S-II is located on the lower bank and adjacent parietal operculum of the lateral sulcus in humans and monkeys.

Description A: The receptive fields of neurons in S-II are larger than those in S-I.
Description B: The receptive fields of neurons in S-II are smaller than those in S-I.

Description A: Neurons in S-II send copies of the spike trains evoked by the first stimulus to the prefrontal and premotor cortex.
Description B: Neurons in S-II send copies of the spike trains evoked by the first stimulus to the cerebellum and thalamus.

Description A: S-II neurons abstract temporal or intensive properties of the vibratory stimulus, firing at different mean rates for different frequencies.
Description B: S-II neurons do not abstract temporal or intensive properties, firing at identical rates for all frequencies.

Description A: S-II plays key roles in tactile recognition of objects placed in the hand, distinguishing spatial features such as shape and texture.
Description B: S-II plays no role in tactile recognition of objects placed in the hand, distinguishing spatial features such as shape and texture.

Description A: S-I neurons fire brief spike bursts in phase with each vibratory cycle.
Description B: S-I neurons fire continuous spike bursts regardless of vibratory cycles.

Description A: Somatosensory information abstraction occurs in higher-order cortical areas based on sensory features independent of the stimulus position in their receptive field.
Description B: Somatosensory information abstraction occurs in higher-order cortical areas only when stimulus position in their receptive field matches the sensory features.

Description A: An S-I neuron’s response to touch depends primarily on input from within the neuron’s receptive field.
Description B: An S-I neuron’s response to touch does not depend on input from within the neuron’s receptive field.

Description A: S-II responses to vibration depend on the stimulus context: the same vibratory stimulus can evoke different firing rates.
Description B: S-II responses to vibration are independent of the stimulus context: the same vibratory stimulus always evokes the same firing rate.

Description A: Higher centers in the brain utilize top-down cognitive processes like goal-setting.
Description B: Higher centers in the brain neglect top-down cognitive processes like goal-setting.

Description A: Extensive stimulation of afferent pathways through repeated practice may strengthen synaptic inputs.
Description B: Extensive stimulation of afferent pathways through repeated practice weakens synaptic inputs.

Description A: The physiological responses of S-II neurons to motion and vibration are influenced by the large receptive fields.
Description B: The physiological responses of S-II neurons to motion and vibration are unaffected by the large receptive fields.

Description A: Dendrites contain voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels in addition to ligand-gated channels and resting channels.
Description B: Dendrites contain only ligand-gated channels and resting channels, lacking voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels.

Description A: Backpropagating action potentials rely on the activation of voltage-gated Na+ channels in dendrites.
Description B: Backpropagating action potentials rely purely on passive properties of dendrites, without involvement of voltage-gated Na+ channels.

Description A: Axosomatic IPSPs are more effective than axodendritic IPSPs in inhibiting action potential firing in the postsynaptic cell.
Description B: Axodendritic IPSPs are more effective than axosomatic IPSPs in inhibiting action potential firing in the postsynaptic cell.

Description A: NMDA spikes are purely local events and cannot propagate actively without synaptic stimulation.
Description B: NMDA spikes can actively propagate along the dendrite without requiring synaptic stimulation.

Description A: A single strong EPSP at a proximal dendrite site can produce a single action potential at the axon initial segment.
Description B: A single strong EPSP at a proximal dendrite site can produce multiple action potentials at the axon initial segment.

Description A: 95% of all excitatory inputs in the brain terminate on dendritic spines.
Description B: 95% of all excitatory inputs in the brain terminate on dendritic shafts.

Description A: Spines serve as sites where information about presynaptic and postsynaptic activity is integrated.
Description B: Spines restricts the integration of information about presynaptic and postsynaptic activity.

Description A: Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels and NMDA receptors are involved in the formation of plateau potentials.
Description B: Voltage-gated K+ channels and NMDA receptors are involved in the formation of plateau potentials.

Description A: Axodendritic IPSPs are more effective in preventing local dendritic depolarization than axosomatic IPSPs.
Description B: Axosomal IPSPs are more effective in preventing local dendritic depolarization than axodendritic IPSPs.

Description A: Active conductances in dendrites can switch between passive and active integration based on precise timing and strength of synaptic inputs.
Description B: Active conductances in dendrites remain fixed and do not switch between passive and active integration.

Description A: Dendritic spines can implement synapse-specific local learning rules.
Description B: Dendritic spines have no role in implementing synapse-specific local learning rules.

Description A: Backpropagating action potentials paired with presynaptic stimulation result in greater Ca2+ signals than linear summation.
Description B: Backpropagating action potentials paired with presynaptic stimulation result in smaller Ca2+ signals than linear summation.

Description A: Voltage-gated Na+ or Ca2+ channels can produce nonlinear electrical responses in dendrites.
Description B: Voltage-gated K+ channels can produce nonlinear electrical responses in dendrites.

Description A: The number of voltage-gated channels in dendrites is usually not sufficient to support regenerative propagation of action potential to the cell body.
Description B: The number of voltage-gated channels in dendrites is sufficient to support regenerative propagation of action potential to the cell body.

Description A: Spines help localize activity-dependent changes and restrict them to the synapses that are activated.
Description B: Spines distribute activity-dependent changes broadly across all synapses.

Description A: In myelinated nerves, action potentials are regenerated at the nodes of Ranvier.
Description B: In myelinated nerves, action potentials are regenerated at the internodal regions.

Description A: The density of membrane current is much higher at the nodes of Ranvier than in the internodal regions.
Description B: The density of membrane current is much higher in the internodal regions than at the nodes of Ranvier.

Description A: Saltatory conduction is favorable from a metabolic standpoint because less energy is expended by the Na+-K+ pump.
Description B: Saltatory conduction is metabolically unfavorable because more energy is expended by the Na+-K+ pump.

Description A: In demyelinated axons, the spread of the action potential is slowed down or blocked.
Description B: In demyelinated axons, the spread of the action potential is accelerated.

Description A: The action potential in a myelinated axon moves by saltatory conduction.
Description B: The action potential in a myelinated axon moves by continuous conduction.

Description A: Conduction velocities vary depending on axon diameter and degree of myelination.
Description B: Conduction velocities are consistent regardless of axon diameter and degree of myelination.

Description A: Diseases like multiple sclerosis and Guillain-Barré syndrome are caused by demyelination.
Description B: Diseases like multiple sclerosis and Guillain-Barré syndrome are caused by over-myelination.

Description A: Myelinated axons involved in rapid sensory computations generally have high conduction rates.
Description B: Myelinated axons involved in rapid sensory computations generally have low conduction rates.

Description A: The Na+-K+ pump exchanges three intracellular Na+ ions for two extracellular K+ ions.
Description B: The Na+-K+ pump exchanges two intracellular Na+ ions for three extracellular K+ ions.

Description A: When a cell is at rest, the charge separation across the membrane remains constant.
Description B: When a cell is at rest, the charge separation across the membrane varies significantly.

Description A: Action potentials are continually regenerated along the axon, thus conducted without attenuation.
Description B: Action potentials are not regenerated along the axon, thus always subject to attenuation.

Description A: Membrane potential is determined by the ion or ions with the greatest membrane conductances.
Description B: Membrane potential is determined by the ion or ions with the least membrane conductances.

Description A: For rapid signaling pathways, conduction is enhanced by myelination of the axon.
Description B: For rapid signaling pathways, conduction is hindered by myelination of the axon.

Description A: Ion channels typically produce negligible changes in the bulk concentrations of ions.
Description B: Ion channels typically produce significant changes in the bulk concentrations of ions.

Description A: Ion pumps prevent the ionic batteries from running down due to passive fluxes through ion channels.
Description B: Ion pumps do not play a role in preventing the ionic batteries from running down.

Description A: The tip link is composed of protocadherin 15 and cadherin 23 molecules connected in a heterophilic association.
Description B: The tip link is composed of protocadherin 15 and cadherin 23 molecules connected in a homophilic association.

Description A: Hair cells in the cochlea are stimulated when the basilar membrane is driven up and down by differences in pressure between the scala vestibuli and scala tympani.
Description B: Hair cells in the cochlea are stimulated when the basilar membrane is driven sideways by differences in temperature between the scala vestibuli and scala tympani.

Description A: TMC1 and TMC2 are localized near the lower insertion point of the tip link and are thought to form part of the transduction channel complex.
Description B: TMC1 and TMC2 are localized near the upper insertion point of the tip link and are thought to form part of the transduction channel complex.

Description A: Mutations in the genes coding for cadherin 23 and protocadherin 15 lead to Usher syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder associated with deafness and retinitis pigmentosa.
Description B: Mutations in the genes coding for cadherin 23 and protocadherin 15 lead to Marfan syndrome, a disorder unrelated to deafness or retinitis pigmentosa.

Description A: The tension in an elastic element called the gating spring controls the opening and closing of the transduction channels in hair cells.
Description B: The tension in an elastic element called the gating spring controls the movement of the basilar membrane in the cochlea.

Description A: The hair bundles of outer hair cells are attached to the lower surface of the tectorial membrane and are deflected by shearing movements.
Description B: The hair bundles of inner hair cells are attached to the tectorial membrane and are deflected by shearing movements.

Description A: In the absence of LHFPL5, the conductance of the transduction channel is reduced but significant transduction currents can still be measured.
Description B: In the absence of LHFPL5, the conductance of the transduction channel is entirely abolished and no transduction currents are observed.

Description A: Lowering extracellular Ca2+ concentration below 1 μM can disrupt the association of cadherin 23 and protocadherin 15 in the tip link.
Description B: Increasing extracellular Ca2+ concentration above 1 μM can disrupt the association of cadherin 23 and protocadherin 15 in the tip link.

Description A: For mammals to respond to frequencies greater than 100 kHz, hair cells display gating times that are an order of magnitude smaller than 80 μs.
Description B: For mammals to respond to frequencies greater than 100 kHz, hair cells display gating times that are an order of magnitude larger than 80 μs.

Description A: Hair cells must transduce acoustic waveforms with microsecond-level resolution to enable sound source localization based on delays as small as 10 μs.
Description B: Hair cells must transduce acoustic waveforms with millisecond-level resolution to enable sound source localization based on delays as small as 10 μs.

Description A: Harmonin facilitates the anchoring of cadherin 23 to the actin core of stereocilia in the hair cells.
Description B: Harmonin facilitates the binding of protocadherin 15 to the actin core of stereocilia in the hair cells.

Description A: In vestibular hair cells, myosin 1c may set the tip link under tension, but its role in cochlear cells is uncertain.
Description B: In vestibular hair cells, myosin 7a sets the tip link under tension, while myosin 1c plays no role in cochlear cells.

Description A: The molecular motor myosin 7a is part of the protein complex anchoring the upper end of the tip link to actin in cochlear hair cells.
Description B: The molecular motor myosin 7a is part of the protein complex anchoring the lower end of the tip link to actin in cochlear hair cells.

Description A: The optimal auditory communication frequency range for most mammals is 10 Hz to 100 kHz.
Description B: The optimal auditory communication frequency range for most mammals is 1 Hz to 10 kHz.

Description A: In auditory hair cells, the transduction channels are believed to be opened by tension transmitted through the tip links upon mechanical deflection.
Description B: In auditory hair cells, the transduction channels are permanently open, irrespective of tension or mechanical deflection.

Description A: Loss of the gag reflex on one side of the throat indicates injury to the medulla or to cranial nerve X on that side.
Description B: Loss of the gag reflex on one side of the throat indicates injury to cranial nerve IX and the facial nerve.

Description A: Spontaneous facial expressions are virtually always symmetric due to pattern generator neurons in the brain stem.
Description B: Spontaneous facial expressions are asymmetric and controlled by neurons in the cerebral hemispheres.

Description A: The gag reflex involves reversal of peristalsis and closure of the airway.
Description B: The gag reflex involves dilation of pharyngeal muscles and opening of the airway.

Description A: Vomiting is mediated by pattern generator neurons in the ventrolateral medulla.
Description B: Vomiting is mediated by pattern generator neurons exclusively in the prefrontal cortex.

Description A: The baroreceptor reflex ensures adequate blood flow to the brain by mediating effects through cranial nerves IX and X.
Description B: The baroreceptor reflex ensures adequate blood flow to the brain by mediating effects through cranial nerve XI only.

Description A: Breathing movements are generated automatically by the brain stem, starting at 11 to 13 weeks of gestation in humans.
Description B: Breathing movements are generated automatically by the cerebellum, starting at 16 to 18 weeks of gestation in humans.

Description A: The pre-Bötzinger complex generates respiratory rhythm in the medulla.
Description B: The pre-Bötzinger complex generates respiratory rhythm in the hypothalamus.

Description A: Hypoxia stimulates breathing by affecting peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies.
Description B: Hypoxia inhibits breathing by affecting peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies.

Description A: Serotonergic neurons along penetrating arteries in the medulla are sensitive to acidosis and play a role in CO2 reflexes.
Description B: Serotonergic neurons along penetrating arteries in the medulla are sensitive to high oxygen levels but not acidosis.

Description A: Cheyne-Stokes respiration is characterized by cycles of increasing and decreasing ventilation alternating with apnea.
Description B: Cheyne-Stokes respiration is characterized by consistent and uninterrupted ventilation without cycles.

Description A: Acute destruction of the pre-Bötzinger complex results in inability to maintain normal respiratory rhythm.
Description B: Acute destruction of the dorsal respiratory group leads to inability to maintain normal respiratory rhythm.

Description A: In decerebrate rats, neurons in the reticular areas enable appropriate food rejection behaviors.
Description B: In decerebrate rats, neurons in the corpus callosum enable appropriate food rejection behaviors.

Description A: Central chemoreceptors in the medulla respond to elevated CO2 and accompanying pH decrease.
Description B: Central chemoreceptors in the medulla respond exclusively to decreased oxygen levels.

Description A: Neurons in the retrotrapezoid nucleus of the medulla are highly sensitive to CO2 levels.
Description B: Neurons in the retrotrapezoid nucleus of the medulla are highly sensitive to oxygen levels only.

Description A: Surface neurons in the ventral medulla and pyramidal tracts monitor CO2 changes to regulate respiration.
Description B: Surface neurons in the ventral medulla and pyramidal tracts monitor oxygen changes exclusively.

Description A: The innervation number in human skeletal muscles ranges from 5 for an eye muscle to 1,800 for a leg muscle.
Description B: The innervation number in human skeletal muscles ranges from 50 for an eye muscle to 18,000 for a leg muscle.

Description A: The strongest motor unit in the hand’s first dorsal interosseous muscle can exert approximately the same force as the average motor unit in the leg’s medial gastrocnemius muscle.
Description B: The weakest motor unit in the hand’s first dorsal interosseous muscle can exert approximately the same force as the average motor unit in the leg’s medial gastrocnemius muscle.

Description A: The muscle fibers in a cross-section through the middle of an entire muscle are associated with 20 to 50 different motor units.
Description B: The muscle fibers in a cross-section through the middle of an entire muscle are associated with 5 to 15 different motor units.

Description A: The muscle fibers innervated by a single motor unit can be distributed across 8% to 75% of the volume in a limb muscle.
Description B: The muscle fibers innervated by a single motor unit can be distributed across 80% to 100% of the volume in a limb muscle.

Description A: Slow-contracting motor units contain type I muscle fibers, while fast-contracting units include type II fibers.
Description B: Fast-contracting motor units contain type I muscle fibers, while slow-contracting units include type II fibers.

Description A: Hybrid muscle fibers co-express more than one MHC isoform and exhibit contractile properties intermediate between distinct muscle fibers.
Description B: Hybrid muscle fibers express only one MHC isoform and exhibit contractile properties identical to distinct muscle fibers.

Description A: Branches of the median and ulnar nerves in the forearm innervate distinct compartments in three multitendon extrinsic hand muscles.
Description B: Branches of the femoral and tibial nerves in the forearm innervate distinct compartments in three multitendon extrinsic hand muscles.

Description A: The mechanical response to a single action potential is referred to as a twitch contraction.
Description B: The mechanical response to a series of action potentials is referred to as a twitch contraction.

Description A: Type II muscle fibers in fast-contracting motor units can be further classified as type IIa (less fatigable) or type IIb (more fatigable).
Description B: Type II muscle fibers in fast-contracting motor units can be further classified as type IIc (less fatigable) or type IIz (more fatigable).

Description A: Maximal muscle force in slow-contracting motor units is achieved at lower action potential rates compared to fast-contracting motor units.
Description B: Maximal muscle force in fast-contracting motor units is achieved at lower action potential rates compared to slow-contracting motor units.

Description A: The force exerted during a tetanic contraction depends on the rate at which the action potentials are evoked and the contraction time of the motor unit.
Description B: The force exerted during a tetanic contraction depends solely on the amplitude of action potentials.

Description A: The recruitment order of motor units during voluntary contraction starts with slow-contracting, low-force units.
Description B: The recruitment order of motor units during voluntary contraction starts with fast-contracting, high-force units.

Description A: Histochemical stains for myosin ATPase can identify type I (low ATPase levels) and type II (high ATPase levels) muscle fibers.
Description B: Histochemical stains for myosin ATPase can identify type III (medium ATPase levels) and type IV (low ATPase levels) muscle fibers.

Description A: Motor units in humans typically produce low forces and have intermediate contraction times.
Description B: Motor units in humans typically produce high forces and have prolonged contraction times.

Description A: Muscle fibers in slow-contracting motor units express MHC-I, whereas those in highly fatigable fast-contracting units express MHC-IIX.
Description B: Muscle fibers in slow-contracting motor units express MHC-IIX, whereas those in highly fatigable fast-contracting units express MHC-I.

Description A: Some fMRI studies found an intact FFA in patients with prosopagnosia, casting doubt on its necessity for face perception.
Description B: Some fMRI studies found a damaged FFA in all patients with prosopagnosia, confirming its necessity for face perception.

Description A: Later fMRI studies of the healthy human brain helped reveal that the traditional dichotomy between declarative and procedural memory was oversimplified.
Description B: Later fMRI studies of the healthy human brain reaffirmed that the traditional dichotomy between declarative and procedural memory was accurate.

Description A: fMRI studies have shown that tasks thought to rely on declarative memory often recruit regions outside of the hippocampus.
Description B: fMRI studies have shown that tasks thought to rely on declarative memory exclusively recruit the hippocampus.

Description A: fMRI studies using the subsequent memory task revealed differences in the hippocampus and surrounding medial temporal lobe during successful memory formation.
Description B: fMRI studies using the subsequent memory task revealed no differences in the hippocampus and surrounding medial temporal lobe during successful memory formation.

Description A: Central to the theories, midbrain dopaminergic neurons increase their firing in response to unexpected rewards.
Description B: Central to the theories, midbrain dopaminergic neurons decrease their firing in response to unexpected rewards.

Description A: Once a predictive cue has been reliably paired with a reward, the neurons shift their response in time to this predictive cue.
Description B: Once a predictive cue has been reliably paired with a reward, the neurons no longer respond to this predictive cue.

Description A: fMRI findings in humans have been transformative for our understanding of theoretical models of memory.
Description B: fMRI findings in humans have had little impact on our understanding of theoretical models of memory.

Description A: fMRI provides relatively noisy, slow, and indirect measurements of neuronal activity compared to tools available in animals.
Description B: fMRI provides clear, fast, and direct measurements of neuronal activity superior to tools available in animals.

Description A: Functional MRI is the best technology we have so far for probing the healthy human brain.
Description B: Functional MRI is outdated technology compared to current tools for probing the healthy human brain.

Description A: BOLD activity in prefrontal and parietal cortices is predictive of later memory.
Description B: BOLD activity in prefrontal and parietal cortices is unrelated to later memory.

Description A: Forward inference allows researchers to infer that differences in brain activity are related to the mental process of interest.
Description B: Forward inference prevents researchers from inferring that differences in brain activity are related to the mental process of interest.

Description A: Reverse inference in fMRI is often unjustified as it may inaccurately infer mental processes.
Description B: Reverse inference in fMRI is always justified due to its accuracy in inferring mental processes.

Description A: The FFA can be co-opted for recognition of other objects with which we have expertise.
Description B: The FFA is exclusively dedicated to face recognition and cannot be co-opted for other objects.

Description A: Studies have shown that subjects must learn to track the likelihood of reward for each shape through probabilistic associations.
Description B: Studies have shown that subjects cannot learn to track the likelihood of reward for each shape through probabilistic associations.

Description A: Efforts are underway to address the limitations of fMRI, including enhancing temporal and spatial resolution.
Description B: There are no efforts underway to address the limitations of fMRI regarding temporal and spatial resolution.

Description A: Repeated cocaine exposure increases the intrinsic excitability of nucleus accumbens neurons, contributing to reward tolerance.
Description B: Repeated cocaine exposure decreases the intrinsic excitability of nucleus accumbens neurons, reducing reward tolerance.

Description A: Drug-induced LTD-like adaptations in the nucleus accumbens occur coincidently with increased numbers of immature, thin dendritic spines during early withdrawal.
Description B: Drug-induced LTP-like adaptations in the nucleus accumbens occur coincidently with increased numbers of immature, thin dendritic spines during early withdrawal.

Description A: Synaptic plasticity can mediate features of addiction involving maladaptive memories of the association of drug exposure with environmental cues.
Description B: Synaptic plasticity prevents features of addiction involving maladaptive memories of the association of drug exposure with environmental cues.

Description A: CREB and ∆FosB are two transcription factors implicated in drug addiction.
Description B: CREB and ∆FosB are two neurotransmitters implicated in drug addiction.

Description A: Repeated opiate exposure increases the intrinsic excitability of dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area, but impedes dopaminergic transmission to the nucleus accumbens.
Description B: Repeated opiate exposure decreases the intrinsic excitability of dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area, but enhances dopaminergic transmission to the nucleus accumbens.

Description A: NMDA-type glutamate receptors permit Ca2+ entry, which binds calmodulin and activates CaMKII in the cytoplasm and CaMKIV in the cell nucleus.
Description B: NMDA-type glutamate receptors prevent Ca2+ entry, blocking activation of CaMKII in the cytoplasm and CaMKIV in the cell nucleus.

Description A: Natural addictions such as compulsive overeating and gambling may share biological mechanisms with drug addictions.
Description B: Natural addictions such as compulsive overeating and gambling are biologically distinct and unrelated to drug addictions.

Description A: Drug-induced glutamatergic synaptic plasticity occurs in reward-related brain regions such as the ventral tegmental area and nucleus accumbens.
Description B: Drug-induced glutamatergic synaptic plasticity occurs exclusively in the hippocampus and amygdala.

Description A: Expression or knockdown of ∆FosB in mice provides evidence for its role in mediating reward sensitization and drug relapse.
Description B: Expression or knockdown of ∆FosB in mice provides evidence for its role in preventing reward sensitization and drug relapse.

Description A: Long-term potentiation (LTP)-like changes in glutamatergic synapses evolve during prolonged drug withdrawal, weeks to months after early withdrawal periods.
Description B: Long-term depression (LTD)-like changes in glutamatergic synapses evolve during prolonged drug withdrawal, weeks to months after early withdrawal periods.

Description A: M-type channels are partially activated at rest, and their closure in response to muscarinic stimulation causes a decrease in resting K+ conductance.
Description B: M-type channels are fully activated at rest, and their closure in response to muscarinic stimulation causes an increase in resting K+ conductance.

Description A: The fast EPSP is produced by activation of ionotropic nicotinic ACh receptors, and the slow EPSP is produced by activation of metabotropic muscarinic ACh receptors.
Description B: The fast EPSP is produced by activation of metabotropic muscarinic ACh receptors, and the slow EPSP is produced by activation of ionotropic nicotinic ACh receptors.

Description A: The increase in M-type K+ current during prolonged depolarization helps repolarize the membrane below threshold.
Description B: The increase in M-type K+ current during prolonged depolarization maintains the membrane above threshold.

Description A: Muscarinic receptor activation leads to the closing of M-type K+ channels due to decreased levels of PIP2.
Description B: Muscarinic receptor activation leads to the opening of M-type K+ channels due to increased levels of PIP2.

Description A: G protein βγ-subunits directly bind to GIRK channels to modulate their opening.
Description B: G protein βγ-subunits indirectly modulate GIRK channels through second messengers.

Description A: ACh decreases the outward K+ current by closing partially open M-type K+ channels at rest.
Description B: ACh increases the outward K+ current by opening partially closed M-type K+ channels at rest.

Description A: Spike-frequency adaptation occurs when the slow activation of M-type K+ channels generates an outward current during depolarization.
Description B: Spike-frequency adaptation occurs when the rapid closure of M-type K+ channels generates an inward current during depolarization.

Description A: M-type K+ channel closure can lead to a small depolarization at the peak of slow EPSP.
Description B: M-type K+ channel closure can lead to a large hyperpolarization at the peak of slow EPSP.

Description A: In certain neurons, GIRK channels decrease the intrinsic firing rate by hyperpolarizing the membrane.
Description B: In certain neurons, GIRK channels increase the intrinsic firing rate by depolarizing the membrane.

Description A: Muscarinic receptor activation closes M-type channels by activating PLC.
Description B: Muscarinic receptor activation opens M-type channels by activating PLC.

Description A: Muscarinic receptors stimulate G protein activity, directly opening GIRK channels.
Description B: Muscarinic receptors inhibit G protein activity, directly closing GIRK channels.

Description A: In the absence of muscarinic ACh receptor stimulation, the neuron tends to fire only a single action potential.
Description B: In the absence of muscarinic ACh receptor stimulation, the neuron tends to fire multiple action potentials.

Description A: Activation of GIRK channels moves the membrane toward the equilibrium potential EK.
Description B: Activation of GIRK channels moves the membrane away from the equilibrium potential EK.

Description A: The GIRK channels are activated directly by the G protein's βγ-subunit complex.
Description B: The GIRK channels are activated indirectly by the G protein's α-subunit.

Description A: Muscarinic receptor activation does not depend on second messenger production for M-channel closure.
Description B: Muscarinic receptor activation depends on second messenger production for M-channel closure.

Description A: Precision locomotion requires a high degree of visuomotor coordination and involves tasks such as stepping over obstacles.
Description B: Precision locomotion requires minimal visuomotor coordination and does not involve complex tasks such as stepping over obstacles.

Description A: In cats, the motor cortex is involved in precision locomotion by modulating the activity of numerous neurons during obstacle stepping.
Description B: In cats, the motor cortex plays no role in precision locomotion during tasks like stepping over obstacles.

Description A: The posterior parietal cortex (PPC) is involved in planning gait modifications and adjusts two or three steps before reaching an obstacle.
Description B: The posterior parietal cortex (PPC) is not involved in planning gait modifications prior to encountering an obstacle.

Description A: Neurons in the posterior parietal cortex discharge similarly regardless of which leg steps over an obstacle first.
Description B: Neurons in the posterior parietal cortex discharge differently depending on which leg steps over an obstacle first.

Description A: The cerebellum integrates motor commands, movement feedback, and spinal locomotor network states to regulate locomotion.
Description B: The cerebellum is not involved in integrating motor commands, movement feedback, or spinal locomotor network states for locomotion.

Description A: Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex cause animals to misplace their paws and increase the likelihood of contacting obstacles.
Description B: Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex have no effect on how animals place their paws when approaching obstacles.

Description A: The basal ganglia contribute to the selection of motor patterns and are found in all vertebrates.
Description B: The basal ganglia are unique to mammals and have no role in the selection of motor patterns.

Description A: Neurons in the cerebellum modify descendent signals to correct motor errors during locomotion.
Description B: Neurons in the cerebellum do not modify descended signals to adjust errors during locomotion.

Description A: Electrical stimulation to the motor cortex in cats can produce phase-dependent responses in the contralateral limb.
Description B: Electrical stimulation to the motor cortex in cats has no effect on phase-dependent responses in the contralateral limb.

Description A: Working memory involving obstacle parameters is dependent on the posterior parietal cortex.
Description B: Working memory involving obstacle parameters does not involve the posterior parietal cortex.

Description A: The cerebellum is responsible for adapting gait during walking on split treadmills with different belt speeds.
Description B: The cerebellum has no role in adapting gait during walking on split treadmills with different belt speeds.

Description A: Damage to the cerebellum leads to ataxia, which includes impaired limb coordination and a widened base of support.
Description B: Damage to the cerebellum has no effect on coordination of limbs or balance.

Description A: Visual information about obstacles is stored in working memory to coordinate gait across forelimbs and hindlimbs.
Description B: Visual information about obstacles plays no role in coordinating gait between forelimbs and hindlimbs.

Description A: The central pattern generator (CPG) is modulated by corticospinal neurons for specific locomotor tasks.
Description B: The central pattern generator (CPG) is not influenced by corticospinal neurons during locomotor tasks.

Description A: The cerebellum receives detailed proprioceptive information from hind legs through the dorsal spinocerebellar tract.
Description B: The cerebellum does not receive proprioceptive information from hind legs through the dorsal spinocerebellar tract.

Description A: The parvocellular neuroendocrine division includes three major pools of neurons that control anterior pituitary hormone secretion.
Description B: The parvocellular neuroendocrine division does not include any pools of neurons that control anterior pituitary hormone secretion.

Description A: The anterior pituitary is composed of five types of endocrine cells.
Description B: The anterior pituitary is composed of two types of endocrine cells.

Description A: Vasopressin and oxytocin are nine-amino acid peptide hormones.
Description B: Vasopressin and oxytocin are twelve-amino acid peptide hormones.

Description A: The descending division of the paraventricular nucleus modulates eating and drinking behaviors.
Description B: The descending division of the paraventricular nucleus is responsible for auditory processing.

Description A: Magnocellular neurons synthesize and secrete vasopressin and oxytocin.
Description B: Magnocellular neurons synthesize and secrete only adrenaline.

Description A: The genes for vasopressin and oxytocin probably arose by gene duplication.
Description B: The genes for vasopressin and oxytocin are completely unrelated.

Description A: The posterior pituitary is an extension of the brain and contains hormone-secreting axon terminals of hypothalamic neurons.
Description B: The posterior pituitary is separate from the brain and does not contain hormone-secreting axon terminals.

Description A: Circulating steroid and thyroid hormones produce selective effects on particular types of neurons in the paraventricular nucleus.
Description B: Circulating steroid and thyroid hormones do not impact neurons in the paraventricular nucleus.

Description A: The CRH neurons control the release of anterior pituitary adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).
Description B: The CRH neurons control the release of digestive enzymes in the gut.

Description A: Geoffrey Harris proposed that the anterior pituitary is regulated indirectly by the hypothalamus.
Description B: Geoffrey Harris proposed that the anterior pituitary is independently functioning and not regulated by the hypothalamus.

Description A: The identity and position of developing motor neurons and local interneurons depend on the inductive activity of the Shh protein, which is secreted by the notochord and floor plate.
Description B: The identity and position of developing sensory neurons and local interneurons depend on the inductive activity of the Shh protein, which is secreted by the notochord and floor plate.

Description A: Shh acts as a morphogen—a signal that can direct different cell fates at different concentration thresholds.
Description B: Shh acts as a neurotransmitter—a signal that can only direct identical cell fates.

Description A: BMP signals from epidermal cells initially border the neural plate and later flank the dorsal neural tube.
Description B: BMP signals from neural crest cells initially border the neural plate and later flank the dorsal neural tube.

Description A: Different levels of Shh signaling direct progenitor cells in different ventral domains to differentiate as motor neurons and interneurons.
Description B: Different levels of Shh signaling direct progenitor cells in dorsal domains to differentiate as motor neurons and interneurons.

Description A: Defects in Shh signaling have been implicated in a wide variety of human diseases, including spina bifida and certain cancers.
Description B: Defects in BMP signaling have been implicated in a wide variety of human diseases, including spina bifida and certain cancers.

Description A: The neural tube forms by fusion of the dorsal tips of the neural folds.
Description B: The neural tube forms by fusion of the ventral tips of the neural folds.

Description A: Gli targets are genes encoding transcription factors with a basic helix-loop-helix DNA-binding motif.
Description B: Gli targets are genes encoding transcription factors with an alpha-helix motif.

Description A: Shh signaling has shown to control many aspects of embryonic development.
Description B: Shh signaling has shown to control only neural development.

Description A: BMP proteins induce the generation of sensory relay neurons in the dorsal spinal cord.
Description B: Wnt proteins induce the generation of sensory relay neurons in the dorsal spinal cord.

Description A: The ventral neural tube is patterned by Sonic Hedgehog protein secreted from the notochord and floor plate.
Description B: The ventral neural tube is patterned by Sonic Hedgehog protein secreted from the dorsal plate and roof plate.

Description A: The transcription factors that define adjacent progenitor domains repress each other’s expression.
Description B: The transcription factors that define adjacent progenitor domains activate each other’s expression.

Description A: Shh signaling is initiated by its interaction with a transmembrane receptor complex called patched and smoothened.
Description B: Shh signaling is initiated by its interaction with a cytoplasmic receptor complex called patched and activated.

Description A: Active Shh protein is synthesized from a larger precursor protein through an unusual autocatalytic process.
Description B: Active Shh protein is synthesized from a smaller precursor protein through a standard cleavage process.

Description A: After the neural tube has closed, roof plate cells express BMP and Wnt proteins.
Description B: After the neural tube has closed, floor plate cells express BMP and Wnt proteins.

Description A: Wnt proteins promote the proliferation of progenitor cells in the dorsal neural tube.
Description B: Shh proteins promote the proliferation of progenitor cells in the dorsal neural tube.

Description A: Shh signals from the ventral midline set up early progenitor domains that later produce neurons of the basal ganglia.
Description B: BMP signals from the ventral midline set up early progenitor domains that later produce neurons of the basal ganglia.

Description A: Individual neurons in a sensory pathway respond to a range of stimulus values.
Description B: Individual neurons in a sensory pathway respond to only one specific stimulus value.

Description A: A neuron’s response peaks at a particular value, forming a bell-shaped tuning curve with a particular bandwidth.
Description B: A neuron’s response peaks at several values, forming an irregularly shaped tuning curve with varying bandwidths.

Description A: To determine the wavelength, one needs at least two neurons representing filters centered at different wavelengths.
Description B: To determine the wavelength, a single neuron representing a filter is sufficient.

Description A: A single visual percept is the product of the activity of a number of neurons operating in a specific combinatorial and interactive fashion called a population code.
Description B: A single visual percept is the product of the activity of a single neuron operating independently.

Description A: Vector averaging is one model for population coding in neural circuits.
Description B: Vector summation is the only model for population coding in neural circuits.

Description A: Visual circuitry is modulated by individual visual experience.
Description B: Visual circuitry remains unchanged by individual visual experience.

Description A: V1 neurons sharing basic properties such as spatial location or orientation preference form columns extending vertically.
Description B: V1 neurons sharing basic properties form networks dispersed randomly across the cortex.

Description A: Parallel processing starts at the retina, analyzing each point of visual input for different local features.
Description B: Parallel processing starts only in the brain, with the retina providing undifferentiated input.

Description A: The dendrites and cell bodies of V1 neurons are organized in layers.
Description B: The different channels enter V1 at different layers, primarily at input layers 4 and 6.

Description A: Receptive fields grow larger and more complex as they progress along the visual pathway.
Description B: Receptive fields remain the same size and complexity regardless of their stage in the visual pathway.

Description A: Neurons in the temporal lobe are selective for complex objects such as faces.
Description B: Neurons in the parietal lobe are selective for complex objects such as faces.

Description A: The optic nerves from the two eyes regroup at the optic chiasm.
Description B: The optic nerves from the two eyes do not regroup at any point and remain entirely separate.

Description A: The brain uses visual input to infer information about objects and their movement.
Description B: The brain provides no inference about objects or their movement based on visual input.

Description A: Population coding helps the periphery analyze a visual location for a full set of V1 visual features.
Description B: V1 circuits effectively analyze each visual location, in parallel, for the full set of V1 visual features.

Description A: Orientation preference columns are superimposed on a 'visuotopic' map in V1.
Description B: Orientation preference columns are isolated from the 'visuotopic' map in V1.

Description A: Processing of sensory information in the cerebral cortex occurs in multiple cortical areas in parallel and is not strictly hierarchical.
Description B: Processing of sensory information in the cerebral cortex occurs in a single cortical area and is strictly hierarchical.

Description A: Exteroception includes thermal senses of heat and cold as controllers of behavior.
Description B: Exteroception excludes thermal senses of heat and cold as controllers of behavior.

Description A: Proprioception involves receptors in skeletal muscle, joint capsules, and the skin, enabling conscious awareness of posture and movements.
Description B: Proprioception involves receptors only in the skin, enabling conscious awareness of posture and movements.

Description A: Nociception is a response to external events that damage or harm the body.
Description B: Nociception is unrelated to external events that damage or harm the body.

Description A: Dorsal root ganglion neurons are the primary sensory receptor cells of the somatosensory system.
Description B: Dorsal root ganglion neurons play no role as sensory receptor cells in the somatosensory system.

Description A: Peripheral somatosensory nerve fibers conduct action potentials at different rates.
Description B: Peripheral somatosensory nerve fibers conduct action potentials at a single uniform rate.

Description A: Thermal receptors detect changes in skin temperature.
Description B: Thermal receptors do not detect changes in skin temperature.

Description A: Mechanoreceptors mediate touch and proprioception.
Description B: Mechanoreceptors mediate touch but not proprioception.

Description A: The neural activity in a set of thousands or millions of neurons conveys a 'neural image' of specific properties of the external world.
Description B: The neural activity in a set of neurons cannot convey a 'neural image' of specific properties of the external world.

Description A: Visceral sensations represent the status of internal organs.
Description B: Visceral sensations do not represent the status of internal organs.

Description A: Our sensory systems are recognized as computational and algorithmic encoders, processors, and decoders of information.
Description B: Our sensory systems are unrelated to computational and algorithmic encoding, processing, and decoding of information.

Description A: Some touch involves an active motor component such as stroking or tapping.
Description B: Touch never involves an active motor component such as stroking or tapping.

Description A: Itch is a distinctive cutaneous sensation.
Description B: Itch is not considered a distinctive cutaneous sensation.

Description A: Feedback connections from brain areas involved in cognition and memory control the incoming stream of sensory information.
Description B: Feedback connections from brain areas involved in cognition and memory do not influence the incoming stream of sensory information.

Description A: Sensory information enters the central nervous system via spinal or cranial nerves.
Description B: Sensory information enters the central nervous system only through peripheral nerves.

Description A: Implicit memory operates unconsciously and automatically, as in the memory for conditioned responses, habits, and perceptual and motor skills.
Description B: Implicit memory operates consciously and automatically, as in the memory for conditioned responses, habits, and perceptual and motor skills.

Description A: Explicit memory operates consciously, as in the memory for people, places, and objects.
Description B: Explicit memory operates unconsciously, as in the memory for people, places, and objects.

Description A: The circuitry for long-term memory storage differs between explicit and implicit memory.
Description B: The circuitry for long-term memory storage is the same for explicit and implicit memory.

Description A: Long-term storage of explicit memory begins in the hippocampus and the medial temporal lobe of the neocortex.
Description B: Long-term storage of explicit memory begins in the cerebellum and the basal ganglia.

Description A: The striatum is involved in the storage of skills and habits as a form of implicit memory.
Description B: The striatum is involved in the storage of emotional responses as a form of implicit memory.

Description A: The amygdala is involved in Pavlovian threat conditioning, also known as fear conditioning.
Description B: The amygdala is involved in procedural memory, such as skills and habits.

Description A: Habituation results from presynaptic depression of synaptic transmission.
Description B: Habituation results from presynaptic facilitation of synaptic transmission.

Description A: Sensitization involves presynaptic facilitation of synaptic transmission.
Description B: Sensitization involves presynaptic depression of synaptic transmission.

Description A: Memory stored in a sensory-motor synapse becomes destabilized following retrieval but can be restabilized.
Description B: Memory stored in a sensory-motor synapse becomes permanent following retrieval and cannot be restabilized.

Description A: Explicit memories are transferred to different regions of the neocortex over time.
Description B: Explicit memories remain in the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe indefinitely.

Description A: Many cognitive, motor, and perceptual skills initially stored as explicit memory can become implicit memory with practice.
Description B: Cognitive, motor, and perceptual skills stored as explicit memory cannot become implicit memory.

Description A: Mammals' implicit memory for motor skills and habits involves the cerebellum and basal ganglia.
Description B: Mammals' implicit memory for motor skills and habits involves the hippocampus and amygdala.

Description A: Long-term synaptic facilitation in implicit memory storage is synapse-specific.
Description B: Long-term synaptic facilitation in implicit memory storage affects the entire neural circuit uniformly.

Description A: The cAMP-PKA-CREB pathway is involved in long-term storage of implicit memory.
Description B: The cAMP-PKA-CREB pathway is involved in short-term storage of explicit memory.

Description A: Learning-induced changes in the structure of the brain contribute to the biological basis of individuality.
Description B: Learning-induced changes in the structure of the brain have no impact on the biological basis of individuality.

Description A: Vestibular inputs regarding body posture and motion can be ambiguous.
Description B: Vestibular inputs regarding body posture and motion are always clear and unambiguous.

Description A: The postural system cannot distinguish between tilt and linear acceleration of the body based on otolith inputs alone.
Description B: The postural system can distinguish between tilt and linear acceleration of the body based on otolith inputs alone.

Description A: Mechanoreceptors of the vestibular system are hair bundles that bend in response to shearing forces.
Description B: Mechanoreceptors of the vestibular system are hair bundles that remain rigid in response to shearing forces.

Description A: Henry Head described the body schema as a dynamic system in which both spatial and temporal features are continually updated.
Description B: Henry Head described the body schema as a static system with fixed spatial and temporal features.

Description A: Visual vertical and gravitational vertical are independent of each other.
Description B: Visual vertical and gravitational vertical depend on each other.

Description A: Disorientation or motion sickness may result when the actual sensory information does not match the expected sensory information.
Description B: Disorientation or motion sickness may result when the actual sensory information perfectly matches the expected sensory information.

Description A: Information from multiple sensory systems is integrated into a central representation of the body called the body schema.
Description B: Information from multiple sensory systems is separated and never integrated into a central representation.

Description A: A healthy nervous system adapts quickly to changing tasks, goals, and environments.
Description B: A healthy nervous system struggles to adapt to changing tasks, goals, and environments.

Description A: When the support surface is unstable, subjects depend more on vestibular and visual information.
Description B: When the support surface is unstable, subjects depend more on auditory information.

Description A: Vestibular information is critical when visual and somatosensory information is ambiguous or absent.
Description B: Vestibular information is irrelevant when visual and somatosensory information is ambiguous or absent.

Description A: Postural orientation and balance are achieved through the dynamic interplay among all levels of the central nervous system.
Description B: Postural orientation and balance are controlled solely by the spinal cord.

Description A: The body schema must incorporate the mass and inertia of each segment for movement planning.
Description B: The body schema considers only the length of each segment for movement planning.

Description A: In the microgravity environment of space flight, the model is gradually updated until expected and actual sensory information agree.
Description B: In the microgravity environment, sensory models remain unchanged and static.

Description A: Patients with asymmetrical vestibular function show abnormal visual vertical but normal gravitational vertical.
Description B: Patients with asymmetrical vestibular function show normal visual vertical but abnormal gravitational vertical.

Description A: Adult cats with complete spinal transection can support their weight but have little control of balance.
Description B: Adult cats with complete spinal transection can maintain perfect balance without support.

Description A: If the optic nerve is cut and the eye is surgically rotated in its socket before the nerve regenerates, visually guided behavior is aberrant.
Description B: If the optic nerve is cut and the eye is surgically rotated in its socket after the nerve regenerates, visually guided behavior is perfectly normal.

Description A: Neurons in the anterior retina project axons to the posterior tectum, while neurons in the posterior retina project to the anterior tectum.
Description B: Neurons in the anterior retina project axons to the anterior tectum, while neurons in the posterior retina project to the posterior tectum.

Description A: Human perception of colors results from the simultaneous activation of three different classes of photoreceptors in the retina.
Description B: Human perception of colors results from the simultaneous activation of five different classes of photoreceptors in the retina.

Description A: In the example shown, strong activation of red cones along with moderate stimulation of green cones and weak activation of blue cones produces the perception of yellow.
Description B: In the example shown, strong activation of blue cones along with moderate stimulation of red cones and weak activation of green cones produces the perception of yellow.

Description A: Cone cells are classified as red, green, or blue type photoreceptors.
Description B: Cone cells are classified as red, yellow, or blue type photoreceptors.

Description A: The neural coding of stimulus intensity is faithfully transmitted from peripheral receptors to cortical centers.
Description B: The neural coding of stimulus intensity is poorly transmitted from peripheral receptors to cortical centers.

Description A: The recognition of an analog-to-digital transformation dates back to 1925 when Edgar Adrian and Yngve Zotterman discovered the all-or-none properties of the action potential in sensory neurons.
Description B: The recognition of an analog-to-digital transformation dates back to 1980 when Edgar Adrian and Yngve Zotterman discovered the all-or-none properties of the action potential in sensory neurons.

Description A: Rod cells in the retina are activated by very low light levels and reach their maximal receptor potentials and firing rates in dim daylight.
Description B: Cone cells in the retina are activated by very low light levels and reach their maximal receptor potentials and firing rates in dim daylight.

Description A: Receptor adaptation is thought to be an important neural basis of perceptual adaptation, whereby a constant stimulus fades from consciousness.
Description B: Receptor adaptation is thought to be an important neural basis of perceptual attraction, whereby a constant stimulus becomes more prominent.

Description A: In the example, rapidly adapting receptors cease firing in response to constant amplitude stimulation and are active only when the stimulus intensity increases or decreases.
Description B: In the example, rapidly adapting receptors maintain firing in response to constant amplitude stimulation and are inactive only when the stimulus intensity increases or decreases.

Description A: Firing of sensory neurons stops after the probe is retracted.
Description B: Firing of sensory neurons continues after the probe is retracted.

Description A: Humans can report changes in sensory experience that correspond to alterations within a few milliseconds in the firing patterns of sensory neurons.
Description B: Humans can report changes in sensory experience that correspond to alterations within a few seconds in the firing patterns of sensory neurons.

Description A: The firing rates of each neuron in a population can be plotted in a coordinate system with multiple axes such as modality, location, intensity, and time.
Description B: The firing rates of each neuron in a population can be plotted in a coordinate system with a single axis such as modality.

Description A: Most sensory systems have low- and high-threshold receptors.
Description B: Most sensory systems have only low-threshold receptors.

Description A: Steady rhythmic firing in nerves innervating the hand is perceived as steady pressure or vibration.
Description B: Steady rhythmic firing in nerves innervating the hand is perceived as motion.

Description A: The relationship between the neural firing rate and the pressure stimulus is linear.
Description B: The relationship between the neural firing rate and the pressure stimulus is logarithmic.

Description A: Rapidly adapting sensors illustrate another important principle of sensory coding by being active only when the stimulus intensity increases or decreases.
Description B: Rapidly adapting sensors illustrate another important principle of sensory coding by being active continuously regardless of changes in the stimulus intensity.

Description A: Dermatomes represent areas of skin innervated by a single dorsal root nerve or a branch of the trigeminal nerve.
Description B: Dermatomes represent areas of skin innervated by multiple dorsal root nerves simultaneously.

Description A: Level C1 has no dorsal root, only a ventral root.
Description B: Level C1 has both dorsal and ventral roots.

Description A: Neurons in lamina I generally have small receptive fields localized to one dermatome.
Description B: Neurons in lamina I have large receptive fields that span multiple dermatomes.

Description A: LTMRs targeting laminae III to V include large myelinated sensory fibers like Aβ fibers.
Description B: LTMRs targeting laminae III to V include unmyelinated sensory fibers like C fibers.

Description A: Sensory information related to cold, pain, and itch is transmitted via Aδ and C fibers.
Description B: Sensory information related to cold, pain, and itch is transmitted via Aα and Aβ fibers.

Description A: Receptor potentials at distal nerve terminals convert into trains of action potentials based on stimulus strength.
Description B: Receptor potentials at distal nerve terminals convert into trains of action potentials randomly, irrespective of stimulus strength.

Description A: The dorsal column-medial lemniscal system transmits tactile and proprioceptive information to the thalamus.
Description B: The dorsal column-medial lemniscal system transmits pain and thermal information to the thalamus.

Description A: Thermoreceptors are excited by TRP ion channels that respond to specific temperature ranges.
Description B: Thermoreceptors are excited by TRP ion channels, which respond universally to all temperature ranges.

Description A: Afferent C fibers from the viscera terminate ipsilaterally in laminae I, II, V, and X in the spinal cord.
Description B: Afferent C fibers from the viscera terminate contralaterally in laminae I, II, V, and X in the spinal cord only.

Description A: Mechanosensation is mediated by Piezo2 proteins that detect compression or stretch.
Description B: Mechanosensation is mediated by Piezo2 proteins that detect changes in temperature only.

Description A: The spinothalamic tract conveys pain and thermal information either to the midbrain or the thalamus.
Description B: The spinothalamic tract conveys tactile information exclusively to the cerebellum.

Description A: Activation of somatosensory receptors causes local depolarization, called receptor potential, at distal nerve terminals.
Description B: Activation of somatosensory receptors does not cause local depolarization but directly produces action potentials.

Description A: The anatomical arrangement in laminae enables spinal nerves to produce a somatotopic representation of adjacent skin regions.
Description B: The anatomical arrangement in laminae prevents somatotopic representation of adjacent skin regions.

Description A: DRG neurons form overlapping receptive fields by innervating multiple sense organs with divergent distal terminals.
Description B: DRG neurons create isolated receptive fields by restricting sensory input to one sense organ only.

Description A: Primary afferent fibers from muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs terminate in the deepest laminae of the ventral horn.
Description B: Primary afferent fibers from muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs terminate selectively in lamina I of the dorsal horn.

Description A: Grid fields and place fields expand in size as a function of neuronal location along the dorsoventral axis of the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus.
Description B: Grid fields and place fields contract in size as a function of neuronal location along the dorsoventral axis of the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus.

Description A: Place fields from different locations along the dorsoventral axis of the hippocampus show larger field size as cells are more ventral.
Description B: Place fields from different locations along the dorsoventral axis of the hippocampus show smaller field size as cells are more ventral.

Description A: Head direction cells in the medial entorhinal cortex fire selectively based on the direction the rat faces.
Description B: Head direction cells in the medial entorhinal cortex fire randomly, irrespective of the direction the rat faces.

Description A: Border cells have firing fields that align with the edges of geometric enclosures.
Description B: Border cells have firing fields that avoid the edges of geometric enclosures.

Description A: Speed cells show a high correspondence between speed and firing rate during free foraging.
Description B: Speed cells show no correspondence between speed and firing rate during free foraging.

Description A: Place cells form independent maps for different environments.
Description B: Place cells form identical maps for different environments.

Description A: The firing pattern of a hippocampal place cell is sensitive to environmental changes.
Description B: The firing pattern of a hippocampal place cell is insensitive to environmental changes.

Description A: Remapping in hippocampal place cells helps minimize memory interference.
Description B: Remapping in hippocampal place cells increases memory interference.

Description A: Speed cells maintain their unique tuning to running speed across different environments.
Description B: Speed cells lose their unique tuning to running speed across different environments.

Description A: Grid cells maintain their firing patterns regardless of context or environment.
Description B: Grid cells change their firing patterns with different contexts or environments.

Description A: The medial entorhinal cortex acts as a universal map of space, disregarding environmental details.
Description B: The medial entorhinal cortex maps space by emphasizing environmental details.

Description A: Place cells are thought to store memory in position-related firing patterns.
Description B: Place cells do not store memory in position-related firing patterns.

Description A: Place fields of a given cell in the hippocampus switch contextually.
Description B: Place fields of a given cell in the hippocampus remain static regardless of context.

Description A: Rigidity in firing patterns is observed in all entorhinal cell types such as grid cells and head direction cells.
Description B: Rigidity in firing patterns is not observed in entorhinal cell types such as grid cells and head direction cells.

Description A: Ensembles of co-localized grid cells maintain consistent overlapping patterns across environments.
Description B: Ensembles of co-localized grid cells show varied overlapping patterns across environments.

Description A: Dendritic spine motility and turnover in the mouse visual cortex increase after eye closure during early postnatal development, suggesting synaptic connections are beginning to rearrange.
Description B: Dendritic spine motility and turnover in the mouse visual cortex decrease after eye closure during early postnatal development, suggesting synaptic connections are becoming static.

Description A: Spine alterations following eye closure are localized primarily in the superficial and deep layers of the visual cortex containing binocular neurons.
Description B: Spine alterations following eye closure are localized primarily in layer IV of the visual cortex containing monocular neurons.

Description A: Closure of one eye during the critical period causes the number of dendritic spines on apical dendrites of pyramidal neurons to decrease initially and then increase after longer periods of deprivation.
Description B: Closure of one eye during the critical period causes the number of dendritic spines on apical dendrites of pyramidal neurons to increase initially and then decrease after longer periods of deprivation.

Description A: Structurally, spine alterations do not occur in adult mice following eye closure during the critical period.
Description B: Structurally, spine alterations occur in adult mice following eye closure during the critical period.

Description A: Binocular neurons in the visual cortex lose responsiveness to the closed eye due to imbalances in synaptic inputs from the open and closed eyes.
Description B: Binocular neurons in the visual cortex gain responsiveness to the closed eye due to imbalances in synaptic inputs from the open and closed eyes.

Description A: Enhanced GABA signaling causes earlier timing of the critical period for ocular dominance plasticity in mice.
Description B: Enhanced GABA signaling causes later timing of the critical period for ocular dominance plasticity in mice.

Description A: Homeostatic plasticity induces compensatory increases in excitatory drive from the open eye following loss of input from the closed eye.
Description B: Homeostatic plasticity reduces excitatory drive from the open eye following loss of input from the closed eye.

Description A: The first physiological changes in binocular neurons occur in cortical layers II/III and V rather than layer IV.
Description B: The first physiological changes in binocular neurons occur in cortical layer IV rather than cortical layers II/III and V.

Description A: Alterations in dendritic spines in the visual cortex correlate with changes observed during the critical period of ocular dominance plasticity.
Description B: Alterations in dendritic spines in the visual cortex do not correlate with changes observed during the critical period of ocular dominance plasticity.

Description A: Thalamic axons carry input from only one eye during visual processing.
Description B: Thalamic axons carry input from both eyes during visual processing.

Description A: Spike timing–dependent plasticity contributes to the early weakening of responses to the closed eye.
Description B: Spike timing–dependent plasticity contributes to the early strengthening of responses to the closed eye.

Description A: During monocular deprivation in the critical period, thalamic-input remodeling contributes to the shift in neuronal responsiveness.
Description B: During monocular deprivation in the critical period, thalamic-input remodeling prevents the shift in neuronal responsiveness.

Description A: The loss of cortical responsiveness following eye closure results from a circuit alteration rather than a simple loss of input.
Description B: The loss of cortical responsiveness following eye closure results from a simple loss of input rather than a circuit alteration.

Description A: Maturation of inhibitory input coincides with the onset of the critical period for ocular dominance plasticity.
Description B: Maturation of inhibitory input coincides with the conclusion of the critical period for ocular dominance plasticity.

Description A: Visual cortical neurons are influenced by both excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission during the critical period.
Description B: Visual cortical neurons are influenced only by excitatory neurotransmission during the critical period.

Description A: The hippocampus is critically important for the long-term storage of explicit memories and receives major input from the entorhinal cortex.
Description B: The hippocampus is not important for the long-term storage of explicit memories and does not receive input from the entorhinal cortex.

Description A: Long-term memory storage involves changes in the strength of neural connections in the hippocampus.
Description B: Long-term memory storage does not involve changes in the strength of neural connections in the hippocampus.

Description A: The CA1 region of the hippocampus is the major output area and is linked with profound memory loss if damaged.
Description B: The CA1 region of the hippocampus is not a major output area and does not impact memory significantly if damaged.

Description A: The trisynaptic pathway in the hippocampus involves excitatory synapses at three stages: the dentate gyrus, CA3, and CA1.
Description B: The trisynaptic pathway in the hippocampus bypasses the dentate gyrus and involves only CA3 and CA1.

Description A: The CA2 region of the hippocampus is important for encoding social memory and receives hormonal input from the hypothalamus.
Description B: The CA2 region of the hippocampus has no role in social memory and does not receive hormonal input from the hypothalamus.

Description A: Place cells in the hippocampus contribute to the neural basis of spatial memory in mammals.
Description B: Place cells in the hippocampus are unrelated to the neural basis of spatial memory in mammals.
