Description A: Explicit memory storage is distributed throughout the neocortex but requires processes in the hippocampus for successful storage.
Description B: Explicit memory storage is localized entirely within the hippocampus and does not involve the neocortex.

Description A: The dentate gyrus is important for pattern separation in explicit memory processing.
Description B: The dentate gyrus has no role in pattern separation in explicit memory processing.

Description A: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity provides a mechanism for altering synaptic strength and contributes to memory processes.
Description B: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity does not alter synaptic strength or contribute to memory processes.

Description A: In the indirect trisynaptic pathway, information flows through the dentate gyrus, CA3, and then CA1.
Description B: In the indirect trisynaptic pathway, information flows directly from the entorhinal cortex to CA1 without intermediate stops.

Description A: Long-term potentiation in the hippocampus is essential for explicit memory storage and has early and late phases.
Description B: Long-term potentiation in the hippocampus is not involved in explicit memory storage and only has one phase.

Description A: Entorhinal cortex neurons provide distinct spatial representations vital for spatial memory.
Description B: Entorhinal cortex neurons do not contribute to spatial representations and are irrelevant to spatial memory.

Description A: Donald Hebb proposed that memory traces are formed when synaptic connections strengthen due to coincident activity.
Description B: Donald Hebb proposed that memory traces weaken when synaptic connections show coincident activity.

Description A: Recurrent collaterals in CA3 neurons contribute to associative memory storage and recall.
Description B: Recurrent collaterals in CA3 neurons inhibit associative memory storage and recall.

Description A: Hippocampal lesions can disrupt autobiographical memory, demonstrating its role in this type of recollection.
Description B: Hippocampal lesions have no effect on autobiographical memory.

Description A: Early developmental principles are conserved not only among tissues but also across species and phyla.
Description B: Early developmental principles are unique to different tissues and specific to individual species.

Description A: The neural plate arises from a narrow central strip of the ectoderm.
Description B: The neural plate arises from the endoderm, the innermost germ layer.

Description A: The caudal region of the neural tube gives rise to the spinal cord.
Description B: The caudal region of the neural tube develops into the brain.

Description A: The interaction of localized inductive signals and intrinsic cell responsiveness is evident at virtually every step throughout neural development.
Description B: Localized inductive signals do not affect the progression of neural development.

Description A: Spemann and Mangold grafted the dorsal blastopore lip from an early gastrula stage embryo to a ventral region of a host embryo.
Description B: Spemann and Mangold grafted ventral ectoderm cells to a dorsal region of a host embryo.

Description A: The mesoderm induces one part of the ectoderm to become the neural plate.
Description B: The mesoderm induces the endoderm to become the neural plate.

Description A: The neural tube lies over the notochord and is flanked by somites.
Description B: The neural tube is located beneath the notochord and somites.

Description A: The first step in nervous system development is the formation of the neural plate from a restricted region of the ectoderm.
Description B: The first step in nervous system development is the formation of the neural plate from mesodermal cells.

Description A: Inductive factors are signaling molecules secreted by nearby cells.
Description B: Inductive factors are surface receptors that enable cells to respond to nearby signals.

Description A: Neural induction is mediated by peptide growth factors and their inhibitors.
Description B: Neural induction is mediated by vitamin complexes and their antagonists.

Description A: Hans Spemann and Hilde Mangold discovered that differentiation of the neural plate from uncommitted ectoderm depends on signals from the organizer region.
Description B: Hans Spemann and Hilde Mangold discovered that differentiation of the neural plate from uncommitted ectoderm does not involve external signals.

Description A: Cells at the junction between the neural tube and ectoderm are set aside to become the neural crest.
Description B: Cells at the junction between the neural tube and ectoderm become part of the mesoderm.

Description A: Signals from the organizer region induce a second neural axis.
Description B: Signals from the organizer region suppress the formation of any additional neural axis.

Description A: Host ectodermal cells were induced to form a complete copy of the nervous system by transplanted donor cells.
Description B: Host ectodermal cells were unaffected by transplanted donor cells.

Description A: Spemann and Mangold's studies demonstrated a critical role for induction in neural development.
Description B: Spemann and Mangold's studies showed that induction plays no role in neural development.

Description A: Thalamocortical relay neurons can fire spontaneously in brief bursts of action potentials in the absence of synaptic input, driven by inward currents through HCN and Cav3 channels.
Description B: Thalamocortical relay neurons require synaptic input to fire spontaneously in brief bursts of action potentials, driven by inward currents through HCN and Cav3 channels.

Description A: The nodes of Ranvier in myelinated axons have a high density of Na+ channels and a low density of voltage-activated K+ channels.
Description B: The nodes of Ranvier in myelinated axons have a low density of Na+ channels and a high density of voltage-activated K+ channels.

Description A: Neurons from the suprachiasmatic nucleus generate spontaneous pacemaker potentials driven by Na+ currents during the interspike interval.
Description B: Neurons from the suprachiasmatic nucleus generate spontaneous pacemaker potentials driven by K+ currents during the interspike interval.

Description A: In myelinated axons, a higher density of voltage-activated K+ channels can be found under the myelin sheath near the ends of each internodal segment.
Description B: In myelinated axons, a higher density of voltage-activated Na+ channels can be found under the myelin sheath near the ends of each internodal segment.

Description A: Voltage-gated sodium channels select for sodium based on size, charge, and energy of hydration.
Description B: Voltage-gated sodium channels select for sodium based on voltage activation alone.

Description A: Most neurons express multiple kinds of voltage-gated Na+, Ca2+, K+, HCN, and Cl− channels.
Description B: Most neurons express a single type of voltage-gated Na+, Ca2+, K+, HCN, and Cl− channel.

Description A: The refractory period of action potential reflects Na+ channel inactivation and K+ channel activation.
Description B: The refractory period of action potential reflects only Na+ channel activation.

Description A: Injection of a depolarizing current pulse into a neuron can trigger a delay in action potentials if the cell is held at a hyperpolarized membrane potential.
Description B: Injection of a depolarizing current pulse always triggers immediate action potentials regardless of membrane potential state.

Description A: Presynaptic nerve terminals at chemical synapses have a high density of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels that trigger transmitter release.
Description B: Presynaptic nerve terminals at chemical synapses have a low density of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels that inhibit transmitter release.

Description A: Netrin-1 is generated by floor plate cells and ventral neural progenitors. It attracts the axons of commissural neurons to the floor plate at the ventral midline of the spinal cord.
Description B: Netrin-1 is generated by dorsal plate cells and dorsal neural progenitors. It attracts the axons of commissural neurons to the dorsal plate at the dorsal midline of the spinal cord.

Description A: Most commissural axons fail to reach the floor plate when netrin or DCC proteins are eliminated.
Description B: Most commissural axons reach the floor plate even when netrin or DCC proteins are eliminated.

Description A: Slit proteins secreted by floor plate cells interact with Robo receptors on commissural axons to prevent these axons from recrossing the midline.
Description B: Slit proteins secreted by roof plate cells interact with DCC receptors on commissural axons to encourage these axons to cross the midline.

Description A: Roger Sperry proposed a chemospecificity hypothesis to explain the specific growth of axons from different parts of the retina to different parts of the optic tectum.
Description B: Roger Sperry proposed a chemospecificity hypothesis to explain the random growth of axons from different parts of the retina to various parts of the brain.

Description A: The expression and activity of netrins have been conserved throughout evolution, secreted by ventral midline cells in worms, flies, and vertebrates.
Description B: The expression and activity of netrins have evolved uniquely in vertebrates, secreted by dorsal cells only.

Description A: Growth cones at the tips of axons serve as both sensory and motor elements to guide axons to their destinations.
Description B: Axon terminals at the tips of axons serve solely as motor elements to guide axons to their destinations.

Description A: Prior to crossing, but not after, commissural axons express robo3 in addition to robo1 and robo2, with Rig-1 protein inactivating the Robo receptors.
Description B: After crossing, commissural axons express only robo1 and robo2, with Rig-1 protein activating the Robo receptors.

Description A: Once axons arrive at the floor plate, they become sensitive to Slit, a chemorepellent signal secreted by floor plate cells.
Description B: Once axons arrive at the floor plate, they become insensitive to Slit, as it is a chemorepellent signal secreted by roof plate cells.

Description A: Wnt proteins secreted from floor plate cells and distributed in a rostrocaudal gradient interact with frizzled proteins on the commissural axons, guiding the axons toward the brain.
Description B: Wnt proteins secreted from roof plate cells and distributed in a caudorostral gradient interact with frizzled proteins on the commissural axons, guiding the axons toward the spinal cord.

Description A: Both attractive and repellent molecules guide axons across midline structures, a process called decussation. Evolutionarily conserved signals include Slits, netrins, and Wnts.
Description B: Only attractive molecules guide axons across midline structures, a process called intersection. Evolutionarily unique signals include Slits, netrins, and BMPs.

Description A: Ionotropic receptors underlie fast synaptic signaling that is the basis of all behaviors, from simple reflexes to complex cognitive processes.
Description B: Metabotropic receptors underlie fast synaptic signaling that is the basis of all behaviors, from simple reflexes to complex cognitive processes.

Description A: Activation of metabotropic receptors regulates the opening of ion channels indirectly through biochemical signaling pathways.
Description B: Activation of ionotropic receptors regulates the opening of ion channels indirectly through biochemical signaling pathways.

Description A: Metabotropic receptors can modify reflex strength, activate motor patterns, focus attention, set emotional states, and contribute to long-lasting changes in neural circuits.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors can modify reflex strength, activate motor patterns, focus attention, set emotional states, and contribute to long-lasting changes in neural circuits.

Description A: The cyclic AMP pathway is the best understood second-messenger signaling cascade initiated by G protein–coupled receptors.
Description B: The cyclic AMP pathway is the least understood second-messenger signaling cascade initiated by G protein–coupled receptors.

Description A: G protein–coupled receptors can activate a variety of effectors, typically enzymes producing diffusible second messengers.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors can activate a variety of effectors, typically enzymes producing diffusible second messengers.

Description A: Receptor tyrosine kinases initiate a cascade of protein phosphorylation reactions, beginning with autophosphorylation of the kinase itself on tyrosine residues.
Description B: G protein–coupled receptors initiate a cascade of protein phosphorylation reactions, beginning with autophosphorylation of the kinase itself on tyrosine residues.

Description A: Endocannabinoids inhibit presynaptic transmitter release.
Description B: Endocannabinoids enhance presynaptic transmitter release.

Description A: Gases like nitric oxide can act as transcellular signals stimulating cyclic GMP synthesis.
Description B: Gases like nitric oxide can act as transcellular signals inhibiting cyclic GMP synthesis.

Description A: Second-messenger cascades can increase or decrease the opening of many types of ion channels.
Description B: Second-messenger cascades can only decrease the opening of ion channels.

Description A: Cyclic AMP–dependent protein phosphorylation can close potassium channels.
Description B: Cyclic AMP–dependent protein phosphorylation can open potassium channels.

Description A: Upon the binding of ligand, a G protein–coupled receptor undergoes a conformational change that promotes the exchange of GDP with GTP.
Description B: Upon the binding of ligand, a G protein–coupled receptor remains unchanged and does not promote the exchange of GDP with GTP.

Description A: Once a G protein–coupled receptor binds a ligand, it can interact sequentially with more than one G protein macromolecule.
Description B: Once a ionotropic receptor binds a ligand, it can interact sequentially with more than one G protein macromolecule.

Description A: Protein kinase A is a heterotetrameric enzyme consisting of a dimer of two regulatory subunits and two catalytic subunits.
Description B: Protein kinase A is a homotetrameric enzyme consisting of only catalytic subunits.

Description A: Activation of protein kinase A requires the binding of cAMP to its regulatory subunits, freeing the catalytic subunits.
Description B: Activation of protein kinase A inhibits the binding of cAMP to its regulatory subunits, freeing the catalytic subunits.

Description A: Kinases can phosphorylate proteins on serine and threonine residues within a context of specific phosphorylation consensus sequences.
Description B: Kinases can phosphorylate proteins on any residue without requiring specific phosphorylation consensus sequences.

Description A: The sarcomere is the basic functional unit of muscle.
Description B: The Z disk is the basic functional unit of muscle.

Description A: The thin filament includes polymerized actin along with the regulatory proteins tropomyosin and troponin.
Description B: The thin filament includes polymerized actin along with the structural proteins tropomyosin and titin.

Description A: The protein titin maintains the position of each thick filament in the middle of the sarcomere.
Description B: The protein desmin maintains the position of each thick filament in the middle of the sarcomere.

Description A: Maximal force can be achieved only with a series of action potentials that sustains the Ca2+ concentration in the sarcoplasm.
Description B: Maximal force can be achieved with a single action potential that sustains the Ca2+ concentration in the sarcoplasm.

Description A: The amount of overlap between actin and myosin is optimal at an intermediate sarcomere length, and the relative force is maximal.
Description B: The amount of overlap between actin and myosin is optimal at a short sarcomere length, and the relative force is maximal.

Description A: Muscle stiffness corresponds to the slope of the relation between muscle force and muscle length.
Description B: Muscle stiffness corresponds to the slope of the relation between muscle tension and muscle width.

Description A: When the length of the muscle fiber is not held fixed, the direction and rate of change in sarcomere length depend on the amount of muscle fiber force.
Description B: When the length of the muscle fiber is held fixed, the direction and rate of change in sarcomere length depend on the load alone.

Description A: Sarcomere length decreases when the muscle fiber force exceeds the load.
Description B: Sarcomere length decreases when the muscle fiber force is less than the load.

Description A: The maximal rate at which a muscle fiber can shorten is limited by the peak rate at which cross bridges can form.
Description B: The maximal rate at which a muscle fiber can shorten is limited by the energy capacity of the mitochondria.

Description A: The variation in fiber force during contraction is largely caused by differences in the average force exerted by each cross bridge.
Description B: The variation in fiber force during contraction is largely caused by the energy storage in the muscle fiber.

Description A: The anatomy of a muscle has a pronounced effect on its force capacity, range of motion, and shortening velocity.
Description B: The anatomy of a muscle has no apparent effect on its force capacity, range of motion, and shortening velocity.

Description A: Several myofibrils lie side by side in a fiber, and each myofibril is made up of sarcomeres arranged end to end.
Description B: Each myofibril lies alone in a fiber, and is made up of sarcomeres arranged end to end.

Description A: Once activated, cross bridges perform work and cause the thick and thin filaments to slide relative to one another.
Description B: Once activated, cross bridges perform no work and keep thick and thin filaments stationary.

Description A: Conversely, the increase in force during a lengthening contraction reflects the stretching of incompletely activated sarcomeres.
Description B: Conversely, the increase in force during a lengthening contraction reflects the compression of fully activated sarcomeres.

Description A: The rate of cross-bridge cycling increases after a brief isometric contraction.
Description B: The rate of cross-bridge cycling decreases after a brief isometric contraction.

Description A: Voltage-gated Na+ channels are blocked by application of tetrodotoxin, reducing the amplitude of the presynaptic spike below 40 mV, causing the EPSP to disappear.
Description B: Voltage-gated K+ channels are blocked by application of tetrodotoxin, reducing the amplitude of the presynaptic spike below 50 mV, causing the EPSP to disappear.

Description A: When Na+ channels are progressively blocked by TTX, the presynaptic action potential and excitatory postsynaptic potential decrease.
Description B: When Na+ channels are progressively blocked by TTX, the presynaptic action potential and excitatory postsynaptic potential increase.

Description A: A 40-mV presynaptic action potential is required to produce a postsynaptic potential.
Description B: A 50-mV presynaptic action potential is required to produce a postsynaptic potential.

Description A: Transmitter release can be triggered by depolarizing the presynaptic terminal, even if voltage-gated Na+ channels are completely blocked by TTX.
Description B: Transmitter release cannot be triggered by depolarizing the presynaptic terminal if voltage-gated Na+ channels are blocked by TTX.

Description A: Blocking both Na+ and K+ channels helps control presynaptic voltage and produces a steep input-output curve.
Description B: Blocking both Na+ and Ca2+ channels helps control presynaptic voltage and produces a steep input-output curve.

Description A: Calcium channels do not inactivate quickly and stay open as long as the presynaptic depolarization lasts.
Description B: Calcium channels inactivate quickly and close as soon as the presynaptic depolarization starts.

Description A: Calcium channels are largely localized in presynaptic terminals at active zones, opposite the postsynaptic receptors.
Description B: Calcium channels are largely localized in postsynaptic terminals at active zones, opposite the presynaptic receptors.

Description A: The extracellular Ca2+ concentration is much higher than the intracellular concentration, approximately 105-fold greater.
Description B: The intracellular Ca2+ concentration is much higher than the extracellular concentration, approximately 105-fold greater.

Description A: Katz and Miledi demonstrated that neither Na+ nor K+ flux is required for transmitter release.
Description B: Katz and Miledi demonstrated that both Na+ and K+ flux are required for transmitter release.

Description A: Presynaptic Na+ influx is important only for depolarizing the membrane enough for transmitter release to occur.
Description B: Presynaptic Na+ influx is necessary for the actual process of transmitter release.

Description A: Voltage-sensitive Na+ and K+ channels were blocked at the squid giant synapse to study Ca2+ influx.
Description B: Voltage-sensitive Ca2+ and Mg2+ channels were blocked at the squid giant synapse to study Na+ influx.

Description A: Presynaptic depolarizations greater than 40 mV can lead to a steep increase in the EPSP.
Description B: Presynaptic depolarizations less than 40 mV can lead to a steep increase in the EPSP.

Description A: A 13.5-mV increase in presynaptic spike amplitude results in a 10-fold increase in EPSP amplitude.
Description B: A 20-mV increase in presynaptic spike amplitude results in a 2-fold increase in EPSP amplitude.

Description A: The original presynaptic resting membrane potential was approximately −70 mV.
Description B: The original presynaptic resting membrane potential was approximately −50 mV.

Description A: Ca2+ serves as both a carrier of depolarizing charge and as a special chemical signal.
Description B: Ca2+ serves only as a carrier of depolarizing charge, not as a chemical signal.

Description A: Spontaneous otoacoustic emissions are generally too faint to be directly audible by others.
Description B: Spontaneous otoacoustic emissions are usually readily audible to others.

Description A: The basilar membrane displays compressive nonlinearity that accommodates a wide range of sound pressure into a narrow range of vibration amplitude.
Description B: The basilar membrane displays linear responsiveness that accommodates a wide range of sound pressure into a broad range of vibration amplitude.

Description A: The vomeronasal organ is present in many mammals, although not in humans.
Description B: The vomeronasal organ is present in many mammals, including humans.

Description A: Specific anosmias to some odorants are common, with a few occurring in 1% to 20% of people.
Description B: Specific anosmias to some odorants are uncommon, occurring in less than 1% of people.

Description A: Although the V1R receptors are thought to recognize volatile chemicals, at least some V2Rs are thought to recognize proteins.
Description B: Although the V1R receptors are thought to recognize proteins, at least some V2Rs are thought to recognize volatile chemicals.

Description A: Recent studies indicate that specific anosmias can be caused by mutations in particular odorant receptor genes.
Description B: Recent studies indicate that specific anosmias are unrelated to mutations in odorant receptor genes.

Description A: Chronic anosmia or hyposmia can result from damage to the olfactory epithelium caused by infections.
Description B: Chronic anosmia or hyposmia cannot result from damage to the olfactory epithelium caused by infections.

Description A: Pheromones are detected by two separate structures: the nasal olfactory epithelium and the vomeronasal organ.
Description B: Pheromones are detected by only one structure: the nasal olfactory epithelium.

Description A: In Drosophila, the main odorant receptor family has only 60 genes.
Description B: In Drosophila, the main odorant receptor family has more than 600 genes.

Description A: Invertebrates can be used to study odor coding and behavior due to their simple nervous systems.
Description B: Invertebrates cannot be used to study odor coding and behavior due to their complex nervous systems.

Description A: Pheromones play important roles in a variety of mammals, although they have not been demonstrated in humans.
Description B: Pheromones play important roles in both mammals and humans.

Description A: The V2R receptor differs from both V1R and odorant receptors in having a large extracellular domain at the N-terminal end.
Description B: The V2R receptor does not have a large extracellular domain at the N-terminal end.

Description A: Sensory detection in the vomeronasal organ differs from that in the olfactory epithelium.
Description B: Sensory detection in the vomeronasal organ is the same as that in the olfactory epithelium.

Description A: The vomeronasal organ has a family of five formyl peptide-related receptors (FPRs).
Description B: The vomeronasal organ has a family of ten formyl peptide-related receptors (FPRs).

Description A: Each olfactory neuron expresses one or sometimes two functional odorant receptor genes.
Description B: Each olfactory neuron expresses more than five functional odorant receptor genes.

Description A: Variation in amino acid sequence between members of each receptor family suggests that each family may recognize a variety of different ligands.
Description B: Variation in amino acid sequence between members of each receptor family suggests that each family recognizes only one ligand.

Description A: The insect odorant receptors were discovered by finding multigene receptor families in the Drosophila genome.
Description B: The insect odorant receptors were discovered by finding a single gene receptor in the Drosophila genome.

Description A: The activation of the Na+ current is preceded by a brief capacitive gating current (Ig), reflecting the outward movement of positive charges within the walls of the Na+ channels.
Description B: The activation of the Na+ current is preceded by a brief capacitive gating current (Ig), reflecting the inward movement of negative charges within the walls of the Na+ channels.

Description A: The sodium channel α-subunit consists of four repeated domains, each containing six transmembrane regions.
Description B: The sodium channel α-subunit consists of three repeated domains, each containing six transmembrane regions.

Description A: Depolarization of the cell membrane causes gating charge to move outward, activating the sodium channel.
Description B: Depolarization of the cell membrane causes gating charge to move inward, activating the sodium channel.

Description A: The sodium channel selects for Na+ over K+ based on the size and hydrogen-bonding characteristics of the ions.
Description B: The sodium channel selects for Na+ over K+ based on the electrostatic repulsion between the ions.

Description A: The selectivity filter has rectangular dimensions of 0.3 × 0.5 nm, large enough to accommodate one Na+ ion contacting one water molecule.
Description B: The selectivity filter has rectangular dimensions of 1.0 × 1.5 nm, large enough to accommodate one Na+ ion contacting one water molecule.

Description A: The voltage dependence of sodium channel activation is determined by the number of gating charges.
Description B: The voltage dependence of sodium channel activation is determined by the number of sodium ions.

Description A: In mammalian neurons, genes encode nine different α-subunits for voltage-gated sodium channels.
Description B: In mammalian neurons, genes encode three different α-subunits for voltage-gated sodium channels.

Description A: The functional diversity of voltage-gated channels can result from the addition of regulatory elements in cytoplasmic domains.
Description B: The functional diversity of voltage-gated channels solely depends on the transmembrane domains of the protein.

Description A: Some neurons express a dozen or more types of voltage-gated ion channels to expand signaling capabilities.
Description B: Some neurons express only one type of voltage-gated ion channel to expand signaling capabilities.

Description A: The voltage-gated sodium channels allow complex information processing and modulatory control in mammalian neurons.
Description B: The voltage-gated sodium channels allow only basic information processing in mammalian neurons.

Description A: Mutations or epigenetic changes in voltage-gated channels can produce neurological diseases known as channelopathies.
Description B: Mutations or epigenetic changes in voltage-gated channels have no effect on neuronal function.

Description A: Principal pore-forming α-subunits of voltage-gated channels are commonly combined with different accessory subunits to form various functional types.
Description B: Principal pore-forming α-subunits of voltage-gated channels are never combined with accessory subunits.

Description A: Some β-subunits enhance the efficiency of transporting channel proteins from the rough endoplasmic reticulum to the membrane.
Description B: Some β-subunits reduce the efficiency of transporting channel proteins from the rough endoplasmic reticulum to the membrane.

Description A: Channel diversity varies widely between different areas of the nervous system and different types of neurons.
Description B: Channel diversity is identical across all areas of the nervous system and across all types of neurons.

Description A: Voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels are encoded by an extended gene superfamily that also includes genes for cyclic nucleotide-gated channels.
Description B: Voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels are encoded by unrelated genes without a shared superfamily.

Description A: The primary motor cortex plays an important role in generating motor commands that control spinal activity, including selecting the timing and magnitude of muscle activity.
Description B: The spinal motor cortex solely controls spinal activity and does not participate in selecting the timing and magnitude of muscle activity.

Description A: The primary motor cortex contains an orderly motor map of major parts of the contralateral body, necessary for voluntary control of corresponding body parts.
Description B: The primary motor cortex contains a chaotic motor map of ipsilateral body parts, making voluntary control random.

Description A: The motor map in primates disproportionately represents finely controlled body parts, such as fingers, face, and mouth, due to a larger number of neurons required for fine motor control.
Description B: The motor map in primates proportionately represents all body parts equally, regardless of their motor function or control complexity.

Description A: Neurons controlling distal arm muscles are primarily concentrated within a central zone of the arm motor map, while neurons for proximal arm muscles are in a surrounding horseshoe-shaped ring.
Description B: Neurons controlling proximal arm muscles are concentrated within a central zone of the arm motor map, while neurons for distal arm muscles are in a surrounding horseshoe-shaped ring.

Description A: Corticomotoneuronal cells, which synapse directly onto spinal motor neurons, are found mostly in the caudal primary motor cortex in the anterior bank of the central sulcus.
Description B: Corticomotoneuronal cells, which synapse directly onto spinal motor neurons, are evenly distributed throughout the primary motor cortex.

Description A: Studies by Wilder Penfield demonstrated that areas controlling the hand and mouth are larger in humans compared to monkeys.
Description B: Studies by Wilder Penfield demonstrated that areas controlling the hand and mouth are smaller in humans compared to monkeys.

Description A: The motor map in the human cortex follows a general mediolateral organization similar to that observed in monkeys.
Description B: The motor map in the human cortex is randomly organized and does not follow patterns observed in monkeys.

Description A: CM cells projecting to spinal motor pools display a wide and overlapping distribution within the arm motor map.
Description B: CM cells projecting to spinal motor pools are isolated to specific, non-overlapping regions within the arm motor map.

Description A: Stimulating adjacent areas of the primary motor cortex evokes movements in adjacent body parts, demonstrating a topographic relationship.
Description B: Stimulating adjacent areas of the primary motor cortex evokes movements in random body parts, with no topographic relationship.

Description A: Horizontal axonal connections within the motor map allow coordination across different sites during the formation of motor commands.
Description B: Horizontal axonal connections within the motor map inhibit coordination across different sites during the formation of motor commands.

Description A: CM cells are uncommon or absent in nonprimate species and constitute a progressively larger component of the corticospinal tract in primates.
Description B: CM cells are common in nonprimate species and become less prevalent in the corticospinal tract of higher primates.

Description A: The motor cortex's representation of body parts is not a point-to-point anatomical reproduction but emphasizes finely controlled body parts disproportionately.
Description B: The motor cortex's representation of body parts is a point-to-point anatomical reproduction without disproportionate emphasis on any body parts.

Description A: Lesioning a cortical site typically perturbs or eliminates voluntary movement of the corresponding body part.
Description B: Lesioning a cortical site has no effect on voluntary movement of the corresponding body part.

Description A: Experimental studies by Gustav Fritsch and Eduard Hitzig demonstrated electrical stimulation of the cortex evokes movements in parts of the contralateral body.
Description B: Experimental studies by Gustav Fritsch and Eduard Hitzig demonstrated electrical stimulation of the cortex evokes movements in parts of the ipsilateral body.

Description A: Each muscle can be activated by stimulating multiple dispersed sites within the motor map.
Description B: Each muscle can only be activated by stimulating a single site within the motor map.

Description A: Taste buds are clustered in papillae on the tongue.
Description B: Taste buds are randomly scattered on the tongue surface.

Description A: Fungiform papillae are located on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
Description B: Fungiform papillae are located on the posterior third of the tongue.

Description A: Circumvallate papillae are structures surrounded by grooves lined with taste buds.
Description B: Circumvallate papillae are hollow structures without grooves.

Description A: Taste cells extend microvilli into the taste pore to contact chemicals dissolved in saliva.
Description B: Taste cells extend fibers into the brain to contact chemicals dissolved in saliva.

Description A: Taste cells can generate action potentials.
Description B: Taste cells cannot generate action potentials.

Description A: Taste cells have voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels.
Description B: Taste cells have voltage-gated Cl-, Mg2+, and Fe2+ channels.

Description A: Sweet tastants are detected by a combination of T1R2 and T1R3 receptors.
Description B: Sweet tastants are detected by a combination of T2R1 and T2R3 receptors.

Description A: T1R3 was initially discovered at the mouse saccharin preference (Sac) locus.
Description B: T1R3 was initially discovered at the human carbohydrate preference (Carb) locus.

Description A: Taste cells are nonneural but resemble neurons.
Description B: Taste cells are neurons with direct connections to the brain.

Description A: Umami tastants are detected by a combination of T1R1 and T1R3 receptors.
Description B: Umami tastants are detected by a combination of T1R2 and T1R4 receptors.

Description A: Salty tastants activate specific ion channels directly.
Description B: Salty tastants activate G protein–coupled receptors.

Description A: Bitter tastants are detected by T2R receptors.
Description B: Bitter tastants are detected by T1R receptors.

Description A: Taste cells are very short-lived and are continually replaced from stem cells.
Description B: Taste cells are long-lived and rarely replaced.

Description A: The pleasurable sensation of umami taste encourages the ingestion of proteins.
Description B: The pleasurable sensation of umami taste discourages the ingestion of proteins.

Description A: Each taste bud contains approximately 100 taste receptor cells.
Description B: Each taste bud contains approximately 10 taste receptor cells.

Description A: Taste cell turnover requires cells to differentiate to detect one of the five taste qualities.
Description B: Taste cell turnover allows detection of unlimited taste qualities.

Description A: At the peak of the action potential, the membrane potential approaches the Na+ equilibrium potential.
Description B: At the peak of the action potential, the membrane potential approaches the K+ equilibrium potential.

Description A: The Goldman equation takes into account both ionic concentration gradients and membrane permeability to calculate membrane potential.
Description B: The Goldman equation considers only ionic concentration gradients and ignores membrane permeability to calculate membrane potential.

Description A: The permeability ratio at the peak of the action potential is PK: PNa: PCl = 1.0 : 20 : 0.45.
Description B: The permeability ratio at the peak of the action potential is PK: PNa: PCl = 1.0 : 0.04 : 0.45.

Description A: The Na+-K+ pump moves three Na+ ions out and two K+ ions into the cell per cycle.
Description B: The Na+-K+ pump moves two Na+ ions out and three K+ ions into the cell per cycle.

Description A: The lipid bilayer gives the membrane electrical capacitance by separating charges on either side.
Description B: The lipid bilayer carries an electrical current across the membrane due to its conductance.

Description A: A typical capacitance value for a nerve cell membrane is approximately 1 μF per cm² of membrane area.
Description B: A typical capacitance value for a nerve cell membrane is approximately 100 μF per cm² of membrane area.

Description A: According to Ohm’s law, ionic current through a single-ion channel is determined by the voltage across the membrane.
Description B: According to Ohm’s law, ionic current through a single-ion channel is determined solely by the ion's concentration gradient.

Description A: Resting membrane potential is primarily influenced by K+ channels, which have higher permeability compared to Na+ and Cl− channels.
Description B: Resting membrane potential is primarily influenced by Na+ channels, which have higher permeability compared to K+ and Cl− channels.

Description A: [Na+]o has a minor effect on resting potential as compared to [K+]o.
Description B: [Na+]o has a strong effect on resting potential as compared to [K+]o.

Description A: The equivalent circuit of a neuron includes components like resistors, batteries, and capacitors to represent electrical properties.
Description B: The equivalent circuit of a neuron includes only batteries and capacitors, disregarding resistors.

Description A: The resting K+ current depends on the electrochemical driving force, which is given by (Vm − EK).
Description B: The resting K+ current depends only on the membrane potential, independent of EK.

Description A: A spherical nerve cell with a resting potential of −60 mV requires only a small fraction of ions to create this voltage.
Description B: A spherical nerve cell with a resting potential of −60 mV requires a large majority of ions in the cytoplasm to create this voltage.

Description A: The bulk of cytoplasm remains electroneutral despite charge separation across the membrane.
Description B: The bulk of cytoplasm develops a significant charge imbalance due to charge separation across the membrane.

Description A: The Goldman equation reduces to the Nernst equation when permeability to one ion dominates.
Description B: The Goldman equation replaces the Nernst equation regardless of permeability dominance.

Description A: The Na+-K+ pump contributes to the steady-state condition by balancing passive Na+ and K+ fluxes.
Description B: The Na+-K+ pump decreases the steady-state condition by overriding passive Na+ and K+ fluxes.

Description A: Clathrin-mediated uptake is often referred to as receptor-mediated endocytosis.
Description B: Clathrin-mediated uptake is often referred to as vesicle-mediated endocytosis.

Description A: One oligodendrocyte produces myelin sheaths for segments of as many as 30 axons.
Description B: One oligodendrocyte produces myelin sheaths for one segment of one axon.

Description A: Schwann cells produce myelin in the peripheral nervous system.
Description B: Schwann cells produce myelin in the central nervous system.

Description A: Axons with very small diameters are not myelinated.
Description B: Axons with very small diameters are heavily myelinated.

Description A: Receptor-mediated endocytosis involves selective uptake of molecules via receptors.
Description B: Receptor-mediated endocytosis involves non-selective uptake of extracellular molecules.

Description A: Nodes of Ranvier are unmyelinated gaps that expose the axon to extracellular space.
Description B: Nodes of Ranvier are heavily myelinated regions of the axon.

Description A: Myelination greatly increases the speed of nerve impulse conduction.
Description B: Myelination decreases the speed of nerve impulse conduction.

Description A: Glial cells play critical roles in brain development, function, and disease.
Description B: Glial cells primarily serve as structural support with minor functional roles in the brain.

Description A: CNS myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes.
Description B: CNS myelin is produced by Schwann cells.

Description A: The nodes of Ranvier contain a high density of Na+ channels.
Description B: The nodes of Ranvier contain a low density of Na+ channels.

Description A: One Schwann cell produces a single myelin sheath for one segment of one axon.
Description B: One Schwann cell can myelinate segments of many axons.

Description A: Astrocytes interact with neurons and synapses in the brain.
Description B: Astrocytes exclusively interact with blood vessels in the brain.

Description A: Saltatory conduction occurs in myelinated axons because the signal jumps from node to node.
Description B: Saltatory conduction occurs in unmyelinated axons due to continuous signal propagation.

Description A: Peripheral myelin is produced by Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system.
Description B: Peripheral myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes in the peripheral nervous system.

Description A: The number of myelin layers is proportional to the diameter of the axon.
Description B: The number of myelin layers is inversely proportional to the diameter of the axon.

Description A: In spinal muscular atrophy, genetic lesions (commonly deletions) in SMN1 lead to a marked reduction in levels of total SMN protein.
Description B: In spinal muscular atrophy, genetic lesions (commonly duplications) in SMN1 lead to a marked reduction in levels of total SMN protein.

Description A: Normally, most of the survival motor neuron (SMN) protein is produced from the SMN1 gene, whose mRNA is spliced from eight exons.
Description B: Normally, most of the survival motor neuron (SMN) protein is produced from the SMN2 gene, whose mRNA is spliced from eight exons.

Description A: An alternative therapeutic approach is to deliver an antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) that blocks the effect of hnRNPA1/A2, thereby enhancing production of a full-length mRNA from SMN2.
Description B: An alternative therapeutic approach is to use small interfering RNA (siRNA) that blocks the effect of hnRNPA1/A2, thereby enhancing production of a full-length mRNA from SMN2.

Description A: The best-known acute neuropathy is Guillain-Barré syndrome.
Description B: The best-known chronic neuropathy is Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Description A: Neuropathies may be categorized as demyelinating or axonal.
Description B: Neuropathies are only categorized as demyelinating.

Description A: In demyelinating neuropathies, conduction velocity is slowed.
Description B: In demyelinating neuropathies, conduction velocity is increased.

Description A: In axonal neuropathies, the myelin sheath is not affected and conduction velocity is normal.
Description B: In axonal neuropathies, the myelin sheath is affected and conduction velocity is slowed.

Description A: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is characterized by muscle weakness and wasting.
Description B: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is characterized by muscle strength increase and growth.

Description A: One form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (type 1) has the features of a demyelinating neuropathy.
Description B: One form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (type 1) has the features of an axonal neuropathy.

Description A: Type 2 Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has normal nerve conduction velocity and is considered an axonal neuropathy without demyelination.
Description B: Type 2 Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has reduced nerve conduction velocity and is considered a demyelinating neuropathy.

Description A: Myelin proteins are affected in a group of demyelinating hereditary peripheral neuropathies collectively termed Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.
Description B: Myelin proteins are unaffected in demyelinating hereditary peripheral neuropathies like Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.

Description A: Guillain-Barré syndrome may occur without apparent preceding illness.
Description B: Guillain-Barré syndrome always occurs after a preceding illness.

Description A: Peripheral neuropathies may lead to positive symptoms such as paresthesias.
Description B: Peripheral neuropathies may only lead to negative symptoms such as loss of sensation.

Description A: Axonal and demyelinating neuropathies may lead to both positive and negative symptoms.
Description B: Axonal and demyelinating neuropathies lead only to positive symptoms.

Description A: Demyelinating neuropathies are associated with a slowing of conduction velocity.
Description B: Demyelinating neuropathies are associated with an increase in conduction velocity.

Description A: IP3 stimulates the release of Ca2+ from intracellular stores in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.
Description B: IP3 stimulates the release of Ca2+ from external stores in the cytoplasmic membrane.

Description A: Calcium often acts by binding to the protein calmodulin to activate CaM kinase.
Description B: Calcium often acts by binding to the protein calmodulin to deactivate CaM kinase.

Description A: PKC is composed of a single protein molecule with both a regulatory domain and a catalytic domain.
Description B: PKC is composed of multiple protein molecules each with separate regulatory and catalytic domains.

Description A: PKC can become persistently active through the expression of a PKC isoform lacking a regulatory domain.
Description B: PKC can become persistently active through the expression of a PKC isoform lacking a catalytic domain.

Description A: Receptor tyrosine kinases are activated when bound by peptide hormones such as EGF and NGF.
Description B: Receptor tyrosine kinases are deactivated when bound by peptide hormones such as EGF and NGF.

Description A: After autophosphorylation, receptor tyrosine kinases activate signaling cascades through adaptor proteins.
Description B: Before autophosphorylation, receptor tyrosine kinases activate signaling cascades through adaptor proteins.

Description A: Tyrosine kinases regulate the activity of neuronal proteins they phosphorylate, including ion channel activity.
Description B: Tyrosine kinases decrease the activity of neuronal proteins they phosphorylate, including ion channel activity.

Description A: MAP kinases can be activated by a signaling cascade initiated by receptor tyrosine kinase.
Description B: MAP kinases can be inhibited by a signaling cascade initiated by receptor tyrosine kinase.

Description A: MAP kinases translocate to the nucleus to turn on gene transcription by phosphorylating transcription factors.
Description B: MAP kinases translocate to the cytoplasm to activate gene transcription by phosphorylating transcription factors.

Description A: Transcellular messengers can affect the cell that produces them and neighboring cells.
Description B: Transcellular messengers only affect the cell that produces them and not neighboring cells.

Description A: Endocannabinoids are a class of transcellular messengers.
Description B: Endocannabinoids are a class of intracellular second messengers.

Description A: Transcellular messengers act slower than those at fast synapses.
Description B: Transcellular messengers act faster than those at slow synapses.

Description A: Receptor Tyrosine Kinases initiate cascades involving adaptor proteins and protein kinases to change gene transcription.
Description B: Receptor Tyrosine Kinases inhibit cascades involving adaptor proteins and protein kinases to change gene transcription.

Description A: Calcium/calmodulin complex activates protein kinase by causing conformational changes.
Description B: Calcium/calmodulin complex deactivates protein kinase by causing conformational changes.

Description A: Phospholipase Cγ is activated by binding to phosphotyrosine residues.
Description B: Phospholipase Cγ is activated by binding to phosphoserine residues.

Description A: Cells in the primary visual cortex with similar functional properties are located close together in columns that extend from the surface of the cortex to the white matter.
Description B: Cells in the primary visual cortex with similar functional properties are randomly distributed across the cortex without any columnar organization.

Description A: Ocular dominance columns in the cortex are approximately 750 μm in width and appear as alternating left- and right-eye stripes.
Description B: Ocular dominance columns in the cortex are approximately 2500 μm in width and appear as overlapping left- and right-eye areas.

Description A: Ocular dominance reflects the segregation of thalamocortical inputs arriving from different layers of the LGN.
Description B: Ocular dominance reflects the integration of thalamocortical inputs from the same layer of the LGN.

Description A: The primary visual cortex develops properties like orientation specificity and the integration of inputs from the two eyes.
Description B: The primary visual cortex develops properties like sound localization and the integration of auditory inputs.

Description A: The magnification factor refers to the cortical area dedicated to each degree of visual space, which varies with eccentricity.
Description B: The magnification factor refers to the auditory area dedicated to each frequency, which varies with pitch.

Description A: The central part of the visual field commands the largest area of cortex in the primary visual cortex V1.
Description B: The peripheral part of the visual field commands the largest area of cortex in the primary visual cortex V1.

Description A: Receptive field size increases with distance from the fovea.
Description B: Receptive field size decreases with distance from the fovea.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus have circular symmetric receptive fields with antagonistic center and surround.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus have linear asymmetric receptive fields with harmonious center and surround.

Description A: A hypercolumn contains all possible combinations of orientation preference and left- and right-eye dominance.
Description B: A hypercolumn contains only one combination of orientation preference and eye dominance.

Description A: Blobs in the primary visual cortex are specialized to provide information about surfaces rather than edges.
Description B: Blobs in the primary visual cortex are specialized to provide information purely about edges and motion.

Description A: Cells with similar orientation preferences in the cortex are grouped into columns that cycle clockwise and counterclockwise.
Description B: Cells with similar orientation preferences in the cortex are randomly scattered without any cyclic pattern.

Description A: Orientation columns have a full 180° cycle that repeats every 750 μm in the cortex.
Description B: Orientation columns have a variable cycle that repeats every 2500 μm in the cortex.

Description A: Intrinsic-signal optical imaging visualizes changes in surface reflectance linked to metabolic needs of neurons.
Description B: Intrinsic-signal optical imaging visualizes external changes in retinal light adaptation.

Description A: The primary visual cortex is organized into columns, and this structure reflects the functional role of that area in vision.
Description B: The primary visual cortex is disorganized, and this structure lacks functional significance.

Description A: Histochemical labeling with cytochrome oxidase helped reveal clusters of neurons with color selectivity in the visual cortex.
Description B: Histochemical labeling with cytochrome oxidase showed clusters of neurons with sound selectivity in the auditory cortex.

Description A: Patients with global aphasia are almost completely unable to comprehend language or formulate and repeat sentences.
Description B: Patients with global aphasia can comprehend language and easily formulate and repeat sentences.

Description A: Wernicke's aphasia results from damage to the left posterior temporal lobe structures.
Description B: Wernicke's aphasia results from damage to the right anterior temporal lobe structures.

Description A: Broca's aphasia results from damage to Broca's area and surrounding frontal fields.
Description B: Broca's aphasia results from damage to the posterior occipital lobe and surrounding parietal fields.

Description A: Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the left superior temporal gyrus and inferior parietal lobe.
Description B: Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the right superior temporal gyrus and superior parietal lobe.

Description A: Transcortical motor aphasia involves damage to pathways connecting speech centers of the cortex to the rest of the brain.
Description B: Transcortical motor aphasia involves damage to pathways connecting the cerebellum to the spinal cord.

Description A: Transcortical sensory aphasia appears to be caused by damage to the ventral stream.
Description B: Transcortical sensory aphasia appears to be caused by damage to the dorsal stream.

Description A: Broca's aphasics typically have no difficulty perceiving speech sounds or recognizing their own errors.
Description B: Broca's aphasics typically have major difficulty perceiving speech sounds or recognizing their own errors.

Description A: Classic global aphasia involves damage to the inferior frontal and parietal cortices and the posterior superior temporal cortex.
Description B: Classic global aphasia involves damage to the inferior occipital and parietal cortices and the anterior superior temporal cortex.

Description A: Wernicke’s aphasics have difficulty selecting words that accurately represent their intended meaning, known as semantic paraphasia.
Description B: Wernicke’s aphasics do not experience difficulty selecting words that represent their intended meaning.

Description A: Damage to the left hemisphere auditory regions often produces speech production deficits.
Description B: Damage to the right hemisphere occipital regions often produces visual deficits.

Description A: Transcortical aphasias can be caused by damage that spares the arcuate fasciculus and the dorsal stream.
Description B: Transcortical aphasias can be caused by damage that affects the arcuate fasciculus and the dorsal stream.

Description A: Broca's aphasia patients may recover when damage is restricted to Broca's area alone.
Description B: Broca's aphasia patients never recover, even if damage is restricted to Broca's area alone.

Description A: Speech produced by Wernicke's aphasics can sound melodic but be unintelligible due to phonemic paraphasias.
Description B: Speech produced by Wernicke's aphasics is typically very clear and easily understood.

Description A: The supplementary motor area contributes to the initiation of speech.
Description B: The inferior occipital area contributes to the initiation of speech.

Description A: Damage to the left primary auditory cortex can extend in cases of conduction aphasia.
Description B: Damage to the right primary visual cortex can extend in cases of conduction aphasia.

Description A: Time delays in the sensorimotor system can be on the order of 100 ms and depend on the particular sensory modality.
Description B: Time delays in the sensorimotor system can be on the order of 10 ms and do not depend on the particular sensory modality.

Description A: Reflexes are stereotyped responses to specific stimuli and occur on a shorter timescale than voluntary responses.
Description B: Reflexes are random responses to any stimuli and occur on a longer timescale than voluntary responses.

Description A: Voluntary movements can be generated in the absence of a stimulus.
Description B: Voluntary movements require a stimulus to be generated.

Description A: Feedforward control situations involve open-loop control, reflecting that the sensorimotor loop is not completed by sensory feedback.
Description B: Feedforward control situations involve closed-loop control, reflecting that the sensorimotor loop is completed by sensory feedback.

Description A: Muscles have substantial passive properties that depend on both the motor command acting on the muscle and the muscle’s length and rate of change of length.
Description B: Muscles have no passive properties and depend solely on the motor command acting on the muscle.

Description A: The strength of a reflex tends to increase with the tension in a muscle, a concept known as gain-scaling.
Description B: The strength of a reflex is unaffected by the tension in a muscle, which is unrelated to gain-scaling.

Description A: The vestibulo-ocular reflex uses open-loop control to fix gaze on an object during head rotation.
Description B: The vestibulo-ocular reflex uses closed-loop control to fix gaze on an object during head rotation.

Description A: Feedforward control is required for rapid movements due to delays in sensing and acting in the sensorimotor system.
Description B: Feedforward control is not required for rapid movements as there are no delays in sensing and acting in the sensorimotor system.

Description A: Multisynaptic reflexes can produce responses at around 70 ms and are adaptable to changes in behavioral goals.
Description B: Multisynaptic reflexes produce responses at around 700 ms and are not adaptable to changes in behavioral goals.

Description A: Motor control occurs through a hierarchy of control centers with higher levels planning more global goals.
Description B: Motor control occurs without hierarchy or planning and relies solely on spontaneous actions.

Description A: Conscious processes are not necessary for moment-to-moment control of movement.
Description B: Conscious processes are essential for moment-to-moment control of movement.

Description A: Sensory inputs can cause motor output directly without intervention of higher brain centers.
Description B: Sensory inputs always require intervention of higher brain centers for motor output.

Description A: The motion of each body segment produces torques and potentially motions at all other body segments through mechanical interactions.
Description B: The motion of each body segment has no effect on other body segments.

Description A: Reflexes are generated by simple neural circuits in the spinal cord or brain stem and occur faster than voluntary movements.
Description B: Reflexes are generated by complex neural circuits in the cerebral cortex and occur slower than voluntary movements.

Description A: Voluntary correction to a small physical perturbation can occur with a latency of about 110 ms.
Description B: Voluntary correction to a small physical perturbation can occur with a latency of about 10 ms.

Description A: Circadian rhythms are driven by a small group of GABAergic neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus located in the hypothalamus above the optic chiasm.
Description B: Circadian rhythms are driven by dopamine-releasing neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus located below the optic chiasm.

Description A: BMAL1 and CLOCK form a dimer that binds to the E-box motif, regulating the transcription of Period and Cryptochrome genes.
Description B: BMAL1 and CLOCK form a dimer that binds to the D-box motif, regulating the transcription of Period and Cryptochrome genes.

Description A: The sublaterodorsal area in rodents corresponds to the subceruleus region in humans and is involved in generating REM sleep.
Description B: The sublaterodorsal area in rodents corresponds to the suprachiasmatic nucleus in humans and is involved in generating REM sleep.

Description A: Loss of REM-on neurons in the sublaterodorsal area can result in REM sleep behavior disorder, allowing individuals to act out their dreams.
Description B: Loss of REM-on neurons in the sublaterodorsal area causes insomnia because individuals cannot achieve REM sleep.

Description A: Cholinergic neurons in the pedunculopontine and laterodorsal tegmental nuclei promote REM sleep.
Description B: Serotonergic neurons in the pedunculopontine and laterodorsal tegmental nuclei promote REM sleep.

Description A: Orexinergic neurons play a role in maintaining wakefulness and are active during non-REM sleep.
Description B: Orexinergic neurons play a role in maintaining wakefulness but become inactive during REM sleep.

Description A: Homeostatic sleep drive gradually builds up during wakefulness and peaks at bedtime.
Description B: Homeostatic sleep drive gradually builds up during sleep and peaks during waking hours.

Description A: Antidepressants that increase monoamine levels suppress REM sleep.
Description B: Antidepressants that increase monoamine levels promote REM sleep.

Description A: The ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO) releases GABA and galanin to inhibit arousal systems during sleep.
Description B: The ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO) releases glutamate and galanin to inhibit arousal systems during sleep.

Description A: The dorsal raphe nucleus inhibits the REM generator using serotonergic inputs.
Description B: The dorsal raphe nucleus inhibits the REM generator using acetylcholine inputs.

Description A: Circadian wake signals collapse rapidly before bedtime as the homeostatic sleep drive rises.
Description B: Circadian wake signals increase rapidly before bedtime as the homeostatic sleep drive falls.

Description A: Loss of orexinergic neurons can cause abrupt onset of REM sleep.
Description B: Loss of orexinergic neurons can inhibit REM-on neurons, preventing REM sleep entirely.

Description A: The flip-flop switch mechanism helps regulate transitions between wakefulness and sleep.
Description B: The flip-flop switch mechanism disrupts transitions between wakefulness and sleep.

Description A: The REM sleep switch involves both REM-on and REM-off neurons, which are mutually inhibitory.
Description B: The REM sleep switch involves only REM-on neurons that activate REM sleep.

Description A: Circadian rhythms in humans are primarily driven by transcriptional-translational cycles of clock genes.
Description B: Circadian rhythms in humans are primarily driven by homeostatic changes in melatonin secretion without clock genes.

Description A: Patients with amnesia have difficulty imagining the future as well as remembering the past due to loss of creativity.
Description B: Patients with amnesia have no difficulty imagining the future, only remembering the past.

Description A: Damage to the frontal cortex can impair metacognition while leaving decision-making intact.
Description B: Damage to the frontal cortex affects both metacognition and decision-making.

Description A: A sense of agency can become detached from the control of action in extreme cases.
Description B: A sense of agency is always reliably connected to the control of action.

Description A: Confidence in our choices is an example of metacognition.
Description B: Confidence in our choices is purely a result of instinct rather than metacognition.

Description A: Verbal reports are not always reliable because people can fake memory loss.
Description B: Verbal reports are always reliable and cannot be faked.

Description A: Memory is a creative process based on imperfect recall filled out with general knowledge.
Description B: Memory is a direct process identical to replaying a video.

Description A: Antipsychotic drugs act on dopaminergic systems in the brain.
Description B: Antipsychotic drugs primarily act on cholinergic systems in the brain.

Description A: Schizophrenia is characterized by cognitive impairments, deficit symptoms, and psychotic symptoms.
Description B: Schizophrenia is characterized only by psychotic symptoms.

Description A: Mental illnesses are the leading cause of disability worldwide.
Description B: Mental illnesses are a minor cause of disability worldwide.

Description A: Schizophrenia has a characteristic course of illness with onset during the second and third decades of life.
Description B: Schizophrenia typically begins after the third decade of life.

Description A: The psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia tend to be episodic.
Description B: The psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia are continuous.

Description A: Abnormalities in brain development during adolescence may be responsible for schizophrenia.
Description B: Brain development abnormalities during childhood are solely responsible for schizophrenia.

Description A: Loss of gray matter in the cerebral cortex appears to result from loss of synaptic contacts rather than loss of cells.
Description B: Loss of gray matter in the cerebral cortex results primarily from the loss of cells.

Description A: Damage to the inferior temporal cortex can result in loss of conscious awareness of the shape of an object.
Description B: Damage to the inferior temporal cortex enhances conscious awareness of the shape of an object.

Description A: People can fake memory loss to escape justice, which resembles disorders such as hysterical amnesia.
Description B: People cannot fake memory loss to escape justice, as it always appears different from disorders like hysterical amnesia.

Description A: In adult muscle, ACh receptors are relatively stable with a half-life of approximately 2 weeks.
Description B: In adult muscle, ACh receptors are relatively stable with a half-life of approximately 2 days.

Description A: During the first few postnatal days, the γ gene in ACh receptors is turned off and a closely related gene called ε is activated.
Description B: During the first few postnatal days, the δ gene in ACh receptors is turned off and a closely related gene called γ is activated.

Description A: The metabolic stabilization of ACh receptors helps concentrate them at synaptic sites and stabilize the postsynaptic apparatus.
Description B: The metabolic stabilization of ACh receptors disperses them from synaptic sites and destabilizes the postsynaptic apparatus.

Description A: In the embryo, ACh receptors are turned over rapidly, with a half-life of approximately 1 day.
Description B: In the embryo, ACh receptors are turned over slowly, with a half-life of approximately 1 week.

Description A: The initial aggregate of ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction appears to have a plaque-like appearance.
Description B: The initial aggregate of ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction appears to have a pretzel-like appearance.

Description A: Central synapses and neuromuscular junctions are structurally and functionally similar in several ways.
Description B: Central synapses and neuromuscular junctions are completely distinct in structure and function.

Description A: The cellular logic of synapse formation is conserved between neuromuscular junctions and central synapses.
Description B: The cellular logic of synapse formation is distinct between neuromuscular junctions and central synapses.

Description A: Agrin and laminins do not play key roles at central synapses but are crucial at neuromuscular junctions.
Description B: Agrin and laminins play a critical role at central synapses just as they do at neuromuscular junctions.

Description A: Electrical activity regulates expression of neurotransmitter receptors in neurons.
Description B: Electrical activity inhibits expression of neurotransmitter receptors in neurons.

Description A: At inhibitory synapses, clusters of glycine receptors fail to form in gephyrin-deficient mutant mice.
Description B: At inhibitory synapses, clusters of glycine receptors form normally in gephyrin-deficient mutant mice.

Description A: Neurotransmitter receptors like GABA and glutamate receptors are concentrated in patches aligned with nerve terminals.
Description B: Neurotransmitter receptors like GABA and glutamate receptors are distributed randomly across neuronal membranes.

Description A: The postsynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction matures in stages, starting as loose aggregates and later forming folds.
Description B: The postsynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction matures in a single stage, immediately forming folds.

Description A: Newly formed ACh receptor clusters in the embryo are composed of α-, β-, δ-, and γ-subunits.
Description B: Newly formed ACh receptor clusters in the embryo are composed of α-, β-, δ-, and ε-subunits.

Description A: Neurexins are enriched in presynaptic membranes, and neuroligins are concentrated in postsynaptic membranes.
Description B: Neurexins are concentrated in postsynaptic membranes, and neuroligins are enriched in presynaptic membranes.

Description A: Glutamate and GABA receptors become selectively clustered beneath terminals releasing corresponding neurotransmitters.
Description B: Glutamate and GABA receptors are randomly clustered, independent of neurotransmitter release by terminals.

Description A: Microglia interact with synaptic elements in the healthy brain and contribute to neuroinflammation and synapse loss in neurodegenerative diseases.
Description B: Microglia solely interact with synaptic elements in the healthy brain and do not contribute to neuroinflammation or synapse loss in neurodegenerative diseases.

Description A: The choroid plexus is the primary site of cerebrospinal fluid production, with ciliary motion aiding its circulation.
Description B: The ependymal cells are the primary site of cerebrospinal fluid production, with ciliary motion aiding its circulation.

Description A: The choroid plexus epithelial cells form tight junctions to regulate molecule movement into the brain.
Description B: The choroid plexus epithelial cells form loose junctions to regulate molecule movement into the brain.

Description A: The choroid plexus epithelial cells synthesize and secrete many proteins into the cerebrospinal fluid that modulate neural stem cell development and cortical plasticity.
Description B: The choroid plexus epithelial cells do not synthesize or secrete proteins into the cerebrospinal fluid.

Description A: Neurons are highly polarized cells with dendritic and axonal compartments specialized for receiving and transmitting signals.
Description B: Neurons are highly polarized cells with non-specialized compartments for generalized cellular functions.

Description A: Most neuronal proteins are synthesized in the cell body, but synthesis also occurs in dendrites and axons.
Description B: Most neuronal proteins are synthesized in dendrites and axons, with minimal synthesis occurring in the cell body.

Description A: Astrocytes regulate extracellular ion concentrations and actively participate in the formation and function of synapses.
Description B: Astrocytes regulate extracellular ion concentrations but do not participate in synapse formation or function.

Description A: The cytoskeleton provides a framework for organelle transport and controls axonal and dendritic morphology in neurons.
Description B: The cytoskeleton solely controls neuronal morphology and does not play a role in organelle transport.

Description A: Transport of proteins and mRNA in neurons occurs with great specificity, supporting vectorial transport to selected membrane components.
Description B: Transport of proteins and mRNA in neurons occurs randomly and does not support vectorial transport.

Description A: Loose junctions between ependymal cells provide cerebrospinal fluid access to the brain's interstitial space.
Description B: Tight junctions between ependymal cells block cerebrospinal fluid access to the brain's interstitial space.

Description A: Neuronal activity profoundly modifies cell structure and function, driving neural circuit adaptation to experience.
Description B: Neuronal activity has no significant effect on cell structure or function, preventing adaptation to experience.

Description A: Oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells produce myelin insulation to enable axons to conduct electrical signals rapidly.
Description B: Both oligodendrocytes and astrocytes produce myelin insulation to enable axons to conduct electrical signals rapidly.

Description A: The choroid plexus epithelial cell secretome can be altered by inflammatory signals, impacting neuronal function during infection and aging.
Description B: The choroid plexus epithelial cell secretome remains unchanged by inflammatory signals during infection or aging.

Description A: Fenestrated capillaries in the choroid plexus allow free passage of water and small molecules into the stromal space.
Description B: Fenestrated capillaries in the choroid plexus block passage of water and small molecules into the stromal space.

Description A: Active transport in the choroid plexus epithelium regulates bidirectional flux of molecules between cerebrospinal fluid and peripheral circulation.
Description B: Passive transport in the choroid plexus epithelium regulates bidirectional flux of molecules between cerebrospinal fluid and peripheral circulation.

Description A: The RNS System provides proof-of-concept evidence for closed-loop seizure detection and stimulation.
Description B: The RNS System uses open-loop seizure detection and stimulation as proof-of-concept evidence.

Description A: The vagus nerve stimulator can be activated by the patient using a hand-held magnet during an aura to prevent a seizure.
Description B: The vagus nerve stimulator activates automatically without patient intervention during an aura to prevent a seizure.

Description A: In the optogenetic approach, a virus is engineered to express ion channels or pumps that reduce neuron excitability when exposed to light.
Description B: In the optogenetic approach, a virus is engineered to deliver electric shocks to neurons to reduce excitability when exposed to light.

Description A: Unlike focal onset seizures, generalized onset seizures are not preceded by an aura or followed by postictal symptoms.
Description B: Unlike generalized onset seizures, focal onset seizures are not preceded by an aura or followed by postictal symptoms.

Description A: Focal seizures that secondarily generalize can involve both hemispheres through transcallosal pathways.
Description B: Focal seizures that secondarily generalize predominantly remain in one hemisphere and do not involve transcallosal pathways.

Description A: T-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels play a role in generalized onset seizures like typical absence seizures.
Description B: T-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels play no role in generalized onset seizures like typical absence seizures.

Description A: Ethosuximide and valproic acid block T-type channels, reducing the occurrence of typical absence seizures.
Description B: Ethosuximide and valproic acid increase T-type channel activity, promoting typical absence seizures.

Description A: Rapid generalization of focal onset seizures is more likely to occur when they begin in the neocortex.
Description B: Rapid generalization of focal onset seizures is more likely to occur when they begin in the limbic system.

Description A: Thalamocortical circuits contribute significantly to the spread of generalized onset seizures.
Description B: Thalamocortical circuits are not involved in the spread of generalized onset seizures.

Description A: Generalized onset seizures disrupt activity in both cerebral hemispheres simultaneously.
Description B: Generalized onset seizures usually disrupt activity in only one cerebral hemisphere.

Description A: Patients with typical absence seizures can experience impaired awareness along with minor motor symptoms.
Description B: Patients with typical absence seizures do not experience impaired awareness, but only exhibit minor motor symptoms.

Description A: Penfield and Jasper hypothesized that generalized seizures could be attributed to rhythmic activity in the thalamus.
Description B: Penfield and Jasper hypothesized that generalized seizures were not related to thalamic activity.

Description A: The postictal period may include symptoms such as confusion and drowsiness or even focal neurological deficits.
Description B: The postictal period is generally free of symptoms such as confusion or focal neurological deficits.

Description A: Patients with focal onset seizures followed by secondary generalization usually experience loss of consciousness.
Description B: Patients with focal onset seizures followed by secondary generalization rarely experience loss of consciousness.

Description A: Pre-ictal EEG patterns show great variability between patients, making it difficult to predict seizures.
Description B: Pre-ictal EEG patterns remain consistent among patients, making it easy to predict seizures.

Description A: The activity of many primary motor cortex neurons increases with the amplitude of static torque generated across a single joint.
Description B: The activity of many primary motor cortex neurons decreases with the amplitude of static torque generated across a single joint.

Description A: The activity of some primary motor cortex neurons varies with the direction of isometric forces.
Description B: The activity of all primary motor cortex neurons varies uniformly with the direction of isometric forces.

Description A: Reaching movements with similar hand trajectories but different arm orientations require changes in joint-centered torques and muscle activity.
Description B: Reaching movements with similar hand trajectories and different arm orientations do not require changes in muscle activity or joint-centered torques.

Description A: Muscular torques tend to be larger for movements to the right and left compared to movements away from or toward the body.
Description B: Muscular torques tend to be smaller for movements to the right and left compared to movements away from or toward the body.

Description A: Joint power is greatest for movements away from the body and slightly to the left.
