Description B: Joint power is lowest for movements away from the body and slightly to the left.

Description A: Preferred directions of proximal-limb muscles tend to align with movements that require greater muscular power.
Description B: Preferred directions of proximal-limb muscles tend to align with movements that require minimal muscular power.

Description A: The distribution of preferred directions of M1 neurons parallels the bias in the physics of limb movement.
Description B: The distribution of preferred directions of M1 neurons does not relate to the physics of limb movement.

Description A: Some single M1 neurons can be correlated with specific components of muscle contraction patterns during motor tasks.
Description B: No single M1 neurons are correlated with specific components of muscle contraction patterns during motor tasks.

Description A: The final pattern of muscle activity is generated by spinal motor neurons, which integrate supraspinal inputs and interneuronal processes.
Description B: The final pattern of muscle activity is generated by M1 neurons exclusively, without additional integration from supraspinal inputs.

Description A: Voluntary motor control involves coordinated activity of many neurons throughout the motor system.
Description B: Voluntary motor control involves activity of individual neurons independently, without coordination across the motor system.

Description A: Vector notation is used to represent neuron activity in M1 during reaching movements, with preferred directions and discharge rates determining the resultant movement.
Description B: Vector notation is not capable of representing neuron activity in M1 during reaching movements or predicting resultant movements.

Description A: Population vectors from the activity of 250 M1 neurons can predict the direction of reach movements.
Description B: Population vectors from the activity of 250 M1 neurons do not provide insight into the direction of reach movements.

Description A: Instantaneous population vectors extracted from M1 neuron activity predict changes in arm trajectory during sequential time intervals.
Description B: Instantaneous population vectors fail to predict changes in arm trajectory during sequential time intervals.

Description A: Coordination of M1 neuron activity distinguishes the unique identity of different reach actions.
Description B: Coordination of M1 neuron activity fails to distinguish the unique identity of different reach actions.

Description A: M1 neurons distributed throughout the arm motor map contribute to motor control during reaching movements.
Description B: M1 neurons in the arm motor map are not involved in motor control during reaching movements.

Description A: In the visual system, feedforward projections from the primary visual cortex to secondary and tertiary visual areas originate mainly in layer III and terminate mainly in layer IV of the target cortical area.
Description B: In the visual system, feedforward projections from the primary visual cortex to secondary and tertiary visual areas originate mainly in layer V and terminate mainly in layer II of the target cortical area.

Description A: The cerebral cortex is organized into columns of cells that extend from the white matter to the surface of the cortex, forming highly specialized computational modules.
Description B: The cerebral cortex is organized into columns of cells that extend from the gray matter to the hippocampus, forming nonspecialized computational modules.

Description A: The somatosensory cortex contains several somatotopic maps, including four complete maps of the skin in Brodmann areas 3a, 3b, 1, and 2.
Description B: The somatosensory cortex contains several somatotopic maps, including six complete maps of the skin in Brodmann areas 3a, 4b, 1, and 2.

Description A: Area 2 of the somatosensory cortex may be responsible for integrated perception of three-dimensional solid objects, termed stereognosis.
Description B: Area 2 of the somatosensory cortex may be responsible for integrated perception of two-dimensional surfaces, termed stereognosis.

Description A: The corticospinal tract is also known as the pyramidal tract because its fibers form the medullary pyramids on the ventral surface of the medulla.
Description B: The corticospinal tract is also known as the pyramidal tract because its fibers form the cortical columns on the ventral surface of the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Approximately 40% of the axons in the human corticospinal tract originate in the motor cortex.
Description B: Approximately 80% of the axons in the human corticospinal tract originate in the motor cortex.

Description A: Most corticospinal fibers cross the midline at the pyramidal decussation in the medulla.
Description B: Most corticospinal fibers cross the midline at the pyramidal decussation in the cerebral peduncle.

Description A: The motor cortex outputs are influenced by the cerebellum and basal ganglia, which provide feedback for smooth execution of skilled movements.
Description B: The motor cortex outputs are influenced by the thalamus and amygdala, which provide feedback for smooth execution of skilled movements.

Description A: Ascending feedforward pathways generally originate in superficial layers of the cortex and invariably terminate in layer IV.
Description B: Ascending feedforward pathways generally originate in deep layers of the cortex and invariably terminate in layer VI.

Description A: Descending feedback pathways generally originate from deep cortical layers and terminate in layers I and VI.
Description B: Descending feedback pathways generally originate from superficial cortical layers and terminate in layers II and IV.

Description A: The primary somatosensory cortex projects to both the motor cortex in the frontal lobe and the somatosensory association area in the parietal cortex.
Description B: The primary somatosensory cortex projects to both the multimodal association cortex in the frontal lobe and the premotor cortex in the occipital region.

Description A: The somatosensory association area projects to higher-order somatosensory association areas and the premotor cortex.
Description B: The somatosensory association area projects to lower-order somatosensory areas and the hippocampus.

Description A: Unimodal association areas converge on multimodal association areas to integrate sensory modalities.
Description B: Unimodal association areas diverge from multimodal association areas to separate sensory modalities.

Description A: Neurons in a single cortical column typically share similar response properties, forming a local processing network.
Description B: Neurons in a single cortical column typically have widely varying response properties, forming a global processing network.

Description A: Columns in the cerebral cortex are roughly one-third of a millimeter in diameter.
Description B: Columns in the cerebral cortex are roughly one millimeter in diameter.

Description A: The basal ganglia exercise influence over external structures by the fundamental processes of inhibition and disinhibition.
Description B: The basal ganglia exercise influence over external structures primarily through excitatory processes.

Description A: GABAergic neurons in the basal ganglia output nuclei typically have high tonic firing rates, ensuring constant inhibitory control over target regions.
Description B: GABAergic neurons in the basal ganglia output nuclei typically have low tonic firing rates, minimizing their influence on target regions.

Description A: Focused suppression from striatal inputs releases targeted regions in the thalamus and brain stem from tonic inhibition.
Description B: Focused suppression from striatal inputs enhances tonic inhibition in targeted regions of the thalamus and brain stem.

Description A: The basal ganglia architecture has remained highly conserved across vertebrate evolution for over 500 million years.
Description B: The basal ganglia architecture has undergone significant changes during vertebrate evolution over 500 million years.

Description A: The basal ganglia are shared by all vertebrate species and solve selection problems unchanged for millions of years.
Description B: The basal ganglia are exclusive to mammals and have evolved specifically for human-centric selection problems.

Description A: In vertebrate multimodal sensory systems, selective attention resolves competing external stimuli to direct movement.
Description B: In vertebrate multimodal sensory systems, selective attention enhances multiple external stimuli simultaneously to direct movement.

Description A: The intrinsic circuits in the basal ganglia nuclei are similar across limbic, associative, and sensorimotor territories.
Description B: The intrinsic circuits in the basal ganglia nuclei are unique to the sensorimotor territories.

Description A: The phasic excitatory input signals to the striatum carry representations of behavioral options competing for expression.
Description B: The phasic excitatory input signals to the striatum suppress representations of behavioral options competing for expression.

Description A: The basal ganglia evaluate competing options based on their relative biological importance or salience.
Description B: The basal ganglia evaluate competing options based on their speed of neural transmission.

Description A: Selective disinhibition by the basal ganglia prevents distortion of the selected option’s input to motor systems.
Description B: Selective disinhibition by the basal ganglia enhances distortion of the selected option’s input to motor systems.

Description A: The basal ganglia architecture supports competitions between sensory, motivational, cognitive, and motor systems.
Description B: The basal ganglia architecture excludes competitions between sensory, motivational, cognitive, and motor systems.

Description A: Tonic inhibitory output is maintained on nonselected channels within the basal ganglia network.
Description B: Tonic inhibitory output is completely suppressed on nonselected channels within the basal ganglia network.

Description A: The return connections of the basal ganglia loops via the thalamus are often omitted in simplified diagrams for clarity.
Description B: The return connections of the basal ganglia loops via the thalamus are rarely included due to their irrelevance to functional processes.

Description A: Comparisons of mammalian basal ganglia with those of ancient vertebrates show remarkable similarities in structure and function.
Description B: Comparisons of mammalian basal ganglia with those of ancient vertebrates show significant divergences in structure and function.

Description A: The basal ganglia play a recurring role in action selection and reinforcement learning.
Description B: The basal ganglia primarily function as systems for sensory enhancement and motor suppression.

Description A: Neurons in the primary visual cortex (area V1) are the first to respond differentially to the direction of motion in higher mammals and primates.
Description B: Neurons in the somatosensory cortex are the first to respond differentially to the direction of motion in higher mammals and primates.

Description A: The frequency of the second test stimulus (f2) in the vibratory task was chosen from a range of values between 10 to 30 Hz.
Description B: The frequency of the second test stimulus (f2) in the vibratory task was chosen from a range of values between 20 to 40 Hz.

Description A: In the random dot motion discrimination task, motion strength is expressed as a percentage coherence ranging from 0% to 100%.
Description B: In the random dot motion discrimination task, motion strength is expressed as a percentage coherence ranging from 50% to 150%.

Description A: The psychometric function models the relationship between the accuracy of an animal’s choice and motion strength.
Description B: The psychometric function models the relationship between neural firing rates and motion strength.

Description A: Area MT contains a complete map of the contralateral visual field and features neurons that are direction-selective.
Description B: Area V1 contains a complete map of the contralateral visual field and features neurons that are direction-selective.

Description A: Leftward and rightward direction-selective neurons contribute noisy evidence to perceptual decisions.
Description B: Direction-tuned neurons in the thalamus contribute noisy evidence to perceptual decisions.

Description A: In flutter-vibration tasks, monkeys identify whether the second vibration frequency is higher or lower than the first frequency.
Description B: In flutter-vibration tasks, monkeys identify whether the first vibration frequency is higher or lower than the second frequency.

Description A: At 0% coherence in the random dot motion task, the dots appear to dance randomly like snowflakes with no dominant direction.
Description B: At 0% coherence in the random dot motion task, the dots appear to move consistently to the right or left.

Description A: Area MT, also known as area V5 in humans, is involved in processing motion direction and strength.
Description B: Area V1, also known as area V5 in humans, is involved in processing motion direction and strength.

Description A: The decision variable in the motion discrimination task represents the difference between firing rates of left- and right-preferring neurons.
Description B: The decision variable in the motion discrimination task represents the average firing rate of all direction-tuned neurons.

Description A: Monkeys perform the random dot motion discrimination task at nearly identical levels to humans.
Description B: Monkeys perform the random dot motion discrimination task at drastically lower levels than humans.

Description A: In the random dot motion task, difficulty is manipulated by degrading the signal-to-noise ratio.
Description B: In the random dot motion task, difficulty is manipulated by increasing the angular difference between motion directions.

Description A: Mountcastle found neurons phase-locked to flutter frequencies but did not observe neurons tuned to specific frequencies like those in area MT.
Description B: Mountcastle observed neurons phase-locked to flutter frequencies and tuned to specific frequencies like those in area MT.

Description A: During trials of the random dot motion task, monkeys are rewarded for correct answers at all levels of difficulty.
Description B: During trials of the random dot motion task, monkeys are rewarded only during weak-motion trials.

Description A: At lower coherence values, random motion introduces variability in the evidence gathered by neurons during the motion discrimination task.
Description B: At lower coherence values, directional neurons eliminate variability in the evidence gathered during the motion discrimination task.

Description A: The gluteus medius muscle in the cat responds to motion in several directions in the horizontal plane, as shown by electromyographic (EMG) activity.
Description B: The gluteus medius muscle in the cat responds exclusively to motion in one direction in the horizontal plane, as shown by electromyographic (EMG) activity.

Description A: Postural responses adapt gradually to new biomechanical conditions and are influenced by recent experience.
Description B: Postural responses immediately adapt to new biomechanical conditions and are not influenced by recent experience.

Description A: When forward sway is induced by backward motion of a narrow beam, anterior muscles of the hip and trunk are activated to restore equilibrium using the hip strategy.
Description B: When forward sway is induced by backward motion of a narrow beam, posterior muscles of the ankle are activated to restore equilibrium using the hip strategy.

Description A: The ankle strategy rotates the body primarily about the ankle joints, restoring balance during postural sway.
Description B: The ankle strategy restores balance primarily by bending forward at the hip joints during postural sway.

Description A: Trial-to-trial changes in postural behavior occur generally at a subconscious level, involving implicit learning and updates to the body schema.
Description B: Trial-to-trial changes in postural behavior occur instantaneously, involving explicit feedback rather than implicit learning.

Description A: Muscle synergies group the activation of several muscles into fixed proportions to achieve specific postural goals.
Description B: Muscle synergies activate muscles individually to achieve specific postural goals without grouping them into fixed proportions.

Description A: Only four synergies are needed to account for the majority of activation patterns of 13 leg and trunk muscles during postural responses.
Description B: Thirteen synergies are needed to account for the activation patterns of 13 leg and trunk muscles during postural responses.

Description A: Each muscle belongs to more than one synergy and contributes to multiple postural goals.
Description B: Each muscle belongs exclusively to one synergy and contributes to only one postural goal.

Description A: Concurrent activation of synergies simplifies neural command signals while allowing flexibility and adaptability in postural control.
Description B: Concurrent activation of synergies fragments neural command signals, reducing flexibility and adaptability in postural control.

Description A: The center of mass (CoM) is shifted by activating specific muscle synergies in response to postural disturbances.
Description B: The center of mass (CoM) remains static and does not involve muscle synergies in response to postural disturbances.

Description A: Responses to postural disturbances must occur within a time limit or balance will be lost.
Description B: Responses to postural disturbances can occur at any time with no impact on balance.

Description A: Postural commands activate synergies rather than individual muscles to produce coordinated mechanical outputs.
Description B: Postural commands activate individual muscles rather than synergies to produce coordinated mechanical outputs.

Description A: Postural responses improve with practice and are retained as a sign of motor learning.
Description B: Postural responses become worse with practice and do not show retention as a sign of motor learning.

Description A: The hip strategy restores the body's center of mass by bending forward at the hip joints and counter-rotating at the ankles.
Description B: The hip strategy restores the body's center of mass by rotating the body solely about the ankle joints.

Description A: Sensory stimulation changes immediately after moving from the beam to the floor, but postural responses adjust gradually.
Description B: Sensory stimulation changes gradually after moving from the beam to the floor, and postural responses adjust immediately.

Description A: The ease with which we move, from tying our shoelaces to returning a tennis serve, masks the complexity of the control processes involved.
Description B: The complexity of the control processes involved in movement is clearly visible in tasks like tying our shoelaces and returning a tennis serve.

Description A: Motor systems produce neural commands that act on the muscles, causing them to contract and generate movement.
Description B: Motor systems produce neural commands that act directly on the skeletal system, bypassing the muscles entirely.

Description A: Voluntary movements are generated by neural circuits that span different levels of the sensory and motor hierarchies.
Description B: Voluntary movements are generated by neural circuits confined to the spinal cord.

Description A: Focal damage to different structures can cause distinct motor deficits.
Description B: Focal damage to different structures cannot cause any motor deficits.

Description A: The brain and spinal areas normally work together as a network.
Description B: The brain and spinal areas function independently without forming a network.

Description A: The variability inherent in noise limits our ability to perceive accurately and act precisely.
Description B: Noise enhances our ability to perceive accurately and act precisely.

Description A: Motor systems have to contend with different forms of uncertainty, such as incomplete knowledge about the state of the world.
Description B: Motor systems operate without any uncertainty about the state of the world.

Description A: Motor planning involves adopting an appropriate stance to return the expected serve.
Description B: Motor planning is unnecessary when returning an expected tennis serve.

Description A: The motor system reduces the degrees of freedom of the musculoskeletal system by controlling groups of muscles, termed synergies.
Description B: The motor system increases the degrees of freedom of the musculoskeletal system by controlling individual muscles instead of synergies.

Description A: No robot can manipulate a chess piece with the dexterity of a 6-year-old child.
Description B: Robots can now manipulate a chess piece with greater dexterity than a 6-year-old child.

Description A: The control of movement poses challenges for the nervous system.
Description B: The control of movement poses no challenges for the nervous system.

Description A: Prediction can compensate for sensorimotor delays.
Description B: Prediction cannot compensate for sensorimotor delays.

Description A: Feedback control uses sensory signals to correct movements.
Description B: Feedback control uses neural signals to reinforce movements without correcting them.

Description A: The amount of noise in our motor commands tends to increase with stronger commands.
Description B: The amount of noise in our motor commands decreases with stronger commands.

Description A: Skilled performance requires reducing uncertainty by anticipating events we may encounter.
Description B: Skilled performance is unaffected by uncertainty and anticipation of events.

Description A: The abducens nerve (VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle.
Description B: The abducens nerve (IV) innervates the lateral rectus muscle.

Description A: The trochlear nerve (IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle.
Description B: The trochlear nerve (VI) innervates the superior oblique muscle.

Description A: The oculomotor nerve (III) innervates the medial, superior, and inferior recti, and inferior oblique muscles.
Description B: The oculomotor nerve (VI) innervates the medial, superior, and inferior recti, and inferior oblique muscles.

Description A: The superior oblique muscle's tendon passes through the trochlea before inserting on the globe.
Description B: The superior oblique muscle's tendon passes directly on the globe without going through any structure.

Description A: The annulus of Zinn is the common origin of the four rectus muscles.
Description B: The annulus of Zinn is the common insertion point of the four rectus muscles.

Description A: The inferior rectus and superior oblique depress the eye.
Description B: The inferior rectus and inferior oblique depress the eye.

Description A: The extraocular muscles are controlled by three cranial nerves.
Description B: The extraocular muscles are controlled by four cranial nerves.

Description A: Binocular vision facilitates stereopsis, the ability to perceive a visual scene in three dimensions.
Description B: Binocular vision prevents stereopsis, making perception of visual scenes in three dimensions impossible.

Description A: A lesion of the abducens nerve causes weakness of the lateral rectus muscle.
Description B: A lesion of the abducens nerve enhances the strength of the lateral rectus muscle.

Description A: The pupil and eyelid receive sympathetic innervation from the intermediolateral cell column of the ipsilateral upper thoracic spinal cord.
Description B: The pupil but not the eyelid receives sympathetic innervation from the intermediolateral cell column of the ipsilateral upper thoracic spinal cord.

Description A: Oculomotor nerve lesions can result in ptosis and pupillary dilation.
Description B: Oculomotor nerve lesions result only in pupillary contraction, not ptosis.

Description A: Interruption of sympathetic pathways to the eye leads to Horner syndrome.
Description B: Interruption of parasympathetic pathways to the eye leads to Horner syndrome.

Description A: Superior rectus axons cross the midline and join the contralateral oculomotor nerve.
Description B: Superior rectus axons remain on the same side and do not cross over.

Description A: Both superior rectus and superior oblique innervate respective muscles on the opposite side.
Description B: Both superior rectus and superior oblique innervate respective muscles on the same side.

Description A: Contraction of extraocular muscles results in rotation of the eye.
Description B: Relaxation of extraocular muscles results in rotation of the eye.

Description A: At all levels of depolarization, the Na+ channels open more rapidly than K+ channels.
Description B: At all levels of depolarization, the K+ channels open more rapidly than Na+ channels.

Description A: The Na+ channels open rapidly, causing an inward Na+ current.
Description B: The Na+ channels open slowly, causing an inward Na+ current.

Description A: Squid axon K+ channels do not inactivate; they remain open as long as the membrane is depolarized.
Description B: Squid axon Na+ channels do not inactivate; they remain open as long as the membrane is depolarized.

Description A: Depolarization causes Na+ channels to switch between three different states: resting, activated, or inactivated.
Description B: Depolarization causes K+ channels to switch between three different states: resting, activated, or inactivated.

Description A: Hodgkin and Huxley were able to calculate gNa and gK by dividing measured Na+ and K+ currents by the known Na+ and K+ electrochemical driving forces.
Description B: Hodgkin and Huxley were able to calculate gNa and gK by multiplying measured Na+ and K+ currents by the known Na+ and K+ electrochemical driving forces.

Description A: During prolonged depolarization, Na+ channels close after opening due to the closure of an inactivation gate.
Description B: During prolonged depolarization, K+ channels close after opening due to the closure of an inactivation gate.

Description A: The depolarization limits the duration of the action potential by inactivating Na+ channels and opening K+ channels.
Description B: The depolarization extends the duration of the action potential by inactivating Na+ channels and opening K+ channels.

Description A: Both Na+ and K+ channels open in response to depolarization.
Description B: Both Na+ and K+ channels close in response to depolarization.

Description A: The calculations of membrane conductances are done using voltage-clamp currents.
Description B: The calculations of membrane conductances are done using current-clamp currents.

Description A: The Hodgkin-Huxley model is known for its accuracy and success in describing the action potential.
Description B: The Hodgkin-Huxley model is known for its inaccuracies and failures in describing the action potential.

Description A: The inactivation of Na+ channels can be reversed only by repolarizing the membrane to its negative resting potential.
Description B: The inactivation of Na+ channels can be reversed only by depolarizing the membrane to its positive resting potential.

Description A: Voltage-gated sodium and potassium conductances are calculated from their currents.
Description B: Voltage-gated sodium and potassium conductances are calculated from their voltages.

Description A: The variables IK and INa can be calculated from records of voltage-clamp experiments.
Description B: The variables IK and INa can be calculated from records of current-clamp experiments.

Description A: Depolarization causes further depolarization by opening more Na+ channels, a regenerative process.
Description B: Depolarization causes further repolarization by closing more Na+ channels, a regenerative process.

Description A: Measurements of gNa and gK reveal two functional similarities and two differences between Na+ and K+ channels.
Description B: Measurements of gNa and gK reveal two functional differences and no similarities between Na+ and K+ channels.

Description A: The gustatory system detects five basic tastes: sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami.
Description B: The gustatory system detects four basic tastes: sweet, sour, bitter, and salty.

Description A: Chorda tympani, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves terminate in the nucleus of the solitary tract in the brain stem.
Description B: Chorda tympani, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves terminate in the thalamus in the brain stem.

Description A: The detection of five different taste modalities is mediated by different taste receptor cells, each dedicated to one modality.
Description B: The detection of five different taste modalities is mediated by the same taste receptor cell.

Description A: In contrast to sweet, umami, and bitter receptors, salty and sour tastes are detected by ion channels.
Description B: Sweet, salty, umami, and bitter receptors are all detected by ion channels.

Description A: Different GRs are found in sugar cells versus bitter cells.
Description B: The same GRs are found in sugar cells versus bitter cells.

Description A: Sweet tastants are detected by a single type of receptor composed of two subunits, T1R2 and T1R3.
Description B: Sweet tastants are detected by multiple receptors composed of two subunits, T1R2 and T1R3.

Description A: Bitter taste receptors constitute a family of approximately 30 related but diverse receptors.
Description B: Bitter taste receptors constitute a family of approximately 10 related but diverse receptors.

Description A: Odor detection in the nose is mediated by a large family of odorant receptors, numbering approximately 350 in humans.
Description B: Odor detection in the nose is mediated by a small family of odorant receptors, numbering approximately 50 in humans.

Description A: The gustatory cortex projects to many brain areas involved in motor control, feeding, hedonic value, learning, and memory.
Description B: The gustatory cortex projects to a few brain areas involved in feeding only.

Description A: Taste signals travel from taste buds through cranial nerves from gustatory sensory neurons in the geniculate, petrosal, and nodose ganglia.
Description B: Taste signals travel from taste buds through spinal nerves from gustatory sensory neurons in the geniculate, petrosal, and nodose ganglia.

Description A: In the olfactory bulb, the axons of sensory neurons expressing the same receptor converge in receptor-specific glomeruli.
Description B: In the olfactory bulb, the axons of sensory neurons expressing different receptors converge in receptor-specific glomeruli.

Description A: Activation of sugar cells drives food acceptance behavior, whereas activation of bitter cells drives food rejection.
Description B: Activation of sugar cells drives food rejection behavior, whereas activation of bitter cells drives food acceptance.

Description A: Members of the gustatory receptor gene family participate in the detection of sugars and bitter compounds.
Description B: Members of the gustatory receptor gene family participate in the detection of sour and umami compounds.

Description A: The gustatory system detects tastants primarily in taste buds on the tongue and palate epithelium.
Description B: The gustatory system detects tastants primarily in taste buds on the lips and gum epithelium.

Description A: Different odorants activate different combinations of receptors.
Description B: Different odorants activate the same combinations of receptors.

Description A: Serotonin enhances CREB-1 activity, promoting memory consolidation.
Description B: Serotonin reduces CREB-1 activity, hindering memory consolidation.

Description A: piRNA-F enhances methylation of the CREB-2 gene leading to transcriptional repression.
Description B: piRNA-F reduces methylation of the CREB-2 gene leading to transcriptional activation.

Description A: Long-term memory storage is generally thought to be synapse specific.
Description B: Long-term memory storage is generally thought to affect all synapses equally.

Description A: Long-term habituation leads to a loss of synapses, while sensitization leads to an increase.
Description B: Long-term habituation leads to an increase in synapses, while sensitization leads to a decrease.

Description A: Short-term facilitation is observed following a single pulse of serotonin.
Description B: Short-term facilitation is observed only following five pulses of serotonin.

Description A: Sensory neuron synapses with motor neurons undergo structural changes after serotonin application.
Description B: Sensory neuron synapses with motor neurons remain unchanged after serotonin application.

Description A: Long-term synaptic facilitation is synapse specific.
Description B: Long-term synaptic facilitation affects all synapses equally.

Description A: Long-term sensitization of sensory neurons doubles the number of presynaptic terminals.
Description B: Long-term sensitization of sensory neurons halves the number of presynaptic terminals.

Description A: Serotonin application results in increased varicosities in sensory neuron axons.
Description B: Serotonin application results in decreased varicosities in sensory neuron axons.

Description A: Gene products recruited during long-term memory storage may alter the strength of select synapses.
Description B: Gene products recruited during long-term memory storage always alter the strength of all synapses.

Description A: CREB-2 inhibits the action of CREB-1 in the process of memory consolidation.
Description B: CREB-2 enhances the action of CREB-1 in the process of memory consolidation.

Description A: The sensory neuron axon contacts motor neurons to mimic neural effects of a shock.
Description B: The sensory neuron axon contacts motor neurons to reduce the neural effects of a shock.

Description A: Long-term facilitation at synapses requires gene transcription and protein synthesis.
Description B: Long-term facilitation at synapses requires only electrical stimulation.

Description A: Only synapses that receive the modulatory serotonin signal manifest long-term facilitation.
Description B: All synapses in the neuron manifest long-term facilitation regardless of serotonin signals.

Description A: Activation of CREB-1 subsequently activates the transcription factor C/EBP.
Description B: Activation of CREB-1 subsequently inhibits the transcription factor C/EBP.

Description A: Notch signaling inhibits progenitor cells from differentiating into neurons.
Description B: Notch signaling promotes progenitor cells to differentiate into neurons.

Description A: Activation of Notch signaling in glial progenitor cells results in differentiation of the cells as astrocytes and inhibits differentiation as oligodendrocytes.
Description B: Activation of Notch signaling in glial progenitor cells results in differentiation of the cells as oligodendrocytes and inhibits differentiation as astrocytes.

Description A: REST/NRSF is rapidly degraded as neurons differentiate, permitting the expression of neurogenic bHLH factors and other neuronal genes.
Description B: REST/NRSF is maintained as neurons differentiate, preventing the expression of neurogenic bHLH factors and other neuronal genes.

Description A: Radial glial cells serve as the primary scaffold for radial neuronal migration.
Description B: Tangential migration serves as the primary scaffold for radial neuronal migration.

Description A: The layering of neurons in the cerebral cortex follows an inside-first, outside-last rule.
Description B: The layering of neurons in the cerebral cortex follows an outside-first, inside-last rule.

Description A: Cells that migrate from the ventricular and subventricular zones give rise to neurons that settle in the deepest layers of the cortex.
Description B: Cells that migrate from the cortical plate give rise to neurons that settle in the deepest layers of the cortex.

Description A: Interneurons enter the cortex from subcortical sites by a process called tangential migration.
Description B: Interneurons enter the cortex from subcortical sites by a process called radial migration.

Description A: In the mouse mutant reeler, the layering of neurons in the cortical plate is severely disrupted and partially inverted.
Description B: In the mouse mutant reeler, the layering of neurons in the cortical plate is correctly organized and follows the usual pattern.

Description A: Cells that exit the cell cycle at progressively later stages migrate over longer distances and settle in more superficial layers of the cortex.
Description B: Cells that exit the cell cycle at progressively later stages settle in the deepest layers of the cortex.

Description A: A microtubular lattice forms a cage around the nucleus; movement of the nucleus depends on a centrosome-like structure, termed a basal body.
Description B: A microtubular lattice forms a cage around the nucleus; movement of the nucleus does not depend on any specific structure.

Description A: Radial glial scaffolds are especially important in the development of the primate cortex.
Description B: Radial glial scaffolds are not important in the development of the primate cortex.

Description A: A single radial glial cell scaffold can support the migration of up to 30 generations of cortical neurons before differentiating into an astrocyte.
Description B: A single radial glial cell scaffold supports only one generation of cortical neurons before differentiating into an astrocyte.

Description A: The migration of neurons along glial fibers is different from the extension of axons driven by growth cones.
Description B: The migration of neurons along glial fibers is exactly the same as the extension of axons driven by growth cones.

Description A: During normal cortical development, neurons use radial glial cells as migratory scaffolds as they enter the cortical plate.
Description B: During normal cortical development, neurons use tangential glial cells as migratory scaffolds as they enter the cortical plate.

Description A: Adhesive receptors such as integrins promote neuronal extension on radial glial cells.
Description B: Adhesive receptors such as integrins inhibit neuronal extension on radial glial cells.

Description A: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) initiates locomotion by activating neurons in the medial reticular formation whose axons descend in the ventrolateral funiculus to the spinal locomotor system.
Description B: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) initiates locomotion by directly activating neurons in the spinal locomotor system without involvement of the medial reticular formation.

Description A: In a decerebrate cat, stimulating group I fibers from ankle extensors prevents initiation of the swing phase during walking.
Description B: In a decerebrate cat, stimulating group I fibers from ankle flexors prevents initiation of the swing phase during walking.

Description A: Corrective responses to a mild stimulus applied to the paw during the swing phase produce excitation of flexor motor neurons and inhibition of extensor motor neurons.
Description B: Corrective responses to a mild stimulus applied to the paw during the swing phase produce inhibition of flexor motor neurons and excitation of extensor motor neurons.

Description A: The pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) contains both glutamatergic and cholinergic neurons.
Description B: The pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) contains only glutamatergic neurons.

Description A: Glutamatergic neurons in the cuneiform nucleus (CNF) are necessary for high-speed locomotion such as gallop and bound.
Description B: Glutamatergic neurons in the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) are necessary for high-speed locomotion such as gallop and bound.

Description A: The corrective reflex during locomotion is phase-dependent, producing opposite responses in stance and swing phases.
Description B: The corrective reflex during locomotion is phase-independent, producing identical responses regardless of the phase.

Description A: Serotonergic pathways involved in locomotion have been observed in the caudal brain stem of mammals.
Description B: Serotonergic pathways involved in locomotion have been observed exclusively in spinal cord circuits in mammals.

Description A: Electrical stimulation of the mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) in the cat can change gait from slow walking to galloping.
Description B: Electrical stimulation of the mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) in the cat exclusively produces slow walking without altering gait.

Description A: The cuneiform nucleus receives input principally from structures involved in escape responses.
Description B: The cuneiform nucleus receives input principally from the basal ganglia and sensorimotor cortex.

Description A: Supraspinal structures like the cerebellum and basal ganglia regulate speed and postural balance during locomotion.
Description B: Supraspinal structures like the spinal cord regulate speed and postural balance during locomotion.

Description A: The mesencephalic locomotor region is evolutionarily conserved across vertebrates.
Description B: The mesencephalic locomotor region is exclusive to mammals and absent in other vertebrates.

Description A: Selective activation of glutamatergic neurons in the PPN supports slower exploratory locomotion such as walking and trotting.
Description B: Selective activation of glutamatergic neurons in the PPN supports faster locomotion such as galloping and bound.

Description A: Neurons in the subthalamic locomotor region bypass the PPN and CNF to initiate locomotion.
Description B: Neurons in the subthalamic locomotor region exclusively rely on connections with the PPN to initiate locomotion.

Description A: The corrective reflex in cats is largely mediated by circuits entirely contained in the spinal cord.
Description B: The corrective reflex in cats is primarily mediated by supraspinal circuits outside the spinal cord.

Description A: Neurons in the medial reticular formation relay excitatory signals to the spinal cord through both glutamatergic and serotonergic pathways.
Description B: Neurons in the medial reticular formation relay excitatory signals to the spinal cord exclusively through serotonergic pathways.

Description A: The amygdala consists of approximately 12 nuclei, but the lateral and central nuclei are especially important in fear conditioning.
Description B: The amygdala consists of approximately 15 nuclei, but the lateral and central nuclei are especially important in fear conditioning.

Description A: The lateral nucleus of the amygdala receives most sensory input, while the medial nucleus receives olfactory input.
Description B: The medial nucleus of the amygdala receives most sensory input, while the lateral nucleus receives olfactory input.

Description A: The amygdala plays a role in evaluating the emotional charge of a stimulus and can influence cognitive functions such as attention, perception, memory, and decision making.
Description B: The amygdala is solely responsible for evaluating the emotional charge of a stimulus and does not influence cognitive functions such as attention, perception, memory, and decision making.

Description A: The central nucleus of the amygdala relays signals to regions controlling motor responses, including freezing behavior.
Description B: The basal nucleus of the amygdala relays signals to regions controlling motor responses, including freezing behavior.

Description A: Research using optogenetics has begun to dissect the amygdala’s role in fear learning by manipulating specific neurons.
Description B: Research using optogenetics has shown that the prefrontal cortex, not the amygdala, plays the primary role in fear learning.

Description A: Patients with bilateral amygdala lesions fail to show fear reactions to both externally presented threats and interoceptive stimuli such as suffocation.
Description B: Patients with bilateral amygdala lesions fail to show fear reactions to externally presented threats but can react with panic to interoceptive stimuli such as suffocation.

Description A: Freezing behavior is mediated by connections from the central nucleus of the amygdala to the ventral periaqueductal gray region.
Description B: Freezing behavior is mediated by connections from the central nucleus of the amygdala to the dorsal periaqueductal gray region.

Description A: The medial amygdala processes unconditioned threats such as predator odors, while the lateral amygdala processes auditory threats.
Description B: The medial amygdala processes auditory threats, while the lateral amygdala processes unconditioned threats such as predator odors.

Description A: Synaptic plasticity in the amygdala underlies fear learning, with key contributions from the lateral and central nuclei.
Description B: Synaptic plasticity in the amygdala underlies fear learning, but the basal nucleus is the sole contributor to this process.

Description A: Humans can exhibit fear responses to a conditioned stimulus (CS) even without directly experiencing the unconditioned stimulus (US), as through observation or verbal instruction.
Description B: Humans cannot exhibit fear responses to a conditioned stimulus (CS) unless they directly experience the unconditioned stimulus (US).

Description A: The amygdala is necessary for Pavlovian fear conditioning, as animals with amygdala damage fail to associate the CS and US.
Description B: The amygdala is not necessary for Pavlovian fear conditioning, as animals with amygdala damage can still associate the CS and US.

Description A: Patients with amygdala damage often lack autonomic fear responses to external stimuli but may experience panic in response to interoceptive cues.
Description B: Patients with amygdala damage often lack autonomic fear responses to any stimuli, whether external or interoceptive.

Description A: Snakes and spiders are thought to be innate fear stimuli for some people, though others may keep them as pets without fear.
Description B: Snakes and spiders are universally feared innate stimuli that no humans ever keep as pets.

Description A: The amygdala modulates cognitive functions through projections to the cortex, including the prefrontal and sensory cortices.
Description B: The amygdala does not influence cognitive functions and lacks projections to cortical structures.

Description A: Human fear learning includes uniquely advanced mechanisms such as active pedagogy, where another person teaches someone that a stimulus is dangerous.
Description B: Human fear learning is entirely reliant on direct personal experience and lacks advanced mechanisms like active pedagogy.

Description A: Neurons in the hypothalamus receive top-down feedforward inputs from neurons that anticipate future homeostatic challenges.
Description B: Neurons in the hypothalamus receive only sensory feedback inputs and do not anticipate future homeostatic challenges.

Description A: Key regulatory neurons for body temperature are located in the median preoptic nucleus (MnPO).
Description B: Key regulatory neurons for body temperature are located in the arcuate nucleus.

Description A: The sympathetic preganglionic cell column extends between the cervical and lumbosacral enlargements of the spinal cord.
Description B: The sympathetic preganglionic cell column is confined to the cranial and sacral sections of the spinal cord.

Description A: The parasympathetic pathways arise from cranial nerve zones in the brain stem and sacral segments of the spinal cord.
Description B: The parasympathetic pathways arise from thoracic nerve zones in the spinal cord.

Description A: The sympathetic motor system regulates systemic physiological parameters such as blood pressure and body temperature.
Description B: The sympathetic motor system regulates solely the digestive processes in the body.

Description A: Preganglionic neurons synthesize and release acetylcholine, which acts on nicotinic ACh receptors on postganglionic neurons.
Description B: Preganglionic neurons synthesize and release dopamine, which acts on nicotinic ACh receptors on postganglionic neurons.

Description A: The autonomic system is divided into sympathetic, parasympathetic, and enteric divisions.
Description B: The autonomic system is divided into sympathetic and skeletal muscle divisions.

Description A: Effector cells controlled by autonomic neurons include smooth muscle, gland cells, and cardiac muscle.
Description B: Effector cells controlled by autonomic neurons include skeletal muscle and epithelial cells in the skin.

Description A: Unlike the somatic motor system, autonomic motor neurons are found in ganglia.
Description B: Similar to the somatic motor system, autonomic motor neurons are found in the central nervous system.

Description A: Gravity-specific hypothalamic neurons link interoceptive sensory feedback with outputs that control adaptive behaviors and physiological responses.
Description B: Modality-specific hypothalamic neurons link interoceptive sensory feedback with outputs that control adaptive behaviors and physiological responses.

Description A: The median preoptic nucleus (MnPO) is one of the sites that regulates water balance.
Description B: The median preoptic nucleus (MnPO) does not play a role in the regulation of water balance.

Description A: Langley proposed that specific chemical substances must be released by preganglionic neurons of the autonomic ganglia.
Description B: Langley proposed that autonomic ganglia operate without the need for chemical substances released by preganglionic neurons.

Description A: Thermogenesis by brown adipose tissue is largely subservient to the hypothalamus.
Description B: Thermogenesis by brown adipose tissue is independent of the hypothalamus.

Description A: Visceral motor neurons in the autonomic system are organized into ganglia.
Description B: Visceral motor neurons in the autonomic system are organized into direct pathways.

Description A: The autonomic system is also regulated by circuits in the brain stem and spinal cord.
Description B: The autonomic system operates independently of the brain stem and spinal cord.

Description A: Purkinje cells are normally spontaneously active, and they inhibit their downstream targets.
Description B: Purkinje cells are normally inactive, and they excite their downstream targets.

Description A: Studies of the cerebellum illustrate how neural circuits mediate learning through trial and error.
Description B: Studies of the cerebellum show how neural circuits mediate learning by direct supervision.

Description A: The cerebellum is a focus of intense experimental and theoretical research on learning and memory.
Description B: The cerebellum is lightly researched with little theoretical focus on learning and memory.

Description A: Granule–Purkinje cell synapses exhibit plasticity leading to learned motor responses.
Description B: Granule–Purkinje cell synapses are rigid and incapable of learning motor responses.

Description A: Purkinje cells integrate a rich diversity of signals related to both the external world and the animal's internal state.
Description B: Purkinje cells integrate signals exclusively related to the external world.

Description A: Climbing fibers provide error signals to weaken synapses that were previously active.
Description B: Climbing fibers provide positive reinforcement to strengthen synapses that were previously inactive.

Description A: Functional MRI is non-invasive and does not require surgery or ionizing radiation.
Description B: Functional MRI is invasive and requires surgery or ionizing radiation.

Description A: fMRI measures activity across the whole brain simultaneously.
Description B: fMRI measures activity in isolated regions of the brain sequentially.

Description A: Neural circuits use feedforward motifs to process information from sensory streams.
Description B: Neural circuits rely exclusively on recurrent motifs to handle information from sensory streams.

Description A: Neural coding describes how stimulus features are represented by neuronal activity.
Description B: Neural coding describes how intended actions are hidden from neuronal activity.

Description A: Synaptic plasticity supports longer-lasting changes in neural circuits underlying learning and memory.
Description B: Synaptic plasticity leads to short-term changes that are unrelated to memory.

Description A: Hebbian plasticity can extract signals from a complex set of inputs without supervision.
Description B: Hebbian plasticity requires constant supervision to extract signals from inputs.

Description A: Computer simulations have shown that learning of appropriately timed responses can be explained by granule–Purkinje cell synapse plasticity.
Description B: Computer simulations have shown that learning of appropriately timed responses is impossible without external stimuli.

Description A: Functional MRI experiments measure neurovascular activity.
Description B: Functional MRI experiments measure neurocellular activity.

Description A: Direct evidence for temporal representations in granule cells within the mammalian cerebellum has not yet been obtained.
Description B: Direct evidence for temporal representations in granule cells within the mammalian cerebellum has been abundantly obtained.

Description A: Chemical synapses amplify neuronal signals and can produce either excitatory or inhibitory actions in postsynaptic cells.
Description B: Chemical synapses dampen neuronal signals and can produce only excitatory actions in postsynaptic cells.

Description A: Electrical synapses are employed primarily for rapid and synchronous signal transmission between interconnected cells.
Description B: Electrical synapses are employed primarily for slow and asynchronous signal transmission between interconnected cells.

Description A: At chemical synapses, neurotransmitters diffuse across the synaptic cleft to interact with postsynaptic receptors.
Description B: At chemical synapses, neurotransmitters are directly transferred through gap junctions to the postsynaptic cell.

Description A: Electrical synapses involve cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and postsynaptic cells via gap-junction channels.
Description B: Electrical synapses lack cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and postsynaptic cells and operate through synaptic clefts.

Description A: The distance between pre- and postsynaptic cell membranes at electrical synapses is approximately 4 nm.
Description B: The distance between pre- and postsynaptic cell membranes at electrical synapses is approximately 40 nm.

Description A: Chemical synapses typically have a synaptic delay of at least 0.3 milliseconds and often longer.
Description B: Chemical synapses experience no synaptic delay regardless of signaling conditions.

Description A: Electrical synaptic transmission was first demonstrated in the giant motor synapse of the crayfish.
Description B: Electrical synaptic transmission was first demonstrated in the mammalian motor cortex.

Description A: Chemical synaptic transmission involves neurotransmitter release that binds to postsynaptic receptors to initiate changes in ion channel activity.
Description B: Chemical synaptic transmission does not involve neurotransmitter release but instead relies on passive ion flow between neurons.

Description A: Voltage-gated ion channels in the presynaptic cell play a critical role in generating the ionic current at electrical synapses.
Description B: Voltage-gated ion channels in the postsynaptic cell initiate neurotransmitter release at electrical synapses.

Description A: The term 'synapse' was introduced at the beginning of the 20th century by Charles Sherrington.
Description B: The term 'synapse' was introduced at the beginning of the 18th century by Charles Sherrington.

Description A: In contrast to electrical synapses, chemical synapses have a synaptic cleft between pre- and postsynaptic cells, preventing cytoplasmic continuity.
Description B: Chemical synapses allow direct cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and postsynaptic cells through special channels.

Description A: Synaptic plasticity refers to the ability of synapses to enhance or diminish their strength based on neuronal activity.
Description B: Synaptic plasticity permanently fixes synaptic strength, preventing changes based on neuronal activity.

Description A: Chemical synapses can initiate changes in the postsynaptic cell lasting from milliseconds to hours.
Description B: Chemical synapses have no lasting effect on postsynaptic cells, regardless of signal duration.

Description A: Electrical synapses are usually bidirectional, enabling current flow in both directions.
Description B: Electrical synapses are always unidirectional, allowing current flow only in one direction.

Description A: Chemical synapses can initiate a depolarization in the postsynaptic cell by opening ion channels upon neurotransmitter binding.
Description B: Chemical synapses prevent depolarization in the postsynaptic cell due to the lack of ion channel activity.

Description A: Movement planning and execution are not completely segregated at the level of single neurons or neural populations in a given cortical area.
Description B: Movement planning and execution are completely segregated at the level of single neurons or neural populations in a given cortical area.

Description A: In a reaction-time task, the monkey does not know in which direction to move until the target appears.
Description B: In a reaction-time task, the monkey knows in advance in which direction to move before the target appears.

Description A: The parietal cortex is a key brain region in sensory processing for motor action.
Description B: The parietal cortex is mainly involved in auditory processing for motor action.

Description A: The S-I and adjacent superior parietal cortex regions PE, MIP, and PEip are a major source of proprioceptive and tactile sensory information.
Description B: The S-I and adjacent superior parietal cortex regions PE, MIP, and PEip are primarily involved in olfactory sensory information processing.

Description A: Monkeys with experimental lesions in Brodmann’s area 2 and the adjacent superior parietal lobule show deficits in reaching to and manipulating objects under proprioceptive and tactile guidance without vision.
Description B: Monkeys with experimental lesions in Brodmann’s area 2 and the adjacent superior parietal lobule show improved ability in reaching to and manipulating objects under proprioceptive and tactile guidance without vision.

Description A: The posterior parietal cortex contains several distinct functional areas that work in parallel and receive different combinations of sensory and motor inputs.
Description B: The posterior parietal cortex contains a single functional area that works in parallel and receives the same combination of sensory and motor inputs.

Description A: Human subjects with lesions of the posterior parietal cortex often demonstrate specific impairments in using sensory information to guide motor action.
Description B: Human subjects with lesions of the posterior parietal cortex often demonstrate no impairments in using sensory information to guide motor action.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) respond to visual input from extrastriate cortical areas.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) respond primarily to auditory input from extrastriate cortical areas.

Description A: Many VIP neurons respond to visual stimuli and somatosensory stimuli with receptive fields on the face or head.
Description B: Many VIP neurons respond only to olfactory stimuli with receptive fields on the face or head.

Description A: Each functional area in the parietal cortex is connected to frontal motor regions involved in control of the same effectors.
Description B: Each functional area in the parietal cortex is isolated from frontal motor regions involved in control of the same effectors.

Description A: Neurons in areas PE and PEip provide a more stable signal about the location of the reach target relative to the current position of the hand.
Description B: Neurons in areas PE and PEip provide a less stable signal about the location of the reach target relative to the current position of the hand.

Description A: The parietal reach region (PRR) likely corresponds to the medial intraparietal cortex (MIP) and adjacent arm-control parts of the superior and inferior parietal cortex.
Description B: The parietal reach region (PRR) corresponds solely to the lateral prefrontal cortex.

Description A: Many neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) shift to new spatial locations whenever the monkey changes its direction of gaze.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) maintain a fixed spatial location despite changes in the monkey's direction of gaze.

Description A: The parietal lobe, especially PE, PEip, and MIP, receives strong somatic sensory inputs about body posture and movement from S-I.
Description B: The parietal lobe, especially PE, PEip, and MIP, receives visual sensory inputs about body posture and movement from S-I.

Description A: The ventral intraparietal area (VIP) is involved in the analysis of optic flow and visual motion.
Description B: The ventral intraparietal area (VIP) is involved in the analysis of auditory signals and sound localization.

Description A: The amygdala is implicated in both negatively valenced and positively valenced emotions through distinct populations of neurons.
Description B: The amygdala is exclusively implicated in negatively valenced emotions and does not process positively valenced stimuli.

Description A: Emotions are neurobiological states that trigger coordinated behavioral and cognitive responses due to brain activity.
Description B: Emotions are purely psychological states with no involvement of the brain's neurobiological processes.

Description A: The physiological systems engaged during emotional states include the endocrine glands, autonomic motor system, and musculoskeletal system.
Description B: The physiological systems engaged during emotional states exclude the endocrine glands and musculoskeletal system, focusing solely on the autonomic motor system.

Description A: Subjective ratings of emotions depend on culture-specific words and concepts for emotions.
Description B: Subjective ratings of emotions are universally independent of culture-specific words and concepts for emotions.

Description A: Potentiation of the startle reflex is used to assess anxiety levels in both humans and animals.
Description B: Potentiation of the startle reflex is exclusively used to assess anxiety levels in humans and has not been validated in animals.

Description A: The galvanic skin response measures sympathetic autonomic arousal derived from palm sweatiness.
Description B: The galvanic skin response measures parasympathetic autonomic relaxation derived from palm dryness.

Description A: Facial electromyography (EMG) can provide fine-grained information about emotions.
Description B: Facial electromyography (EMG) primarily measures valence and arousal, not fine-grained emotional information.

Description A: Experience sampling quantifies emotions experienced in everyday life by stopping participants during their ongoing activities.
Description B: Experience sampling quantifies emotions experienced in everyday life solely through passive observation, without active participant engagement.

Description A: Darwin’s 1872 book 'The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals' noted the correspondence between human and animal behavior.
Description B: Darwin’s 1872 book 'The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals' was solely focused on human emotional behavior, with no mention of animals.

Description A: Unconditioned stimuli can trigger emotions without any prior learning, such as a painful shock or disgusting taste.
Description B: Unconditioned stimuli require associative learning to trigger emotions, such as a painful shock or disgusting taste.

Description A: Hormonal responses to emotional states are typically slower than psychophysiological measures.
Description B: Hormonal responses to emotional states are typically faster than psychophysiological measures.

Description A: Emotional states can influence cognitive processes such as attention, memory processing, and decision making.
Description B: Emotional states are entirely separate from cognitive processes like attention, memory processing, and decision making.

Description A: Emotional responses can be updated through extinction and regulation mechanisms.
Description B: Emotional responses are static and cannot be updated through extinction or regulation mechanisms.

Description A: Animals often exhibit stereotyped behaviors as a consequence of certain emotional states, such as freezing or attacking.
Description B: Animals rarely exhibit stereotyped behaviors as a consequence of emotional states, making their responses unpredictable.

Description A: Distinct populations of neurons in the amygdala process negatively valenced and positively valenced stimuli.
Description B: A single population of neurons in the amygdala exclusively processes either negatively or positively valenced stimuli.

Description A: PER protein is highly unstable; most of it is degraded so quickly that it never has a chance to repress CLOCK-dependent per transcription.
Description B: PER protein is highly stable and effectively represses CLOCK-dependent per transcription without degradation.

Description A: Activation of cGMP signaling in young honeybees can cause them to enter the forager stage prematurely.
Description B: Activation of cAMP signaling in young honeybees can cause them to enter the forager stage prematurely.

Description A: The difference between social and solitary worms is caused by a single amino acid substitution in a single gene, npr-1.
Description B: The difference between social and solitary worms is caused by a deletion of a gene, npr-1.

Description A: Male prairie voles form long-lasting pair-bonds with females and help them raise their offspring.
Description B: Male prairie voles do not form pair-bonds with females and do not help raise their offspring.

Description A: The for gene is expressed at high levels in the brains of active foraging honeybees and at low levels in the younger nurse bees.
Description B: The for gene is expressed at high levels in the brains of young nurse honeybees and at low levels in the older foraging bees.

Description A: When PER binds to TIM, PER is protected from degradation.
Description B: When PER binds to TIM, PER is tagged for degradation.

Description A: Light activates cryptochrome, which destroys TIM protein.
Description B: Darkness activates cryptochrome, which destroys TIM protein.

Description A: Honeybees exhibit different behaviors at different stages of their life; in general, young bees are nurses, while older bees become foragers.
Description B: Honeybees exhibit the same behaviors throughout their life; both young and older bees are foragers.

Description A: Oxytocin released in the brain of female prairie voles during mating stimulates pair-bond formation.
Description B: Oxytocin released in the brain of female prairie voles during mating inhibits pair-bond formation.

Description A: During daylight, TIM protein is degraded by signaling pathways that are regulated by light.
Description B: During daylight, TIM protein accumulates unregulated by light.

Description A: Neuropeptide receptors have been implicated in the regulation of mammalian social behavior.
Description B: Neuropeptide receptors have not been implicated in the regulation of mammalian social behavior.

Description A: Light signaling pathways regulate cryptochrome and TIM protein degradation.
Description B: Light signaling pathways promote cryptochrome binding and TIM protein stabilization.

Description A: The foraging behavior difference in Drosophila melanogaster maps to a single protein kinase gene, for.
Description B: The foraging behavior difference in Drosophila melanogaster maps to multiple unrelated genes.

Description A: V1a vasopressin receptors are expressed at high levels in the ventral pallidum of prairie voles.
Description B: V1a vasopressin receptors are expressed at low levels in the ventral pallidum of prairie voles.

Description A: In montane voles, V1a vasopressin receptor levels are much lower in the ventral pallidum, although high in other brain regions.
Description B: In montane voles, V1a vasopressin receptor levels are much higher in the ventral pallidum than in other brain regions.

Description A: Serotonin is synthesized in a group of brain stem nuclei called the raphe nuclei, and these neurons project widely to areas including the forebrain and spinal cord.
Description B: Serotonin is synthesized exclusively in the cortex and does not project outside of the forebrain.

Description A: Monoamine oxidase (MAO) metabolizes neurotransmitters in the cytoplasm, specifically breaking down serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.
Description B: Monoamine oxidase (MAO) primarily metabolizes neurotransmitters only within synaptic vesicles, breaking down serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.

Description A: The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) were first approved in the 1980s and selectively inhibit SERT for the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders.
Description B: The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) were first discovered in the 1950s and selectively inhibit NET for the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders.

Description A: Ketamine represents a novel antidepressant approach because it does not exert its primary action on monoamine neurotransmission.
Description B: Ketamine represents a traditional antidepressant approach because it primarily acts on monoamine neurotransmission.

Description A: Cognitive therapies for depression aim to correct excessively negative interpretations of events and interactions.
Description B: Cognitive therapies for depression aim to enhance automatic negative thinking to develop coping mechanisms.

Description A: The raphe nuclei form a continuous collection of cell groups close to the midline of the brainstem and extend along its length.
Description B: The raphe nuclei are located exclusively in the forebrain and do not extend along the brainstem.

Description A: Monoamine neurotransmitters such as serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine originate from cells within brain stem nuclei.
Description B: Monoamine neurotransmitters such as serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine originate exclusively from cortical neurons.

Description A: Tricyclic antidepressants block the norepinephrine transporter (NET) and serotonin reuptake transporter (SERT), with some blocking both.
Description B: Tricyclic antidepressants only block dopamine transporters and are ineffective on norepinephrine or serotonin reuptake.

Description A: MAO inhibitors prevent the breakdown of neurotransmitters like norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine, increasing their availability for release.
Description B: MAO inhibitors accelerate the breakdown of neurotransmitters like norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine, reducing their availability for release.

Description A: Ketamine has been shown to produce antidepressant effects within 2 hours, lasting approximately 7 days after intravenous infusion.
Description B: Ketamine produces antidepressant effects slowly over several weeks and lasts indefinitely after intravenous infusion.

Description A: Serotonergic neurons project extensively to brain regions including the hypothalamus, hippocampus, amygdala, basal ganglia, and cerebral cortex.
Description B: Serotonergic neurons project only to the spinal cord, excluding brain regions like the hypothalamus or hippocampus.

Description A: Inhibition of MAO-A in the gut can allow bioactive amines like tyramine to enter the bloodstream and cause elevated blood pressure.
Description B: Inhibition of MAO-A in the gut prevents bioactive amines like tyramine from entering the bloodstream, lowering blood pressure.

Description A: SSRIs are widely used because of their milder side effects and greater safety in overdose compared to older antidepressant drugs.
Description B: SSRIs are rarely used due to severe side effects and high risk in overdose compared to older antidepressant drugs.

Description A: The locus ceruleus is the largest norepinephrine-producing nucleus located beneath the floor of the fourth ventricle in the rostrolateral pons.
Description B: The locus ceruleus is a dopamine-producing nucleus located exclusively within the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Monoamine neurotransmitters bind synaptic receptors after vesicular release to exert their effects or are cleared from the synapse by specific transporter proteins.
Description B: Monoamine neurotransmitters are not released from synaptic vesicles but act directly through cytoplasmic diffusion.

Description A: PMd neurons are selectively activated in monkeys when reaching for a target despite target uncertainty.
Description B: PRR neurons are selectively activated in monkeys when reaching for a target despite target uncertainty.

Description A: Dorsal premotor cortex is involved in applying rules that govern behavior based on associations.
Description B: The parietal cortex is involved in applying rules that govern behavior based on associations.

Description A: The neural activity in the dorsal premotor cortex of monkeys during movement planning can be viewed as transitions between different activation states.
Description B: The neural activity in the parietal cortex of monkeys during movement planning can be viewed as transitions between different activation states.

Description A: In the PMd, neurons that prefer potential reach movements are simultaneously activated during target uncertainty.
Description B: In the PRR, neurons that prefer potential reach movements are simultaneously activated during target uncertainty.

Description A: Neurons in premotor areas respond selectively to specific cues in monkeys trained to associate cues with movements.
Description B: Neurons in sensory areas respond selectively to specific cues in monkeys trained to associate cues with movements.

Description A: A dynamical system perspective suggests that planning-related neural activity does not initiate movement because it reflects specific network states.
Description B: A chemical process perspective suggests that planning-related neural activity does not initiate movement because it reflects specific network states.

Description A: During the planning phase, activity patterns in the PMd reflect different states in the network.
Description B: During the planning phase, activity patterns in the PRR reflect different states in the network.

Description A: Neurons in PMd encode potential reach actions during target uncertainty.
Description B: Neurons in PRR encode potential reach actions during target uncertainty.

Description A: Neurons in the PMd change activity rapidly to signal the chosen reach movement after the color cue appears.
Description B: Neurons in the PRR change activity rapidly to signal the chosen reach movement after the color cue appears.

Description A: In an instructed-delay task, the cell's activity decreases if the monkey is instructed not to move after the go cue appears.
Description B: In an instructed-delay task, the cell's activity increases if the monkey is instructed not to move after the go cue appears.

Description A: The PMd is implicated in the acquisition of new movement-related associations or rules.
Description B: The PRR is implicated in the acquisition of new movement-related associations or rules.

Description A: Cells are sorted based on their preferred movement direction in the PMd during a reach task.
Description B: Cells are sorted based on their preferred movement direction in the PRR during a reach task.

Description A: The activity of premotor cortex neurons in monkeys is evident in making decisions about response choices.
Description B: The activity of sensory cortex neurons in monkeys is evident in making decisions about response choices.

Description A: Activity patterns during planning and execution reflect different network states, including a delay period state in the PMd.
Description B: Activity patterns during planning and execution reflect different network states, including a delay period state in the PRR.

Description A: The PMd plays a role in mapping color cues to target locations in a two-target task.
Description B: The PRR plays a role in mapping color cues to target locations in a two-target task.

Description A: The vomeronasal organ (VNO) in mice is anatomically connected to the accessory olfactory bulb (AOB).
Description B: The vomeronasal organ (VNO) in mice is anatomically connected to the main olfactory bulb (MOB).

Description A: Female mice treated with testosterone exhibit male sexual behavior toward females.
Description B: Female mice treated with testosterone exhibit female mating behavior more intensely than untreated females.

Description A: High levels of DNA methylation at the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) promoter in rat pups lead to lower levels of GR expression in the hippocampus.
Description B: High levels of DNA methylation at the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) promoter in rat pups lead to increased levels of GR expression in the hippocampus.

Description A: Pups reared by high-LG mothers exhibit less anxiety-like behavior in stressful conditions compared to pups reared by low-LG mothers.
Description B: Pups reared by high-LG mothers exhibit higher anxiety-like behavior in stressful conditions compared to pups reared by low-LG mothers.

Description A: Oxytocin regulates milk let-down reflex through stimulation by suckling.
Description B: Oxytocin regulates smooth muscle contraction in the mammary gland, but not through stimulation by suckling.

Description A: Female offspring of high-LG mothers exhibit higher oxytocin receptor levels in specific brain regions compared to female offspring of low-LG mothers.
Description B: Female offspring of high-LG mothers exhibit lower oxytocin receptor levels in specific brain regions compared to female offspring of low-LG mothers.

Description A: In neonatal rodent females, testosterone is converted into estrogen, which can masculinize the brain.
Description B: In neonatal rodent females, testosterone directly masculinizes the brain without being converted into estrogen.

Description A: Estrogen plasticity contributes to changes in hypothalamic connectivity across the female estrous cycle.
Description B: Testosterone plasticity contributes to changes in hypothalamic connectivity across the female estrous cycle.

Description A: Female mice possess the neural circuitry for male sexual behavior, but its activation is inhibited by sensory input from the VNO and lack of testosterone.
Description B: Female mice lack the neural circuitry for male sexual behavior, and its activation is precluded by their genetics.

Description A: Early tactile stimulation by high-LG mothers reduces hypothalamic stress hormone release in rat pups.
