Description B: Early tactile stimulation by high-LG mothers increases hypothalamic stress hormone release in rat pups.

Description A: Maternal behavior in rats can be pharmacologically reversed by modifying epigenetic marks at the GR promoter.
Description B: Maternal behavior in rats is genetically fixed and cannot be reversed by altering epigenetic marks.

Description A: Sexual dimorphic behaviors in rodents are regulated by sexually dimorphic circuits within shared neural pathways.
Description B: Sexual dimorphic behaviors in rodents are regulated by unique neural pathways found only in one sex.

Description A: Maternal behavior in rats is influenced by early-life experience rather than solely by genetic factors.
Description B: Maternal behavior in rats is solely determined by genetic factors and not influenced by early-life experience.

Description A: The estrous cycle in female rodents involves periodic hormonal-driven reconfiguration of synapses.
Description B: The estrous cycle in female rodents does not involve periodic hormonal-driven reconfiguration of synapses.

Description A: Oxytocin and vasopressin regulate both maternal bonding behaviors and other social interactions via brain receptors.
Description B: Oxytocin and vasopressin only regulate milk production and have no role in social behaviors.

Description A: The discharge rate has a greater influence on muscle force than does changes in the number of active motor units.
Description B: The discharge rate has a lesser influence on muscle force than does changes in the number of active motor units.

Description A: Monoaminergic input from the brain stem can adjust the gain of the motor unit pool to meet the demands of different tasks.
Description B: Monoaminergic input from the brain stem cannot adjust the gain of the motor unit pool to meet the demands of different tasks.

Description A: The sliding filament hypothesis of muscle contraction was proposed by A. F. Huxley and H. E. Huxley in the 1950s.
Description B: The sliding filament hypothesis of muscle contraction was proposed by A. F. Huxley and H. E. Huxley in the 1960s.

Description A: Muscle force depends on the arrangement of fibers in the muscle as well as motor neuron activity.
Description B: Muscle force depends only on the motor neuron activity and not on the arrangement of fibers in the muscle.

Description A: Sarcomeres are arranged in series to form a myofibril.
Description B: Sarcomeres are arranged in parallel to form a myofibril.

Description A: The transverse tubules, terminal cisternae, and sarcoplasmic reticulum constitute an activation system that transforms an action potential into the sliding of the thick and thin filaments.
Description B: The transverse tubules, terminal cisternae, and sarcoplasmic reticulum constitute a storage system for proteins.

Description A: During muscle activation, the width of the light band decreases while the width of the dark band remains unchanged.
Description B: During muscle activation, the width of the dark band decreases while the width of the light band remains unchanged.

Description A: The primary components of the thin filament are two helical strands of fibrous F-actin.
Description B: The primary components of the thin filament are two helical strands of fibrous G-actin.

Description A: Tropomyosin consists of two coiled strands that lie in the groove of the F-actin helix.
Description B: Tropomyosin consists of two coiled strands that lie outside the F-actin helix.

Description A: The force generated by an activated sarcomere can be explained by the cross-bridge cycle when its length does not change or decreases.
Description B: The force generated by an activated sarcomere is independent of the cross-bridge cycle.

Description A: The dendrites of motor neurons passively transmit synaptic current to the cell body in the absence of monoaminergic input.
Description B: The dendrites of motor neurons actively transmit synaptic current in the absence of monoaminergic input.

Description A: A brief inhibitory input can terminate self-sustained firing in an active motor neuron.
Description B: A brief excitatory input can terminate self-sustained firing in an active motor neuron.

Description A: Calcium is stored in the terminal cisternae next to transverse tubules.
Description B: Calcium is stored in the mitochondria next to transverse tubules.

Description A: The force that each sarcomere generates arises from the interaction of thick and thin filaments.
Description B: The force that each sarcomere generates arises solely from the interaction of thick filaments.

Description A: The excitability of the pool of motor neurons innervating a single muscle is partly under control of the brain stem.
Description B: The excitability of the pool of motor neurons innervating a single muscle is independent of the brain stem.

Description A: The initial segment of the axon is known as the trigger zone because it has the highest density of voltage-sensitive Na+ channels.
Description B: The initial segment of the axon is known as the trigger zone because it has the lowest density of voltage-sensitive Na+ channels.

Description A: The action potential does not decay as it travels along the axon to its target.
Description B: The action potential decays as it travels along the axon to its target.

Description A: Neurotransmitter molecules are contained in synaptic vesicles.
Description B: Neurotransmitter molecules are contained in the neuron’s plasma membrane.

Description A: The frequency of action potentials determines the intensity of sensation.
Description B: The amplitude of action potentials determines the intensity of sensation.

Description A: Synaptic potentials are graded either hyperpolarizing or depolarizing.
Description B: Synaptic potentials are all-or-none and always depolarizing.

Description A: Action potentials vary only subtly from one nerve cell to another.
Description B: Action potentials vary significantly from one nerve cell to another.

Description A: The output signal of a neuron is graded according to the amount of neurotransmitter released.
Description B: The output signal of a neuron is fixed regardless of the amount of neurotransmitter released.

Description A: Interconnected neurons form anatomically and functionally distinct pathways that convey information.
Description B: Individual neurons, not interconnected pathways, convey information.

Description A: Some spontaneously active nerve cells fire in regular bursts of action potentials.
Description B: Some spontaneously active nerve cells fire action potentials regularly.

Description A: The action potential is all-or-none: stimuli below threshold do not produce a signal.
Description B: The action potential is graded: stimuli below threshold can produce variable signal strengths.

Description A: An excitatory synaptic potential may initiate action potentials in a non-spontaneously active cell.
Description B: An excitatory synaptic potential cannot initiate action potentials in a non-spontaneously active cell.

Description A: Neurons differ in the ion channels and transmitters they use, affecting synaptic potential encodings.
Description B: All neurons use the same ion channels and transmitters, leading to uniform synaptic potential encodings.

Description A: Some neurons do not generate action potentials due to the lack of a conductive axon component.
Description B: All neurons generate action potentials regardless of their axon components.

Description A: The amplitude and duration of action potentials remain the same regardless of the intensity of stimuli.
Description B: The amplitude and duration of action potentials vary with the intensity of stimuli.

Description A: Neurotransmitter effects depend on the type of receptor in the postsynaptic cell, not the transmitter itself.
Description B: Neurotransmitter effects depend solely on the chemical neurotransmitter, not the receptor type.

Description A: Inhibition can establish periods of silence in spontaneously active cells.
Description B: Inhibition cannot establish periods of silence in spontaneously active cells.

Description A: The human brain is a network of more than 80 billion individual nerve cells.
Description B: The human brain is a network of more than 8 million individual nerve cells.

Description A: Neural science attempts to link the computational logic of neural circuitry to the mind.
Description B: Neural science attempts to link the computational logic of neural circuitry to genetics.

Description A: New imaging techniques permit us to visualize the human brain in action.
Description B: Traditional imaging techniques permit us to visualize the human brain in action.

Description A: The specificity of synaptic connections established during development underlies behavior.
Description B: The randomness of synaptic connections established during development underlies behavior.

Description A: Part Editors: Eric R. Kandel and Michael N. Shadlen.
Description B: Part Editors: William James and Sigmund Freud.

Description A: Today, it is possible to link the cellular dynamics of interconnected circuits of neurons to perceptual and motor acts in the brain.
Description B: It is impossible to link the cellular dynamics of interconnected circuits of neurons to perceptual and motor acts in the brain.

Description A: The focus of biology has shifted to neural science in the first half of the 21st century.
Description B: The focus of biology has shifted to the study of ecosystems in the first half of the 21st century.

Description A: Cognitive psychology and psychoanalytic theory have emphasized the diversity and complexity of human mental experience.
Description B: Cognitive psychology and psychoanalytic theory have emphasized the simplicity of human mental experience.

Description A: Our goal is to provide not simply the facts but the principles of brain organization, function, and computation.
Description B: Our goal is to provide only the facts without principles of brain organization, function, and computation.

Description A: The brain weighs only 1.5 kg.
Description B: The brain weighs only 2 kilograms.

Description A: In the first part of this book, mental functions can be localized to specific regions of the brain.
Description B: In the first part of this book, mental functions are generalized across the entire brain.

Description A: Technological advances have opened new horizons for the scientific study of the brain.
Description B: Technological advances have closed off possibilities for the scientific study of the brain.

Description A: Neural circuits construct perceptions of the external world and guide decisions.
Description B: Neural circuits have no role in constructing perceptions of the external world or guiding decisions.

Description A: The study of mind begins with the study of the brain, as proposed by Hippocrates.
Description B: The study of mind begins with the study of behavior, as proposed by Aristotle.

Description A: Genes encode proteins that initially govern the development of neural circuits.
Description B: Genes encode proteins that play no role in the development of neural circuits.

Description A: The presynaptic terminal at the neuromuscular junction is filled with a dye fura-2 under resting conditions, showing local hotspots of intracellular Ca2+ in response to a single presynaptic action potential.
Description B: The presynaptic terminal of the neuromuscular junction is filled with a dye rhodamine-B under active conditions, showing local hotspots of intracellular Mg2+ in response to a dual presynaptic action potential.

Description A: A presynaptic action potential normally produces only a brief rise in presynaptic Ca2+ concentration because the Ca2+ channels open only for a short time.
Description B: A presynaptic action potential typically produces a prolonged rise in presynaptic K+ concentration because the K+ channels open for an extended period.

Description A: Experiments revealed that a rise in Ca2+ concentration of less than 1 μM is sufficient to induce release of some transmitter.
Description B: Experiments showed that a rise in Ca2+ concentration of less than 1 mM is necessary to prevent the release of any transmitter.

Description A: Neurons contain five broad classes of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels: the L-type, P/Q-type, N-type, R-type, and T-type.
Description B: Neurons contain three broad classes of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels: the L-type, I-type, and S-type.

Description A: The calyx synapse includes almost a thousand active zones that function as independent release sites.
Description B: The calyx synapse comprises less than a hundred active zones that function as dependent release sites.

Description A: Once Ca2+ enters the terminal, the transmitter is rapidly released with a delay of only a few hundred microseconds.
Description B: Once Ca2+ enters the terminal, the transmitter is gradually released with a delay of several hundred milliseconds.

Description A: The synaptic delay is largely attributable to the time required to open Ca2+ channels.
Description B: The synaptic delay is mainly due to the time required to close Na+ channels.

Description A: Calcium channels are multimeric proteins whose distinct properties are determined by their pore-forming subunit, the α1-subunit
Description B: Calcium channels are monomeric proteins whose distinct properties are determined by their pore-blocking subunit, the β1-subunit.

Description A: The large presynaptic terminal of the calyx of Held in the mammalian brain stem engulfs a postsynaptic cell body.
Description B: The small post synaptic terminal of the calyx of Held in the mammalian brain stem engulfs a presynaptic cell body.

Description A: A rise in Ca2+ concentration of less than 1 μM is sufficient to induce release of some transmitter, but 10 to 30 μM Ca2+ is required for normal release.
Description B: A rise in K+ concentration of less than 0.5 μM is sufficient to prevent release of some transmitter, but 5 to 15 μM K+ is required for normal release.

Description A: In skeletal and cardiac muscle cells, calcium channels are important for excitation-contraction coupling.
Description B: In skeletal and cardiac muscle cells, sodium channels are crucial for excitation-contraction coupling.

Description A: The calyx of Held synapse specializes in rapid and reliable transmission to allow precise sound localization.
Description B: The calyx of Held synapse specializes in slow and sporadic transmission, hindering precise sound localization.

Description A: A presynaptic action potential normally produces a brief rise in presynaptic Ca2+ concentration.
Description B: A presynaptic action potential normally produces an extended rise in presynaptic Mg2+ concentration.

Description A: The α1-subunit of calcium channels is homologous to the α-subunit of voltage-gated Na+ channels.
Description B: The α1-subunit of calcium channels is homologous to the β-subunit of voltage-gated Cl- channels.

Description A: A model depicts that release is triggered by a major Ca2+ sensor that binds five Ca2+ ions.
Description B: A model depicts that release is triggered by a major K+ sensor that binds two Ca2+ ions.

Description A: The basal ganglia are important for adapting postural responses to a sudden change in initial conditions.
Description B: The basal ganglia are unimportant for adapting postural responses to a sudden change in initial conditions.

Description A: Lesions of insular cortex can impair perception of the visual vertical.
Description B: Lesions of insular cortex do not affect perception of the visual vertical.

Description A: The rostral and ventral subdivisions of the anterior cingulate cortex have extensive connections with the hippocampus, amygdala, orbital prefrontal cortex, anterior insula, and nucleus accumbens and are involved in the integration of emotion, cognition, and autonomic nervous system function.
Description B: The caudal subdivision of the anterior cingulate cortex has extensive connections with the hippocampus, amygdala, orbital prefrontal cortex, anterior insula, and nucleus accumbens and are involved in the integration of emotion, cognition, and autonomic nervous system function.

Description A: Studies of rodents have shown that new neurons within the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus can be incorporated into functional neural circuits.
Description B: Studies of rodents have shown that new neurons within the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus cannot be incorporated into functional neural circuits.

Description A: Reduced hippocampal volume has been reported in cases of PTSD and in major depression.
Description B: Increased hippocampal volume has been reported in cases of PTSD and in major depression.

Description A: Excess glucocorticoid secretion, as occurs in depression, could cause hippocampal volume loss by inhibiting neurogenesis over time.
Description B: Excess glucocorticoid secretion, as occurs in depression, enhances hippocampal volume by stimulating neurogenesis over time.

Description A: Major depressive disorder can be treated effectively with antidepressant drugs, cognitive psychotherapy, and electroconvulsive therapy.
Description B: Major depressive disorder can be treated effectively only with electroconvulsive therapy.

Description A: Current antidepressant drugs affect monoaminergic neural systems.
Description B: Current antidepressant drugs exclusively affect dopaminergic neural systems.

Description A: Induced sadness in healthy subjects increases activity in the rostral anterior cingulate cortex.
Description B: Induced sadness in healthy subjects decreases activity in the rostral anterior cingulate cortex.

Description A: Functional abnormalities of brain reward circuitry may play a role in the symptoms of mood disorders.
Description B: Functional abnormalities of brain reward circuitry are unrelated to the symptoms of mood disorders.

Description A: The reward circuitry comprises the dopaminergic projections from the ventral tegmental area of the midbrain to forebrain targets.
Description B: The reward circuitry comprises projections from the cerebellum to forebrain targets.

Description A: Volume reductions in patients with major depression correlate with the duration of depressive episodes.
Description B: Volume reductions in patients with major depression correlate with improved mood.

Description A: Functional abnormalities of brain reward circuitry may also play a role in the symptoms of mood disorders.
Description B: Functional abnormalities of brain reward circuitry are not associated with symptoms of mood disorders.

Description A: The acquired loss of hippocampal volume in major depression could result from either loss of dendrites and dendritic spines or decreased cell numbers.
Description B: The acquired loss of hippocampal volume in major depression does not result from loss of dendrites and dendritic spines.

Description A: Stressful or aversive treatments inhibit the proliferation of granule cell precursors and suppress normal rates of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.
Description B: Stressful or aversive treatments enhance the proliferation of granule cell precursors and boost rates of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.

Description A: Antidepressants increase the rate of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.
Description B: Antidepressants decrease the rate of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.

Description A: Elevated cortisol levels in patients with major depression might be associated with reduced hippocampal volumes.
Description B: Elevated cortisol levels in patients with major depression might be associated with increased hippocampal volumes.

Description A: Glial cells greatly outnumber neurons—there are 2 to 10 times more glia than neurons in the vertebrate central nervous system.
Description B: Neurons greatly outnumber glial cells—there are 2 to 10 times more neurons than glia in the vertebrate central nervous system.

Description A: Interneurons comprise the most numerous functional category, subdivided into relay and local classes.
Description B: Motor neurons comprise the most numerous functional category, subdivided into relay and local classes.

Description A: A simple behavior, the knee-jerk reflex, is controlled by a circuit of sensory and motor neurons.
Description B: A complex behavior, the knee-jerk reflex, is controlled by a circuit of sensory and motor neurons.

Description A: Relay or projection interneurons have long axons and convey signals over considerable distances.
Description B: Local interneurons have long axons and convey signals over considerable distances.

Description A: Sensory neurons supply the brain with data, whereas motor neurons convert ideation into praxis.
Description B: Motor neurons supply the brain with data, whereas sensory neurons convert ideation into praxis.

Description A: Sensory neurons make both excitatory and inhibitory connections in the knee-jerk reflex.
Description B: Sensory neurons make only excitatory connections in the knee-jerk reflex.

Description A: Feedforward inhibition in the knee-jerk reflex involves both extensor and flexor muscles.
Description B: Feedforward inhibition in the knee-jerk reflex involves only flexor muscles.

Description A: The dendrites of the retinal ganglion cells determine their type based on size and shape.
Description B: The axons of the retinal ganglion cells determine their type based on size and shape.

Description A: Glia do not form dendrites and axons.
Description B: Glia form dendrites and axons like neurons.

Description A: Convergence is common at the output stages of the nervous system.
Description B: Divergence is common at the output stages of the nervous system.

Description A: The knee-jerk reflex is a stretch reflex activated by tapping the tendon just below the patella.
Description B: The knee-jerk reflex is a flexion reflex activated by tapping the tendon just below the patella.

Description A: The sensory neurons involved in the knee-jerk reflex are pseudo-unipolar cells.
Description B: The sensory neurons involved in the knee-jerk reflex are bipolar cells.

Description A: Afferent neurons from extensor muscles excite inhibitory interneurons in the knee-jerk reflex.
Description B: Afferent neurons from flexor muscles excite inhibitory interneurons in the knee-jerk reflex.

Description A: The knee-jerk reflex is used clinically to test the integrity of the nerves.
Description B: The knee-jerk reflex is used clinically to test the elasticity of the muscles.

Description A: Local interneurons have short axons because they form connections with nearby neurons.
Description B: Local interneurons have long axons because they form connections with nearby neurons.

Description A: In the macaque monkey, V1 is located on the surface of the occipital lobe and sends axons in two pathways.
Description B: In the macaque monkey, V1 is located on the surface of the frontal lobe and sends axons in two pathways.

Description A: The dorsal or movement-guidance pathway connects the primary visual cortex with the parietal lobe and then with the frontal lobes.
Description B: The dorsal or movement-guidance pathway connects the primary visual cortex directly to the temporal lobes.

Description A: Patients with lesions of parietal areas fail to attend to objects on one side of the body, a syndrome called unilateral neglect.
Description B: Patients with lesions of temporal areas fail to attend to objects on one side of the body, a syndrome called unilateral neglect.

Description A: The inferior temporal cortex stores information about the shapes and identities of objects; damage to that region results in the inability to recognize faces (prosopagnosia).
Description B: The parietal cortex stores information about the shapes and identities of objects; damage to that region results in the inability to recognize faces (prosopagnosia).

Description A: Receptive fields with the same eccentricity are relatively small at early levels in visual processing and become progressively larger at later levels.
Description B: Receptive fields with the same eccentricity are relatively large at early levels in visual processing and become progressively smaller at later levels.

Description A: Functional specificity has been demonstrated for a number of visual areas: VO1 is implicated in color processing.
Description B: Functional specificity has been demonstrated for a number of visual areas: VO1 is implicated in object shape processing.

Description A: A ventral pathway projects through V4 into areas of the inferior temporal cortex and mediates object recognition.
Description B: A ventral pathway projects through V4 into areas of the frontal lobe and mediates object recognition.

Description A: The pulvinar in the thalamus serves as a relay between cortical areas.
Description B: The lateral geniculate nucleus in the thalamus serves as a relay between cortical areas.

Description A: The on-center cells fire when a spot of light is turned on within a circular central region.
Description B: The on-center cells fire when a spot of light is turned off within a circular central region.

Description A: The lateral intraparietal area is involved in representing points in space that are the targets of eye movements or reaching.
Description B: The lateral occipital complex is involved in representing points in space that are the targets of eye movements or reaching.

Description A: Areas in the intraparietal sulcus are involved in control of spatial attention and saccadic eye movements.
Description B: Areas in the inferior temporal cortex are involved in control of spatial attention and saccadic eye movements.

Description A: The fusiform face area (FFA) codes faces.
Description B: The fusiform face area (FFA) codes places.

Description A: Responses to only one spot of light yielded a limited understanding of a cell’s receptive field.
Description B: Responses to only one spot of light yielded a comprehensive understanding of a cell’s receptive field.

Description A: The boundaries of these maps can be used to demarcate the boundaries of visual areas.
Description B: The boundaries of these maps can be used to demarcate the boundaries of auditory areas.

Description A: The extrastriate body area (EBA) responds more strongly to body parts than objects.
Description B: The extrastriate body area (EBA) responds more strongly to objects than body parts.

Description A: Current maps usually place the primary motor cortex (M1) in Brodmann’s area 4.
Description B: Current maps usually place the primary motor cortex (M1) in Brodmann’s area 6.

Description A: Optimal feedback control emphasizes the importance of feedback signals for the planning and control of movements.
Description B: Optimal feedback control emphasizes the importance of feedforward signals for the planning and control of movements.

Description A: Experimental tasks dissociate different types of movement-related information by revealing differences in neural activity across cortical motor regions.
Description B: Experimental tasks show uniform neural activity across all cortical motor regions regardless of the movement-related information.

Description A: The primary somatosensory cortex (S-I) processes cutaneous and muscle mechanoreceptor signals.
Description B: The primary somatosensory cortex (S-I) processes visual and auditory signals.

Description A: The optimal feedback control framework divides the control of voluntary movements into three key processes: state estimation, task selection, and control policy.
Description B: The optimal feedback control framework divides the control of voluntary movements into two key processes: state estimation and control policy.

Description A: At the neuromuscular junction, EEPSP = 0 mV, EK = −100 mV, and ENa = +55 mV.
Description B: At the neuromuscular junction, EEPSP = +5 mV, EK = −10 mV, and ENa = +55 mV.

Description A: Tetrodotoxin blocks the voltage-gated Na+ channel but does not block the influx of Na+ through the nicotinic ACh receptor-channels.
Description B: Tetrodotoxin blocks the voltage-gated K+ channel but does not block the influx of Na+ through the nicotinic ACh receptor-channels.

Description A: The conductance of the ACh receptor-channel for Na+ is slightly higher than for K+.
Description B: The conductance of the ACh receptor-channel for K+ is slightly higher than for Na+.

Description A: The ACh receptors have two binding sites for ACh, both must be occupied by transmitter for the channel to open efficiently.
Description B: The ACh receptors have one binding site for ACh, which must be occupied by transmitter for the channel to open efficiently.

Description A: A minimal reaction model captures key steps of ACh receptor-channel function.
Description B: A complex reaction model captures key steps of ACh receptor-channel function.

Description A: Recent X-ray crystallographic data have provided a direct view of the large pore of the ACh receptor-channel.
Description B: Recent infrared spectroscopy data have provided a direct view of the large pore of the ACh receptor-channel.

Description A: The rapid opening of many channels causes a large increase in the total conductance of the end-plate membrane.
Description B: The rapid opening of a few channels causes a large increase in the total conductance of the end-plate membrane.

Description A: α-bungarotoxin binds tightly to the nicotinic receptors and blocks the action of ACh but does not interfere with voltage-gated Na+ channels.
Description B: α-bungarotoxin binds loosely to the nicotinic receptors and blocks the action of ACh but does not interfere with voltage-gated Na+ channels.

Description A: Heavy smokers can build up sufficient levels of nicotine to desensitize receptors in the brain.
Description B: Heavy smokers can build up insufficient levels of nicotine to desensitize receptors in the brain.

Description A: To trigger an action potential, a synaptic potential must recruit neighboring voltage-gated Na+ channels.
Description B: To trigger an action potential, a synaptic potential must recruit neighboring voltage-gated K+ channels.

Description A: The end-plate potential resulting from the opening of acetylcholine receptor-channels opens voltage-gated sodium channels.
Description B: The end-plate potential resulting from the opening of acetylcholine receptor-channels opens voltage-gated potassium channels.

Description A: The mature nicotinic ACh receptor is a membrane glycoprotein formed from five subunits.
Description B: The mature nicotinic ACh receptor is a membrane glycoprotein formed from three subunits.

Description A: One molecule of ACh must bind at each of the two sites for the channel to open efficiently.
Description B: Two molecules of ACh must bind at each of the two sites for the channel to open efficiently.

Description A: A single type of ion channel, the ACh receptor-channel, generates the end-plate potential by allowing both Na+ and K+ to pass with nearly equal permeability.
Description B: Two types of ion channels generate the end-plate potential by allowing both Na+ and K+ to pass with nearly equal permeability.

Description A: The action potential is generated by sequential activation of two distinct classes of voltage-gated channels.
Description B: The action potential is generated by simultaneous activation of three distinct classes of voltage-gated channels.

Description A: Feedback control systems are known as feedback or closed-loop control because the sensorimotor loop is complete.
Description B: Feedback control systems are known as open-loop control because the sensorimotor loop is incomplete.

Description A: If feedback delay increases, the control system may start to oscillate and eventually become unstable.
Description B: If feedback delay decreases, the control system may start to oscillate and eventually become unstable.

Description A: Internal models can answer how can we generate motor commands and predict their consequences.
Description B: Internal models can answer how can we perceive body temperature and predict weather conditions.

Description A: The simplest form of feedback control occurs when the error exceeds a certain threshold.
Description B: The simplest form of feedback control occurs when the error is below a certain threshold.

Description A: Smooth pursuit eye movement uses feedback to minimize the velocity error on the retina.
Description B: Smooth pursuit eye movement uses feedforward to maximize the velocity error on the retina.

Description A: Skilled motor performance requires both control and prediction.
Description B: Skilled motor performance requires control but not prediction.

Description A: Internal sensorimotor models represent relationships of the body and external world.
Description B: Internal sensorimotor models only represent the internal state of the body.

Description A: Feedback control can be sensitive to feedback delays.
Description B: Feedback control is immune to feedback delays.

Description A: Internal models allow an organism to contemplate consequences without committing to actions.
Description B: Internal models force an organism to act out consequences to understand them.

Description A: State estimation can be improved by combining multiple sensory modalities.
Description B: State estimation cannot be improved by combining sensory modalities.

Description A: Prediction and control map onto forward and inverse models.
Description B: Prediction and control are unrelated to forward and inverse models.

Description A: The vestibulo-ocular reflex offers precise fixation due to feedforward control.
Description B: The vestibulo-ocular reflex offers precise fixation due to feedback control.

Description A: Sophisticated computation is required to estimate current body states accurately.
Description B: Estimation of body states is simple and requires no computation.

Description A: Estimating the body’s state uses internal models of sensorimotor transformations.
Description B: Estimating the body’s state does not use any form of internal models.

Description A: Feedback control is robust to noise but sensitive to delays.
Description B: Feedback control is insensitive to noise and delays.

Description A: A single motor neuron may be the target of as many as 10,000 different presynaptic terminals.
Description B: A single motor neuron may be the target of only 100 different presynaptic terminals.

Description A: The reversal potential for Cl− is typically more negative than the resting potential, leading to hyperpolarization.
Description B: The reversal potential for Cl− is typically more positive than the resting potential, leading to hyperpolarization.

Description A: GABAB responses turn on more slowly and persist for a longer time compared with GABAA responses.
Description B: GABAB responses turn on more quickly and persist for a shorter time compared with GABAA responses.

Description A: 5-HT3 receptor-channels are permeable to monovalent cations and have a reversal potential near 0 mV.
Description B: 5-HT3 receptor-channels are impermeable to monovalent cations and have a reversal potential far from 0 mV.

Description A: EPSPs produced by motor neurons are often only 0.2 to 0.4 mV in amplitude.
Description B: EPSPs produced by motor neurons are often 10 to 12 mV in amplitude.

Description A: P2X receptor-channels are permeable to both monovalent cations and Ca2+, with a reversal potential near 0 mV.
Description B: P2X receptor-channels are impermeable to Ca2+, with a reversal potential near 0 mV.

Description A: Neuronal integration reflects the task that confronts the nervous system as a whole.
Description B: Neuronal integration is unrelated to the task that confronts the nervous system as a whole.

Description A: In some neurons, the resting potential is approximately equal to ECl, making the electrochemical driving force on Cl− nearly zero.
Description B: In some neurons, the resting potential is substantially different from ECl, making the electrochemical driving force on Cl− large.

Description A: The opening of Cl− channels results in a positive current corresponding to an influx of Cl− ions.
Description B: The opening of Cl− channels results in a negative current corresponding to an influx of Cl− ions.

Description A: Opening Cl− channels in neurons can result in short-circuiting or shunting effects.
Description B: Opening Cl− channels in neurons can result in amplification or enhancing effects.

Description A: Some central neurons have a resting potential nearly equal to the Cl− reversal potential.
Description B: All central neurons have a resting potential much more positive than the Cl− reversal potential.

Description A: Excitatory inputs added in neurons result in summation.
Description B: Excitatory inputs added in neurons result in division.

Description A: Cl− efflux can lead to depolarizing responses under certain conditions.
Description B: Cl− efflux frequently leads to hyperpolarizing responses under all conditions.

Description A: The charge carrier in Cl− channel opening is a negatively charged Cl− ion.
Description B: The charge carrier in Cl− channel opening is a positively charged Cl− ion.

Description A: Activation of GABAA receptors can cause depolarization in newborn animals.
Description B: Activation of GABAA receptors typically causes hyperpolarization in newborn animals.

Description A: During transport of glutamate, one negatively charged molecule of the transmitter is imported with three Na+ ions and one proton in exchange for the export of one K+, leading to a net influx of two positive charges.
Description B: During transport of glutamate, one negatively charged molecule of the transmitter is imported with three Na+ ions and one proton in exchange for the export of two K+, leading to a net influx of three positive charges.

Description A: The psychostimulatory effects of cocaine result from its action to prevent reuptake of dopamine, thereby increasing its extracellular levels.
Description B: The psychostimulatory effects of cocaine result from its action to enhance the uptake of dopamine, thereby reducing its extracellular levels.

Description A: Synaptic vesicles in the periphery are highly concentrated in nerve endings and, in the brain, tend to be at varicosities along the axon at presynaptic sites.
Description B: Synaptic vesicles in the periphery are scarce in nerve endings and, in the brain, never tend to be at varicosities along the axon at presynaptic sites.

Description A: The enzymes that regulate transmitter biosynthesis are under tight regulatory control and can produce homeostatic changes in the levels and activity of these enzymes.
Description B: The enzymes that regulate transmitter biosynthesis are under loose regulation and cannot produce homeostatic changes in the levels and activity of these enzymes.

Description A: Glutamate transport requires the countertransport of K+ driven by the electrochemical potential provided by the Na+ gradient.
Description B: Glutamate transport requires the cotransport of Cl− driven by the electrochemical potential provided by the Na+ gradient.

Description A: The co-release of several neuroactive substances onto appropriate postsynaptic receptors permits great diversity of information to be transferred in a single synaptic action.
Description B: The co-release of several neuroactive substances onto appropriate postsynaptic receptors limits the diversity of information to be transferred in a single synaptic action.

Description A: Amphetamine-induced dopamine release through DAT requires phosphorylation of its N-terminus.
Description B: Amphetamine-induced dopamine release through DAT occurs independently of phosphorylation of its N-terminus.

Description A: Precise mechanisms for terminating transmitter actions are nearly as important as transmitting synthesis and release.
Description B: Precise mechanisms for terminating transmitter actions are not important compared to transmitting synthesis and release.

Description A: The normal physiological role of the phosphorylation of DAT's N-terminus remains a mystery.
Description B: The normal physiological role of the phosphorylation of DAT's N-terminus is fully understood.

Description A: The NSS proteins can run backward, allowing them to generate transmitter efflux and are best characterized for dopamine.
Description B: The NSS proteins run strictly forward, which restricts their ability to generate transmitter efflux for dopamine.

Description A: Acetylcholine is rapidly hydrolyzed by acetylcholinesterase to choline and acetate.
Description B: Acetylcholine is slowly converted by acetyltransferase to acetyl-CoA and acetate.

Description A: Computational studies suggest phosphorylation-regulated interactions of DAT's N-terminus with acidic lipids play a role in modulating transporter function.
Description B: Experimental studies show phosphorylated interactions of DAT's C-terminus with neutral lipids play a role in modulating transporter function.

Description A: Small-molecule transmitters are taken up and highly concentrated in vesicles, protected from degradative enzymes in the cytoplasm.
Description B: Small-molecule transmitters are dispersed loosely in the cytoplasm and vulnerable to degradative enzymes.

Description A: Not all molecules released by a neuron are chemical messengers—only those that bind to appropriate receptors and initiate functional changes are considered neurotransmitters.
Description B: All molecules released by a neuron are chemical messengers regardless of receptor binding and functional initiation.

Description A: The electrochemical driving force is often sufficient for NSS transporters to carry transmitters into the cell, thereby increasing the cytoplasmic transmitter concentration.
Description B: The electrochemical driving force is never sufficient for NSS transporters to carry transmitters into the cell, resulting in the decrease of cytoplasmic transmitter concentration.

Description A: The deepest dendrites of J-RGCs are represented in red in the transgenic labeling of the mouse retina.
Description B: The deepest dendrites of J-RGCs are represented in blue in the transgenic labeling of the mouse retina.

Description A: The history of developmental neurobiology includes Santiago Ramón y Cajal's anatomical studies on the nervous system's structure.
Description B: The history of developmental neurobiology excludes Santiago Ramón y Cajal's anatomical studies on the nervous system's structure.

Description A: Some molecules that control neural development are transcription factors that regulate gene expression.
Description B: Transcription factors do not play a role in controlling gene expression during neural development.

Description A: Genetic programs governing body plan and neural connectivity are conserved throughout phylogeny.
Description B: Genetic programs governing body plan and neural connectivity are not conserved throughout phylogeny.

Description A: Axons of many neuronal types must often navigate long distances during neural development.
Description B: Axons of many neuronal types only travel short distances during neural development.

Description A: The experience-dependent remodeling of the brain is especially prominent and prolonged in humans.
Description B: The experience-dependent remodeling of the brain is minimal and short-lived in humans.

Description A: Santiago Ramón y Cajal deduced many developmental principles of neurobiology using light microscopic analysis of fixed tissue.
Description B: Santiago Ramón y Cajal used electron microscopy to deduce developmental principles of neurobiology.

Description A: Neuronal wiring includes the migration of somata, axon guidance, and synaptic connection formation.
Description B: Neuronal wiring exclusively involves synaptic connection formation.

Description A: The first epoch of neural development involves the generation and differentiation of neurons and glia.
Description B: The first epoch of neural development primarily involves the establishment of synaptic connections.

Description A: Transcription factors, which are cell-autonomous factors, regulate gene expression during neural development.
Description B: Transcription factors, which are cell non-autonomous factors, regulate gene expression during neural development.

Description A: Cell non-autonomous factors include cell surface and secreted molecules that arise from other cells.
Description B: Cell non-autonomous factors do not involve cell surface or secreted molecules.

Description A: The etiology of some neurological diseases is being elucidated through neural development studies.
Description B: Neurological diseases have no connection to neural development studies.

Description A: Fruit flies and nematode worms are genetically accessible organisms used to study neural development.
Description B: Butterflies and beetles are the primary organisms used to study neural development.

Description A: The nervous system's plasticity is evident during early life and can be recruited in adults.
Description B: The nervous system's plasticity is purely a factor of early life and cannot be recruited in adults.

Description A: Developmental neurobiology has progressed significantly with advances in methods like electrophysiology and molecular biology.
Description B: Developmental neurobiology has remained unchanged due to a lack of advancements in methods.

Description A: The neocortex receives inputs from the thalamus, other cortical regions on both sides of the brain, and other subcortical structures.
Description B: The neocortex receives inputs exclusively from cortical regions on both sides of the brain.

Description A: Layer IV in the primary visual cortex is so heavily populated by neurons and so complex that it is divided into three sublayers.
Description B: Layer IV in the primary visual cortex is sparsely populated by neurons, making it less complex and not divided into sublayers.

Description A: Areas with a prominent layer IV are called granular cortex.
Description B: Areas with a prominent layer IV are called agranular cortex.

Description A: Layer V, the internal pyramidal cell layer, contains mainly pyramidally shaped cells that are typically larger than those in layer III.
Description B: Layer V, the internal pyramidal cell layer, contains mainly pyramidally shaped cells that are typically smaller than those in layer III.

Description A: Layer VI is called the polymorphic or multiform layer.
Description B: Layer VI is called the monomorphic or single-form layer.

Description A: Korbinian Brodmann divided the cerebral cortex into 47 regions based on cytoarchitectonic differences.
Description B: Korbinian Brodmann divided the cerebral cortex into 30 regions based on cytoarchitectonic differences.

Description A: The neocortex's organization increases its computational efficiency.
Description B: The neocortex's organization reduces its computational efficiency.

Description A: The Golgi stain reveals a subset of neuronal cell bodies, axons, and dendritic trees.
Description B: The Golgi stain reveals the pattern of myelinated fibers.

Description A: Approximately two-thirds of the neocortex is along the deep wrinkles of the cortex, termed sulci.
Description B: Approximately one-third of the neocortex is along the deep wrinkles of the cortex, termed sulci.

Description A: Layer IV is the main recipient of sensory input from the thalamus.
Description B: Layer IV is primarily responsible for processing motor output.

Description A: The neurons located deeper in layer III are typically larger than those located more superficially.
Description B: The neurons located deeper in layer III are typically smaller than those located more superficially.

Description A: The thickness of individual layers and details of their functional organization vary throughout the cortex.
Description B: The thickness of individual layers and details of their functional organization are uniform throughout the cortex.

Description A: Layer I, the molecular layer, is occupied by the dendrites of cells located in deeper layers and axons that travel through this layer.
Description B: Layer I, the molecular layer, contains primarily axons and lacks dendrites.

Description A: The external granular cell layer is one of two layers that contain small spherical neurons.
Description B: The external pyramidal cell layer exclusively contains small spherical neurons.

Description A: Corticocortical connections arise primarily from neurons in layers II and III.
Description B: Corticocortical connections arise primarily from neurons in layers IV and V.

Description A: Synaptotagmin mediates Ca2+-dependent transmitter release by forming a protein complex that favors vesicle fusion.
Description B: Synaptotagmin mediates K+-dependent transmitter release by forming a protein complex that favors vesicle fusion.

Description A: Vesicles are tethered to filamentous proteins of the active zone.
Description B: Vesicles are untethered in the active zone, floating freely.

Description A: Zippering of the synaptotagmin-complexin-SNARE complex mediates vesicle fusion.
Description B: Zippering of the synaptotagmin-complexin-SNARE complex inhibits vesicle fusion.

Description A: Synaptic depression refers to a decrease in the size of the postsynaptic response to repeated stimulation.
Description B: Synaptic depression refers to an increase in the size of the postsynaptic response to repeated stimulation.

Description A: During tetanic stimulation, so much Ca2+ flows into the axon terminals that Ca2+ buffering and clearance systems can become saturated.
Description B: During tetanic stimulation, so little Ca2+ flows into the axon terminals that they deplete Ca2+ buffering systems.

Description A: High-frequency stimulation is called tetanic stimulation and can cause dramatic changes in synaptic strength.
Description B: Low-frequency stimulation is called tetanic stimulation and can cause dramatic changes in synaptic strength.

Description A: The active zone coordinates and regulates the docking and priming of synaptic vesicles.
Description B: The active zone releases neurotransmitters without regulating docking and priming of synaptic vesicles.

Description A: RIM and RIM-BP mediate the recruitment of Ca2+ channels to the active zone.
Description B: RIM and RIM-BP mediate the recruitment of K+ channels to the active zone.

Description A: Synaptic facilitation is the enhancement of transmission with repeated stimulation.
Description B: Synaptic facilitation is the reduction of transmission with repeated stimulation.

Description A: Munc13 and RIM are used to counteract vesicle depletion during high-frequency stimulation.
Description B: Munc13 and RIM are used to promote vesicle depletion during high-frequency stimulation.

Description A: Phosphorylation of RIM by cAMP-dependent protein kinase enhances transmitter release.
Description B: Phosphorylation of RIM by cAMP-dependent protein kinase inhibits transmitter release.

Description A: Synaptic vesicle binding to RIM and Munc13 is essential for priming vesicles for exocytosis.
Description B: Synaptic vesicle binding to RIM and Munc13 is unnecessary for exocytosis.

Description A: Residual Ca2+ enhances synaptic transmission by activating Ca2+-dependent enzymes.
Description B: Residual Ca2+ diminishes synaptic transmission by deactivating Ca2+-dependent enzymes.

Description A: Synaptic plasticity can dramatically and rapidly modulate synaptic effectiveness.
Description B: Synaptic plasticity stabilizes synaptic effectiveness, preventing changes.

Description A: Axosomatic synaptic actions affect all branches of the postsynaptic neuron’s axon.
Description B: Axosomatic synaptic actions selectively control individual terminals of the axon.

Description A: Long-term potentiation can last for many hours or days.
Description B: Long-term potentiation can last for a few seconds.

Description A: Electrical synaptic transmission is rapid because it results from the direct passage of current between cells.
Description B: Electrical synaptic transmission is slow because it results from indirect passage of current between cells.

Description A: The tail-flip response of goldfish is mediated by a giant neuron in the brain stem known as the Mauthner cell.
Description B: The tail-flip response of goldfish is mediated by a small neuron in the spinal cord known as the Mauthner cell.

Description A: Gap-junction channels conduct a variety of inorganic cations and anions, including Ca2+, and even moderate-sized organic compounds.
Description B: Gap-junction channels conduct only organic compounds and proteins, excluding inorganic cations and anions.

Description A: Gap junctions are formed between glial cells as well as between neurons.
Description B: Gap junctions are only formed between neurons and are not found in glial cells.

Description A: Chemical synapses can amplify signals due to the release of neurotransmitter from synaptic vesicles.
Description B: Chemical synapses cannot amplify signals and rely on direct electrical transmission.

Description A: In chemical synaptic transmission, transmitter is released from synaptic boutons that contain 100 to 200 synaptic vesicles.
Description B: In chemical synaptic transmission, transmitter is released from axon terminals that contain only 2 to 5 synaptic vesicles.

Description A: A neurotransmitter binds to receptors in the postsynaptic membrane, leading to the opening or closing of ion channels.
Description B: A neurotransmitter binds to receptors in the postsynaptic membrane, leading to the permanent closure of ion channels.

Description A: Inherited mutations in connexin can disrupt the function of gap junction channels and cause congenital deafness.
Description B: Inherited mutations in connexin have no impact on the function of gap junction channels in hearing.

Description A: Chemical synaptic transmission has a property of amplification, allowing one synaptic vesicle to open thousands of ion channels.
Description B: Chemical synaptic transmission lacks amplification, with each synaptic vesicle opening only one ion channel.

Description A: Gap junctions in the mammalian brain help generate synchronous 40- to 100-Hz gamma oscillations.
Description B: Gap junctions in the mammalian brain disrupt the generation of synchronous 40- to 100-Hz gamma oscillations.

Description A: Electrical synapses transmit metabolic signals between cells through large-diameter pore channels.
Description B: Electrical synapses allow rapid and synchronous firing of interconnected cells.

Description A: Electrical stimulation of neuronal pathways can trigger a rise in intracellular Ca2+ in astrocytes.
Description B: Electrical stimulation of neuronal pathways completely blocks intracellular signaling in astrocytes.

Description A: The synaptic cleft at chemical synapses is usually slightly wider (20–40 nm) than the nonsynaptic intercellular space.
Description B: The synaptic cleft at chemical synapses is usually narrower than the nonsynaptic intercellular space.

Description A: At chemical synapses, there is no structural continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic neurons.
Description B: At chemical synapses, there is complete structural continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic neurons.

Description A: Electrically coupled cells fire synchronously once their high threshold is surpassed.
Description B: Electrically coupled cells always fire independently regardless of their thresholds.

Description A: The stretch reflex acts to resist the lengthening of a muscle.
Description B: The stretch reflex acts to promote the lengthening of a muscle.

Description A: Charles Sherrington recognized the importance of sensory information in regulating movements in 1906.
Description B: Charles Sherrington recognized the importance of sensory information in regulating movements in 1925.

Description A: Extensive damage to glutamatergic neurons in the parabrachial and pedunculopontine nuclei can cause a prolonged coma.
Description B: Minimal damage to glutamatergic neurons in the parabrachial and pedunculopontine nuclei can cause a prolonged coma.

Description A: Ablation of any one of the monoaminergic cell groups has little effect on the waking state.
Description B: Ablation of any one of the monoaminergic cell groups causes a profound effect on the waking state.

Description A: Thalamic relay neurons fire single spikes related to incoming sensory stimuli during wakefulness.
Description B: Thalamic relay neurons fire in rhythmic bursts related to incoming sensory stimuli during wakefulness.

Description A: Both noradrenergic and serotonergic neurons innervate the parabrachial complex.
Description B: Both noradrenergic and serotonergic neurons innervate the cerebellum.

Description A: Antihistamines cause drowsiness.
Description B: Antihistamines enhance alertness.

Description A: The firing pattern of thalamic and cortical neurons changes from burst mode to single-spike mode when the cells are depolarized by acetylcholine.
Description B: The firing pattern of thalamic and cortical neurons changes from single-spike mode to burst mode when the cells are depolarized by acetylcholine.

Description A: Parabrachial, noradrenergic, serotonergic, histaminergic, and cholinergic inputs modulate the thalamus's ability to transmit sensory information to the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Parabrachial, noradrenergic, serotonergic, histaminergic, and cholinergic inputs modulate the cerebellum's ability to transmit sensory information to the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Nicotine is a powerful stimulant.
Description B: Nicotine is a powerful depressant.

Description A: A large portion of all central nervous system–active drugs act on monoaminergic pathways.
Description B: A large portion of all central nervous system–active drugs act on purinergic pathways.

Description A: Patients with Parkinson disease lose noradrenergic neurons in the locus ceruleus and tend to be abnormally sleepy during the day.
Description B: Patients with Parkinson disease gain noradrenergic neurons in the locus ceruleus and tend to be alert during the day.

Description A: Dopamine reuptake blockers like amphetamines induce arousal.
Description B: Dopamine reuptake blockers like amphetamines induce sleep.

Description A: Monoaminergic neurons participate in the ascending arousal system by regulating cortical activity.
Description B: Monoaminergic neurons hinder the ascending arousal system by silencing cortical activity.

Description A: The parabrachial–pedunculopontine–basal forebrain–cortical pathway is essential to maintaining a waking state.
Description B: The thalamic–cerebellar–midbrain–cortical pathway is essential to maintaining a waking state.

Description A: Monoaminergic pathways modulate specific cellular properties of postsynaptic neurons in the thalamus and cerebral cortex.
Description B: Monoaminergic pathways stabilize cellular properties of postsynaptic neurons in the thalamus and cerebral cortex.

Description A: Both acetylcholine and monoamines convert the firing patterns of cortical and thalamic neurons from burst mode to single-spike mode.
Description B: Both acetylcholine and monoamines convert the firing patterns of cortical and thalamic neurons from single-spike mode to burst mode.

Description A: In male rodents, the spinal nucleus of the bulbocavernosus (SNB) promotes the survival of target muscles by expressing the androgen receptor and responding to testosterone.
Description B: In female rodents, the spinal nucleus of the bulbocavernosus (SNB) promotes the survival of target muscles by expressing the androgen receptor and responding to testosterone.

Description A: Zebra finches exhibit sexual dimorphism in the song circuit, with larger regions in male songbirds contributing more neurons to song production.
Description B: Zebra finches exhibit sexual dimorphism in the song circuit, with larger regions in female songbirds contributing more neurons to song production.

Description A: The male-specific perinatal surge of testosterone promotes the survival of neurons in the SDN-POA and BNST in male rodents.
Description B: The female-specific perinatal surge of testosterone promotes the survival of neurons in the SDN-POA and BNST in male rodents.

Description A: Removal of the olfactory bulb abolishes mating and aggression in mice, indicating an essential role for olfactory stimulation.
Description B: Enhancement of the olfactory bulb promotes mating and aggression in mice, indicating an essential role for olfactory stimulation.

Description A: Estrogen produced from testosterone aromatization in the male rodent brain promotes neuron survival via activation of estrogen receptors.
Description B: Estrogen produced from testosterone aromatization in the female rodent brain promotes neuron survival via activation of estrogen receptors.

Description A: Male-specific neurons survive due to testosterone aromatization into estrogen in the SDN-POA and BNST.
Description B: Female-specific neurons survive due to testosterone aromatization into estrogen in the SDN-POA and BNST.

Description A: Sensory neurons in the main olfactory epithelium (MOE) detect volatile odors, whereas the vomeronasal organ (VNO) detects nonvolatile cues.
Description B: Sensory neurons in the vomeronasal organ (VNO) detect volatile odors, whereas the main olfactory epithelium (MOE) detects nonvolatile cues.

Description A: Pheromone detection in the vomeronasal organ (VNO) is crucial for sex discrimination and mating behavior in mice.
Description B: Pheromone detection in the main olfactory epithelium (MOE) is crucial for sex discrimination and mating behavior in mice.

Description A: Trpc2 is essential for pheromone signaling in vomeronasal organ (VNO) neurons, not expressed in MOE neurons.
Description B: Trpc2 is essential for pheromone signaling in main olfactory epithelium (MOE) neurons, not expressed in VNO neurons.

Description A: In zebra finches, the male high vocal center (HVC) is larger in volume and contains more neurons than the comparable regions in the female.
Description B: In zebra finches, the female high vocal center (HVC) is larger in volume and contains more neurons than the comparable regions in the male.

Description A: The ability of brain testosterone to promote neuron survival is exerted via aromatization into estrogen.
Description B: The ability of brain testosterone to promote neuron survival is exerted directly without aromatization into estrogen.

Description A: In newborn females, the small amount of estrogen present is easily sequestered by binding to α-fetoprotein.
Description B: In newborn males, the small amount of estrogen present is easily sequestered by binding to α-fetoprotein.

Description A: Female mice lacking α-fetoprotein exhibit male-typical behaviors and reduced female-typical sexual receptivity.
Description B: Male mice lacking α-fetoprotein exhibit female-typical behaviors and reduced male-typical sexual receptivity.

Description A: Genetically engineered disruption of pheromone responsiveness in MOE or VNO reveals a complex role in mouse mating behavior.
Description B: Genetically engineered enhancement of pheromone responsiveness in MOE or VNO reveals a simple role in mouse mating behavior.

Description A: The lateral magnocellular nucleus of the anterior neostriatum (LMAN) is larger in volume in male zebra finches than in females.
Description B: The lateral magnocellular nucleus of the anterior neostriatum (LMAN) is larger in volume in female zebra finches than in males.

Description A: Structural magnetic resonance imaging depicts the near-complete removal of the right occipital cortex in a patient, M.S., who suffered pharmacologically intractable epilepsy with a right occipital cortical focus.
Description B: Structural magnetic resonance imaging depicts the near-complete removal of the left occipital cortex in a patient, M.S., who suffered pharmacologically intractable epilepsy with a right occipital cortical focus.

Description A: Font-specific priming is intact in amnesic patients (AMN) and their controls as well as in the controls for patient M.S., but not in M.S. himself.
Description B: Font-specific priming is intact in amnesic patients (AMN) and their controls as well as in patient M.S. himself, but not in the controls for M.S.

Description A: Implicit memory refers to forms of knowledge that guide behavior without conscious awareness.
Description B: Implicit memory refers to forms of knowledge that guide behavior with full conscious awareness.

Description A: Damage to unimodal sensory regions of cortex impairs modality-specific perceptual priming.
Description B: Damage to unimodal sensory regions of cortex enhances modality-specific perceptual priming.

Description A: The patient M.S. has normal explicit memory, even for visual cues, but lacks implicit memory for specific properties of visually presented words.
Description B: The patient M.S. lacks normal explicit memory, even for visual cues, but has implicit memory for specific properties of visually presented words.

Description A: H.M. was able to acquire new visuomotor skills, like the mirror-tracing task.
Description B: H.M. was unable to acquire new visuomotor skills, like the mirror-tracing task.

Description A: Statistical learning is typically measured by a faster reaction time to repeated compared to nonrepeated sequences.
Description B: Statistical learning is typically measured by a slower reaction time to repeated compared to nonrepeated sequences.

Description A: Functional imaging of healthy individuals during sensorimotor learning shows changes in the activity of the basal ganglia and cerebellum and their connectivity with cortical regions.
Description B: Functional imaging of healthy individuals during sensorimotor learning shows a decrease in the activity of the basal ganglia and cerebellum and their connectivity with cortical regions.

Description A: Patients with cerebellar lesions also have difficulties acquiring some motor skills.
Description B: Patients with cerebellar lesions have no difficulties acquiring any motor skills.

Description A: Incremental learning of stimulus-reward associations depends on the striatum.
Description B: Incremental learning of stimulus-reward associations does not depend on the striatum.

Description A: fMRI studies show functional connectivity between the hippocampus and the striatum in support of learning across a variety of tasks.
Description B: fMRI studies show lack of functional connectivity between the hippocampus and the striatum in support of learning across a variety of tasks.

Description A: Habituation is a decrease in a response that occurs when a benign stimulus is presented repeatedly.
Description B: Habituation is an increased response that occurs when a benign stimulus is presented repeatedly.

Description A: Sensitization is an enhanced response to a wide variety of stimuli after the presentation of an intense or noxious stimulus.
Description B: Sensitization is a reduced response to a wide variety of stimuli after the presentation of an intense or noxious stimulus.

Description A: Learning of sensorimotor skills depends on numerous brain regions that vary with the specific associations being learned.
Description B: Learning of sensorimotor skills depends exclusively on the hippocampus and does not vary with the specific associations being learned.

Description A: Nonassociative learning results when a subject is exposed once or repeatedly to a single type of stimulus.
Description B: Nonassociative learning results only when a subject is exposed to multiple types of stimuli.

Description A: The human brain carries out actions in ways no current computer can begin to approach.
Description B: The human brain is less capable of carrying out actions than current computers.

Description A: The brain is hierarchically organized such that information processed at one level is passed to higher-level circuits for more complex and refined processing.
Description B: The brain processes information in a scattered manner with no specific order of complexity.

Description A: The somatosensory system is particularly well understood and helps illustrate the interaction of sensory processing circuits at several levels.
Description B: The somatosensory system is the least understood system and does not illustrate the interaction of sensory processing circuits.

Description A: Voluntary movement is mediated by direct connections between the cortex and spinal cord.
Description B: Voluntary movement is mediated by indirect connections between the cortex and pancreas.

Description A: The hippocampal formation is interconnected with the highest-level polysensory cortical regions.
Description B: The hippocampal formation is isolated from all polysensory cortical regions.

Description A: Explicit memory depends on circuits in the hippocampus.
Description B: Explicit memory depends solely on circuits in the spinal cord.

Description A: Sensory information processing culminates in the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Sensory information processing culminates in the cerebellum.

Description A: The thalamus is an essential link between sensory receptors and the cerebral cortex.
Description B: The thalamus is unrelated to sensory processing and acts only as a motor control center.

Description A: The peripheral nervous system is anatomically distinct from the central nervous system.
Description B: The peripheral nervous system is integrated seamlessly within the central nervous system.

Description A: Complex behaviors require the integrated action of several nuclei and cortical regions.
Description B: Complex behaviors can be carried out by a single neuron acting independently.

Description A: Within the spinal cord, simple reflex circuits receive sensory information from stretch receptors and send output to various muscle groups.
Description B: Within the spinal cord, simple reflex circuits only process pain information and have no output.

Description A: The dorsal column–medial lemniscal pathway is the major afferent pathway for somatosensory information.
Description B: The dorsal column–medial lemniscal pathway is primarily involved in motor control.

Description A: Information is processed in the brain in a hierarchical fashion.
Description B: Information in the brain is processed randomly and lacks any hierarchy.

Description A: For complex behavioral functions, different stages of information processing are carried out in networks in different regions of the nervous system.
Description B: Complex behavioral functions are processed only in one central region of the nervous system.

Description A: The somatic sensory cortex is located in the postcentral gyrus.
Description B: The somatic sensory cortex is located in the frontal gyrus.

Description A: The caudate nucleus excites the frontal eye fields and inhibits the substantia nigra.
Description B: The caudate nucleus, which in turn is excited by the frontal eye fields, inhibits the substantia nigra.

Description A: A lesion of the cerebellar fastigial nucleus causes hypometric ipsiversive saccades.
Description B: Damage to the oculomotor vermis disinhibits the fastigial nucleus and causes hypometric ipsiversive saccades.

Description A: The superior colliculus integrates auditory and motor information into oculomotor signals for the brain stem.
Description B: The superior colliculus integrates visual and motor information into oculomotor signals for the brain stem.

Description A: The pontine and mesencephalic burst circuits provide sensory signals necessary to drive the extraocular muscles for saccades.
Description B: The pontine and mesencephalic burst circuits provide the motor signals necessary to drive the extraocular muscles for saccades.

Description A: Damage to the fastigial nucleus results in hypermetric contraversive saccades and hypometric ipsiversive saccades.
Description B: A lesion of the cerebellar fastigial nucleus causes ipsiversive saccades to overshoot their targets (hypermetric saccades), and contraversive saccades undershoot their targets (hypometric saccades).

Description A: Neurons in the superior colliculus are arranged in a tonotopic map.
Description B: Neurons in the superior colliculus are organized in a retinotopic map.

Description A: The superior colliculus is controlled solely by the frontal eye field of the cerebral cortex.
Description B: The superior colliculus is controlled by two regions of the cerebral cortex that have overlapping but distinct functions: the lateral intraparietal area and the frontal eye field.

Description A: In monkeys, sensory activity in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus directly leads to motor output.
Description B: Activity in the superficial and intermediate layers of the superior colliculus can occur independently: sensory activity in the superficial layers does not always lead to motor output.

Description A: The substantia nigra excites neurons in the intermediate layers of the superior colliculus during a saccade.
Description B: A neuron in the substantia nigra pars reticulata inhibits neurons in the intermediate layers of the superior colliculus.

Description A: Neurons in the superior colliculus superficial layers respond specifically to auditory stimuli.
Description B: Neurons in the superior colliculus superficial layers respond to visual stimuli.

Description A: A large population of cells in the superior colliculus is active before each auditory movement.
Description B: A large population of cells is thus active before each saccade, and eye movement is encoded by the entire ensemble of these broadly tuned cells.

Description A: Neurons in the rostral superior colliculus discharge strongly during passive visual fixation.
Description B: Neurons in the rostral superior colliculus discharge strongly during active visual fixation.

Description A: The frontal eye fields release the superior colliculus from suppression through direct inhibition of the substantia nigra.
Description B: The frontal eye fields directly excite the colliculus and indirectly release it from suppression by the substantia nigra by exciting the caudate nucleus, which inhibits the substantia nigra.

Description A: Neurons in the intermediate layers of the superior colliculus project directly to the visual cortex.
Description B: Neurons in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus do not provide a large projection directly to the intermediate layers.

Description A: Lesions of a small part of the superior colliculus have no effect on saccades.
Description B: Lesions of a small part of the colliculus affect the latency, accuracy, and velocity of saccades.

Description A: Growth cones have three main compartments: filopodia, lamellipodia, and a central core.
Description B: Growth cones have four main compartments: filopodia, lamellipodia, a central core, and dendrites.

Description A: Filopodia on growth cones are actin-rich structures that are highly motile and help in sensing environmental signals.
Description B: Filopodia on growth cones are tubulin-rich structures that are static and do not participate in sensing environmental signals.

Description A: Ramón y Cajal discovered the growth cone and had key insights about its role in axonal pathfinding.
Description B: Ramón y Cajal discovered dendrites and had key insights about their role in neuronal communication.

Description A: The movement of actin along myosin in filopodia is similar to the contraction mechanism of skeletal muscle fibers.
Description B: The movement of actin along tubulin in filopodia is similar to the contraction mechanism of skeletal muscle fibers.

Description A: Calcium concentration in growth cones affects cytoskeleton organization and modulates motility.
Description B: Potassium concentration in growth cones affects cytoskeleton organization and modulates motility.

Description A: Filopodia length permits them to sample environments far in advance of the central core of the growth cone.
Description B: Filopodia length limits them to environments close to the central core of the growth cone.

Description A: Growth cones are both sensory and motor structures that drive axon elongation.
Description B: Growth cones are only sensory structures and do not play a role in axon elongation.

Description A: Integrin receptors in growth cones influence motility by coupling to actin.
Description B: Integrin receptors in growth cones influence motility by coupling to tubulin.

Description A: Filopodia are rod-like, actin-rich, membrane-limited structures that are highly motile.
Description B: Filopodia are sheet-like, tubulin-rich structures that are static.

Description A: Growth cone motility is optimal within a narrow range of calcium concentrations, known as a set point.
Description B: Growth cone motility is optimal within a narrow range of potassium concentrations, known as a set point.

Description A: Growth cones transduce positive and negative cues into signals that regulate the cytoskeleton.
Description B: Growth cones transduce positive and negative cues into signals that regulate mitochondrial activity.

Description A: Application of growth factors to one side of an embryonic neuron growth cone leads it to turn toward the source.
Description B: Application of growth factors to one side of an embryonic neuron growth cone leads it to turn away from the source.

Description A: Growth cones contain the machinery for protein synthesis, including a subset of messenger RNAs.
Description B: Growth cones do not contain machinery for protein synthesis and depend entirely on the cell body.

Description A: Ramón y Cajal envisioned growth cones to be 'endowed with exquisite chemical sensitivity.'
Description B: Ramón y Cajal envisioned dendritic spines to be 'endowed with exquisite chemical sensitivity.'

Description A: Cyclic nucleotides modulate the activity of enzymes such as protein kinases.
Description B: Cyclic nucleotides modulate the activity of enzymes such as lactase.

Description A: The retina transforms light patterns projected onto photoreceptors into neural signals that are conveyed through the optic nerve to specialized visual centers in the brain.
Description B: The retina transforms sound patterns projected onto photoreceptors into neural signals that are conveyed through the optic nerve to specialized visual centers in the brain.

Description A: Rod photoreceptors are efficient collectors of light and serve nocturnal vision.
Description B: Cone photoreceptors are efficient collectors of light and serve nocturnal vision.

Description A: Through lateral networks, light in the receptive-field surround of a ganglion cell counteracts the effect of light in the center.
Description B: Through lateral networks, light in the receptive-field center of a ganglion cell counteracts the effect of light in the surround.

Description A: Cones synapse onto bipolar cells that in turn excite ganglion cells.
Description B: Rods synapse onto bipolar cells that in turn excite ganglion cells.

Description A: The visual system follows Weber’s law approximately.
Description B: The visual system follows Weber’s law precisely.

Description A: Dopamine released by specialized amacrine cells is an important regulator of changes in receptive-field properties in the retina.
Description B: Light released by specialized amacrine cells is an important regulator of changes in receptive-field properties in the retina.
