Description A: Rod bipolar cells begin to adapt at somewhat higher light intensities, changing their responsiveness depending on the average light level.
Description B: Cone bipolar cells begin to adapt at somewhat higher light intensities, changing their responsiveness depending on the average light level.

Description A: When illumination is continuous, the Ca2+ concentration remains low, and reactions are in a steady state that lowers the gain and accelerates the response to light.
Description B: When illumination is continuous, the Ca2+ concentration remains high, and reactions are in a steady state that lowers the gain and accelerates the response to light.

Description A: The firing rates of optic nerve fibers can vary effectively over only two orders of magnitude.
Description B: The firing rates of optic nerve fibers can vary effectively over three orders of magnitude.

Description A: Rod cells connect to specialized rod bipolar cells whose signals are conveyed through amacrine cells to the cone bipolar cells.
Description B: Cone cells connect to specialized cone bipolar cells whose signals are conveyed through amacrine cells to the rod bipolar cells.

Description A: Light adaptation results principally from gain changes within the cones as ambient light increases further.
Description B: Light adaptation results principally from gain changes within the rods as ambient light increases further.

Description A: Ganglion cells have a sharp center-surround structure in their receptive fields, but this structure changes as light dims.
Description B: Ganglion cells have a broad receptive field structure that doesn't change as light dims.

Description A: The transduction of light stimuli begins in the outer segment of the photoreceptor cell when a pigment molecule absorbs a photon.
Description B: The transduction of sound stimuli begins in the outer segment of the photoreceptor cell when a pigment molecule absorbs a photon.

Description A: Horizontal connections are primarily inhibitory in the excitatory pathways.
Description B: Horizontal connections are primarily excitatory in the excitatory pathways.

Description A: Sensitivity decreases somewhat less steeply with increasing background intensity.
Description B: Sensitivity decreases more steeply with increasing background intensity.

Description A: The distal segment of the axon experiences degeneration through a process called Wallerian degeneration, which is actively regulated.
Description B: The proximal segment of the axon experiences degeneration through a process called Wallerian degeneration, which is actively regulated.

Description A: In Wlds mutant mice, the distal portion of severed axons persists much longer compared to normal mice, suggesting an actively regulated response to axotomy.
Description B: In Wlds mutant mice, the proximal portion of severed axons persists much longer compared to normal mice, suggesting an actively regulated response to axotomy.

Description A: Axotomy divides the axon into a proximal segment that remains attached to the cell body and a distal segment that loses attachment.
Description B: Axotomy divides the axon into a distal segment that remains attached to the cell body and a proximal segment that loses attachment.

Description A: Santiago Ramón y Cajal believed that in the injured central nervous system, nothing may be regenerated.
Description B: Santiago Ramón y Cajal believed that in the injured central nervous system, everything may be regenerated.

Description A: NMNAT1 is confined to the nucleus in normal conditions, but mislocalizes to the axon in Wlds mutant mice.
Description B: NMNAT1 is confined to the axon in normal conditions, but mislocalizes to the nucleus in Wlds mutant mice.

Description A: Chromatolysis involves swelling of the cell body and movement of the nucleus to an eccentric position.
Description B: Chromatolysis involves shrinking of the cell body and movement of the nucleus to a central position.

Description A: Evidence has accumulated that neurogenesis occurs in certain regions of the adult mammalian brain.
Description B: Evidence has accumulated that neurogenesis does not occur in any regions of the adult mammalian brain.

Description A: Following axotomy, calcium levels rise within the axon, activating proteases which initiate cytoskeletal disassembly.
Description B: Following axotomy, calcium levels decrease within the axon, activating proteases which initiate cytoskeletal disassembly.

Description A: In Wlds mutant mice, a mutant form of NMNAT1 forms, which can substitute for NMNAT2 to prolong axonal survival.
Description B: In Wlds mutant mice, a mutant form of NMNAT2 forms, which can substitute for NMNAT1 to prolong axonal survival.

Description A: Axon degeneration in Wlds mutant mice is delayed compared to wild type mice due to mislocalization of the mutant protein.
Description B: Axon degeneration in Wlds mutant mice is accelerated compared to wild type mice due to mislocalization of the mutant protein.

Description A: Wallerian degeneration was first described by Augustus Waller in 1850.
Description B: Wallerian degeneration was first described by Augustus Waller in 1950.

Description A: The distal stump of the axon undergoes degeneration due to the loss of attachment from the cell body and dwindling energy supplies.
Description B: The proximal stump of the axon undergoes degeneration due to the loss of attachment from the cell body and dwindling energy supplies.

Description A: SARM1 activation leads to degradation of NAD, promoting axon degeneration.
Description B: SARM1 activation leads to synthesis of NAD, preventing axon degeneration.

Description A: NMNAT2 normally present in axons generates NAD and inhibits SARM1 to maintain energy metabolism.
Description B: NMNAT2 normally present in neurons generates NAD and inhibits SARM1 to maintain energy metabolism.

Description A: The inability to form new neurons in the adult brain was a central dogma of neuroscience for most of the last century.
Description B: The ability to form new neurons in the adult brain was a central dogma of neuroscience for most of the last century.

Description A: In English, adjectives typically precede the noun.
Description B: In English, adjectives typically follow the noun.

Description A: By the age of 3 years, children know approximately 1,000 words.
Description B: By the age of 3 years, children know approximately 10,000 words.

Description A: Infants ‘coo’ with vowel-like sounds at 3 months of age.
Description B: Infants ‘coo’ with vowel-like sounds at 6 months of age.

Description A: The combination /zb/ is not allowed in English but is common in Polish.
Description B: The combination /zb/ is allowed in English but not in Polish.

Description A: Between 36 and 48 months, children respond to grammatical sentences in an adult-like way.
Description B: Between 36 and 48 months, children cannot respond to grammatical sentences.

Description A: Chinese toddlers’ utterances reflect the pitch, rhythm, and phonetic structure of Mandarin.
Description B: Chinese toddlers’ utterances reflect the pitch and rhythm of English.

Description A: Japanese speakers often use the /r/ and /l/ sounds interchangeably when producing words.
Description B: Japanese speakers distinctly differentiate between the /r/ and /l/ sounds when producing words.

Description A: Infants are sensitive to the statistical properties of the language they hear.
Description B: Infants are insensitive to the statistical properties of the language they hear.

Description A: Adults find it difficult to discern phonetic units in languages they are not fluent in.
Description B: Adults easily discern phonetic units in languages they are not fluent in.

Description A: The behavioral psychologist B. F. Skinner proposed that language was acquired through learning.
Description B: The behavioral psychologist B. F. Skinner proposed that language was innate and not reliant on learning.

Description A: The nativist Noam Chomsky argued that traditional reinforcement learning has little to do with language acquisition.
Description B: The nativist Noam Chomsky argued that traditional reinforcement learning is crucial to language acquisition.

Description A: Speech perception becomes language-specific before speech production.
Description B: Speech production becomes language-specific before speech perception.

Description A: Categorical perception occurs in both humans and nonhuman mammals.
Description B: Categorical perception occurs only in humans, not in nonhuman mammals.

Description A: Infants begin to produce babbling using consonant–vowel combinations at about 7 months of age.
Description B: Infants begin to produce babbling using consonant–vowel combinations at about 3 months of age.

Description A: The order of words within larger elements differs between languages like English and Japanese.
Description B: The order of words within larger elements is identical between languages like English and Japanese.
